HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans;
Bush Steps Up Campaign as Buchanan Lays Out an Agenda

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 10

 BODY:
Criticized by his opponent in the Republican primary for supposedly ignoring New Hampshire's economic problems, President Bush today sought to make his presence felt in the state through long-distance interviews on Manchester radio and television stations.
In telephone interviews from the White House on two morning radio programs, Mr. Bush promoted his economic and health-care plans.
He was also critical of proposals put forward by some Democrats, as well as by his Republican challenger, the conservative columnist Patrick J. Buchanan, for broader tax reductions for the middle class. The President said the country "doesn't need these broad proposals to cut everybody's taxes at a time when we've got these enormous deficits." 
 Though he did not mention Mr. Buchanan by name, the President told reporters at WGIR-AM, a news-talk radio station, that "it would be nice not to have to be attacked from the right."
 
Send a Message
 Taking note of his challenger's call to "Send the President a message," Mr. Bush said the state's Republican voters ought to direct their anger toward Congress.
"But my view is, look, let's take a message and send it to the United States Congress to get something done; that's where the message should be sent," the President said.
 
Expanded Exposure
 With only eight days left before the primary here, the Bush campaign has stepped-up its efforts, making the President available for the radio interviews and a taped interview tonight with WMUR-TV, the state's largest television station. He said the endorsement two days ago of his re-election by former President Ronald Reagan would "resonate" with the state's voters. The President and his wife are expected to visit the state on Wednesday to address the state legislature.
"He must be nervous," deadpanned Mr. Buchanan, when asked about the President's interviews today.
For its part, the Buchanan campaign began several new television commercials today laying out what Mr. Buchanan would do if elected President and showing he had been moved by the suffering he has seen in the state.
In one, he ticks off a seven-point program that he says would revive the economy. Included in his menu of proposals are items like a freeze on Federal hiring and spending, cuts in foreign aid, term limits on members of Congress and a middle-class tax cut.
In another, he speaks of "women who break down as they talk of how their husbands have lost their jobs, how they can't meet the mortgage, how they're about to lose their homes."
"And until I came up and announced my candidacy, those people in Washington behaved as if they did not care," Mr. Buchanan says. "Well, I care."
The advertisement appears to be an attempt to soften Mr. Buchanan's image as a flinty conservative.
Aides to Mr. Buchanan said the commercials would replace those attacking the President for breaking his pledge not to raise taxes. The advertisements have blanketed the state and their constant repetition, by some accounts, has begun to irritate some voters.
Public opinion surveys taken over the last few days show the President with a commanding lead over Mr. Buchanan, though a recent poll by The Boston Globe indicates some erosion in support for Mr. Bush. In the telephone poll of 440 likely Republican voters conducted over the weekend, 51 percent of those surveyed said they favored the President, compared to 27 percent who said they would vote for Mr. Buchanan. A similar poll conducted by The Globe last month found Mr. Bush leading his rival by 58 percent to 28 percent.

HEADLINE: CPC Earnings Climb by 8.5%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., Feb. 10

 BODY:
The food giant CPC International Inc. reported today that fourth-quarter net income rose 8.5 percent, to $110.1 million, or $1.43 a share, from 101.5 million, or $1.32 a share, in the comparable quarter in 1990. Sales increased 1.6 percent, to $1.55 billion.
For the full year of 1991, CPC reported an increase in earnings per share from continuing operations of 8.1 percent, to $5.22, compared with $4.83 in 1990. This excludes a special charge of 42 cents a share for environmental costs relating to discontinued non-food businesses, taken in the third quarter of 1991. 
 Including the environmental charge relating to discontinued operations, earnings per share for 1991 were $4.80, or six-tenths of 1 percent lower, and net income was $372.7 million, or three-tenths of 1 percent lower.
Worldwide sales for 1991 were $6.19 billion, 7.1 percent above their 1990 level of $5.78 billion. Higher volumes were chiefly responsible for the gain, the company said.
"The recessionary environment in the United States, as well as very difficult conditions in some countries of Latin America, continued to constrain our progress in the fourth quarter, as they did throughout the year," said C. R. Shoemate, chairman and chief executive officer.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
Democrats' Hopes Fade As Front-Runner Slips

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KEENE, N.H., Feb. 10

 BODY:
Only a couple of weeks ago, senior people in the Democratic Party were telling each other that this time they would not waste their energies squabbling. This time they would choose a nominee early. Then they could unite, plot the strategy and raise the money needed to beat President Bush.
That soothing vision was fading fast today as the Iowa caucuses took place and the New Hampshire primary campaign entered its final week. 
 The people of this state are as proud of their predilection for surprising the experts as they are of their low-tax government. They have a habit of making up their minds who to support very late in the game, as they did with George S. McGovern in 1972 and then with George Bush four years ago.
This time, they seem determined to wait until the last minute once again. Of 58 Democratic voters questioned in this city in the southwestern part of the state over the last few days, only 18 said they had decided who to back, and of those 5 said they might still switch before voting on Feb. 18.
In that kind of situation, today's conventional wisdom can be tomorrow's misapprehension. But the professionals, at least, see Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas slipping, day by day. They see former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts gaining. They see the rest of the field still scrambling for a foothold. And it adds up, in their view, to trouble.
Their view is a pragmatic one, which is why the word "electability" buzzes through Democratic circles these days the way "momentum" used to. Many party leaders and many voters in New Hampshire have backed Mr. Clinton in large part because they thought that he, as a telegenic Southern moderate capable of articulating economic and social policies in sharp contrast to Mr. Bush's, would have the best chance of winning in November.
But in recent days that argument seems to have been working against Mr. Clinton. In the wake of charges of marital infidelity and manipulation of his draft status, both of which the Governor has denied, some voters here and many influential people in Washington seem to be edging away from him not so much because of his alleged transgressions but because they fear that the charges would make him a sitting duck for the Republicans later in the year if he can still win the nomination.
The New Hampshire electorate has it in its power either to confirm or overturn that view. A solid victory would quiet the talk; a narrow one might turn the volume down. But a loss, when a big victory had seemed so likely only two weeks ago, would be terribly damaging, even if Mr. Clinton could recover his balance in the South, his home base where many states hold primaries on March 10.
Only Mr. Tsongas, it is widely believed here, is in a position to defeat Mr. Clinton. If that happened, the party would be left with a wounded former front-runner, a victor who has done no organizing to speak of outside New England, and three also-rans whose reputations have not been enhanced very much by the New Hampshire campaign -- Senators Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and Tom Harkin of Iowa and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California.
Not a happy prospect for the Democrats, especially with Mr. Bush apparently headed for a relatively comfortable win over Patrick J. Buchanan.
Mr. Clinton is expected to open a new television campaign in the next few days, intended to make voters think twice about how to beat Mr. Bush and improve their economic lot -- in other words, to persuade them once again, as he did earlier this year, that he is the only electable Democrat. His aides are talking about the primary as if it were Armageddon, considering attacks on Mr. Tsongas and preparing to deal more directly with the attacks on Mr. Clinton's own character if need be.
Mr. Tsongas has drawn the support of liberals like Dudley Dudley, a power in New Hampshire politics for decades, as well as those with fresh doubts about Mr. Clinton, though the former Senator from Massachusetts is no knee-jerk liberal. For example, he backs nuclear power, opposes tax cuts and favors only limited gun control.
Confident that the tide is running with their man, his strategists foresee a final week devoted to countering the notion that he cannot win by emphasizing how far he has come since his forlorn beginnings here.
In 1976, when the previously unknown Jimmy Carter won in both Iowa and New Hampshire, money and support in states where he had done little organizing rapidly flowed to him. But he had shown strength in two parts of the country not his own, the Midwest and Northeast, and the next stops on the political calendar were in the South.
Even if he wins next Tuesday, Mr. Tsongas will have won only at home.
Few pros believe that both Mr. Harkin and Mr. Kerrey will do well enough here to raise the money to compete in other states, although both speak of fighting on to the convention. Both made biting comments about their rivals last week, and either might decide this week to turn to negative commercials in a last-ditch bid for survival.

HEADLINE: Global Plan To Rescue Species Set For Release

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Moving beyond a "Save The Panda approach," an international team plans to make public here on Tuesday a comprehensive strategy to protect the world's diversity of plant and animal species and to tap this diversity for human benefit.
The fruit of a three-year effort involving 500 advisers around the world, the "Global Biodiversity Strategy" addresses growing concern that the extinction of species will deprive future generations of new medicines and new strains of food crops. 
 With as many as 50 plant species disappearing each day, scientists calculate that the planet's biodiversity could be reduced by 10 percent by the year 2015.
"We have got to realize that next to the human mind, the earth's biological wealth is the greatest thing about this planet," said James Gustave Speth, president of World Resources Institute, a Washington organization that was one of the sponsors of the 244-page report.
 
A Guide for Policy Makers
 Sponsors hope the report's 85 recommendations will guide world environmental policy makers who are to meet next June in Rio de Janeiro for the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development, a once-a-decade gathering.
Recommendations involve human actors ranging from the United Nations down to forest tribes.
On the international level, the report recommends the establishment of an early warning network to identify and protect ecosystems around the world that suddenly become threatened. The report calls on governments and multilateral development agencies to devote at least $1 billion a year to conserving endangered ecosystems.
On the national level, countries are being encouraged to assert control over their genetic resources and to exact royalties for their commercial uses.
In one pioneering effort, the recently formed National Biodiversity Institute of Costa Rica has started to conduct an inventory of that Central American nation's plant and animal species. Merck Pharmaceutical has signed a contract to pay the institute 2 percent royalties on sales of any new medicines developed from the institute's samples.
One-fourth of all prescriptions now dispensed in the United States contain active ingredients from plants. The number of plant species used in traditional medicine is 2,000 in northwestern Amazonia, 2,500 in the area of the former Soviet Union and 5,100 in China.
To preserve and to promote such traditional knowledge, the Global Strategy recommends furthering recognition of local lore and local use of wild products.
Recognizing the development needs of third-world countries, the report steers away from sentimental appeals for conservation. Instead, it repeatedly underlines the economic value to genetic diversity.
"A wild tomato, found only in the Galapagos Islands, can grow in sea water and possesses jointless fruit stalks -- a trait that has been bred into domesticated tomatoes to make them easier to harvest mechanically," reads the report, which was also sponsored by the World Conservation Union of Switzerland and by the United Nations Environmental Program of Kenya.
Noting crop gains in the United States, the report said, "An estimated $1 billion annually has been added to the value of U.S. agricultural output by the widened genetic base."
In another example, wild species of rice give the world's rice crop its resistance to two of the four major rice diseases.
 
Threats to Gene Pool
 Threats to the world's gene pool come from headlong expansion of human activity. These threats include: unsustainably high rates of population growth, a narrowing spectrum of trade products from farms, fisheries and forests, ignorance of the value of threatened ecosystems, and legal systems and economic policies that promote development that is destructive to the environment.
Sponsors hope the report, which is to be issued in English, French, Portuguese and Spanish, will influence thinking and action at the United Nations conference in Rio.
"The Global Diversity Strategy is an important contribution to the formulation of concrete measures to protect our natural heritage," Maurice F. Strong, Secretary General of the United Nations environmental conference, said of the new study. "The conservation of biodiversity is one of the key issues for the United Nations conference."

HEADLINE: The Talk of Hollywood;
Though a Year Old, Disney Memo Still Provokes Gossip

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 10

 BODY:
One year ago, Jeffrey Katzenberg, the chairman of the Walt Disney studios, wrote the memo that rocked Hollywood.
Not that Mr. Katzenberg said anything startling or even surprising. Far from it. But the 28-page document, which criticized the movie industry's "tidal wave of runaway costs and mindless competition" and chastised his own company for making the big budget, low-profit "Dick Tracy," served for months as a source of anger, resentment, debate and jokes within Hollywood. Mr. Katzenberg may have stated the obvious but -- like so much else in a world of fantasy, hype and vast wealth -- his comments stirred an outsize reaction. 
 And it's still going on.
Mr. Katzenberg, who doesn't often refrain from expressing his views, routinely declines to discuss the memo, largely because it set off such a storm. His supporters say that he was not only prescient about Hollywood but that he also seemed to anticipate the current wave of cost cutting that has seized most of the film studios as movie-theater audiences decline. But his critics say the studio chief winked and acquiesced in the leaking of the memo to the trade paper Variety to signal, less to Hollywood than to Wall Street, that the Disney Company would make cheaper movies after such critical and financial duds as "V. I. Warshawski," "Billy Bathgate," "The Marrying Man" and "Scenes From a Mall."
In his memo, Mr. Katzenberg singled out Disney's own "Dick Tracy," starring Warren Beatty and other stars. The movie grossed just over $100 million in the United States, but cost just about that to film and market. " 'Dick Tracy,' " he added, "made demands on our time, talent and treasury that upon reflection may not have been worth it."
In a comment that ruptured his relationship with Mr. Beatty, Mr. Katzenberg said "Bugsy," the actor's planned project with director Barry Levinson, was precisely the kind of risky movie Disney would not make, largely because of its $40 million cost.
Echoing the view of several other movie executives, Mike Medavoy, the chairman of Tri-Star Pictures, which produced "Hook" and "Bugsy," said in a recent interview: "There's nothing in that memo other than self-serving palaver. Everyone else is thinking about cutting back and cutting costs. What he was saying is, 'I'll never do "Dick Tracy" again.' That's ridiculous. To try to establish rules and say, 'I'll never make a movie over $12 million or $15 million or $20 million is ridiculous. It's just a silly statement."
But Robert A. Daly, the chairman of Warner Brothers, observed: "It was a good memo. It affected the way Disney did business, but I don't think it affected the industry itself because we all, more or less, came to the same conclusion. The reality is, you can't survive if costs were going up the way they were going up. Things had to change."
In some ways, Mr. Katzenberg has had the last laugh on his critics. His studio's flops last year left him vulnerable to attack in such magazines as New York and Vanity Fair, which cited his obsessive meddling in the writing, production and editing of his movies. But Mr. Katzenberg's luck has turned.
Disney has had the most successful start of any studio in 1992 after a tepid 1991. Its major successes include "The Hand That Rocks the Cradle," a scare film released through its subsidiary Buena Vista about a nanny from hell, which cost $12 million and has so far grossed $51.4 million; "Beauty and the Beast," the sophisticated animated musical, which has so far grossed about $106.4 million, and "Father of the Bride," the remake of the M-G-M classic, which is a surprise hit at about $72.3 million. And this week, Disney's "Medicine Man," also released through Buena Vista, is No. 1 at the box office.
"Bugsy" has received dazzling critical reviews, but has so far grossed a somewhat disappointing $39.5 million. The film will probably eke out a profit if it fares well at the Academy Awards.
Several studio executives said that for all the attention it received in Hollywood, the Katzenberg memo had far less impact than the near-collapse of Carolco, the independent company that paid some of the highest prices in town for actors, writers and directors. The company produced the No. 1 film of 1991, "Terminator 2: Judgment Day," but many of its other films have failed, and Carolco has been riven with internal strife.
An example of Carolco's extravagance was the $15 million it paid Michael Douglas to appear in its newest film, "Basic Instinct," which was made before the company began to shrivel. In contrast, 20th Century Fox paid Mr. Douglas about $5.5 million for "Shining Through."
With Carolco laying off employees and in financial crisis, rival studio executives say, the huge prices that drove up costs across Hollywood have already begun to shrink. Disney and other studios have scaled back on the amounts spent on high-priced talent. Although a handful of stars -- including Arnold Schwarzenegger, Tom Cruise, Mel Gibson, Julia Roberts and Harrison Ford -- still receive enormous sums, other well-known actors have been forced to dramatically lower their $3 million to $5 million salaries because their presence alone in a movie is not enough to lure big audiences. They include Bill Murray, Richard Dreyfuss, John Candy, Jeff Bridges, Tom Hanks and Dennis Quaid.
After his appearance in the disastrous "Havana," Robert Redford agreed to a gross percentage deal -- and no fee -- to work on a caper film, "Sneakers." Other actors in the film, including Dan Aykroyd, River Phoenix and Sidney Poitier, are also working for less money.
Two other stars, Meryl Streep and Goldie Hawn, are believed to be receiving about $3 million each -- as opposed to their customary $5 million -- to star in a new Robert Zemeckis comedy, "Death Becomes Her," which is being produced by Universal. When Kevin Kline also sought $3 million for the picture, film executives said, he was promptly dropped in favor of Bruce Willis, who actively sought out the part and accepted a gross percentage deal favorable to the studio. Such deals and fee reductions for these actors would have been improbable last year.
Mr. Daly of Warner Brothers said: "In some cases we're telling people: 'This is what we're spending, and this is what we'll pay, and if you like it, fine, and if not, we'll get someone else. No hard feelings.' "
Senior executives, not only at Disney and Warner Brothers, but also at such studios as Universal, 20th Century Fox, Columbia and Tri-Star, said that in his memo Mr. Katzenberg had simply tapped early into a mood that seized Hollywood, only partly because of the recession.
"Look, the movie business slipped because bad movies were made," said Barry Diller, the chairman of Fox. "Jeffrey's memo was an internal memo to his people. But since then, every birdbrain in town has made comments about the recession, the economy, other entertainment alternatives. All these reasons were not as good as looking at ourselves in the mirror and saying we made turkey movies. Suddenly a few movies, hardly great, came out over Christmas and the audience came flooding back. You make good movies, people come."
But other executives and producers said the industry itself was in the grip of more turmoil and fear than it had faced for decades, largely because of high costs, declining audiences and the national economic torpor.
Steve Tisch, a producer, said: "The town is running on fear now: it's the currency of the business. Studios that once had 300 projects in development have now cut back to 120. The talent agencies are cutting back. Studios are saying to stars and directors and writers, 'Take it or leave it.' Jeffrey's memo is looked on as a kind of historical document. As if he were looking into the future like the Dead Sea Scrolls."
Another producer, Bob Rehme, who, with his partner, Mace Neufeld, is making "Patriot Games," based on the Tom Clancy thriller, with Harrison Ford, said: "There's enormous belt-tightening now. All over the industry you see layoffs, cutbacks, a serious attempt to control costs, more of a mix of low-budget with high-budget movies."
At the time the memo was leaked, Mr. Katzenberg's boss, Michael D. Eisner, the chairman of the Disney Company, was known to be furious about the content of the document and the hoopla that surrounded it. But now Mr. Eisner speaks of Mr. Katzenberg in glowing terms. Mr. Eisner said the "period of constriction" now engulfing the movie industry was anticipated in the memo.
"The fact that Jeffrey placed his thoughts on paper -- whether every sentence is appropriate or not -- forced him to come to grips with theproblem," Mr. Eisner said. "Then he did something about it. I loved that. Whether I would have changed a sentence here or there, yes. But the memo he wrote was a kind of map. An internal map that was followed. Jeffrey may not have acted in a popular way. He may not have been lauded in the circles of people trying to sell him product.
"But he acted in a way that we think is the absolute appropriate way. He's done a spectacular job."

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Castro's Road of Economic Failures

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
"The Last Communist" is an unsparing account of the rapid rise and long decline of Fidel Castro and his romantic revolution. The "Frontline" documentary, at 9 tonight on Channels 13 and 49, uses veteran Castro watchers like Tad Szulc and Georgie Anne Geyer and former Cuban and American officials to explore the qualities that made the dictator an enduring hero of his country and a faded favorite of left-wing intellectuals around the world.
An acquaintance tells of the young Castro's admiration for Mussolini -- not his Fascism but his emotion-stirring Latin style -- and newsreel clips capture resemblances of arm-flailing speechifying. Mr. Castro's great years came early, when he led the revolt that toppled Fulgencio Batista, the corrupt Cuban dictator who long enjoyed the support of Washington and accommodated American business interests like the United Fruit Company and the shady characters who ran the country's casinos and brothels. 
 In this plausible analysis, Mr. Castro's understandable anti-Americanism turned Cuba into a cold-war client of the Soviet Union and pushed the United States into such ill-conceived ventures as the 1961 Bay of Pigs invasion and assassination attempts. Mr. Castro used Washington's campaign against him to justify authoritarian rule at home and adventures abroad that made him a leader in the third world. (There he is, embracing the ever embraceable Yasir Arafat.) He blamed the American trade embargo, imposed after he nationalized American businesses, for most of Cuba's economic ills, to which the maximum leader himself is shown to have contributed generously.
Credit is given to Mr. Castro for significant improvements in literacy, medical care and housing. But, as reported here, his nutty schemes for the Cuban economy resulted in failure after failure. The stories of the destruction wreaked on the land by his determination to raise farm production by a far-fetched 15 percent a year, the investments that produced sour grapes, tasteless strawberries and a glut of sugar and the crossbreeding of cattle that gave neither milk nor meat might be funny if they did not mean sustained deprivation for the Cuban people. Former Castroites tell of the luxury goods and privileges available to the country's high-ups, while the masses are fed nine-hour speeches.
Even as sympathizers in the United States and Europe were paying celebrity visits to the island and returning with raves about Communism with a human face, Mr. Castro was cracking down on intellectual freedom and throwing what he called antisocial elements, like political opponents and homosexuals, into prison. "So what we're really talking about here is one single word," says Mr. Szulc, "which is control, control, control of everything everywhere."
The advent of Mikhail S. Gorbachev sped the Cuban calamity. "Castro hates Gorbachev," says Ms. Geyer, who observes that the Cuban dictator is determined to be "the last Communist even though he never was a Communist." Mr. Szulc calls Mr. Castro, for whom he and other observers seem to retain residual affection, "the greatest victim of the end of the cold war." Today, he says, "he is zero as an international player." And with the former Soviet republics having troubles enough without worrying about subsidies for a distant client, the ordinary Cuban's life is harder than ever.
Tonight's PBS documentary and this Thursday night's fair-minded treatment of black American conservatives should appease the right-wingers in the Senate who are trying to hold back Federal money for public broadcasting on the ground that leftism is running rampant. More to the point, they are both illuminating programs.

HEADLINE: Not So Fast, Mr. Fernandez

 BODY:
Give the New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph Fernandez, a B for Bravado. With Mayor David Dinkins's new budget proposal not even due until April, Mr. Fernandez made a pre-emptive strike, seeking about $50 million a year from the city and the Municipal Assistance Corporation. He would use the money for new and enhanced programs, including innovations like a longer school day and longer school year for some students.
Mr. Fernandez, as usual a forceful advocate for the schools, knows how to capture the imagination. And no New Yorker can object to his desire for more and better instruction. But recession-pressed City Hall must weigh the relative importance of education against many other worthy services, like keeping libraries open or providing better foster care and drug treatment. The Chancellor will have to justify his provocative ideas with a full-scale proposal and details on cost. 
 From what Mr. Fernandez has revealed so far, he wants more money for three purposes: to expand computer-assisted learning programs, to introduce reforms in special education that would save money in the long run, and to improve science and math instruction in the middle schools.
Students in enhanced math and science classes would go to school an additional hour four days a week, and attend a 25-day summer session. Of 250,000 middle school students, the number who would participate in the science and math programs depends on the money available, according to Deputy Chancellor Stanley Litow.
Mr. Fernandez said he'd like up to $250 million out of an expected $900 million -- $700 million from refinancing city bonds and $200 million from the M.A.C. But he has not spelled out how he would spend the funds.
The officials shaping the stringent budget have a responsibility to focus first on restoring or at least maintaining deteriorating services. They must make government more productive before considering bold initiatives. Mr. Fernandez needs to persuade the public that the schools are performing as well as they can with the time and resources already available before claiming additional resources.
If Mr. Fernandez's ideas would ultimately cut costs and add productivity, as he suggests, then they warrant serious consideration. But he bears the burden of demonstrating, in a detailed proposal complete with cost implications, that his interesting ideas will not put the city deeper in the hole.

HEADLINE: Side With Refugees, Not Thugs

 BODY:
Even now, knowing that the United States has slammed its doors on their outstretched fingers, desperate Haitians flee their homeland in rickety boats. With seeming similar desperation, the Bush Administration forces them onto Coast Guard cutters and drags them back home.
How are Americans to account for this cruelty? Surely not out of any misunderstanding of the facts. If there were any doubt, it has now been put to rest by interviewers for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. They tell of "double-backers" who fled a second time after being jailed, beaten and threatened with death after the U.S. forcibly returned them to Haiti last year. 
 Many Haitians, fearful of starvation, may nonetheless be economic refugees not entitled to sanctuary. Many others legitimately fear political persecution. In either case, the Haitian boat people are desperate about survival.
But there's no explaining the Administration's ugly desperation. In six months, Washington has moved from enlightened engagement with a radical but democratic government to shameful complicity with a murderous dictatorship.
U.S. law permits a more worthy response to today's Haitian refugee problem. It's called "temporary protected status" and it provides interim sanctuary until a short-term crisis is resolved. The President can grant it on his own. If he won't, Congress can enact it by statute. Either way, it needs to be activated fast.
As regional efforts to negotiate a return to democratic rule have foundered, the Bush Administration has seemed mesmerized by fear that an unending flow of poor black Haitian refugees would lose votes in Florida. That's strange, since polls indicate Floridians support compassionate treatment of Haitians and Florida's conservative Republican Senator, Connie Mack, has spoken out forcefully in the refugees' behalf.
Nevertheless, the Administration decided to insist harshly on forcible repatriation. State Department officials began describing Haitian conditions more positively, as if to mitigate the appearance of what diplomats call, evocatively, refoulement. There's little evidence to justify the rosy Administration view. Indeed, the U.N. reports about double-backers undermine that expedient optimism.
An extraordinarily high proportion of Haitian boat people have a well-founded fear of political retribution. Even under a technical reading of U.S. law, the Administration finds that nearly a third qualify for political asylum. Thousands of others have been turned back because they could not demonstrate that the thugs who lead the new military regime had targeted them personally for abuse. Many nevertheless face mortal danger.
In the long term, Haitian refugees are no more entitled to permanent admission than are desperate, destitute Africans, or Asians or survivors of Communism. Long term, the Administration is right to try discouraging purely economic migrants. But that imperative gives no excuse for short-term cruelty. Before forcing Haitians out of the frying pan, the Administration has a duty first to help put out the fire.

HEADLINE: An Overdue Correction for Real Estate

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The Tinkerer: Mr. Bush's New War, and Paper Sword," your Jan. 30 lead editorial, I believe you are inaccurate and misleading in your comments concerning the portions of President Bush's State of the Union Message that deal with real estate.
You state that "Mr. Bush proposes lavish tax breaks on real estate investors." You state furthermore that "the tax code already subsidizes real estate." 
 A casual, let alone a careful, reading of Mr. Bush's proposal makes it clear that, far from a lavish tax break, what Mr. Bush is proposing is a correction of a significant inequity that has existed since the enactment of the 1986 tax reform.
Mr. Bush is proposing to allow real estate developers and others who are active in the real estate business to offset losses from real estate activities against income from real estate activities.
This ability to offset gains and losses in one's business is available to every type of business other than real estate. This correction is more than five years overdue and can hardly be characterized as either lavish or a tax break.
It should be obvious to everyone that since 1986, real estate is no longer subsidized by the tax code and in fact represents an industry that is suffering disproportionately in the United States today.
This is particularly serious because so many economists now agree that it will require a healthy real estate industry to lead us out of our recession.
 
HARVEY SCHULWEIS
President, Schulweis Realty
New York, Jan. 30, 1992

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Clinton Says He's Victim of G.O.P. 'Attack Machine'

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NASHUA, N.H., Feb. 10

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton rolled back into New Hampshire today with a full-scale political attack: He presented himself as the victim of a "Republican attack machine," asserted that the relentless focus on his character was cheating the voters and promised to "fight like hell" in the last eight days of this primary campaign.
Mr. Clinton, who returned from a weekend in Arkansas to a suddenly tight Democratic race with former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, delivered his speech on a snowy hill in a suburban subdivision, and he sought the high ground in more ways than one. He tried to present himself as the candidate rewarded by the voters for his emphasis on "the real problems of real people," who had then paid a heavy price for his success. 
 "The Republican attack machine went into action," said Mr. Clinton, who was flanked by his wife, Hillary. "We know their game plan. They've run it against me for years in Arkansas. We've seen it in this country before. Define and destroy before people really get to know the candidate."
 
No New Evidence
 Mr. Clinton offered no new evidence at his news conference today that connected the national Republican Party to the recent series of stories that have buffeted his campaign: the accusations printed by a supermarket tabloid that he had a 12-year sexual affair with a cabaret singer or the suggestions in other publications that he had sought to avoid the draft during the Vietnam War. Mr. Clinton has denied both accusations, but in the view of many political professionals here, they have taken a heavy toll.
Asked for evidence for Mr. Clinton's assertions, the campaign provided a collection of previous reports suggesting that Arkansas Republicans had encouraged rumors about infidelity and Mr. Clinton. Gary Koops, the spokesman for the Republican National Committee, said, "This is nonsense."
Throughout the furor of the past few weeks, the Clinton campaign has clearly hoped to capitalize on a backlash against the news media and its probing of candidates' personal lives. After a weekend when campaign advisers clearly realized that Mr. Clinton needed to escalate his counteroffensive, Mr. Clinton tried to broaden the debate, asserting that the tenor of the past few weeks represented a dangerous return to the negative politics of 1988, and that the voters would be the losers.
"There's just too much at stake this time around," Mr. Clinton said. "The past few weeks of this campaign have descended into a bizarre series of diversions that don't have anything to do with the hopes and dreams, crises and fears of the people of New Hampshire or this country."

New Spotlight on Tsongas
Special to The New York Times
MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 10 -- Mr. Tsongas is experiencing a sea change in his quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
Polls released over the weekend showed him pulling even with Mr. Clinton. After weeks of being relatively neglected by the press, Mr. Tsongas, who was the first Democratic candidate to challenge Mr. Bush last April, today found himself the subject of much media attention. Mr. Tsongas was philosophical about this newfound visibility.
"This too will pass," he said as he sat in a car signing copies of his economic plan, "A Call to Arms," before his next appearance. "I didn't get depressed over the hard times and I'm not going to get euphoric over the good times."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1715 words

HEADLINE: Digging for Ore Still Pays; Should Miners Pay, Too?

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARLIN, Nev.

 BODY:
Like the wizened old prospectors with a pick, a shovel and a dream, today's gold miners search for treasures in the public lands of the West. But they use explosives rather than picks, carve holes 600 feet into the earth and haul ore on trucks so huge the tires are 13 feet tall.
Using the latest technology, the Barrick Gold Strike Mine here in the foothills of the Tuscarora Mountains recovered about 500,000 ounces of gold last year. But like its pick-and-shovel forebears, Barrick did not pay a cent in Federal royalties on the $175 million worth of gold it took from public land.
 
An 1872 Law Endures
 While mining has changed substantially, the 1872 Mining Act has not. Under the law, which was signed by President Ulysses S. Grant to encourage settlement of the West, prospectors who stake a mineral claim are not required to pay for using the land or to pay royalties on the minerals it takes. 
 The Mining Act, which is headed for a showdown in Congress, has become the latest battleground in the debate over the best use of public lands in the West. Like earlier battles over grazing fees and logging rights, the mining issue tends to pit environmentalists against Westerners who work the land. And it raises the question of how much of the Old West culture and economy is appropriate for the New West.
Senator Dale Bumpers, Democrat of Arkansas, has called the Mining Act "a license to steal." He has sponsored a bill, which has been through subcommittee hearings, that would impose a 5 percent royalty on minerals. That would bring $200 million a year to the Federal treasury, based on Government estimates of $4 billion worth of minerals removed from Federal land every year.
The bill would set aside a third of the money for environmental cleanup of old mines and would establish stiffer standards for reclamation, the practice of returning mined land to its original condition. The measure would also grant broader discretion to officials in the Bureau of Land Management and the Forest Service to reject unsuitable efforts to mine public lands. A similar bill, sponsored by Representative Nick J. Rahall 2d, Democrat of West Virginia, would not impose royalties.
The Mining Act has remained intact as politicians in Western states have joined forces with conservatives in other parts of the country to beat back efforts to change it. "But this year, we feel we have the best shot at completely rewriting this law that we've had in a long time," said Katherine Holmann, a lawyer with the Sierra Club, who says there is now enough support in Congress to pass the Bumpers bill.
The mining industry says that provisions in that bill would be crippling, resulting in a loss of 30,000 jobs in Western states. They say the proposal would simply spur mining companies to move to other countries with looser restrictions. State governments that rely heavily on local taxes on mining companies would see their treasuries dwindle; in Nevada alone, mining companies paid $78.6 million in state taxes in 1990. And rural economies in the West, the miners say, would become even more dependent on jobs in tourism, which rarely pay anywhere near the $15-an-hour wages that the average mine worker earns.
 
Growth in Elko
 The mining industry says the proposal would hurt communities like Elko, which is about an hour away from the Barrick mine. Because of the mine, Elko has grown to about 22,000 from 12,000 in the past six years and its main strip is lit with neon and dotted with bars, casinos and pawn shops.
This arid, desolate stretch of northeast Nevada is the ancient homeland of the Shoshone Indians, and many members of the tribe now work for the mine. Most of the mine workers live in Elko, where Barrick has subsidized the construction of more than 100 homes. The company, which has about 1,200 workers, contributes $3,000 toward the college or trade school education of each employee's child.
"Before the mines got going big, it was like a permanent recession around here," said Christine Curnow, who had been earning about $3 an hour as a waitress in an Elko coffee shop, and now earns $13 an hour working for Barrick.
 
Hard Hats and Explosives
 Wearing a hard hat and steel-toed boots, Ms. Curnow works on a survey crew that marks the spots in the pit bottom where holes are to be drilled and plugged with explosives.
After the daily 2 P.M. blasting here, the loosened dirt, rock and gold residue is scooped by huge, automated shovels into giant trucks that grind their way up from the depths of the pit bottom.
If they have any significant amount of gold,, the rocks are taken by the trucks to a processing mill, where they are ground to the fineness of talcum powder; rocks with a lower gold content are put on a "heap leaching" pile. The leaching process, a new method of using chemicals to soak the gold from the ore, has vastly increased the amount of gold that can be recovered, and Barrick has emerged as one of the most productive mines in North America.
The gold leaves here in bricks that are 85 percent pure, and goes to a refinery before making its way onto world markets, where it is now selling for about $350 an ounce.
 
20 Acres for $5
 Under the Mining Act, anyone who finds commercial minerals on public lands must establish a claim with the Federal Government to obtain mining rights. And if a mining company wishes, it can "patent" 20-acre tracts for $5 or less, transferring ownership to private hands. Up to now, some 3.2 million acres of public land, an area about the size of Connecticut, have been sold under this patenting process. In some cases, the law has allowed people to buy Federal land and make millions of dollars in profits by converting the property to ski resorts, golf courses and condominiums.
Mining officials denounce such abuses. But they contend that the Government could stop such scams, which have been well-publicized, without drastically changing the 1872 Act. They also say they would not oppose the payment of holding fees on public lands. But 5 percent royalties on the selling price of the gold, as called for in the Bumpers bill, would put many mines out of business, they contend.
"The mining industry doesn't have any philosophical problems with paying a royalty; they just can't afford it," said Steve Alfers, a Denver lawyer who worked on a study of the potential effects of proposed mining law changes. "They just don't have those margins. Look at the arithmetic. The average cost of producing an ounce of gold is $317. The finished price of gold is $350. With a 5 percent royalty, you're talking about 50 percent of that margin. It's just too high."
Oil and gas producers pay leasing fees of 12.5 percent. Coal producers pay an 8 percent royalty. But mining officials say the cost of mineral exploration is much higher. Companies spend hundreds of millions of dollars in exploration before finding a rich lode, they say. The mineral mining endured hard times in the 1970s and 1980s, when employment fell nearly 30 percent. Experts on Western economy say another severe blow would be devastating.
And John Knebel, president of the American Mining Congress, argues that changes in the law "wouldn't just hurt mine workers in the West."
"If we have to cut projects, and stop buying machinery, then the guy on the line at the Caterpillar plant in Illinois, where they make the tractors, he goes out of a job," Mr. Knebel said.
 
Environmental Costs
 Critics of the 1872 Mining Act say they finally have an unbeatable alliance: environmentalists and fiscal conservatives. Both argue that taxpayers are being saddled with huge costs to clean up abandoned mines. The U.S. Bureau of Mines has estimated that 10,000 miles of rivers have been poisoned by mine wastes. Acid from metal residue continues to seep from old pits into streams and rivers.
"The environmental costs of cleaning up these mines is running at $880 million a year," said Phil Hocker, head of the Minerals Policy Center, a mining policy research group with an environmentalist perspective. "Until we get this law fixed, the taxpayer is going to bear those costs."
In many cases, environmentalists say even huge amounts of money cannot correct problems caused by mining. They now fear efforts to open a large mine just two miles from Yellowstone National Park. Canada's Noranda Minerals Corporation plans to mine gold, silver and copper near the tiny tourist town of Cooke City, Mont.
The project would employ 140 people in an area that, supporters say, sorely needs the jobs. But environmentalists say the acid drainage from the project could flow into the park through Soda Butte Creek, and ultimately threaten the survival of the endangered Yellowstone Cutthroat fish.
"It's all the worst elements conceivable," said Louisa Wilcox, a spokesman for the Greater Yellowstone Coaliton, an environmental group. "It's near the park. It's in grizzly bear habitat. It's going to be a major pollution source forever because of the acid mine drainage."
But the mining industry has accused its critics of dishonestly blurring the line between past and present. They concede that ecological concerns were sometimes cast aside in the past. But nowadays, they say, mining must conform to strict standards imposed by a host of state and Federal environmental laws like the Clean Water Act.
Barrick is bonded for more than $20 million to pay for reclamation in case the company went defunct, said John McDonough, the general manager of the mine here. Until now, the Barrick mine has not patented the public land it uses, saying that the bureaucratic hassles involved in securing a patent would outweigh the benefits. But as Congress considers changing the Mining Act, the company said it was considering applying for such a patent.
As for changes in the old law, "Mining people are pretty nervous about these proposals, which are pretty draconian," said Pat Garver, a lawyer for Barrick. "Some companies will move to foreign markets, like Mexico, where there are almost no environmental restrictions."
That might be bad news for Ms. Curnow, who is 29 and has three children. "My husband works at the mine, and so does my mom and my brother," she said. "It's given us a good, solid middle-class life."

The open pit mine is about 1,700 feet deep and a mile and a half across. Many area residents credit such mines with keeping the local economy going. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times) (pg. D25)

HEADLINE: Rights Leader Urges Blacks Not to Buy Japanese Autos

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Feb. 11

 BODY:
The head of the N.A.A.C.P. urged blacks today not to buy Japanese cars because he said Japanese auto makers were reluctant to establish dealerships owned by blacks and unwilling to build plants in inner cities.
"This is not Japanese bashing, said Benjamin Hooks, the group's executive director. "We don't hate anybody. But we want to take care of our own." 
 Mr. Hooks made the statement during the 83d anniversary celebration of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. He added that blacks had a big stake in the survival of the United States Big Three auto makers, which have treated them far better than their Japanese counterparts.
More than 140,000 black Americans are employed by General Motors, Ford and Chrysler, in the plants where the cars are made and in the corporate offices, Mr. Hooks said.
 
Disappointment From Talks
 "I just resent people saying that we don't make a good product," he said. There were 259 dealerships owned by members of minorities among those of American auto companies last year, as against 11 dealerships among those of the Japanese companies, he said.
Mr. Hooks also said that recent talks between his group and Japanese officials have been disappointing. He said the idea his organization was getting was that the Japanese would not go out of their way to promote blacks or build plants in inner-city areas.
Bob Butorac, a spokesman for American Honda Motor Company in Torrance, Calif., said the Japanese car manufacturer had made progress in hiring and promoting members of minorities and would continue to do more. He said about 3.7 percent of Honda's dealers were members of minorities.
Edd Snyder, a black who owns who is black and is the owner of Mid-State Toyota in Delaware, Ohio, said Toyota had treated him very well when he wanted to becaome a dealer. He added that that Mr. Hooks's statement was simplistic. "I operate in a worldwide economic community," he said adding that he had cars on his lot built in Kentucky.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Journal;
New Hampshire Voters Taking the High Road

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 11

 BODY:
Voters have kept telling pollsters that they care about substantive issues, not tabloid sex stories. But the experts have been skeptical, because people often give falsely virtuous answers on delicate subjects.
This "social-desirability effect," as pollsters call it, prompts people in surveys to hide their racial animosities, exaggerate how regularly they vote, and underreport their interest in pornography. From what people tell interviewers, you might conclude that one peculiar recluse somewhere is buying all 1.6 million copies of Penthouse magazine every month. 
 But some new data here suggest that New Hampshire voters might be telling the truth after all. Contrary to the expectations of some social scientists, politicians, journalists and tabloid distributors, the public has shown more interest in obtaining Gov. Bill Clinton's "Plan for America's Future" than in buying Gennifer Flowers's account of "My 12-Year Affair with Bill Clinton."
The distributors of the tabloid Star, who braced for sell-outs at the supermarket after the extraordinary publicity for Ms. Flowers' cover story, report only a small increase in sales across New Hampshire. People's failure to buy the tabloid, of course, doesn't necessarily mean that they're indifferent to the accusations. They may be disgusted and decide to shun both the tabloid and Mr. Clinton, or they might have satisfied their curiosity through news reports about the accusations.
 
Surprisingly Small
 But the modest increase in sales does seem surprising, especially considering how many journalists and campaign professionals were here to boost sales. In Manchester, the only outlets in need of extra copies were at the airport and in a downtown hotel filled with journalists.
The number of extra purchasers of Star, whose cover headlines promised "Mistress Tells All" and "The Secret Love Tapes That Prove It!" was much smaller than the number of people who called Mr. Clinton's headquarters asking for a copy of his plan, whose cover promised to "restore our economic leadership."
Moreover, -- and this may be the most startling tribute of all to voters' high-mindedness -- it appears that people here were more likely to borrow Mr. Clinton's 44-page plan from their local library than to buy Star for Ms. Flowers' story.
James R. Beniger, an expert in public-opinion research, was intrigued by Star's sales. Dr. Beniger, a sociologist at the Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Southern California, said the sales seemed to provide a rare bit of hard evidence comparing people's actions with their words -- and possibly an even rarer demonstration of their honesty on a subject like this.
 
Sick of Sex Scandals?
 "The received wisdom may be wrong about the voters this election," Dr. Beniger said. "We didn't want to believe the polls when people said they were interested just in the issues, because we assumed that they wouldn't want to tell a stranger that they're actually interested in cheap tabloid stories about sex. But if there's independent evidence that they didn't buy the tabloid, then maybe they really are sick of sex scandals. Or maybe economic conditions have made those scandals seem unimportant."
The editor of Star, Richard Kaplan, who was perhaps unmindful of his tabloid's uplifting contribution to social science, declined to discuss sales figures for the issue. But a picture emerged from interviews with the five companies that distribute nearly all Star copies sold in the state. Their combined reports indicate Star's sales were about 13 percent above normal for the Feb. 4th issue, which featured Ms. Flowers on the cover.
It is impossible to say exactly how many extra copies of the 95-cent issue were sold in New Hampshire, because some of the companies' figures include sales in border regions of neighboring states, but the distributors said that the figure for New Hampshire was well under 3,000. By comparison, the Clinton campaign reports that more than 7,000 people called to get a free copy of Mr. Clinton's plan, which was advertised on television and distributed to libraries.
Sales of Star were relatively high in Manchester, where most journalists and campaign staffs are based, but even here the increase amounted to only 20 percent above normal, or 500 extra copies. Betty Carr, a librarian at the Manchester City Library, estimated that 600 people have come in and checked out Mr. Clinton's plan.
The state's magazine distributors had expected great sales after all the free publicity on front pages, "60 Minutes," and network and local news.
"I was expecting anguished calls from sold-out stores," said Sam Winebaum, the executive vice president of Winebaum News in Portsmouth, "because with a hot magazine you can double your normal sales. But nothing happened. People didn't care about the Clinton story. In a way I'm pleased with the people of New Hampshire, because they went against the grain. Maybe it shows the seriousness of the political process here."
Dr. Beniger noted that there were a couple of other possible explanations for the sales figures. It could be argued, for instance, that people didn't need to buy the tabloid after hearing so much about it on the news. But the tabloid did offer color pictures and additional details, and the magazine distributors said that publicity usually only spurred sales.
It could also be argued that many voters actually did go out and buy the issue at the same time that the tabloid's regular readers deserted it because the cover featured a politician instead of a Hollywood celebrity. But covers about television stars traditionally sell well, and nobody is a bigger television star here these days than Mr. Clinton, whose commercials are on all day long.
Dr. Beniger was inclined to conclude that voters really don't care about Ms. Flowers. "My sense is that the press embarrassed itself by trying to lead a parade that nobody was following," he said. He noted that Mr. Clinton's standing with the voters was not greatly affected during the week following Ms. Flowers's revelations.
Mr. Clinton's standing in the polls did decline after a second character issue arose last week, the question of how he got a draft deferment in 1969. This might mean that voters care more about military records than marital fidelity. But some voters say that they are deserting Mr. Clinton not because they necessarily believe the charges but merely because of the continuing negative press coverage makes him less "electable."
All of which could logically lead to this conclusion, if you can follow it: Although people here personally don't care about all these personal allegations, as long as the press keeps reporting that they care, they will worry that other people care about the allegations, and so therefore they themselves will eventually start caring about the allegations. Democracy marches on.

HEADLINE: INDIA IS PRESSED ON ATOM PROJECT

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Strategically adrift after the collapse of the Soviet Union and in need of economic and technical assistance from industrial powers, India is coming under increasing international pressure to place its nuclear program under comprehensive safeguards.
An announcement by officials in Norway last week that they had finally obtained documentary evidence of secret Indian purchases of Norwegian heavy water from Romania in 1986 is expected to touch off new interest in India's nuclear program, which is now assumed by arms experts to have a large military component despite New Delhi's assurances to the contrary. 
 Norway's Foreign Minister, Thorvald Stoltenberg, said in Oslo last week that it would be "legitimate" to re-examine aid to a developing country when that country is spending its money on a questionable nuclear program. Japanese officials have given New Delhi similar warnings. Indian publications say Russia has also told India to rethink its opposition to arms control.
 
An Area of Danger
 India's reluctance to sign the 1968 treaty against the spread of nuclear weapons has given neighboring Pakistan a longstanding excuse to refuse also, making South Asia the last major area where there is no prospect for progress in nuclear arms control.
Pakistan, which is now under an American aid embargo because of its nuclear program, acknowledged last week for the first time that it is capable of producing bombs. India set off a nuclear explosion in 1974 and is thought by arms experts to have produced enough plutonium in unsafeguarded reactors for 100 to 200 weapons.
Both India's nuclear program and concern over human-rights violations in India, are likely to be raised in Congress this year. They are already being discussed in British and European Parliamentary committees. India's hopes for aid and investment could be affected, European diplomats say.
Stephen Philip Cohen, co-director of the University of Illinois program in arms control and international security, and a former member of the State Department's policy planning staff, advocates linking India's request for a permanent seat on an expanded United Nations Security Council with greater cooperation on nuclear controls.
 
Regional Talks Sought
 Since last June, Pakistan and the United States have been trying to manuever India into agreeing to regional talks on nuclear weapons. When Pakistan's Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, with American backing, first proposed a five-nation conference involving his own country, India, China and what was then the Soviet Union, India rejected the idea with scorn. But second thoughts followed, as prominent Indians began to ask if an uncooperative attitude at this juncture might not be damaging to Indian interests.
"At least they are listening now," a senior Bush Administration offficial said recently, acknowledging that India's new isolation in the wake of the breakup of the Soviet Union was beginning to be felt in New Delhi.
Another Administration official said the strongest argument for pressing India now was that New Delhi was out of line in an age of "competitive disarmament," when former Soviet republics were abandoning arsenals and nations like North Korea and Argentina were signing inspection agreements. China also says it will sign the accord on the spread of nuclear arms.
"We have the best chance we've ever had to move the Indians, and moving the Indians is indispensible to progress on proliferation," said Gary Milhollin, a University of Wisconsin law professor and director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control.
 
Diversion Through Romania
 It took more than five years of investigations, and the collapse of the Ceausescu Government in Romania, for Norway to find what it considers indisputable evidence that Romania diverted to India about 14 tons of heavy water, a spokesman for the Norwegian Foreign Ministry said Monday.
"For the first time we have solid proof -- real evidence -- because we have been allowed to investigate directly in Romania in the Ceausescu archives with the help of the Romanian police," Bjorn Blokhus, the spokesman, said in a telephone interview from Oslo. "The findings are quite impressive. The documents show that the destination was India, and the address to which the shipment was sent."
Last week, Norway confronted the Indians with its new evidence, Mr. Blokhus said.
"We sent them the material and asked for comments from them," he said. On Friday, India at first said it had never received shipments of Norwegian heavy water, but later agreed to examine the Norwegian documents.
The 1986 shipment was the second the Norwegians say was sent to India in defiance of Norwegian agreements. The first, diverted through a German company in 1983, involved about 17 tons of heavy water.
Experts say that the two shipments diverted from Norway were only part of the substantial tonnage of heavy water India bought "under the table" in the 1980's, much of it from China and the Soviet Union. Moscow also openly sold safeguarded heavy water to India, which apparently went to reactors that are open to inspection.
"India had made well over a ton of unsafeguarded plutonium by 1990," Mr. Milhollin said in an interview Monday.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media;
OLD QUERIES GREET TSONGAS ON CLIMB

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 11

 BODY:
Paul E. Tsongas barely had time today to savor his surprise front-runner status before facing a round of renewed questioning about his health, his political strength outside New Hampshire and his ultimate ability to be elected.
At a news conference here, where a group of women endorsed him because of his support for the right to choose an abortion, the former Senator from Massachusetts joked about the sudden increase in his press coverage and about his climb in the polls. 
 "I'm not used to this situation," he said at the Y.W.C.A., where journalists outnumbered the women making the endorsement. "But I like what I have."
There was laughter all around, but the ensuing dialogue underscored the political reality that when candidates move out in front of the pack they face a renewed need to deal with questions they have already answered.
He was asked, for instance, what made him different from the other Democrats and from President Bush?
 
'Fundamentally 'Pro-Business'
 Mr. Tsongas said he was different because "my economic issues are fundamentally pro-business." He noted he was in favor of a capital gains tax but not in favor of a tax cut for the middle class. "I'm not trying to play Santa Claus," Mr. Tsongas said, repeating what has become one of his more popular lines. "You don't build the economy with a tax cut."
He was asked whether his health was still fragile after his successful fight against cancer eight years ago, whether it was the reason he had scheduled so few public events each day.
No, he replied, he just liked to swim and have lunch with friends out of the spotlight of television cameras. His health is fine, he said, except that as a result of his treatment for cancer he has lost hearing in his left ear.
Did some of his work for corporate clients in the last eight years as a member of a law firm constitute lobbying?
He said he represented a number of business clients as well as the Sierra Club and the Humane Society of the United States.
Mr. Tsongas answered every question with self-deprecation and patient, plainspoken answers.
"The only poll that counts is what happens Election Day," he said. "The worst thing that can happen to a candidate is to become obsessed with polls."
"I would have been for 10 months in the fetal position," he said, speaking of his early popularity showings.
 
Cautious About Polls
 The latest Boston Globe and CNN-USA Today Gallup polls show Mr. Tsongas ahead of his rivals, but he appeared cautious about his new status. He said that in previous campaigns where he had been the underdog he had always thought a time would come when he would pull ahead, as he has now done. He said he had begun to doubt that until recently.
Mr. Tsongas, who recently borrowed $45,000 from his daughters' college fund to finance his campaign, said that in financial and organizational strength Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas was the front-runner in the Democratic race.
"Bill Clinton has raised three times as much money as I have," he said, and "gotten endorsements from governors, senators, congressmen."
Asked how he planned to get through the Southern primaries on March 10, Mr. Tsongas said he could offer no detailed strategy beyond an intent to "just be the last man standing." He said he would campaign in the South.
He said his message that the country must pull itself up by its economic bootstraps would do well in states where manufacturing jobs have dwindled and added."My strength will be in states that have an industrial base."
 
A Clinton Friendship
 Mr. Tsongas refused to join in criticism of his rivals, saying he and Mr. Clinton had become friends and that the Governor's record, which other candidates have criticized, was something Mr. Clinton could be proud of.
Mr. Tsongas was repeatedly asked whether his battle with cancer had left him more susceptible to illness and whether it was responsible for his cough. He said the cough came from talking for long periods.
"Bill Clinton has the same throat problems I do," he said. "And, as you know, he canceled appearances because he was sick. He can do that and there is never a question because there is no reason to question it. I cannot do that. I cannot do that because there is always this lingering doubt."
Mr. Tsongas predicted that his health would be a continuing area of inquiry. He said he had made his doctor available to answer any questions about his health.
Mr. Tsongas said he was increasing his swimming to show he is healthy and would be competing in two national swimming tournaments this year.
He said that he swam the breaststroke on his college swimming team but that during this campaign year he would be doing the difficult and highly aerobic butterfly stroke to show his endurance.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul E. Tsongas is moving to the front of the pack, and gaining political strength beyond New Hampshire. He waited to begin a town meeting at the Palace Theater in Manchester Monday night. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans;
Bush Ready to Step Up His Attacks on Buchanan

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
In a sign of lingering concern over Patrick J. Buchanan's Presidential challenge, President Bush's announcement of his candidacy on Wednesday will kick off a sharply accelerated New Hampshire campaign in which the Bush camp has added events and laid plans for an attack on Mr. Buchanan if it proves necessary.
Initially hoping to reduce the importance of Mr. Buchanan by ignoring him, the Bush organization had planned to keep the President's visits to the state to a minimum and to rely primarily on surrogate campaigners, like his wife, Barbara, as well as television advertisements and interviews conducted by satellite from the Oval Office. 
 But opinion polls showing that Mr. Bush enjoyed a surge in popularity after his last visit on Jan. 15, and then slumped again during his absence of more than three weeks, prompted the campaign to expand Mr. Bush's personal schedule in New Hampshire.
 
Bush Weekend Anticipated
 The President will spend the entire weekend there before Tuesday's vote, instead of the one-day trip on Saturday that was scheduled. Mr. Bush will announce his candidacy to about 1,000 supporters at a Washington hotel and an appearance before the New Hampshire Legislature on Wednesday.
As Mr. Bush prepared for his visit to New Hampshire on Wednesday, his efforts were complicated by a new series of television advertisements by Mr. Buchanan, a conservative columnist, that strike Mr. Bush on the same weak flank that the Democrats have made a target, painting him as indifferent to everday concerns.
"Until I came up and announced my candidacy, those people in Washington behaved as if they did not care," Mr. Buchanan says in a new television commercial. He adds: "Those who did this to you have forgotten you and walked away from you. Together, you and I can take America back and make her great again."
Even if Mr. Buchanan is not a serious threat to Mr. Bush's re-election, as the Bush campaign believes, his new attack on the President highlights the way his challenge vexes Republican strategists: it only serves to reinforce the Democrats' arguments.
 
Hoping to Inflict a Wound
 Instead, the Bush campaign has been forced to confront Mr. Buchanan, developing a strategy that Bush aides described as an effort to wound Mr. Buchanan as much as possible in New Hampshire and then to eliminate him entirely in the next big day of contests, on March 3, in the Georgia and Maryland primaries.
Bush aides hope to be rid of Mr. Buchanan well before the June 2 primary in California. They believe a contest could complicate Mr. Bush's position in the nation's most populous state, which Republicans fear the President could lose in the general election.
Appearing before the New Hampshire Legislature today, Mr. Buchanan delivered the sort of tough, protectionist message that the Bush campaign hopes will prove unappealing to voters.
"I don't want, and no American wants, a trade war," Mr. Buchanan said. "But we Americans have got to stop being trade wimps."
With Mr. Bush publicly saying he wants to avoid a negative campaign, the Bush camp hopes to avoid having to attack Mr. Buchanan directly in New Hampshire. "I really would like to get through this primary without going after another Republican," Mr. Bush said in an interview on Monday with WBZ-TV news of Boston.
 
From the Oval Office?
 But the campaign has prepared outlines for ads attacking the challenger if they are needed in the final weekend, the period when Mr. Bush went on the offensive against Senator Bob Dole of Kansas when it appeared that Mr. Dole might win the 1988 primary. The Bush team also has collected quotations from Mr. Buchanan's prolific writings that could be used to paint him as anti-Semitic, anti-feminist and isolationist.
There will be at least one more Bush advertisement on New Hampshire airwaves by the weekend, which a senior campaign aide described as a "last-minute appeal for votes from the President, delivered from the Oval Office or some other spot in the White House."
But beyond that, the campaign plans to focus on more small-scale, personal events in which Mr. Bush will mingle with voters as much as his security cordon will permit.
Responding to New Hampshire supporters who complained that Mr. Bush did too many set-piece events, the campaign added two stops in shopping malls in Nashua and Bedford to Wednesday's schedule.
The purpose of these efforts is to get Mr. Bush past the stage at which he is apologizing for the state of the economy and promising that he cares and on to a new phase in which he can talk of his own vision.
 
'An Amazing Country'
 "The long-term theme is going to be that this is an amazing country," said Victoria Clarke, Mr. Bush's campaign press secretary. "We have done remarkable things, we have changed the world, and we have to take all that talent and all that energy and all those resources and change America."
Mr. Bush's efforts at long-distance campaigning in New Hampshire have been intensive. On Monday, his voice filled the airwaves and newspaper pages of New Hamsphire and Massachusetts with several "exclusive" interviews for local television and newspaper reporters.
Surrogates like Mrs. Bush, who will follow her own schedule during her husband's visits this week, also have kept the President's campaign going.
