HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
Old Tactics Failing, a Handful of Lawmakers Hustle to Block Pentagon Cuts

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
The military threat from what was once the Soviet Union has all but vanished. The Pentagon has grudgingly pointed its spending plans downward. Opinion polls show strong popular support for diverting military dollars to domestic programs. The question now is whether Congress will accept the change.
Or more precisely, whether a handful of lawmakers, following a familiar political script, can block proposed cuts in the Pentagon budget favored by most of their colleagues to protect particular districts and states from threatened economic losses. 
 The outcome will not be clear until final bargaining over the Pentagon budget is completed in the fall. But there are already several signs that some lawmakers hope to restore money for weapons made in their districts -- and that they face a harder sell than in past years.
Representative Pete Geren is mustering labor unions and civic groups to save the F-16 fighter jet program that employs 16,000 General Dynamics workers in his district in Fort Worth, Tex.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat, is enlisting support from influential colleagues who control the military's checkbook to spare the cancelled Seawolf submarine, assembled by Electric Boat in Groton, Conn.
Representative Thomas J. Downey is rallying the powerful Long Island Congressional delegation to salvage financing for the Grumman Corporation's F-14 fighter plane that the Navy has stopped.
But there are early indications that some of the old strategies might not work this year. Lawmakers say their lobbying tactics are not budging colleagues who are eager to cash in on the Soviet Union's demise.
"No, it can't be business as usual," said Mr. Downey, a veteran of several successful fights to win financing for Grumman, Long Island's largest private employer, with a large plant in Bethpage. "Where in the past members were sympathetic to you, now defense dollars stand in way of highway improvements or education."
So lawmakers have taken a different tack, pushing their interests by wrapping them in the broader mantle of national security priorities like preserving "industrial base," the factories that build certain crucial weapons, or equations that say it is cheaper to keep building a weapon than to pay contractors cancellation fees. In some cases that is true.
At a recent hearing, for example, Senator Dodd said the Pentagon's plan would close America's "only yard capable of producing a ballistic-missile submarine capability." Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney acknowledges that and has expressed concern over the nation's ability to manufacture nuclear submarines.
Many of those strategies are not new and some reflect genuine concerns. But rarely have they been used with such zeal. In an election year in the middle of a recession, a lawmaker's ability to save jobs could spell the margin of victory or defeat at the polls.
 
Cuts and the Jobless
Recognizing that, lawmakers are more willing to compromise than they have been in the past. Mr. Dodd, for example, has written off hopes to regain the submarine-a-year building pace the Navy had planned for the Seawolf.
The Connnecticut and Rhode Island delegations are just trying to recoup financing for two of the $2-billion submarines on order that Mr. Cheney rescinded. The Pentagon plans to buy only one Seawolf.
Ultimately, the something-is-better-than-nothing approach could work. Congress will almost certainly make additional cuts beyond the $10 billion reduction the Bush Administration proposed in its $281 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.
Some cuts could come from slightly deeper troop cuts or by cancelling the four B-2's the Pentagon wants to buy in the fiscal 1993 budget. But few on Capitol Hill want to cut deep enough to lengthen the unemployment lines in an election year.
"With the economy is such bad shape, Congress is more inclined to slow down the pace of defense reductions and try to save some of these jobs, at least in short term," said Bernard L. Weinstein, an economist at the University of North Texas.
 
Formula for Arms Cuts
 In recent years, lawmakers had relied on a proven formula to restore weapons that the Pentagon said it did not want or need.
First, line up support with a member on one of the four key Senate and House committees dealing with the military. Better yet, enlist Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin or Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, who head the armed services committees. Or Representative John P. Murtha of Pennsylvania or Senator Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, chairmen of the lesser known but equally powerful military appropriations subcommittees, which actually disburse funds.
Second, organize letter-writing campaigns by workers and civic groups aimed at influential lawmakers and the Administration.
It's a political game that the Pentagon complains about but plays regularly.
 
Past Bargaining Chip
 "The Pentagon says zero and Congress puts it back; it's been a bargaining chip in the past," Representative Dan Glickman, a Kansas Democrat, said of new engines that a Boeing plant in his district installs on KC-135 fuel-tanker planes.
The old strategies have worked in the past. Mr. Downey, who helped Mr. Aspin regain the committee chairmanship a few years ago, capitalized on their close relationship to have F-14 funds restored.
The Osprey, an aircraft that takes off and lands like a helicopter and flies like a plane, has survived several Pentagon cuts thanks to the powerful delegations from Texas and Pennsylvania, where the aircraft is built.
On the other hand, the B-2, or Stealth, bomber has been cancelled despite having subcontractors in nearly all 50 states.
"Basically, the smaller and less visible the program, the easier it is for a lobbying effort to work," said John Isaacs, legislative director for the Council for a Livable World, an arms control lobbying organization here.
So what about some of the Pentagon's cuts in the proposed 1993 budget?
General Dynamics has already slashed its Fort Worth work force to 21,000, from 31,000 two years ago, and economists say thousands more will lose their jobs if the Air Force stops buying F-16's after next year, as planned.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: New Hampshire;
Cuomo Backers Plan Late TV Drive

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEDFORD, N.H., Feb. 11

 BODY:
With as many as half the potential voters in the Democratic Presidential primary here describing themselves as undecided, supporters of Mario M. Cuomo said today that they would launch a sizable television campaign on Thursday following a speech by the New York Governor on economic issues at Harvard University on Wednesday.
Mr. Cuomo's long-scheduled speech at the John F. Kennedy School of Government has attracted widespread attention because of the unsettled political situation here and the write-in campaign being waged on his behalf. 
 "I'm not running for President," Governor Cuomo said again this week in Buffalo. But in an allusion to the growing write-in effort, he added: "I wouldn't presume to interfere with the good people of New Hampshire. Who am I to tell the people of New Hampshire, 'You shouldn't do that'?"
In Washington and elsewhere in the country, Democratic elders continue to talk about a late entry by Mr. Cuomo or some other candidate, although the impediments to such an action -- early filing deadlines, lack of time to raise money and so on -- are acknowledged by everyone to be formidable.
 
What Boston's Mayor Wants
 Mayor Raymond Flynn of Boston said on Sunday that he hoped the Governor would decide to run, despite his announcement on Dec. 20 that he would not seek the Democratic nomination because of state budget problems.
Elated by Mr. Cuomo's refusal to disavow the write-in effort, Philip Krone, the Chicago real estate and public relations consultant who started the national Draft Cuomo for President Committee, said that television commercials would start running today, on WMUR, New Hampshire's most important television station, and continue for the next five days. The committee also plans radio and newspaper advertisements in the days leading up to the voting here on Feb. 18.
Tom Bonnar, an official of the station, said said the Cuomo campaign has contracted to have commercials on several times a day, in what he described as "a very significant buy."
 
A 'Common Sense' Platform?
 According to those involved in preparing the commercials, they show someone writing in Mr. Cuomo's name and give instructions on how to do it. The Governor is described as "the candidate of common sense" -- an attempt to capitalize on voter dissatisfaction with the quality of the field.
Mr. Krone's goal has been to get at least 15 percent of the total vote, which under the party rules would entitle Mr. Cuomo to some of New Hampshire's delegates to the Democratic National Convention. If the turnout totals 130,000 to 135,000, as predicted by experts, Mr. Cuomo would need at least 20,000 votes next Tuesday.
In polling by The Boston Globe on Sunday and Monday evenings, for which voters were not told of the write-in campaign, 6 percent of the respondents volunteered their intention to vote for Mr. Cuomo, up from 2 percent late last week. American Research Group, a New Hampshire polling concern, puts Mr. Cuomo's current total at 8 percent, using a slightly different question.
"The Cuomo people have the potential to get 20 percent," said Dick Bennett, the president of American Research Group, which is working for none of the candidates. "He could be a viable alternative for an awful lot of people going in to the ballot box full of doubts and indecision. Their campaign is a lot more sophisticated than a lot of what's going on here."
The five active Democratic candidates have begun to take notice of Mr. Cuomo's potential as a spoiler in the hard-fought contest, though some specialists consider the mechanical complexity of write-ins an impediment.
One of the leaders, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, acknowledged at a news conference today that at one stage he had favored the entry of Mr. Cuomo, with whom he agrees on many economic questions. Asked whather he would still welcome a candidacy by the New Yorker, he replied, "Hell, no."
The Cuomo campaign, which is run by Mr. Krone and Don Rose, a Chicago political consultant, has raised about $90,000 so far, including $19,000 on Monday, the best day to date, officials said. Mr. Krone said his major concern was persuading voters who had developed doubts about Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the early front-runner, that Mr. Cuomo could beat President Bush and that Mr. Tsongas could not.

HEADLINE: A Texas-Size Battle to Teach Rich and Poor Alike

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
The scenario has become annoyingly repetitive: The Texas Legislature devises a school financing plan that tries to close the spending gap between rich school districts and poor ones, only to have the State Supreme Court declare the plan unconstitutional.
It happened again last month, for the third time in three years, in a battle that reflects not only the politics of one state but also the difficulty in overhauling school finances. 
 Like Texas, 22 other states are in court over the way they finance public schools. And like Texas, 12 of them have seen financing plans reopened by new lawsuits, which contend that the original plans do not equalize the spending on pupils in poor school districts with those in rich districts. But unlike any other state, Texas has been forced to go back to the drawing board a fourth time.
"Texas certainly is not the norm, but it's also not unique," said David Hornbeck, a former Maryland Education Commissioner who is now a school consultant to several states. "Texas has had more plans that have been overturned."
 
State Provided Formula
 The latest Texas plan declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court was a so-called Robin Hood approach to school aid that was created by the Legislature in special session last March. The plan carved out 188 education districts, formed basically along county boundaries, and allowed the districts to set their property tax rates under guidelines provided by the Legislature. Each district was able to determine the formula for sharing the money among its schools.
The court, voting 7 to 2, said the plan was unconstitutional because it amounted to a statewide property tax and was levied without voter approval.
Two previous plans approved by the Legislature also generated lawsuits contending that school financing was inequitable. Those plans were rejected by the Supreme Court in 1989 and 1991 because they did not raise enough state taxes for the schools. The disparity in spending for each pupil between rich and poor districts in Texas is the greatest of any state. Spending for each pupil ranges from $3,190 in the poorest schools to $11,801 among the richest schools, according to the Equity Center, a Texas education research organization in Austin. The Department of Education estimates that the average for the United States in the current school year is $5,400 to $5,500.
The repeated failures of financing plans in Texas, which has the second largest student population after California's, mirror problems found in other states to a degree: political resistance to new or higher taxes and an inability to sell voters on the need for changes in school finances.
The political pressure on the Legislature against higher taxes is enormous. Texas is just one of five states that does not have a personal or corporate income tax, a distinction the Legislature wants to preserve. One of the others, New Hampshire, is also battling over equitable distribution of school funds among poor and rich school districts.
 
Failure on Two Fronts
 That Texas has gone so long without an income tax is a testament to an era when the state was awash in oil money. The state's wealth allowed the Legislature, which meets every two years, to address school financing inequities by giving poor districts slightly more state money, which comes primarily from a sales tax. This practice not only failed to give poor schools significantly more money but failed to create a more equitable way of financing the schools.
The state's economy changed with the collapse of oil prices in the mid-1980's. But the mentality in the pink granite statehouse in Austin and among voters has not. In the last legislative session, for example, there was sentiment to pass legislation barring a state income tax. So lawmakers, citing pressure from voters, argue that it is political suicide to vote for more taxes.
"The big road block is that to provide a truly equitable solution, we need substantially more state money," said Craig Foster, executive director of the Equity Center.
In an analysis, the center determined that to achieve true equity, state aid should average 55 percent to 60 percent, instead of the 47 percent to 48 percent the state now contributes to the mix of Federal and local property tax money on which the 1,050 school districts operate.
The Legislature has been among its worst enemies in selling the school financing plan to the public. In virtually all of the other 22 states sued over the problem, new financing plans were combined with educational improvements to make higher taxes more palatable to voters. Not in Texas.
 
Facing Court Deadline
 "They haven't comprehensively or strategically connected the financing piece to an education plan," said Mr. Hornbeck, the school consultant who redesigned the Kentucky education system two years ago. "As a consequence, it is not clear to people what the extra money will buy."
As the Legislature faces a June 1, 1993, deadline imposed by the Supreme Court to come up with a new plan, there is little consensus on how to proceed. The current taxing law will remain in effect until the deadline, unless the Legislature comes up with a new one before then.
One solution under consideration is a constitutional amendment that would give the Legislature final authority over financing schools, in effect blocking the courts from having any further say in the matter. Another idea would be to close the spending gap between rich and poor districts by consolidating districts.
"There isn't anything close to an agreement," said Al Kauffman, a lawyer for the Mexican-American Legal Defense and Education Fund, which represents poor schools in the Texas lawsuit. "This is a very tough battle and it's going to be very difficult."

HEADLINE: Is Brushing Up and Down a Drudge? Try Brushing Upscale

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
AND now, at a specialty store near you, regard the leading-edge indicator of consumer chic in America, the brilliant new vehicle for environmental correctness, health consciousness and graphic self-expression: toothpaste.
Toothpaste? 
 O.K., this is not just toothpaste; this is status toothpaste. A rainbow coalition of imported and domestic varieties, offering everything in the way of ingredients like birch extract and anise oil, is nibbling its way to the front of the shelves at drugstore boutiques, upscale health-food emporiums, carriage-trade purveyors and department stores with an attitude.
"It's definitely a trend," said Joyce Bresa, the general manager of Caswell-Massey's flagship store at Lexington Avenue and 48th Street in Manhattan. Sales of specialty toothpaste "are at least 25 percent higher than a year ago," she said.
Toothpaste is no longer, as inventory professionals might put it, just an oral-cleansing product. As Mrs. Bresa sees it, America is reeling from all the bad news, hiding out at home from the economic crisis. "People are looking for the reassurance of simple pleasures these days," she said. "They're spending money on simple luxuries they can afford, instead of all the luxuries they can't."
Like toothpaste. You know, instead of the trip to Kitzbuhel.
To be sure, some people are buying specialty toothpastes out of an abiding commitment to health consciousness or a real concern for the environment. Many nontraditional pastes advertise that they contain no harmful chemicals or whiteners, that they are not tested on animals and that their packaging is made of recyclable materials. Other consumers "are tired of typical American toothpaste," said Giorgio DeLuca, a founder of Dean & DeLuca in Manhattan, which, despite its mission as specialty food purveyor, has been selling imported toothpaste of late.
"American brands are too sweet and too pepperminty," Mr. DeLuca said. "People are switching to toothpastes that might more delicately round out a good meal." Aha: toothpaste as digestif.
Things have come a long way from the Eisenhower days of Bucky Beaver in the "brush-a, brush-a, brush-a, brush-with-new-Ipana" era. Back then, a good bourgeois tube of Ipana or Colgate had the sanctioned cultural inevitability of a 1956 Dodge with tail fins. To Americans reared on minty flavors, the new toothpastes offer anise-flavored accents (think of Sambuca or licorice), or those of sage, arnica or thyme. Be warned, though, that some exotic toothpastes may be under scrutiny by the Food and Drug Administration. Toothpastes that use F.D.A.-approved ingredients can be marketed as cosmetics without elaborate oversight. But others, which make health claims based on fluoride compounds or whitening agents, are considered over-the-counter drugs, and may need approval before they can be marketed, said Sharon Snider, a spokeswoman for the agency.
The imported and health-food toothpastes have not won the Seal of Acceptance of the Council on Dental Therapeutics of the American Dental Association. Dr. Kenneth H. Burrell, director of the council, said the 140,000-member association has not issued warnings against foreign or health-food toothpastes but none have earned the seal, which has been given to 25 American toothpastes for their decay-fighting properties.
Supplying the long-range clinical studies required by the association can cost $100,000 to $1 million and approval can take 6 to 18 months, Dr. Burrell said, and many foreign and health-food makers do not have the resources, or see the need, to apply.
He said that although fluoride toothpastes offer the best decay prevention, even nonfluoride imports and health-food pastes can reduce plaque and gum disease. But many buyers have a different point-of-sale motivation. For them, it all comes down to . . . well, decorating.
For those to whom toothpaste is as much a life-style statement as the Lexus in the driveway or the Swiss coffee grinder on the kitchen counter, the trusty standup Crest pump has gotten a bit long in the tooth. You are what you brush. Or at least you are what you exhibit on the sink by the medicine chest.

HEADLINE: ALBERTVILLE;
No Longer Soviet Skaters, But They Are Still the Best

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBERTVILLE, France, Feb. 11

 BODY:
For all the political changes and economic deprivations that have recast the Soviet Union into a Commonweath of Independent States, one constant remains: However the remaining republics are aligned and whatever they call themselves for the moment, they still produce the world's best pairs in figure skating.
As Natalya Mishkutienok and Artur Dmitriyev performed a glorious free-skate program, rich in emotion, power, grace and elegance, they became the eighth consecutive couple from what was once the Soviet Union to win the gold medal in the Winter Olympics. 
 In so doing, they followed a tradition of pairs who have been proving their superiority in the Olympics since 1964, just the third year in which the Soviet Union participated in the Winter Games. And with another former Soviet couple, Yelena Bechke and Denis Petrov, winning the silver medal, the former Soviet athletes also showed just how far behind they have left the best from so many other countries, including the United States.
 
Solid, but Uninspiring
 The leading Americans were Natasha Kuchiki and Todd Sand of Costa Mesa, Calif., national champions in 1991, who skated a solid, but uninspiring program to finish sixth. Another couple that trains in the same rink with them, Jenni Meno and Scott Wendland, finished 11th. The sentimental American favorites, Calla Urbanski and Rocky Marval, who won the national title last month, were 10th, falling from seventh after the original program.
Isabelle Brasseur and Lloyd Eisler of Canada, who finished second to Mishkutienok and Dmitriyev at the world championships last year, were third.
For these Albertville Olympics, the former Soviet athletes are representing an amalgam known as the Unified Team. Five republics have contributed athletes to the Unified Team, including Russia, which is Dmitriyev's homeland, and Belarus, which is Mishkutienok's.
The roots of both pairs are deep in Soviet tradition, as discovered and nutured by Tamara Moskvina, the coach and former Olympic pairs skater who brought Mishkutienok and Dmitriyev together more than six years ago, and Bechke and Petrov in 1987.
She was particularly fascinated by Dmitriyev's strength and Mishkutienok's delicateness, and as they grew and matured, Moskvina played on those assets. With Aleksandr Matveyev, the choreographer for both couples, she created the program Mishkutienok and Dmitriyev first used two years ago and truly mastered tonight, fairly floating above the ice -- he in lavender, she in pink, both in emotional union -- to "Dreams of Love" by Franz Liszt. Apart from her failure to complete a double axel jump, they were flawless, and the audience embraced them with a standing ovation.
Their success is all the more impressive, given the political landscape in which it
continues. Late last year, what was once the national sports committee in the Soviet Union disbanded, leaving federations for each sport in each republic to its own devises to support athletes.
 
Alarming Increase in Training Costs
 The skaters were far enough along in their training for Albertville, but costs continue increasing at alarming rates. So tonight Moskvina deflected questions relating to the future, beyond a decision to have a glass of champagne and some cavier as soon as possible.
"Our customary celebration," she said, before adding, "Truthfully, these changes have not affected the preparation of these couples greatly. We have extra expenses than previous years, but the federation and myself try to make everybody safe and stable so they can prepare properly.."
For the Americans, the standings were especially disappointing because the United States had a modest streak of its own, with medals in the last two Olympics -- Jill Watson and Peter Oppegard, the bronze in Calgary four years ago; and Kitty and Peter Carruthers, the silver in Sarajevo in 1984.
Urbanski, the 31-year-old waitress from Delaware, and Marval, the 27-year-old trucking company owner from New Jersey, had carried the highest hopes into the Games, for winning their first national title and generating waves of spiritual and financial support simply by capturing imaginations.
 
Costly Mistake Ruins Routine
 But 30 seconds into their program they became tangled when Urbanski landed too close to Marval after he threw her into a triple twist, and her left skate caught his. They nearly toppled, and the mistake threw off the rest of their 4-minute-37-second routine. After a succession of more awkward maneuvers, they finished without a smile.
Speaking to reporters later, Urbanski blamed the early mistake for the problems. "It was a mess after that," she said. "It's not up to our standards and it's not acceptable."
All the Americans said they would likely stick around for another two years for a chance at the next Winter Games, in Lillehammer, Norway. Moskvina was asked if her skaters would be there. She hedged her reply, saying: "Our country just broke down. Nobody has future plans for individuals like us."
But then she smiled, a telling sign. If this group of former Soviet skaters doesn't get there, in all likelihood others will, and everybody knows what that means.

HEADLINE: British Air's Earnings Up

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
British Airways P.L.C. said today that its net profit soared in the last three months of 1991 because of a one-time gain. But the company said recession continued to trouble its main markets in the United States and Britain.
 British Airways said net profit for the three months ended Dec. 31, which is the third quarter of the company's fiscal year, rose to $415 million, from $26 million in the corresponding period a year earlier. Earnings per share rose to 18 cents from 3.6 cents. 
 Sales rose 5.6 percent, to $2.45 billion from $2.32 billion.
The latest figure includes a $262 million one-time gain from the sale of British Airways' engine overhaul business to the General Electric Company of the United States.
The carrier said results for the most recent quarter were also able to outpace those from a year earlier in part because the airlines had been suffering in late 1990 from high fuel costs brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis.
Lord King, chairman of British Airways, said in a statement: "We are positioning ourselves well to take advantage of economic recovery when it happens in our major markets. Meanwhile, in these uncertain conditions, it is essential to seek further cost savings."
British Airways converted its results from pounds to dollars at the Dec. 31 rate of $1.87 to a pound.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
$500 Billion Here, $500 Billion There

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WHEN accountants talk about the cost of the savings and loan debacle, they mean the budgetary cost -- the money Uncle Sam must borrow to pay off every insured depositor. But when economists talk about the cost, they mean something else.
The act of shuffling funds from taxpayers to depositors, they note, does not create or destroy tangible wealth. The real costs, they argue, are the losses in past and future output, the decline in national income from the diversion of savings from productive capital into everything from see-through office buildings in downtown Los Angeles to unrentable shopping malls in yet-to-be-built suburbs of Dallas. 
 And thanks to the intrepid number-crunchers at the Congressional Budget Office, this economic cost has now been estimated. Their recent report reckons the loss through the year 2000 adds up to a whopping half-trillion of today's dollars.
This year Washington will spend an estimated $96 billion to cover failed savings and loans' liabilities to insured depositors. That is a jaw-dropping number, a sum as large as the G.N.P. of Norway. But most analysts agree that the outlay itself will have little direct macroeconomic effect.
The transfer of funds should not change depositors' behavior because they were never given reason to believe their nest eggs were in jeopardy. Nor should interest rates be affected, since the dollars borrowed to make the payoff will flow back into the lendable funds of the banking sector. Indeed, many economists argue that the bailout money does not belong in the budget because it will have virtually no impact on national spending or saving.
This hardly means, though, that the savings and loan meltdown has been costless. The budget office points out that deposit insurance created an enormous interest subsidy for investors in speculative projects, allowing them to borrow at rates close to those offered to blue-chip corporations. And the resulting misallocation of capital -- the spectacular overbuilding in commercial real estate -- reduced the capacity of the economy to produce what people really want to buy.
To calculate the amount of capital that went astray, the researchers worked back from the deposit insurance claims against failed savings and loans. They estimated that on average these claims represented 51 percent of the loss in the market value of real estate projects built with borrowed funds. The rest was borne by the equity investors in bankrupt projects, along with the shareholders in now-insolvent savings and loans.
Budget office analysts then used a computer model designed by Warwick McKibbin of the Brookings Institution and Jeffrey Sachs of Harvard to simulate the effects of the the lost capital resources on national income. The economic effects are first felt in the early 1980's, long before the regulators understood that something had gone badly wrong in the once-sedate savings and loan industry. But the impact is most dramatic in the early 1990's, with a loss of about $40 billion in the gross national product. It diminishes thereafter, as "above the baseline" rates of investment slowly return the economy to the baseline growth path.
The researchers identify two other potential effects that could change G.N.P. Deposit insurance, they note, made depositors feel richer and taxpayers feel poorer. The resulting impact on private savings should largely be self-canceling -- the depositors' gain, after all, is the taxpayers' loss. But the public's long delay in recognizing the potential liability to taxpayers does imply a delay in taxpayer response, and therefore a slower accumulation of capital.
With all three effects counted, the peak annual loss in output is roughly one-tenth greater and the recovery is somewhat slower. All told, the cumulative loss in G.N.P. through the year 2000 comes to a shade less than $500 billion in 1990 dollars.
It does not make much sense to add up the annual losses this way: since time is money, a dollar of income in 1980 is worth a lot less than a dollar lost in 1999. But the more rigorous "present value" figure for lost income is not much different. Recomputed by the Congressional Budget Office from the perspective of 1990, it comes to $484 billion.
Big numbers may not impress the way they once did. But a half-trillion here and a half-trillion there still add up to real money. The $484 billion, for example, is roughly in the range of the output lost during the current recession. And it is greater than the total foreign debt accumulated by the third world in the 1970's.
Perhaps the most remarkable thing about the savings and loan collapse is how little enduring impact it seems to have had on politics and policy. Whole continents stagnate for want of $484 billion. But here in America, the thrift follies seem to have been relegated to just another sour footnote to the what-me-worry 1980's.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises as Hopes Fade For More Interest Rate Cuts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed higher yesterday, as expectations of an imminent cut in interest rates subsided.
Analysts said comments by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, helped puncture speculation that the nation's central bank would nudge rates lower to help revitalize the economy. The dollar gained more than 2 cents against the British pound and nearly 2 pfennigs against the German mark on the remarks. 
 Gold prices moved higher, by 40 cents an ounce in New York.
In a speech at the convention of the Indpendent Bankers Association in San Antonio, Mr. Greenspan repeated his belief that interest rates were low enough to stimluate the economy.
The Fed chairman left open the possibility of further moves to push rates lower. But he said actions already taken by Fed should be "adequate to turn the economy onto the path of sustained recovery."
Financial markets had expected the central bank to push rates downward after the Labor Department issued another bleak employment report last Friday. The Government said the economy lost another 91,000 jobs in January.
But the Fed took no steps on Monday or yesterday to signal that it was easing its monetary policy. And Mr. Greenspan's testimony wiped out any remaining expectations that rates would soon fall.
The Fed chairman "took the speculation out of the market," said Kevin Logan, the chief economist of the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
That was good news for the dollar, which is supported by stable or rising rates. Higher yields increase foreign demand for American securities, which must be bought with dollars.
The dollar rose to 127.55 Japanese yen in New York yesterday from 126.70 on Monday. In Tokyo, markets were closed for a national holiday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 126.90 yen, up from Monday's close of 125.35 yen in Tokyo.
The British pound fell against the dollar, slipping to $1.7970 in New York, from $1.8190 late on Monday. In London, the pound fell to $1.8025, from $1.8280 late on Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Monday, included: 1.5965 German marks, up from 1.5770; 1.4295 Swiss francs, up from 1.4085; 5.4380 French francs, up from 5.3775; 1201.25 Italian lire, up from 1,187.50, and 1.18215 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17765.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold rose 40 cents an ounce, closing at $356.30. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $355.80, also up 40 cents.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $356.15, from $355.00. In Zurich, it rose to a closing bid of $356.25 from $355.00.

HEADLINE: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Fall

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit continued to ease in the week that ended yesterday, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, a publication that tracks bank rates.
"The next direction in savings yields will be influenced by the consumer confidence report due out on Thursday," said Robert K. Heady, The Monitor's publisher. 
 "If there is no improvement, there will be additional pressure on the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates further. In the event it does act, we can expect another wave of rate cutting that will send yields down to even lower levels than at present.
"Right now,"the odds heavily favor another action by the Federal Reserve."
Among New York area commercial banks, the average yield on a money market account dropped by 7 basis points, to 3.51 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Among the savings institutions in this area, money market account yields averaged 4.12 percent, off by 4 basis points.
 
Midlantic's Big Cut
 For money market accounts, the steepest cut among area banks was made by Midlantic Banks Inc. in New Jersey, which lowered its yield by 26 basis points. The Bank of Tokyo Trust in New York posted the sharpest drop in yields on its three-month certificates, with a cut of 19 basis points, while the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company lowered the yield on its six-month certificate by 26 basis points -- more than any other bank in the area.

HEADLINE: Frustrated, Chip Group May Disband

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

 BODY:
A Government advisory panel charged with drafting a strategy to help the American semiconductor industry issued its final report yesterday and prepared to shut itself down, its numerous recommendations having gone largely unheeded.
"I expect that we will go out of business," said Ian Ross, the chairman of the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors and the former president of Bell Laboratories, the research division of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. "We don't really see that there is a role for NACS ongoing, under the present circumstances." 
 Dr. Ross, who spoke at a Washington news conference, could scarcely conceal his disappointment that the committee, which started out with a bang in 1989, is ending with scarcely a whimper. Almost none of its recommendations have been carried out and, in the committee's view, the nation's computer chip industry is still losing ground to Japanese competitors.
Dr. Ross and other industry executives said the group's experience demonstrated how difficult it could be to craft a policy to help a specific industry when the Bush Administration was against "industrial policy" that picks winners or losers.
"Either the stuff they said had no teeth, or the stuff they said was interesting and never had a prayer," said Michael Borrus, a semiconductor industry expert at the University of California at Berkeley who had worked for the committee.
Now, with the economy reeling and an election at hand, the Administration appears to be becoming more receptive to what it calls technology policy. But the committee concluded that it has "done all that it can" in terms of presenting ideas.
 
First Proposals Were Rejected
 The committee, made up of top electronics industry executives and Government officials, was created by the 1988 trade law to advise the Government on a strategy for the semiconductor industry.
Its first report, issued in 1989, contained some bold proposals -- chief of which was the establishment of a corporation, perhaps backed by Government loan guarantees, that would make low-cost capital available to help American companies re-enter the consumer electronics business.
The proposal was "opposed by the Administration very openly and very forthrightly," Dr. Ross recalled yesterday. In retrospect, some analysts say, the committee lost credibility with that initial report and never regained it.
The committee also recommended an increase in the financing for Sematech, the semiconductor industry consortium that is partly financed by the Defense Department. Instead the Bush Administration is proposing to cut the Federal contribution to Sematech next year to $80 million from $100 million.
 
Some Accomplishments Cited
 The committee more recently proposed Micro Tech 2000, an ambitious undertaking in the tradition of the Apollo moon project, to develop the computer chip manufacturing technology that would allow American companies to leapfrog the Japanese. But no plans were ever put forth as to how to organize, coordinate or finance such a project. That task will now fall to the Semiconductor Industry Association, the chip makers' lobbying group.
Still, Dr. Ross pointed to some accomplishments of the group. A proposal to accelerate depreciation for semiconductor manufacturing equipment is now in a bill before Congress. The committee also made many more generic recommendations, such as calling for improved education and improved tax credits for research and development -- measures that have also been suggested by many other parties and which the Administration is trying to implement.
In the last two or three years, American computer chip manufacturers seemed to have stopped losing market share and the Japanese appeared to have stopped gaining ground. But Dr. Ross said he believed this was more an anomaly tied to steep price declines in Japanese memory chips than a true turnaround.
 
A Final Warning
 In its final report, entitled "Attaining Pre-eminence in Semiconductors," the committee warns that Japanese companies are still heavily outspending American ones on research and new equipment. It also says that American market share of electronics equipment, such as computers and televisions, dropped by 14 percentage points between 1985 and 1990.
The report recommends steps to encourage industrial investment. It also recommends that the Government help spur the formation of electronics consortiums, among other things by allowing rival companies to cooperate in manufacturing in nascent areas, such as flat-panel displays.
It also recommends that the Government stimulate manufacturing of electronic products that could be big users of semiconductors, such as by supporting the development of high-speed communications networks and "smart" highways and vehicles, which use electronics to speed traffic flow and reduce accidents.

HEADLINE: Honeywell-Minolta Dispute Teaches Conflicting Lessons

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
In full-page newspaper ads, news conferences and public statements, Honeywell Inc. has been insisting that its $96 million award last week in a patent infringement case against the Japanese company Minolta Camera is less a victory than a vindication of American technological prowess.
Honeywell also asserts that the whole affair highlights how the United States has squandered the benefits of that prowess by failing to demand more international protection for patents and other intellectual property. 
 But Minolta officials say that in the battle over who invented the automatic focusing technology widely used in today's cameras they see a different lesson: America pays a price for the timidity of its industry.
Minolta officials, who have been irked by what they call Honeywell's efforts "to turn a complex business dispute into an international trade issue," say that Americans concerned about the country's economic future should look closely at testimony about Honeywell's decision to quit making a key camera component based on its automatic focusing technology. Minolta says that the retreat was premature and cost the United States hundreds of manufacturing jobs.
"It was typical of a number of American manufacturers that have failed to look to the future," said Sadahei Kusumoto, chairman and chief executive of Minolta Camera's American subsidiary, the Minolta Corporation, based in Ramsey, N.J. "It was a good device," he said. "And with a couple of hundred thousand dollars in investment, everyone would have been able to use it, and they would still be in the photographic business."
The four-month legal battle in Federal District Court in Newark ended in victory for Honeywell on the issue of whether Minolta infringed the automatic-focusing-technology patents that Honeywell filed in the early 1970's, although the jury said the infringement was unintentional.
The jury sided with Minolta on whether it had breached a contract with Honeywell that ran from 1979 to 1985 and covered the use of what was called TCL, a later Honeywell autofocusing technology covered by other patents. It was the TCL technology that Minolta says Honeywell abandoned too soon.
 
Dispute Over Research Money
 As Minolta told the story in court, Honeywell first informed it and other Japanese companies in 1979 that TCL was being developed to provide autofocus technology for single-lens reflex cameras, which were growing in popularity because they allowed consumers to use telephoto lenses and other variations on the standard fixed camera lens. The technology proved to be far more difficult to develop than anticipated, however, and when the first cameras using it reached the market by 1982, they were commercial flops.
At that point, Minolta says, it and other Japanese camera makers told Honeywell that it would have to improve TCL if they were to use it. Minolta said that Honeywell was also informed that Minolta was working on its own autofocus system. It claimed that in 1983, Honeywell responded with a series of what Minolta considered unreasonable demands that the Japanese company pay half the cost of the improvements, commit to purchases and accept delays in the target date for completing the project.
Minolta said that Honeywell had actually already decided to drop the business and was putting off any further investment because it was secretly concentrating on trying to sell its TCL rights to another Japanese company, Mitsubishi.
 
Minolta Produced a Hit
 Eventually, Minolta went with its own system and, in 1985, introduced the Maxxum camera. The Maxxum was a hit with consumers, helping send Minolta into its current position as the leading camera maker in the United States market, with annual sales of about $400 million.
Minolta said that one result of its success was a temporary surge in TCL orders from Japanese rivals desperate to catch up. Those orders waned as the other camera makers developed new technology, and the TCL unit was sold by Honeywell several years later. Today, TCL is used primarily in video cameras.
Honeywell says Minolta's view of TCL's history is misleading. "Honeywell invested tens of millions of dollars in TCL," said Michael V. Ciresi, the Minneapolis attorney who led the Honeywell legal team. "The idea Honeywell wouldn't invest was nonsense."
Mr. Ciresi said that Honeywell was demanding a commitment from Minolta and the other camera makers before investing still more in 1983 because of its experience with the VAF autofocus technology it pioneered in the mid-1970's for lens-shutter cameras -- cameras which, unlike single-lens reflex models, do not allow the user to view the image directly through the camera lens.
 
Japanese Sought an Alternative
 VAF autofocus modules were big sellers in the first few years after Pentax of Japan brought them to market. But the Japanese manufacturers soon began looking for a local alternative. Instead of the passive-focus technologies of VAF and TCL, which simply process the image received by the camera lens, the Japanese switched to active autofocusing technology. This active version relies on shooting a beam of light out to the subject and determining the focus by measuring how long it takes the light to bounce back.
Active autofocusing does not have enough range to work well in all applications in single-lens reflex cameras, which is why TCL continued to be of interest. But Honeywell feared that Minolta and others intended to use TCL only until they could develop their own alternative. "There wasn't any doubt that they were going to go their own way," said Mr. Ciresi.
He also said that Honeywell approached Mitsubishi not for the purpose of selling TCL but to try to establish a joint venture with a Japanese partner that might make the technology more appealing to Japanese camera makers.
Both companies' arguments echoed themes that have risen repeatedly in trade tensions between the United States and Japan. And although both companies say that such tensions are not the problem in their particular dispute, it is likely that further developments in the camera wars will reflect the larger tensions and differences between the two countries.
Honeywell attorneys, for example, said that pretrial investigations had uncovered cooperative practices among the Japanese manufacturers, cooperation the attorneys say would constitute antitrust violations in the United States. Camera industry committees in Japan discussed both the design and pricing of new products before they reached market, Honeywell said Monday.
"Those are interesting issues we are going to pursue in the other cases," said Mr. Ciresi, referring to pending disputes with 14 other Japanese camera manufacturers. Besides the Japanese camera makers, Honeywell has named a Korean company, a Taiwan company and an American corporation, the Eastman Kodak Company, as potential violators of its patents.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Cable Television Stocks Languish

BYLINE: By Geraldine Fabrikant

 BODY:
WHILE the stock market has been soaring, the cable television stocks, particularly Tele-Communications Inc. and the Comcast Corporation, have languished, depressed by the specter of tougher regulations.
Neither is even near the highs they hit in 1989. Tele-Communications closed yesterday at $15.50, off 25 cents. Its high since 1986 was $21.625 in late 1989. Comcast, too, closed yesterday at $15.50, up 37.5 cents. Its high had been $19.938 in late 1989. 
 Two weeks ago, the Senate approved a bill that would let municipalities regulate cable systems rates and would allow television stations to charge cable systems for the right to retransmit their broadcast signals.
The bill faces several other hurdles before it becomes law, but experts and officials say some form of regulation seems inevitable.
If the new rules prove to be relatively mild, then cable stocks could take off, many analysts say, because the uncertainty would be removed.
While concern is focused on the Senate bill, most of the other issues potentially damaging to cable have virtually disappeared, including rising interest rates, and competition from direct broadcast satellites and the regional telephone companies, at least in the near future, said John Kornreich, who follows the media companies for Sandler Capital, an investment firm.
The drop in interest rates has allowed most cable operators to refinance their debt at much lower costs. In the last several months, for example, Tele-Communications has refinanced close to $1 billion of debt, probably saving about $30 million in interest over a year ago, Mr. Kornreich estimates. The company has been piling up long-term debt. It could have used bank debt, which would have offered lower rates in the near term, but left an uncertain future.
Aside from taking advantage of lower interest rates, Tele-Communications has raised its cash flow over the last two years by at least 35 percent.
Comcast was able to finance its $1.5 billion acquisition of Metrophone, a cellular telephone company, more attractively than it might have a year ago.
Moreover, the pay-per-view segment of cable, which allows cable subscribers to pay to watch movies on impulse, is growing. It would not be subject to regulation, since it is not part of the basic cable offering. Indeed, for the first time Time-Warner cited pay-per-view revenue as a noteworthy contributor to the profitability of its cable operations.
As cable operators upgrade their systems, more channels will be available, including more allocated to pay per view.
The recession has slowed cable's growth somewhat, but not as much as had been feared.
"We follow 50 cable companies," Mr. Kornreich said. "Every one had a record year of cash flow. At least 80 percent had double-digit growth. I don't know any that had under 5 percent growth."
Meanwhile, direct broadcast satellites, once viewed as a serious threat to cable, have not proved to be much competition.
And the telephone companies appear more likely to form joint ventures with cable than to challenge it.
Thus if there is a compromise on the Senate bill, the cable stocks probably would react favorably. The cable companies want the issue resolved one way or another. Once there is a resolution, investors would undoubtedly feel reassured.
The House still has to come up with its version of cable reregulation. But based on a moderate bill it passed in 1990, the House will not be as aggressive as the Senate. Then it would go to a compromise committee. President Bush has said that he will veto a harsh bill.
John Reidy, who follows the cable industry for Smith Barney & Company, said he believed the President was likely to accept reasonable legislation. "He has no particular interest in the cable industry, but he has a strong vested interest in preserving his role as a deregulationist," Mr. Reidy said. "If adversaries of cable want to get anything through, it has to be something both the President and the industry can live with."

HEADLINE: Democrats Try to Foil Bush's Tax Agenda

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
As President Bush urged House Republicans to stick with him on his "short-term" economic growth package today, Democrats set the political stage to force them to vote against other parts of his plan.
At a meeting at the White House, Mr. Bush told Republican members of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee that the country wanted action on a cut in taxes on capital gains from 28 percent to 15.4 percent, on faster depreciation for new investments and on various steps to encourage home buying. Action on the other proposals in his State of the Union address and budget request could come later, he said. 
 But Democrats were busy arranging things so that Mr. Bush could not set the legislative agenda. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, introduced all of Mr. Bush's tax proposals in the House as one bill. Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, announced that this was the bill the committee would consider on Wednesday, in a rare open session.
 
Scoring Political Points
 That committee meeting will be televised, like Mr. Bush's opening comments before meeting with committee Republicans today, as the White House and the Congressional Democratic leadership concentrates on scoring political points. The smaller Republican package does not include one major individual tax-cutting provision, a $500 increase in the personal exemption for children. Democrats want to chide the President for not making the "family credit" a priority item.
The bigger White House list includes at least three sections that the Democrats want to use to demonstrate broad opposition by Congressional Republicans. They include imposing Medicare taxes on state and local employees, taxing undistributed investment income on some annuities and disallowing interest deductions for loans on corporate-owned life insurance policies.
In today's White House meeting, Republicans criticized each of those provisions to Mr. Bush, said Representative Raymond J. McGrath, Republican of Long Island.
Republicans emerged from the White House with a unified counterattack against what they called the "Gephardt bill." Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the senior Republican on the Ways and Means Committee, said it was not the President's bill because it lacked the domestic spending cuts Mr. Bush had proposed to pay for further tax reductions.
Representative Nancy Johnson of Connecticut said Mr. Gephardt's approach was "hypocrisy" because he would not try to pay for the tax cuts in the larger Bush proposal. "I'm for the family credit, but I'm not for providing it without funding it," she said.
The proposal Mr. Bush and his allies are now supporting also goes beyond his original plan in reducing capital gains taxes. Under his original proposal, taxpayers subject to the alternative minium tax would have had to pay that 24 percent rate on capital gains. The bill introduced by Republicans Friday omits that requirement, potentially benefiting about 200,000 upper-income taxpayers.
Mr. Gephardt seized on that change today, saying it would cost an additional $2.7 billion and showed that Republican concerns were "focused on the ultra super-rich."
Along with the public effort to embarrass Republicans with the full Administration tax proposal, Mr. Rostenkowski and his Democratic colleagues will caucus privately Wednesday to define an alternative tax bill with a middle-class tax cut paid for by a higher tax rate on upper-income taxpayers.

HEADLINE: Rate Cut Not Ruled Out, The Fed Chief Repeats

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 11

 BODY:
A gathering here of lenders to the nation's small towns and small businesses heard Alan Greenspan restate today that he would not rule out reducing interest rates further if the economony needed an additional spur toward recovery.
But unlike bond traders and Wall Street economists counting on Mr. Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to lower interest rates after last week's disappointing January unemployment report, many of the bankers at a meeting here of the Independent Bankers Association of America have different interests. They fear that cheaper money at this point could damage the fragile economy. 
 "Lower interest rates are not good for people living off fixed-rate certificates of deposit," said James R. Lauffer, chairman and chief executive of the First National Bank of Herminie, a bank with $180 million in assets 25 miles west of Pittsburgh.
"If lower rates aren't generating productivity and expansion in the business sector, then you've got more parts of the economy hurting," he said.
 
Wants 6% C.D. Rates
 Bob Hawkins, chairman of the Southern Commercial Bank, in St. Louis, said, "To give savers a fair return, considering the inflation rate, we should be looking at C.D. rates of 6 percent, not 4 percent."
Small community bankers like Mr. Lauffer and Mr. Hawkins, who heads an institution with assets of $200 million, have lost large amounts of deposits since the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates by a full percentage point on Dec. 20. They say the loss of deposits has forced them to turn cautious on lending to their regular customers who are small businesses, home buyers and consumers.
Their traditional source of the money they lend are older people with large savings in Federally insured, short-term bank deposits. But many of these people have taken money out of banks and helped provide record inflows of money for stock and bond mutual funds in the last eight weeks.
The bankers said they had pursued higher bond yields and capital growth from stocks to capture a portion of income that vanished as interest rates plunged by more than 2.5 percentage points in the last 18 months. But those investments carry more risk than low-yielding bank deposits, and if they tumble in value, the bankers fret that less money will be available to switch back to the bank deposits.
The bankers say the shift of funds has already crimped their ability to make loans. They say the squeeze could worsen when loan demand accelerates.
David Ballweg, head of the bankers' group and president of the Community State Bank, with assets of $80 million in Union Grove, Wis., 25 miles south of Milwaukee, said consumer confidence was the biggest obstacle now to a recovering economy.
 
Backs Investment Credits
 Worries about rising health care costs, a gaping Federal budget deficit projected at $399 billion for the 1993 fiscal year, declining living standards and layoffs probably cannot be cured by lower interest rates, Mr. Ballweg said.
"The investment credits that President Bush proposed would stimulate more activity in the small-business sector," he said. "That is where the new jobs will be added, not in the big companies that are laying off people."
In his speech to 2,000 of the community bankers this morning, Mr. Greenspan repeated his comments before Congress last week that he had not ruled out a further cut in interest rates, but that he still believed enough had been done to put the economy on the path to recovery.
In words slightly stronger than his remarks to the House Budget Committee on Feb. 4, Mr. Greenspan said that the Federal Reserve "must -- and will -- continue to monitor" daily economic reports, and, "if necessary, would move toward an increased degree of monetary ease."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chip Index Rises Again

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11

 BODY:
On the strength of increased chip orders, the semiconductor industry's leading indicator climbed for the fifth straight month in January, a trade group reported today.
The Semiconductor Industry Association, based in San Jose, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 1.08 for the three-month period ending in January, up from a revised figure of 1.07 in December, and from 1.01 in November. The book-to-bill compares orders to shipments and is considered a leading indicator of the industry's performance. A ratio of 1.08 indicates that for every $100 worth of product shipped, $108 was ordered, indicating that demand has increased. 
 At $1.41 billion, three-month orders for January were up 1.4 percent from $1.39 billion for the period ended in December, and 16.7 percent higher than the comparable figure for one year earlier, which was $1.21 billion. Three-month average shipments for January totaled $1.31 billion, flat with December's figure. At $1.24 billion, actual United States market shipments for January were down 11.2 percent from December's $1.39 billion.

HEADLINE: Microsoft Discloses Apple Claim

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11

 BODY:
The Microsoft Corporation today disclosed that Apple Computer Inc. was seeking $4.37 billion in damages in its long-running copyright infringment suit against the software company.
Apple sued Microsoft and the Hewlett-Packard Company in 1989, contending that Microsoft's Windows 2.03 and Hewlett-Packard's New Wave programs copied the look and feel of the Macintosh's visual displays. Apple, based in Cupertino, Calif., later amended its suit to include Windows 3.0, the version currently marketed by Microsoft. 
 Microsoft, based in Redmond, Wash., said it considered the claim insupportable and speculative and noted that before any damages could be awarded, there would have to be a finding of infringment.
The amount of damages sought from Hewlett-Packard were not disclosed and Hewlett officials were unavailable for comment today, but the amount could presumed to be much lower because of the comparably small sales of New Wave.
 
Claim Based on Study
 Christopher Escher, a spokesman for Apple, said the $4 billion was not a formal damage claim. He said it was the conclusion of a study aimed at estimating damages that was done for Apple by Robert Hall, an economist at Stanford University.
"This is one piece of evidence," Mr. Escher said. "There will be more evidence presented." He added that Apple would make its formal damage claim to the jury.
According to Microsoft, the total damages Apple seeks include $3.01 billion in profits Apple claims to have lost because of reduced unit sales and depressed hardware prices resulting from Microsoft Windows being on the market. Apple also seeks to recover gross revenues of $1.34 billion on Microsoft Windows and on products that operate with Windows, like Microsoft Excel for Windows.
Microsoft said the claim was received by its lawyers in February in the course of pretrial discovery in a memorandum marked by Apple as "for attorneys only." Microsoft released the documents late today after Apple agreed to lift the confidentiality requirement.
Federal District Court Judge Vaughn Walker has set Friday as a deadline for motions in the case. No trial date has been set.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Apple in Radius Deal
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11 (Special to The New York Times) -- In a relatively rare move, Apple Computer Inc. has licensed part of its key operating system software to Radius Inc., a company that makes circuit boards that enhance the power of Macintosh computers. Apple has long treated its operating system, the basic software that controls its Macintosh computers, as a key competitive advantage. But Apple is now expressing more willingness to license parts of its software. Radius, based in San Jose, Calif., will help to develop a software product called Rocketshare, which will allow several Macintosh computers or Radius Rocket circuit boards to divide a complex computing task and solve it faster.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed, With Dow Rising 6.49

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday, as investor attention shifted from earnings to interest rates, and from secondary issues to cyclicals. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 6.49 points, to 3,251.57.
Investors cautious ahead of the Treasury's quarterly refunding that began yesterday with an auction of new three-year notes, moved to the sidelines as the Fed again declined to signal an easing at its normal intervention time. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy at 200.2 million shares, up from 188 million shares on Monday. The Big Board composite closed at 228.94, up one-hundredth of a percentage point as the number of gaining issues outdistanced losers by 935 to 774.
Anthony Ludovici, senior vice president and senior investment analyst at Tucker Anthony, saw yesterday's Treasury auction of new three-year notes as a non-event for the stock market, as the bond market eased ahead of the auction results, then firmed when it became apparent that the street was comfortable with the yield.
He also noted the talk by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, before the annual conference of the Independent Bankers Association of America in San Antonio, where he repeated what he has been saying all along, that he expects the effects of recent Fed cuts to be evident reasonably soon, that he believes Fed action to date should be sufficient, and that the Fed stands ready for further monetary easing if necessary
 
Dow Refuses to Retreat
 "The market believes Mr. Greenspan, as cyclicals geared to an economic rebound replace the biotechs and health care stocks in the eyes of the investors," Mr. Ludovici said. "You're talking about the major industrials, manufacturers, machine tool companies, capital goods and automobile companies.
"The Dow refuses to go down, even in its overbought position, as it makes internal adjustments through rotation."
Market activity left the Standard & Poor's index virtually unchanged at 413.76, down one-hundredth of a percentage point, while the American Stock Exchange index showed a 0.32 point gain on the day, to 415.46.
Weakness in secondary issues pulled the Nasdaq composite down 0.76 point, to 633.37, while the Russell 2,000 managed to gain 0.18 point to finish at 210.71.
Traders said after an opening loss, blue-chip issues made moderate gains as they moved out ahead of the broad and secondary markets, with buyers being selective. Airline stocks were active, while biotechs stayed weak, with cyclicals the most sought after. Money rotated out of growth stocks into cyclicals and lower-priced issues. But on the whole investors were content to remain on the sidelines, with only individual stocks reacting to news.
I.B.M. rose 1/2, to 90 1/4, as five of its previously announced ES/9000 models became available ahead of schedule.
Christina Heuer, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham, confirmed a repeat on a "buy" rating for Pfizer, as the stock gained 1 3/8, to 73 7/8. According to traders, she said Pfizer is scheduled to meet with analysts tomorrow and that the shares of the drug company are at an attractive level. Of all the major drug stocks, it has corrected the most, down 13 percent on a year-to-date basis.
Some analysts yesterday recommended Shaw Industries, a carpet manufacturer, following news of its planned merger with Salem Carpet Mills on Monday. Traders said the stock rose 1 3/4, to 45 3/4. Josie Esquivel, an analyst with Lehman Brothers, reiterated her "outperform" rating, saying the merger was a positive move that could increase Shaw's market share.
Goodyear Tire gained 7/8 to close at 61 1/4, as the company posted solid earnings, with cost containments offsetting a slight revenue drop.
Citing a slower and weaker than expected recovery in the cellular phone business, traders said Thomas Kurlak, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, lowered his 1992 and 1993 earnings estimate for Motorola, as the price of the stock fell to 80 1/8.
Conrail tumbled 4 1/2, to 82, after posting a net loss of $9.23 a share for the fourth quarter on Monday, while also making a cautious first-quarter forecast.

HEADLINE: House Sales Rose 7% From December '90

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Sales of existing single-family homes in New York State north of New York City rose by more than 7 percent in December 1991, and realty experts said today that the housing market is slowly starting to rally.
"The recession took a lot of steam out of the real-estate industry during 1990 and 1991," said Charles M. Staro, executive vice president of the New York State Association of Realtors. "We hope this modest rebound aids the housing market, and economy as a whole, shake the recessionary doldrums." 
 The association received sales figures from 40 of its 50 local realtor boards and associations. In December 1991, members reported 4,680 houses were sold statewide, an increase of 7.4 percent from the 4,359 sold in December 1990.
Houses sold in December 1991 averaged $139,167 statewide compared to $127,305 a year earlier, an increase of 9.3 percent, the association said. In Westchester and Rockland Counties houses sold for an average of $338,381 and $188,975, respectively.

HEADLINE: A New Species of Donor Gives to Help the Neediest

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
File this one under "and you thought you'd seen everything."
With only two weeks to go in the 80th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, it seemed that the list of contributors to the fund this year had run the gamut: toddlers and octogenarians, residents of Caracas, Zurich and Dubuque, wealthy people who operate large companies and poor people who have been unemployed for months. Poets, movie stars and mechanics. Nevertheless, yesterday's mail brought a first for this appeal: a $100 check from a dog. 
 "Adam, who is an Irish setter and who lives with me, and I have saved our quarters for a while and decided that we wanted to send you a check," said a letter signed by Florence and Adam Kaye of Upperville, Va. "You can do what we cannot, so we send you our thanks and our blessings."
Adam may be the only contributor who wags his tail when he is happy, but the slow, methodical way he amassed his donation is only one variation on a theme.
 
Pennies and Nickels
 Another contributor, Susan S. Ach of Manhattan, wrote: "We are enclosing a check for $37, which represents $26 of pennies and nickels saved during the year and $5 contributed by Benjamin, 6, and $6 from Rachel, 9."
An anonymous letter attached to a check for $35 said, "For many years I never used the innumerable food coupons that cross our threshold because, I am ashamed to admit, I felt they were more trouble than they were worth. However, last January I decided to try using them for a year and to contribute at least half the savings to the Neediest Cases."
Since the fund was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then the publisher of The Times, it has raised money for disadvantaged New Yorkers by showing readers what The Times initially described as "a world of famine in the midst of plenty; of cruel heart and body hunger with bounty in sight but not in reach." What began as the Hundred Neediest Cases has expanded to meet needs of thousands of individuals.
The newspaper covers all of the campaign's overhead so that every dollar collected can be passed directly to seven charities. The money provides many forms of relief, including food for the hungry, homes for the homeless and clothing for those without. The seven charities also use the money to provide job training for the disabled and counseling for substance abusers and to support a wide array of AIDS-related programs.
 
Coins From Bottle Returns
 Carolyn Holmes of Manhattan cobbled together her $18 donation a nickel at a time. "A year ago I decided to save my coins from bottle returns," she wrote. "My best friend said: 'What a hassle. What are you going to do with the $15 or $20 you might collect?' "
" 'Go to two or three movies,' I replied."
Ms. Holmes continued, "I rarely read this newspaper before subscribing in October and how happy I was to learn of the fund and hence find a better reason for keeping track of the redemptions. I'll be collecting more cans and bottles in 1992 and look forward to contributing to the fund again."

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
After a Tourist's Death, Lingering Pain Remains

BYLINE: By Douglas Martin

 BODY:
IN this time of dangling question marks, it is hard to say whether it helps to remember. For some, it is impossible to forget.
On July 4, Rhona Lantin, a 26-year-old visitor to New York City, was killed by a stray bullet as she sat in a car inching through Chinatown. 
 The slaying of the Philippine native was one of those events that jolt this jaded metropolis, making New Yorkers seem somehow more concerned about the senseless killing of an outsider than of one of their own.
Just as when Brian Watkins, a tourist from Utah, died trying to protect his family, New Yorkers seemed to take notice for a nanosecond, a few perhaps feeling pain over what we have become.
Patrick Canning, who is now 31 years old, was Miss Lantin's fiance. "I will always try to picture her looking at me, and me trying to make her smile," he said.
The bare facts are these: The two worked in the Agriculture Department in Washington and attended the same graduate program in agricultural economics at the University of Maryland. They became engaged on November 1990. The planned wedding date, known only to the couple, was May 30, 1992.
Facts, of course, do not begin to tell this love story with no happy ending. "I more or less carry a kind of resolve, as opposed to letting this consume me," Mr. Canning said in one of several telephone conversations.
Last week, an uncle of Miss Lantin's received a check from the New York State Crime Victims Board for $2,000 -- much appreciated, but less than the cost of her coffin.
There is no more involvement with the city where Ms. Lantin died -- other than the empty promise Mayor David N. Dinkins and then-Deputy Mayor Milton Mollen made in an October meeting. They told Mr. Canning and Miss Lantin's brother, Ryan, that they would be kept regularly informed on the investigation's progress, even if there was none. They have heard nothing.
"I don't want to give the impression that I'm bitter or impatient," Mr. Canning said. "We more or less feel in the dark and alienated."
The deeper darkness is the absence of the merry sound of Miss Lantin's voice. She would sometimes break into song, usually one of the old Broadway standards she loved, as she worked in the computer room at work. "It made everyone embarrassed -- not for her but for their own insecurity," Mr. Canning said.
Miss Lantin made all kinds of rooms sparkle. She crafted dolls for Mr. Canning's nine nephews and nieces. She loved to play the piano. There was no Philippine dish she could not cook wonderfully.
In her master's thesis, she was using a sophisticated methodology urged by her adviser. The adviser, Mr. Canning said, was disappointed that his star student was not going for a Ph.D.
Mr. Canning remembers July 3, the last time he saw his fiancee, as a time of anxiousness for her. Soon, she would have to make the oral defense of her thesis.
But first, she planned two big trips. One was to New York City to join 10 members of her high school class from the Philippines for a mini-reunion. The second was a cross-country camping trip with Mr. Canning; she would join him on the West Coast for the return portion.
"I convinced her, and she wasn't all that hard to convince, that all she could do was to do her best," he said. "She promised me she would have a good time in New York City."
The next few days are forever jumbled. There was a harried flight to Newark from Chicago, where Mr. Canning had been visiting a friend. All the sudden, he was helping identify her body and choosing a coffin.
Then came the flight to Manila with the body. A three-day, 24-hour-a-day wake followed. The mourners, all wearing white, never stopped coming. The experience was ghostlike, enervating, then oddly soothing.
More than half a year has passed. Mr. Canning is finishing the final chapter of Miss Lantin's master's thesis, and will soon present it to the three members of her reviewing committee. He is proud of doing this. He is also administering two scholarship funds in her name, one for poor Philippine children and one for University of Maryland graduate students. Each has collected several thousand dollars.
The address for both is the Rhona Lantin Scholarship Fund, 4513 MacArthur Boulevard N.W., Washington, D.C. 20003. Checks should be made payable to the Philippine National Bank, the transfer agent.
The seasons change, and Mr. Canning has returned to graduate school. But he still hangs close to his fiancee's family -- striving mightily for continuity in a cruelly discontinuous world.
On Sunday, he visited her aunt's house in Maryland. She made pies from baby coconuts. One for dessert, another for him to take home.
