HEADLINE: Convicted Mayor Wins Yet More Time in Office

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 11

 BODY:
For the second time in five days, Mayor Gerald McCann of Jersey City won a stay today of a judge's order that he leave office immediately because of his conviction on Federal fraud charges.
A three-judge appeals panel lifted a temporary stay today on a ruling by Judge Arthur N. D'Italia of Superior Court, who held on Friday that Mr. McCann had forfeited his office. But Mr. McCann was out of office for only a few minutes before his lawyer, Matthew P. Boylan, telephoned the clerk of the New Jersey Supreme Court and won another stay to give the state's highest court time to review the forfeiture ruling. 
 When she stayed Mr. McCann's removal for three business days on Friday, to bring Mr. McCann before the appeals court today, Judge Sylvia B. Pressler of the Appellate Division of Superior Court was heard to say, "What can happen in three days?"
Mr. McCann demonstrated what can happen when he made 21 appointments to Jersey City's planning board, zoning board of adjustment, redevelopment agency, economic development corporation, parking authority, environmental commission, human rights commission, library board, assessment commission and the construction board of appeals.
 
Round of Appointments
 One of those named to the economic development corporation was Peter Murphy, director of the Hudson County Chamber of Commerce and a former vice president of Midlantic National Bank North, which lent Mr. McCann $20,000 in 1986. One of the counts on which Mr. McCann was convicted was that he filed a false application for that loan. There was no evidence at the trial that Mr. Murphy knew Mr. McCann had lied on his application.
The spate of appointments angered members of the City Council, who apparently do not have the power to stop them. On Monday Mr. McCann sent 10 more nominations to the council, but they were for posts, such as municipal judge, that require council confirmation. "They were rejected out of hand," said Councilman Jaime Vazquez.
Mr. Vazquez said Mr. McCann had managed to unite the eight council members against him since he was convicted Dec. 17 of defrauding a Florida savings and loan association of about $260,000. The savings and loan iis now defunct.
The council was evenly divided among supporters and opponents of the Mayor until last week, when Mr. McCann vetoed two ordinances that would have given the council greater influence over independent authorities. The council voted unanimously to override the vetoes.
Councilman Bill O'Dea, a longtime critic of the Mayor, said Mr. McCann was "handing bonbons to his supporters." Councilman Dan Waddleton, once one of the Mayor's strongest allies on the council, issued a statement in which he said: "These last-minute appointments are an insult to everyone who cares about Jersey City. I call upon all of these appointees to act in the best interest of Jersey City and decline their nominations."
Mr. O'Dea said he would recommend that the council file suit to block the appointments, which came after Judge D'Italia's forfeiture order. But Joanne Monahan, the acting city corporation counsel, reminded the council that attempts to block last-minute appointments made by Mr. McCann at the end of his first term as Mayor in 1985 were unsuccessful.
When Mr. McCann lost the mayoralty to Anthony Cucci that year, he showed his anger. Mr. Cucci arrived in City Hall to find the locks on the Mayor's office plugged with Krazy Glue, official documents shredded and the office in a shambles. Mr. McCann won a second term as Mayor, defeating Mr. Cucci, in 1989. The events that led to his conviction occurred during the four years he was out of office.
Mr. O'Dea said that if Mr. McCann repeated his angry leave-taking of 1985 and causes any damage in City Hall, "we'll seek to have criminal charges filed against him."

HEADLINE: Remember the Winter of '78?;
Those Big Snow Stories Are Fading With the Years

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON

 BODY:
A new generation gap is forming, between people whose childhood memories are hip deep in snow and children who have rarely seen snow deep enough to roll into a snowman.
After eight years of snowfalls that have been well below normal, New York City has had only 2.2 inches of snow midway through this winter. That compares with the usual 17 inches by this time in February, and it is less than a tenth of the city's average of 28.3 inches a season. 
 In Connecticut, the National Weather Service has recorded only 9.5 inches in Windsor Locks, where the season's average is 47.9, and in Albany only 19.4 inches has fallen, less than a third of the average winter's 66.
 
A Strange Statistic
 The unusually dry winter is bad news for children with sleds, hardware stores with racks of shovels, and truck owners with new plows. It has been good news for schools, many of which have avoided closing for even a single snow day, and for hard-pressed governments, which stand to save millions of dollars on overtime, sand and salt. If it doesn't snow.
Meteorologists caution not only that it may, indeed, yet snow, but also that snow, after all, is what people remember about winters. Heavy snows are rare in this region south of the snow belt, but a single blizzard roars forever in the human memory.
"Snow is a strange statistic, because it has a high degree of variability from year to year," said Fred Gadomski, a meteorologist at the Penn State Weather Communications Group, a part of Penn State University. "Such a period of below-normal snow is not unprecedented."
He continued: "The anomalous thing was the period from the mid-50's through the late 70's, when seldom was there a winter substantially below normal. That 20-year period may have cemented impressions of a climate of more consistent snowfall than has been the rule."
So people remember 1978, when back-to-back blizzards paralyzed the Northeast, dropping 31.3 inches of snow on Central Park. The winter of 1972-73, when the weather service said New York City had a record low snowfall of 2.8 inches, is less vivid.
 
Rain Is Also Scarce
 "My deepest snow?" 12-year-old Eddie Shuler of Danbury, Conn., said yesterday as he prepared for a day of skiing at Mount Southington in central Connecticut. "Maybe two inches."
"A foot and a half," said his friend, Jay Shoffner, just three years older. With a little prodding from his mother, Joy, he could name the year: 1978.
Most of the northeastern United States is short of snow this winter. The reason, said Robert Stalker, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service in Rockefeller Center, is that the brief bursts of cold air blown into the region by the jet stream have not hit moist low-pressure systems. "They just haven't been linking up," he said.
Rain is also below normal, according to the weather service, and a drought warning declared by New York on Nov. 15 for New York City and Westchester and Rockland counties remains in effect. Average precipitation for January is 3.21 inches, but only 1.68 was recorded last month. And so far February has seen only 0.02 inches.
For now, the lack of snow has made life simpler and cheaper for the people in charge of the region's roads and highways.
In New York, the uneventful winter could save $500,000 worth of sand and salt in the State Department of Transportation region that includes Westchester, Rockland and five counties to the north, estimated Joseph J. Gleeson, a regional highway maintenance engineer.
 
Some Play Catch-Up
 In Maywood, N.J., the superintendent of Public Works, Sam Pernetti, said he has saved not only money, but also time. "This mild winter means that we've had a chance to catch up on all the other work that tends to pile up, like trimming trees and getting lots of indoor painting done," he said. "You just can't complain."
Many officials, however, are wary about counting on savings. Yesterday, Connecticut's Transportation Commissioner, Emil H. Frankel, told the Legislature's Appropriations Committee that he was spending substantially less -- perhaps $3 million -- on snow removal compared with the year before.
But his staff was apprehensive, he said, because last year, amid Connecticut's budget crisis, the Legislature had cut his budget for salt and sand after a mild winter. Now, he said, "I fear the new base will be the winter of '92."
That fear isn't as strong in New York City, where snow removal is such a sensitive issue that the charter sets the snow budget -- currently $11.3 million -- at the average spending for the previous five years. This winter trucks have gone out just six times to plow snow or sand for ice, and $3.5 million is left in the budget, said Anne Canty, a spokeswoman for the city's Sanitation Department.
 
Some Lose Out, Too
 This winter is also saving time and money for everyone who drives in snow or for those who clear their own sidewalk or driveway. But it has played havoc with small businesses that count on snow.
In Lodi, N.J., James J. Corcoran estimates that he has lost $20,000 in sales, repairs and service of snow-blowers at his Tri-County Power Equipment.
"The guy who tries to get his blower started, and can't get it working, normally he'll bring it in the next day for service," Mr. Corcoran said. "But not this winter, because the snow has melted away, and people put it off for the next time."
In Stamford, Conn., Ed Keough Jr., of Keough's Turn of River Hardware, said the weather has wiped out an entire reason for people to enter hardware stores. "One of the things we live on is small disasters," he explained.
"In a bad economy, with a very unseasonable winter, this has certainly affected us," Mr. Keough said. People aren't buying shovels, but they also aren't buying jumper cables, de-icing materials, windshield scrapers or anything else they might see while in the store. And his season is lost.
"If we get a really big storm, we'll sell some shovels," he said, "but we won't sell a lot of ice-melting products. You get into February, and people start thinking it will just go away on its own."

HEADLINE: Panel Pushes For Investing In the Future

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
A mayoral task force committee is calling for a sharp increase in the amount New York City spends on its economic future and a fundamental shift in the way those funds are invested.
The panel's report, which reflects a consensus in a group that includes real-estate developers, business executives and union leaders, argues that unless such changes are made in the city's policies, New York "will experience a painful, long-term economic decline." 
 The report, which has not yet been made public, is likely to be controversial since it includes proposals that are sure to delight and offend virtually all of the city's powerful interest groups. A main recommendation is the creation of an economic development bank that would be started with an initial $250 million in capital, to be matched by an equal amount from other public and state authorities.
Investments would be made in large, public projects like the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan and a biomedical center in the Bronx, as well as enhancements to the city's transportation and telecommunications systems.
Another recommendation calls for the city to give tax credits to companies that make charitable contributions to cultural institutions, libraries or parks.
The task force is also calling for financial help for small businesses and a renewal of recently expired tax incentives for real-estate development.
 
'Very Intriguing'
 Arthur Levitt Jr., the former head of the American Stock Exchange, who was chairman of the committee, stressed that the report was still in draft form and had not yet been endorsed by Mayor David N. Dinkins or the full management advisory task force. Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, who sat on the committee, said that at this stage the Mayor still had more questions than definitive reactions. Still, she said, the report contains some "very intriguing proposals."
In recommending the development bank, the panel is calling for the city to invest $500 million a year over the next five years. If that is done, it would represent a sharp increase over the $74 million in city, state and Federal funds spent on economic development in the last fiscal year, which ended on June 30.
The report suggests that the money for the development bank come from newly issued bonds, which would be repaid with revenues generated by the projects that would be built as a result of the bank's investments. While some committee members said they thought the amount committed to the bank would probably end up being reduced, the bank nonetheless would become the main vehicle for investments in public projects. By funneling the funds through a bank that is financed on a continuing basis, the hope is that those projects would no longer have to compete every year in annual budget wrangling with financing for drug-treatment programs or new homeless shelters. But that very insulation from the political process could invite problems with the City Council, which currently appropriates funds annually for the city's economic development initiatives.
Support for the bank is likely to depend on details that were not specified in the report, like who is appointed to oversee the bank's investments and which projects are chosen to receive funds.
 
Changes in Tax System
 The panel also calls for significant changes in the city's tax system. The group proposes that companies be allowed to credit a portion of the amount they contribute to the city's cultural institutions, libraries and parks against what they pay in commercial rent tax.
That tax, imposed on companies that rent space rather than own it, is singularly unpopular in the business community since New York is the only taxing authority to levy such a tax and since it amounts to a form of double-taxation. (Renters also pay some, if not all, of the property tax on their space because owners typically build it into their rental costs.)
Members of the panel estimate that, based on historical levels of charitable contributions and a ceiling on the total amount of credit that would be allowed, the city could lose $50 million to $70 million in tax revenues from this proposal, a shortfall that would have to be met in some other way at a time when the city is already struggling to meet demands on its budget.
The Levitt committee also proposes that the city permanently phase out the commercial rent tax and the unincorporated business tax, imposed on partnerships, beginning in 1994.
 
An Expired Program
 One surprising decision was the endorsement the group gave to reinstating the Industrial and Commercial Incentive Program, which expired on Dec. 31 and provided exemptions or deferrals for taxes levied on properties in certain areas of the city.
Virtually all of the committee members except Jerry Speyer of Tishman Speyer Properties, the real-estate developers, were said to have opposed the program's reinstatement, at least in part because they regarded it as useless when there was so little financing available for new construction.
Nevertheless, the report calls for the program to be maintained in the boroughs outside Manhattan and to be extended to outmoded buildings in lower Manhattan that need renovation to reduce their vacancy rates.
Committee members said they decided to give in on the real-estate incentive issue to secure Mr. Speyer's support for other parts of the report.
 
Micro-Loan Program
 If the group's proposals are put into effect, far more emphasis would be placed on small businesses as an important engine of growth. The report calls for a dramatic increase -- to $10 million from $1 million -- in the city's micro-loan program, which grants loans ranging from $5,000 to $50,000 to retail and service businesses. And it calls for the economic development bank to begin a venture-capital program through which the city would invest equity funds in promising new companies.
To address the problem of companies leaving the city because they cannot find enough skilled workers, the panel proposed that the city match dollar for dollar the money that companies spend hiring workers who go through training programs. Again, the source of the funds to pay for such a program was not specified in the draft report.
Despite the many details that would have to be worked out for these proposals to be adopted, the panel concludes that, if approved, their recommendations could all be put into effect within 12 months.
 
Members of Panel
 Besides Mr. Levitt, Ms. Hernandez-Pinero and Mr. Speyer, these are the committee members:
Roger Altman, Blackstone Group.
Peter Brennan, Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York.
Robert Catell, Brooklyn Union Gas Company.
Stanley Hill, District Council 37, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
Richard Jalkut, New York Telephone Co.
Thomas Johnson, banker.
Edward Lewis, Essence Communications.
Ronald Shelp, New York City Partnership.
Howard Squadron, Squadron, Ellenoff, Plesent & Lehrer.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
PLEA BARGAIN IN ST. JOHN'S CASE
 The last defendant in the St. John's University sexual-assault case interrupted his trial to plead guilty to sharply reduced charges, then admitted that he had done virtually everything he had originally been accused of. The plea, in an emotional court session, brought to an end a case that had rocked the 19,000-student St. John's, the nation's largest Roman Catholic university, and emerged as one of a series of nationally publicized cases that underlined the legal elusiveness of charges of acquaintance sexual assault. B3.
 
PROFILE OF A SUSPECT
 The unemployed 23-year-old man charged with the brutal slashing murder of a Hasidic woman in Crown Heights had finished a six-year prison term for robbery in October, the authorities said. They added that on several occasions over the last eight months, the suspect, Romane LaFond, had assaulted women in similar but less violent incidents. B3.
 
A CALL FOR CHANGE
 A City University report calls for wide-ranging changes in the supervision of student-sponsored events at City College as a result of a deadly crush that killed nine people at a celebrity basketball game in December. The report also underlines criticism of the college's president, Dr. Bernard W. Harleston. B4.
 
PROTEST AT COLUMBIA
 In a day that hinted briefly at the turmoil of the 1960's, students at Columbia University blockaded doors to the adminstration building for two hours, forcing professors to remain inside, then scaled a wall and occupied an office to protest a plan to limit financial aid to needy students. B3.
 
REGION
 
OF JUSTICES AND JUSTICE
 A gubernatorial task force concluded that New York State's method of electing Supreme Court justices probably violates the Voting Rights Act because of its "uniformly poor" record of placing black, Hispanic and female lawyers on the bench. By warning that the state's judicial system would not survive a legal challenge, the report served as both a confession and a call for change. A1.
 
TEANECK OFFICER IS ACQUITTED
 An all-white jury acquitted Gary Spath, a white police officer from Teaneck, in the fatal shooting of Phillip Pannell, a black teen-ager, in April 1990. After deliberating for almost nine hours, the jury returned its verdict, finding the officer not guilty of manslaughter. A1.
 
HANGING ON AT CITY HALL
 For the seconde time in five days, Mayor Gerald McCann of Jersey City won a stay of a judge's order that he leave office immediately because of his conviction on Federal fraud charges. B5.
 
IT'S TOUGH BEING A COMMUTER
 The siege of the Ronkonkoma tow trucks started Monday, when railroad and township officials made good on a longstanding threat to tow away illegally parked cars that cover the lawns, block exit lanes and protrude haphazardly around the Ronkonkoma railroad station. But the officials got more drama than they bargained for. After 100 cars were towed on Monday, 80 commuters who returned Monday night in sub-freezing temperatures shouted, screamed and tried to storm an improvised impound yard to retrieve their vehicles. B5.

Neediest Cases . . . B2

HEADLINE: The Endless (1996) Campaign

 BODY:
What a difference a quadrennium makes: At this juncture in 1988, Iowans had been marinated in politics. Representative Richard Gephardt of Missouri, after stalking the state for months, had surely earned his narrow victory in the famous Iowa caucuses. Michael Dukakis and the other Democrats had probably shaken every hand twice. The early scrambling made it seem, as in every election since 1972, like an Endless Campaign.
Not this year. The Iowa caucuses, 1992-style, pumped up all the tension of a limp blimp. That's not meant to minimize Senator Tom Harkin's achievement. Even as a native son, he had to work to win 78 percent of the precinct delegates, a margin that reduced his rivals to reading very tiny tea leaves indeed. 
 For instance, with a straight face, former Senator Paul Tsongas issued a press release yesterday crowing that among the five Democrats, he had emerged as a surprising second in Iowa. Some second. He got 4 percent, compared with 12 percent for Undecided. And Senator Bob Kerrey, a native cousin from neighboring Nebraska, won only 2 percent. In any case, it took at least 15 percent to win any delegates.
Total delegates -- that provides one way to measure Senator Harkin's achievement. Even if he should capture all of Iowa's 57 delegates, that's not even 2 percent of the Democrats' 4,318 national total. Momentum offers a more important measure: Will the Iowa outcome affect the New Hampshire primary next Tuesday? Not much, to judge by reaction yesterday. Senator Harkin won only brief coverage on New Hampshire TV.
The deflation of the Iowa caucuses restores proportion to politics, truncating the Endless Campaign. Or does it? A lone political event brightened the noontime calendar in Des Moines Monday. Housing Secretary Jack Kemp came to speak at a Republican luncheon. Why? To help promote Republican turnout at the caucuses. Really? There was no Republican contest.
Considering that Mr. Kemp has run for President before, there may be another explanation, one that resurrects the word "endless" and includes the figures "1996."

HEADLINE: Industrial Policy as Sloppy Slogan

 BODY:
The Presidential candidates have turned industrial policy into a meaningless mantra. What they seem to mean is singling out high-tech industries for Federal assistance. But which industries?
Bob Kerrey wants to support "high-value-added" industry. Bill Clinton proposes steering production toward "high-wage" skills. Paul Tsongas calls for investing in "economically critical" industries. Even Pat Buchanan, conservative Republican, talks of targeted aid. 
 That all might sound smart; translated, it turns into superficial demagoguery. "High-value-added" would mean support for insurance underwriters and oil refineries. "High-wage" would require subsidies for certified public accountants. As for "economically critical," when Mr. Tsongas is asked if he means sugar and textiles, he won't say.
In other words, the candidates are all for helping whichever industries are hurting in whichever state has the next election. They are perverting the potential of industrial policy.
Competitive advantage is no longer reserved for countries blessed with abundant oil reserves or fertile soil. Competitiveness now often depends on a country's willingness to invest shrewdly in emerging technologies. Industrial policy is a way to square private risk-taking with public needs.
The idea is to put up a modest amount of Federal money to bolster private investors going after the next decade's technological winners. The challenge is to resist letting such funds degenerate into protection of the last decade's losers. No candidate has begun to meet that challenge.
The best case for a cautious industrial policy comes from Paul Krugman, an M.I.T. economist. He focuses on interdependence. In some industries, companies using specialized resources -- like highly trained computer programmers -- benefit by locating near one another. Proximity generates benefits well beyond what individual entrepreneurs could create alone. For example, Mr. Krugman cites Silicon Valley in California and the Italian fashion industry, centered in Milan.
The trick is to guess which future industry would throw off huge economy-wide benefits. Such guesses are often bound to be wrong, which is why Mr. Krugman is reluctant to bet more than a few billion dollars a year.
Lester Thurow, dean of M.I.T.'s management school, offers a sharper focus. He points to Europe, which has recently set up projects to spur investment in high-tech ventures like computer software and high-definition TV. These undertakings then invite partnerships of businesses and research institutions to bid for grants.
With reason, Mr. Thurow admires this approach. It artfully combines market and public incentives. Partners are required to put up half the cost of the investment, guaranteeing they won't squander public money.
A smart industrial policy need not put political calculations ahead of the market or stifle Congressional capacity to act in the public good. Money will flow only where private investors are willing to take risks. But the infusion of public money will spur a bit more risk-taking.
In short, a strong case can be made for a modest industrial policy. The wealthy U.S. can afford to risk a few billion dollars a year on good bets. What it cannot afford is for Presidential candidates to turn a good idea into a worthless slogan.

HEADLINE: Help Russia. Help Ourselves.

BYLINE: By Richard A. Gephardt; Richard A. Gephardt is House majority leader.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Beneath the veneer of competence, the Bush Administration's strategy toward the former Soviet Union is a dangerously ineffective response to the greatest democratic awakening and market-opening opportunity of the 20th century. Just as Americans recognize how the Administration has mismanaged the economy, they must now comprehend how its hesitant foreign policy jeopardizes our national security and economic interests.
Boris Yeltsin recently told Congressional leaders that Russia is "in a fight for survival" and had only three months to turn things around. Without more international aid, he said, there would be "an explosion." 
 What was our response? To date, the Administration has done precious little. Although Secretary of State James Baker is right to show the flag, accompanying a shipment of allied relief to Russia, we must not confuse symbolism with substance or meager aid for an actual commitment.
For all the hype, the U.S. assistance and commercial presence in the Commonwealth of Independent States is negligible, and most planned aid shipments will not reach those in need until spring. There appears to be no sense of urgency to negotiate protective agreements for American exporters or to change our tax, trade and export laws to expand business activity and create U.S. jobs. The day after Mr. Bush praised Mr. Yeltsin's efforts, he told Congress he would veto legislation permitting the export of telecommunications equipment to the former Soviet Union. Meanwhile, Japanese and European investment is ready to go full bore.
The Bush policy is, to quote the French politician Boulay de la Meurthe, "worse than a crime, it is a blunder." By failing to act, the U.S. may be locked out of the most important new market and source of raw materials of the 20th century. This is all the worse because we could easily take certain actions to help preserve this critical democratic experiment.
In the short term, we should be stepping up delivery of desperately needed food and medicine, while assisting in distribution, to help the people through the immediate crisis. We should get Saudi help in meeting the republics' energy requirements. And we should lead a Western effort to make the ruble convertible, a prerequisite for a stable market economy. Russia should be allowed to defer its $9 billion in 1992 interest payments owed to the Group of Seven countries. Finally, to monitor the nuclear disarmament, the Administration should press for prompt consideration of relevant portions of Start -- on verification, notification and information exchange.
In the long term, the U.S. must promote commercial ties with the Commonwealth of Independent States -- an effort that will produce jobs and rising living standards in all nations. That means providing preferential trade status, using our oil industry to develop commonwealth energy resources, exporting computers and telecommunications products and aiding U.S. business investment in Russia and the other republics. Every day of delay endangers democratization and market development as well as costing American jobs and profits that will otherwise end up in Japan or Europe.
I would happily join the President in supporting full American participation in a vigorous aid program -- financed solely by military cuts. For example, rather than spending $5.3 billion for Star Wars, as Mr. Bush has requested, we could preserve a strong program at $3.5 billion and use the savings for humanitarian aid and to contribute to the West's economic stabilization fund for the former Soviet Union.
Some say the moment is not right, that only appeals putting "America first" will be heard in these hard economic times. That's why Presidential leadership is so urgent and the offer of bipartisan support is so sincere. If we summon the idealism that enabled the Marshall Plan to succeed in the 1940's, it would mean American jobs and greater security in the 1990's, an outcome that sounds like "America first" to me.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Ad Campaign;
Tsongas: Disdain for Rivals' Plans

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT

 BODY:
SCRIPT:
Narrator: "Some candidates want to give you a tax cut of 97 cents a day. But will that create jobs? One candidate knows it's gimmicks and bigger deficits that got us into this mess. Paul Tsongas offers straight answers. He'll declare an economic emergency immediately to get America moving: Get business to invest in new jobs and plants. Rebuild industry. And make our workers the most skilled and productive in the world."
"Paul Tsongas won't short-change our future. He'll LEAD American back."
 
ON THE SCREEN:
Slow motion of coins representing the 97 cents that Mr. Tsongas estimates the various tax-cut plans of his rivals would save the average family. Stills of an "out of business" sign, workers standing in unemployment lines. Video of a Tsongas speech. A final shot of coins with Mr. Tsongas's book "A Call to Economic Arms" landing on top. (30 seconds.)
 
 ACCURACY:
The message is essentially consistent with his performance in the Senate, when Mr. Tsongas was one of 11 senators who voted against the 1981 Reagan plan to cut taxes. Just before he left the Senate in 1984, he sponsored an amendment to freeze Government spending.
 
SCORECARD:
The ad extends the Tsongas campaign strategy of dismissing rival economic proposals, including President Bush's tax-cut plans, as "gimmicks" that will only worsen the economic slump. It emphasizes Mr. Tsongas's disdain for tax cuts and deficit spending, which he blames for the current economic malaise. Mr. Tsongas presents himself as strong enough to push through plans that, even though unpopular, would energize the economy.

HEADLINE: Our Haiti Policy Doesn't Help Anyone

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Neither of the two components of United States policy toward Haiti, the embargo and the forced repatriation of refugees, is serving the goals of either country. The economic embargo (while well intentioned) has had no impact on changing the repressive political-military regime. Rather, it has produced a colossal economic, environmental and health disaster for Haiti, the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere, as you report in "Land and Health Also Erode in Haiti" (news article, Jan. 28).
The deforestation and soil erosion caused by the embargo will have repercussions for years, perhaps decades, and the famine it has caused is referred to in Haiti as "the curse." 
 Our refusal to accept the refugees fleeing the country is also in need of change. The Supreme Court, interpreting the law, has lifted the injunction against forced repatriation, making it clear that immigration laws must be altered. We are returning Haitians who risk their lives by boat to escape executions or beatings in their homes or on their streets for more of the same, while accepting Cubans who face no personal fear, but see increasing difficulties ahead.
This differing treatment is the result of: (1) a deep bias in our immigration law favoring anyone fleeing from any Communist country and particularly from Cuba; (2) the greater political influence of the United States-Cuban community compared with the Haitian community, and (3) the fact that the fleeing Haitians, who now number 15,000, are all black and may, in some unknown number of cases, have AIDS. Ironically, our embargo is itself a cause of the growth in the number of refugees we are forcing back. It is a vicious cycle that we are aggravating.
We need to change both policies now. The stranglehold of the military and the Tontons Macoutes cannot be lifted without some form of military intervention. It is too deeply ingrained and too powerful, even if a civilian regime may be temporarily installed. Intervention by a force under the direction of the Organization of American States or the United Nations will be needed, and a subsequent period of trusteeship required to establish democratic institutions and safeguard their emergence.
As for our asylum and refugee rules, the demise of the cold war should be reason enough to end the unequal and unfair application of basic principles of human rights. At a minimum, we should provide temporary protective status to the Haitians who are already here, as we are doing for the Chinese, so they are not forced to return until after the current political oppression and retributions end. We gave 125,000 Cubans permanent asylum when they fled in the Mariel boat lift of 1980 and gave 100,000 Nicaraguans asylum from the Sandinista Government in the 80's.
It is time we reviewed our asylum-refugee rules so they reflect the true risks faced by any individuals, fleeing any oppressive or brutal regime, no matter what the ideological bent of that regime, or the ethnicity of the refugees.
 
MARTIN E. GOLD
New York, Feb. 3, 1992
 
The writer is a lawyer who has dealt with immigration matters.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Democratic Race Grows Fiercer In Last Days in New Hampshire

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 11

 BODY:
Elbows were flying in the Democratic primary race today.
In a rough new phase of the New Hampshire campaign, there were sharp attacks, emotional radio and television ads, last-minute image shaping and in every camp a keen recognition that unpredictable New Hampshire was living up to its reputation as the days ticked down to the Feb. 18 primary. 
 Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who has watched his lead in the polls evaporate in the last four days amid accusations of marital infidelity in a supermarket tabloid and questions about his draft status during the Vietnam War, mounted a new television campaign intended to capitalize on his wounds by presenting him as populist martyr.
Drawing on a powerful theme in Southern politics, Mr. Clinton's advertisements plead with the voters, "Send a message to Washington and Wall Street and to the tabloids."
Looking straight into the camera, Mr. Clinton concludes: "This is your election, your economy, your country. Take it back."
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, meanwhile, was glowing with his new status as having an edge over Mr. Clinton in the New Hampshire polls. But he took the opportunity to reiterate his against-the-grain economic message, as the Democrat who calls for a cut in the tax on capital gains to encourage long-term investment and rejects tax cuts for the middle class.
"My economic views are different," he said, campaigning here today, "not only from Governor Clinton's but from every other Democrat and from George Bush."
 
Harkin Uses Iowa Boost
 All of the candidates were scrambling to adjust to a shifting political reality: an electorate that seems to skitter among the candidates, searching for an answer to their recessionary woes, but still uneasy with a field of men who arrived late and are still trying to close the sale. "It's become a classic New Hampshire primary," said George Bruno, a former state Democratic chairman who is a supporter of Mr. Clinton. "In the end, it always tightens up, and the outcome is always unpredictable."
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, for instance, was touting the mandate from his native state as he flew back to New Hampshire today. Mr. Harkin captured 76.5 percent of the vote in Monday's caucuses, based on returns from 97 percent of the precincts. After brandishing hometown headlines about his success, and brushing aside the fact that his rivals largely ceded him the contest in his native state, Mr. Harkin immediately sought to reassert his theme that he is the unashamed, true-believing, orthodox Democrat in the race.
He did so, in part, with an attack on Mr. Tsongas. Mr. Harkin asserted that Mr. Tsongas was esssentially preaching Reaganomics. "I think his mindset is right where Reagan and Bush are," the Iowan said.
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who is running close to Mr. Harkin in the polls in New Hampshire, was concentrating on boosting his Presidential image -- and the President he most preferred to be compared to was John F. Kennedy. Mr. Kerrey is trying to convert what many poll takers say is an undeveloped foundation of personal popularity into Presidential support. Today, he was campaigning on the steps of the Nashua City Hall, where Kennedy made his first campaign stop of the 1960 race and where a bust of the slain President was conveniently available for the television camera crews.
 
Week to Go, Work to Do
 Each candidate enters this final week with work to do. Mr. Clinton, who just a few weeks ago seemed to be on a glide path to the nomination, is struggling to steady his candidacy. He denied the accusations that he conducted a 12-year affair with a cabaret singer, and he denied other reports that he sought to avoid the draft during the Vietnam War. But amid the denials he lost control of his message that as a moderate Southerner he would restore "the forgotten middle class" and lead an economic revival.
This week, he plans a broadcast counterattack: In addition to the 30-second spots, the Clinton campaign is buying half-hour slots on Manchester and Boston television stations for a call-in show in which viewers can ask the Governor questions. The campaign is also running radio commercials in which a Vietnam veteran defends Mr. Clinton's record."
 
Showing Tougher Sides
 Mr. Harkin reveled in the chance today to look like a winner; one of his challenges is to persuade many Democrats that his plea to return to traditional party values is a message that can win. Trying to capitalize on whatever life he could get from the Iowa caucuses, Mr. Harkin argued that they showed the resounding approval of "the people who know me the best."
In a sign of the sharpening tone of this campaign, Mr. Harkin, perhaps the most aggressive campaigner in the field, came back tough when a reporter asked about Mr. Clinton's "latest problem." Mr. Harkin replied, "What's the latest one? I've been out in Iowa; I might have missed it."
And Mr. Kerrey's campaign has been urging people to focus on a candidate's ability to be elected, arguing that this is no longer Mr. Clinton's strong point.
Still, Mr. Kerrey was trying to float above the fray -- not a bad place to be when a multi-candidate field is fully engaged. The Senator from Nebraska, who is trying to cross the bridge from interesting politician to potential President, returned to the theme of generational change today -- a theme that Gary Hart worked with considerable success here in 1984.
Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, meanwhile, was on television tonight with a 30-minute program urging voters to back a grassroots movement to rid politics of the influence special-interest money.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 13, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption yesterday about Senator Tom Harkin's arrival in New Hampshire from Iowa misidentified the woman with him. She was State Representative Mary Chambers of New Hampshire, not Mr. Harkin's wife. The reference to Mrs. Harkin was also incorrect; her name is Ruth, not Judy.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
U.S. Network Is Planned For Cellular

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
The GTE Corporation and three regional Bell companies have announced plans to form a nationwide mobile telephone network that customers could use to send and receive cellular calls anywhere in the country.
Industry analysts said the move, announced Monday, appeared to be an attempt to play catch-up with McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., which, with 1.3 million subscribers, is the nation's largest cellular company. McCaw announced plans last fall to link its system with that of the Southwestern Bell Corporation to form the nationwide Cellular One service. 
 The new GTE-led service will link the local cellular systems operated by GTE, the Nynex Corporation, Ameritech Inc. and the Bell Atlantic Corporation. In a bid to build brand loyalty, the companies also plan to promote their local systems under a common name and to adopt common technical and quality standards. The common name has not yet been chosen.
"We are heading more and more into the information age, where you need accessibility to data and knowledge and mobility," Paul G. Kozlowski, president of GTE Mobile Communications, said in an interview.
 
A Need for Customer Loyalty
 Industry analysts said the move by GTE and the three "Baby Bells" reflected the growing pressure on cellular companies to build loyalty among their subscribers, now that the once-soaring growth of cellular communications has begun to level out.
Cellular customers have long been able to make calls from outside their normal calling areas, thanks to what are known as "roaming" agreements between cellular systems in different markets. But until recently, they could receive calls in cities outside their primary area only if they punched in a special code that informed the nearby cellular system that they were in the area. And someone trying to reach that customer would have to know what city the person was in, as well as knowing the special access number.
 
Easy as a Long-Distance Call
 As envisioned by both the McCaw and GTE ventures, a customer's cellular telephone would automatically inform the local cellular system of the subscriber's presence. The cellular system would also automatically ascertain which cellular company the customer used and whether the person subscribed to special features like voice mail. The local networks would then work together to patch through calls automatically, as easily as wired telephone networks pass along long-distance calls.
With Nynex joining the GTE venture, and McCaw Cellular already serving New York City through its LIN Broadcasting unit, consumers in New York will soon be able to choose between two companies that offer nationwide mobile telephone services.
Jonathan Tarlin, an analyst with Economic and Management Consultants International in Washington, which specializes in mobile communications, said a key to success for cellular companies in coming years would be to hold on to high-volume subscribers who run up big bills and would be likely to use a nationwide service.
Mr. Tarlin estimated that the number of cellular subscribers increased by 35 percent in 1991, to 7.3 million, but that newer subscribers were increasingly those who use their phones very little. As a result, the average monthly bill for subscribers has plunged from about $130 in 1987 to about $80 today.
Analysts also noted that the pace of change in the cellular business was now being set by McCaw, based in Kirkland, Wash., a company outside the traditional telephone industry.
Under rules set up when cellular franchises were first awarded in the 1980's, local telephone companies in each city automatically received one of two licenses to operate cellular telephone service. Under that arrangement, the so-called non-wireline franchises, owned by the non-telephone companies like McCaw, initially seemed less formidable competitors than such "wireline" companies as GTE and the regional Bell companies.
"I think this shows that the wireline companies are now recognizing the advantages of having nationwide name identification," said Michael R. Vernetti, a senior vice president at Telocator Inc., a Washington-based trade association for the cellular and paging industries.

HEADLINE: Student Shot In Hallway Of a School

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
A 16-year-old student described as the principal's protege at Park West High School in the Clinton section of Manhattan was shot in the left ankle yesterday as he walked in a school hallway to his third-period class.
The student, Wilfredo Vega, was listed in stable condition at St. Vincent's Hospital, where he was taken after the shooting. The incident occurred shortly after 10 A.M. in a fourth-floor hallway filled with students changing classes. 
 There have been about 40 incidents involving firearms this school year in the New York public schools. Ten students have been shot, four fatally. Two teachers have been wounded.
The teen-ager was struck once by a bullet from a small-caliber pistol. The police said they had no suspects or motives.
The school's principal, Richard A. Ross, said a serious incident had not taken place in the school, on 50th Street between 10th and 11th Avenues, during the three and a half years he has been there. He said the shooting was particularly troubling to him because the hard-working 11th grader had become like one of his own children.
"I've never found a Wil before, not in 25 years," Mr. Ross said. "This is a kid who is such a good and decent person. He has been to my house. My children love him. Now I've got to explain to my 12-year-old daughter that Wilfredo is shot."
As the principal spoke, his voice broke and his eyes welled with tears, and he briefly left his office to compose himself.
 
The Ingredients of Success
 In Wilfredo, Mr. Ross said, he found the ingredients of success waiting to be inspired in a youth from a poor family in the South Bronx. His father is unemployed and his mother is chronically ill, Mr. Ross said.
The principal said he had found the student a job in the mailroom at a Manhattan advertising agency, and had employed his father for one year in the school cafeteria before he was forced to dismiss him when he failed to report for work.
The shooting stunned teachers and students at Park West, which in recent years has struggled to transform itself from a place of violence and fear to one of relative calm. Several years ago, school officials said, students often carried weapons, assaults and robberies were commonplace, and there were many requests for transfers because of fear.
Mr. Ross said he had first met Wilfredo more than a year ago when he stopped to check the student's report card as he was waiting at a school elevator. The youth had decided to attend Park West High, a school with 2,000 students, because of its culinary arts program, one of several offerings that attract students from throughout the city.
Mr. Ross said he sensed a winner in the would-be chef and restaurant owner. "He is a decent, loving and warm human being," he said.
He said Wilfredo's parents were so impressed with the school that they enrolled their second son, a ninth grader. Mr. Ross said he had got to know Wilfredo's family, including his brother and a sister in the seventh grade. Mr. Ross said he was having difficulty making sense out of the seemingly random act of violence.
Outside his brother's hospital room yesterday, 14-year-old Manny Vega said his older brother did not see who shot him and did not hear any fighting before he was hit. Inside the room, Wilfredo was sitting up in bed, alert and listening to a portable radio.
"He heard gunshots as he was walking and he started running, then he heard another shot and he said it felt like a rock had hit his ankle," his brother said. "He looked down and saw that he was shot."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 15, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about the shooting of a student at Park West High School in Manhattan misstated statistics on shootings at New York City public schools since September and omitted their source. According to the United Federation of Teachers, 44 shootings have occurred in and near schools (not solely in them). Twelve students were shot (not 10), two fatally (not four). The Board of Education disputes the union's figures, reporting fewer than a dozen shootings in and near schools.

HEADLINE: Suspect in Crown Heights Killing Was Released From Prison in October

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Several times over the last seven months, the unemployed 23-year-old man charged in the stabbing murder of a Hasidic woman in Crown Heights entered homes or assaulted women in similar but less violent incidents, according to the police and allegations by neighbors.
Leah Kopel, 35, who lives near the man, Romane LaFond, on President Street said in an interview yesterday that he followed her 4-year-old son into her living room with a screwdriver in his hand last August and asked for water. Mrs. Kopel said she escorted him out. Twenty minutes later, she said, he returned and tried to knock down the door. 
 Mrs. Kopel said that a week earlier Mr. LaFond had entered the home of an acquaintance of hers and had begun choking her, but the woman did not report the incident to the police.
And the police said the arrest of Mr. LaFond in the slaying of Phyllis Lapine last Thursday was tied to another unsolved case of the sexual assault of a Hasidic woman in December.
Mrs. Lapine, a mother of four, was found dead in her home on Lefferts Avenue with more than 30 stab wounds.
The killing briefly revived the tensions that had flared in the racially troubled neighborhood last August after a black child was killed by a Hasidic driver in a car accident and an Australian rabbinical student was stabbed to death by a mob of black youths. On Thursday night Hasidim demonstrating for more police protection were hit by bottles thrown from apartment buildings and some of the demonstrators responded with shouts of "go back to Africa!"
 
Captain Recalls Another Case
 Mr. LaFond was arraigned yesterday at Criminal Court in Brooklyn on two counts of second-degree murder, burglary and criminal possession of a weapon in what Jon L. Besumder, a Brooklyn assistant district attorney, called "the most heinous crime in recent years in this county." Mr. LaFond stood listening quietly. He was ordered held without bail.
His defense attorney, Samuel Gregory, argued that no witnesses had actually seen Mr. LaFond entering or leaving the Lapine residence and that his presence "shouldn't be unusual at all because he lives in the neighborhood."
The police said Mr. Lafond's arrest was helped by cooperation from blacks and Hasidim in Crown Heights. "Everybody we spoke to -- that would be everybody -- was upset, and they told us what they knew," Chief of Detectives Joseph R. Borelli said.
One of the breaks in the case, an official close to the investigation said, came when Capt. Anthony Marra, the executive officer of the 71st Precinct in Crown Heights, who read each day's complaints, remembered the December case.
He checked the record and found the incident on Dec. 26 in which a man had entered a Hasidic woman's home several blocks from the Lapine residence and sexually assaulted her in front of her three children, pulling down her pants and fondling her.
Captain Marra learned the case had not been solved and told detectives that it "resembled in some detail what had happened at the murder scene." Two other officers from the precinct, Carolyn Taylor and Albert Valdez, recalled that they had made an arrest of a man in August in a similar crime -- Mr. LaFond.
The police went back to the December assault victim and she identified Mr. LaFond's picture. On Sunday he was arrested in the December assault, and detectives were able to match his fingerprints to a bloody palmprint found in the Lapine household, the police said.
After he was taken into custody, Mr. LaFond was identified in a police lineup by neighbors of Mrs. Lapine who said he had been going up and down their street on the day of the slaying, handing out his telephone number and asking for work as a handyman.
 
Defense Argument
 At his home at 1625 President Street, a rundown apartment building with litter in the hallways, Mr. LaFond's neighbors described him as a loner who often muttered and talked to himself. Paul Comeau, who lives in the building, said he would take the young man out on moving jobs or construction work with him to give him something to do.
"I knew he was up to trouble, but I never asked him about it," he said, adding that he was shocked by the murder charge. "Everyone says he's crazy, but I say no. He's just not educated and he needs something to do."
Linda Alexander, another neighbor who said she had watched Mr. LaFond grow up, said: "He rambles. I think he has a mental problem."
Mr. Lafond's criminal record began in October 1985 when at age 17 he was convicted of robbery and sentenced to two to six years in prison. State prison officials said he was transferred frequently throughout the prison system because he had adjustment problems and had to be separated from other prisoners. From May 1988 to July 1988, he underwent psychiatric examination.
 
Parole Violations
 He was denied parole three times, said David Ernst, a spokesman for the New York State Division of Parole. When he had served the maximum time under a state law that reduces sentences for good behavior, he was released in December 1989. But he promptly violated his parole and was put back in prison until last April 18.
In less than four months, police and neighbors said, he was in trouble again and complaining that he could not find work. On Aug. 1, he was arrested and charged with possession of burglary tools, and on Aug. 15, he was arrested again and charged with possession of burglary tools. In the first case, he received a conditional discharge on Oct. 16. The second case is still pending, said Patrick Clark, a spokesman for the Brooklyn District Attorney. Mr. Ernst said Mr. LaFond was arrested again for a parole violation at the end of August and held until his sentence expired on Oct. 31.
Although Mr. LaFond was returned to prison for parole violations after the August arrests, he gained his release at the end of October because his original prison term had ended and the burglary cases had not produced a felony conviction, Mr. Ernst said.
One of the cases was still pending, and it seemed to weigh on Mr. LaFond's mind.
On Wednesday, the day before the police say he killed Mrs. Lapine, Mr. LaFond returned to Mrs. Kopel's home, where she was working in her garden, she said. He told her he was worried that he would be returned to prison because of his encounter with her in August. "If they keep this misdemeanor on my record, I'll go back to jail," she said he told her. "I want you to talk to my lawyer."
She said she gave him her phone number to give to his lawyer, and he left.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Bush's Life-Long Credo: Low Capital Gains Tax

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
In his State of the Union Message, President Bush covered the gamut of domestic policy issues -- education and welfare, housing and health, crime and energy and trade.
 For the most part, the treatment seemed perfunctory. "We must do something about crime and drugs," he said at one point, without saying what he had in mind to do. "I ask you tonight to fund our H.O.P.E. housing proposal," he said at another. 
But on one issue, he seemed truly exercised. "This time, at this hour," he said, "I cannot take 'no' for an answer: You must cut the capital gains tax on the people of our country."
 Why is it that when George Bush talks about being the education President or the environment President or about rewriting the banking laws or dealing with energy conservation or handling a host of other economic and social issues, his words often seem to ring so hollow? And why, when he talks about capital gains, does he almost always seem engaged, even passionate?
 The answer may be that support of a low tax rate on capital gains, which are the profits from the sale of investments, is a lifelong credo of Mr. Bush's. This is not a stance like opposition to abortion that he began to stress late in life or one like nuclear disarmament that reflects his response to a changed world.
 In the Wall Street-Greenwich-Andover-Yale milieu of his youth and the Texas oil country where he first went into business, it was written in stone that people with capital should be free to develop it with a minimum of interference from the Government in the way of taxes.
 As a politician, Mr. Bush has tried to placate the two factions of the Republican Party -- the white shoe, Wall Street, Chamber of Commerce, Dewey wing of his youth and the supply-side, Sun Belt, Hoover Institution, Reagan wing of his Vice Presidency and Presidency. On many topics, the two wings are at odds. One dogma they have in common is advocacy of a lower capital gains tax.
 This is one of the few matters on which Mr. Bush has taken political risk as President. Two years ago, negotiating with Congress on the budget, he held out for a capital gains cut long after it was politically wise for him to do so and left himself open to charges by Democrats that he was simply the patron of fat cats.
 Back then, Mr. Bush was proposing that the top capital gains rate be lowered to 19.6 percent from 28 percent. This year, he is going even further. He would reduce the rate to 15.4 percent, the lowest level since 1933.
 Such a cut, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told Congress last week, would "generate substantial income and revenues to the Government, create growth for jobs investment, unleash a torrent of activity."
 Michael J. Boskin, chairman of Mr. Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, figures that economic growth would be more than $30 billion greater each year than it would be otherwise, and that could mean millions more jobs.
 The problem is, for all the evidence Mr. Brady and Mr. Boskin can muster, their Democratic opponents can counter with data showing that a capital gains cut would be little more than a windfall for the rich.
 Mr. Bush observed, for instance, that 60 percent of taxpayers who claim capital gains have incomes below $50,000. But Congressional economists found that 52 percent of the tax savings would be enjoyed by taxpayers with incomes above $200,000 and that 70 percent would go to those with incomes above $100,000.
This week, Citizens for Tax Justice, a labor-sponsored organization that specializes in tax research and analysis, published figures showing that the economy faltered after the last two capital gains reductions, in 1978 and 1981, but boomed after the tax was increased in 1976 and 1986.
 Neither side can prove its case conclusively. Few would argue that the rate of capital gains taxation was the main reason the economy grew or contracted at a particular time. Investment decisions depend much more, for instance, on market conditions, real estate prices and enticing new opportunities than they do on the rate of capital gains taxation.
 But the lack of hard evidence one way or another does not prevent the President's political opponents from accusing him of supporting a tax giveaway to the wealthy.
 And it does not stop George Bush from advocating a deep cut in the capital gains tax as an article of faith.

Mr. and Mrs. Bush are shown above in Houston on the night of the 1964 Republican primary runoff election, receiving a telephone report on the returns. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: New Hampshire;
Clinton Thanked Colonel in '69 For 'Saving Me From the Draft'

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 12

 BODY:
Trying to prevent further damage to his Presidential campaign, Bill Clinton made public today a 1969 letter in which he thanked an Army officer overseeing the Reserve Officers Training Corps program at the University of Arkansas for "saving me from the draft" and also apologized for misleading the officer about the strength of his anti-war feelings.
At a news conference here, the Arkansas Governor said he was issuing the letter, dated Dec. 3, 1969, because he knew it was to be disclosed later today by ABC News. 
 The unexpected development came as Mr. Clinton, whose campaign has been disrupted by accusations that he had an extended extramarital affair with a cabaret singer and manipulated his draft status, was trying to shake free of personal controversy and focus attention on his economic program.
 
Opponents on the Attack
 With the voting in the New Hampshire primary set for Tuesday, Mr. Clinton's Democratic opponents are shedding their reluctance to take advantage of his trouble. Today they adopted the theme that whatever the truth of the accusations, they created a cloud of doubt that detracts from Mr. Clinton's value as a Democratic Presidential nominee.
Mr. Clinton wrote the 1969 letter to Col. Eugene Holmes of the Army to explain why he had decided not to join the university's R.O.T.C. program. When Mr. Clinton agreed to join the program, Colonel Holmes requested that Mr. Clinton be reclassified from 1-A, immediately eligible for the draft, to 1-D, the category for men who joined the reserves or student R.O.T.C. units
In the letter, Mr. Clinton described what he said today was a snapshot of that generation's feelings. The letter shows that the candidate, like thousands of men in his generation, actually opposed both the war and the draft and viewed the R.O.T.C. program mainly as a way of staying out of combat without breaking the law. [Text of letter, page A25.]
In tones of moral anguish, Mr. Clinton wrote about his role in organizing anti-war rallies in the United States and Britain, where he was studying in 1969 as a Rhodes Scholar. He stated that he admired friends who had defied the Selective Service law, but did not want to break the law himself and damage his career and "political viability."
"First, I want to thank you, not just for saving me from the draft, but for being so kind and decent to me last summer, when I was as low as I have ever been," Mr. Clinton wrote.
"One thing which made the bond we struck in good faith somewhat palatable to me was my high regard for you personally," Mr. Clinton wrote. "In retrospect, it seems that the admiration might not have been mutual had you known a little more about me, about my political beliefs and activities. At least you might have thought me more fit for the draft than for R.O.T.C."
Last week, fending off questions about his draft deferment, Mr. Clinton said, "You've got to understand that if you look at the facts as they then existed, instead of some 23-year-later rewrite, the facts are, I put myself into the draft, I didn't take it out."
 
Issue Is Revived
 The question of Mr. Clinton's draft status was revived as an issue last Thursday when The Wall Street Journal reported that in 1969 Mr. Clinton secured a draft deferment by promising to join the R.O.T.C. program supervised by Colonel Holmes and enroll in the University of Arkansas Law School. Instead, he attended Oxford University for a second year then went to law school at Yale University.
Mr. Clinton admitted last week that he had done that, but denied any intention to mislead Colonel Holmes or the local draft board in his hometown, Hope, Ark. He also insisted that he had acted in good faith and later asked to have his R.O.T.C. deferment revoked because he felt a moral obligation to submit to the draft. "I had four of my high school classmates killed in Vietnam," he explained last week, "and I just didn't feel right about it."
The letter released today showed that Mr. Clinton actually signed a letter of intent to join the R.O.T.C., rather than simply making a verbal promise. It also suggested that he knew he was misleading Colonel Holmes about true feelings about the war and the Army when the two men had talked during the summer of 1969. In the letter he wrote of "loathing the military to which you and other good man have devoted years." Colonel Holmes has not been available for comment on the letter.
It was a time of growing discontent with the war, with President Nixon and, at times, with authority. College students and many Democratic politicians worked that year to fan such sentiments. A high point came on Oct. 16 when millions of Americans across a broad spectrum of society wore black armbands, held prayer vigils, chanted at rallies and stayed away from classes or jobs in a protest they called the Vietnam Moratorium.
 
'No Interest in R.O.T.C.'
 "After I signed the R.O.T.C. letter of intent," he continued in the letter, "I began to wonder whether the compromise I had made with myself was not more objectionable than the draft would have been, because I had no interest in the R.O.T.C. program in itself and all I seemed to have done was to protect myself from physical harm.
"Also, I began to think I had deceived you, not by lies -- there were none -- but by failing to tell you all the things I'm writing now. I doubt that I had the mental coherence to articulate them then."
Mr. Clinton went on to describe how his moral torment kept him from sleeping and how on Sept. 12, 1969, he wrote but never mailed a letter telling his draft board to re-classify him as 1-A. He added, "I didn't mail the letter because I didn't see, in the end, how my going in the Army and maybe going to Vietnam would achieve anything except a feeling that I had punished myself and gotten what I deserved."
On Oct. 31, 1969, Colonel Holmes had him re-classified after being told by Mr. Clinton that he would not attend the University of Arkansas. But by that time, Mr. Clinton had been exempted during September and October, when according to The Wall Street Journal he had been informed by the local draft board that he faced the greatest chance of being drafted.
 
Sequence Seen as Chance
 On Sept. 19, 1969, President Nixon announced a 50,000-man reduction in the draft call for the rest of the year and ruled that the October draft call of 29,000 would be spaced out over the final three months of the year. On Dec. 1, 1969, the draft lottery was held and Mr. Clinton drew the number 311, meaning he was no longer in jeopardy. Mr. Clinton said today that he "presumed" he must have known about the lottery drawing when he wrote the letter to Colonel Holmes.
Appearing on the ABC News program "Nightline," tonight, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that his draft lottery number had been drawn on Dec. 1, that he had sent in an application to law school at Yale University on Dec. 2 and that he had written the letter to Colonel Holmes on Dec. 3.
But he denied that the sequence of his actions implied that he was by then confident that he had escaped the draft. Mr. Clinton also emphasized that at his deferment had been revoked and that he had been returned to the draft pool several weeks before the December actions. He added that the two people most directly involved in the change of his deferment were his stepfather and the head of his draft board, both now dead.
Also on "Nightline," Mr. Clinton added that he was seeking to get past the "cloud" which has all but obscured the economic message he said he was trying to send to New Hampshire voters.
"For three weeks, of course I've had some problems in the polls," he said. "All I've been asked about by the press is a woman I didn't sleep with and a draft I didn't dodge."
 
Trying to Broaden Question
 Mr. Clinton also sought to broaden the question of character that has been raised by the accusations by noting that Dick Cheney, the Secretary of Defense had not served in the military and assailing President Bush for advocating a cut in the capital gains tax.
"If we're going to talk about 22 years ago, let's talk about my whole record as Governor, my demonsrations of character, my fitness to lead and compare to that kind of issue I think is very important too," he said.
The Clinton campaign also unveiled a new television commercial in New Hampshire tonight in which they seek to undermine the credibility of all the accusations against him by saying that the cabaret singer, Gennifer Flowers, was paid for her story and by blaming Republicans for the series of damaging disclosures.
At New Hampshire appearances earlier in the day in Claremont and Dover and on the ABC appearance last night, Mr. Clinton vowed to "fight like hell" to continue his campaign.
But the renewal of the questions about how Mr. Clinton handled his draft status added to the confused state of the contest in the nation's first Presidential primary.
"Jeez, another one," said Mr. Harkin, a former Navy pilot, in reference to the latest controversy. "I think voters should be concerned about his veracity and character. Listen, if someone wanted to serve in the military at that time, they could have served."
"Oh, God, please, not another one," said Senator Bob Kerrey, who lost part of a leg and won the Medal of Honor in combat in Vietnam. He has previously questioned the honesty of Mr. Clinton's dealings with the draft, but said he had no direct comment today.
But Mr. Clinton said today: "We've heard a lot in this campaign about the character issue. Well, character is an important issue, and so is patriotism. But this is not about my patriotism. I supported the Persian Gulf war because I thought it was right and in our national interest, just as I opposed the Vietnam War because I thought it was wrong and not in our national interest. And I still think I was right. The real character issue and the real patriotism issue in this election is who has a vision for the country, a plan for the future, and the ability to get it done."
Mr. Clinton also said today he letter had come to his attention again when his campaign director got a call from Ted Koppel, the host of "Nightline." "Ted Koppel told my campaign manager, David Wilhelm, the letter came from the Pentagon," said Mr. Clinton. Mr. Clinton said he obtained the text of the letter from ABC News.
The Pentagon denied a role in the disclosure. "It clearly was not the Pentagon that provided the letter in question," said Maj. Stephen Little of the Marine Corps, a Defense Department spokesman.
Mr. Koppel also said the source had contacted his program today to deny being connected with the Pentagon. The evening news program reported the letter tonight and said one of the program's sources was Col. Clinton Jones, a former Arkansas R.O.T.C. officer.
In response to the accusations from the Clinton campaign that there was a political motivation to the disclosure, Victoria Clarke, press secretary to the Bush campaign, said, "Every time they have a problem, they start whining, they start crying, they start blaming us."

HEADLINE: NASA CHIEF QUITS IN POLICY CONFLICT

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
The head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Richard H. Truly, announced his resignation yesterday after a long and often losing battle with the White House over the direction of the nation's space program. Adminstration officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Truly had been forced to step down.
Mr. Truly, a space pioneer and former astronaut, was chosen to head NASA after the Challenger disaster in January 1986 to try to get the space agency back on its feet. His resignation comes as the agency again faces an uncertain future. 
 The Administration officials said his departure was prompted by mounting friction with the White House over basic policy issues. The White House opposed building more shuttles, wanted to entertain radical ideas for space exploration and sought to scale back plans for huge science projects meant to expand the frontiers of knowledge. These and other initiatives were general resisted by Mr. Truly and the space agency.
 
He Says He Didn't Have Choice
 "Frankly it wasn't what I had planned," Mr. Truly said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press. "It's a situation where the President decided to make a change."
A high NASA official said of the resignation, "This has been in the mill for months."
President Bush said yesterday that the search for a new space agency administrator had begun and that the resignation of Mr. Truly had been accepted regretfully.
NASA said Mr. Truly would remain on the job until April 1. But the agency now finds itself somewhat adrift and with a leadership vacuum. The deputy administrator's slot has been empty since late last year when J. R. Thompson resigned for what he said were personal reasons.
The space agency is at a turning point, most space experts agree. The end of the cold war has diminished its original mission of trying to get a technological upper hand on the Soviets. And a bruising battle in Congress last year to secure financing for the agency's planned $30 billion space station is expected to flare again this year. Some lawmakers who supported the financing last year recently voiced doubts about continuing money for the project in light of the recession and continuing Federal budget deficits.
Most important, the resignation comes just as the agency is set to go before Congress to justify a request for an increase in its budget of about 4 percent for the next fiscal year. That would put the agency's annual budget up to $15 billion.
"It's a bad year to bail out and a bad time of year to bail out because it's right at the beginning of the budget cycle," said John E. Pike, head of space policy for the Federation of American Scientists, a private group in Washington.
A NASA official conceded that it's not a good time for the resignation but added that "Dick will do everything he can to help us get things squared away" before he leaves.
The tenure of Mr. Truly, 55 years old, a retired Navy admiral and the first former astronaut to head the space agency, was marked by two key successes. The agency recovered from the Challenger disaster, having now flown 20 successful missions with the nation's fleet of winged spaceships since then. And it began getting large budget increases for the space station, the centerpiece of the agency's plans.
But the agency also suffered severe setbacks in Mr. Truly's tenure, including bad publicity over repeated launching delays, shuttles that leaked fuel, the discovery of a flawed mirror on the Hubble Space Telescope and, most recently, a stuck antenna that threatens to cut back dramatically on the scientific payoff from the $1.4 billion Galileo spacecraft now on the way to Jupiter.
"Admiral Truly is a good man who did a good job under difficult circumstances," said Senator Al Gore, head of a Senate subcommittee on space. "He leaves with the respect of everyone who worked with him at NASA and in Congress."
A space pioneer, Mr. Truly flew on two early space shuttle missions, including the second flight, in 1981, and became head of the shuttle program shortly after the Challenger explosion, in which seven astronauts died. He is widely credited with getting the space program back on its feet. Under his direction, the shuttles underwent a $2 billion repair program and began flying again in 1988, so far with no in-flight emergencies.
 
Conflict Occurred Early
 Mr. Truly became Administrator in July 1989 and almost immediately fell into conflict with the White House and its National Space Council, headed by Vice President Dan Quayle. The council openly and repeatedly criticized NASA programs for taking too long and costing too much and called on the space agency to get new ideas and new technology from universities, Federal laboratories and private business.
The space agency often resisted, with Mr. Truly occasionally taking his opposition public.
Dr. John M. Logsdon, a space policy analyst at George Washington University, said yesterday that Mr. Truly was "a man of high integrity who fought hard for his vision of what was good for the space program."
But Dr. Logsdon added, "That view was not shared by the White House and was not, in my view, an appropriate approach to putting together a space program for the 1990's and beyond."
Basically, he said, Mr. Truly placed central emphasis on the winged spaceships, which he had piloted, at a time when the nation needed to move toward new alternatives.
 
Outside Vision Sought
 Mr. Truly's conflicts with the White House included whether outside agencies and experts were needed to help set the nation's space agenda. For instance, the White House became interested in ideas for inflatable space stations space ships, which would cost far less than the rigid metallic structures sought by the space agency.
In 1990, the White House began actively reaching beyond NASA in a search for new ways to advance the nation's manned space program, challenging a near monopoly the agency had held for more than three decades.
In another conflict, the space agency fought bitterly and hard for a huge a series of orbiting platforms, the Earth Observing System, that would carry instruments to study environmental changes in the atmosphere and on earth. But the White House wanted the proposed $30 billion system in smaller pieces to reduce the risk of failure, allow flexibility to change the program in midcourse and possibly send some instruments aloft earlier than first planned.
After many battles, often waged with panels of outside experts, the White House won.
Neither the space agency nor the White House gave a reason for Mr. Truly's resignation. But agency officials said the White House asked Mr. Truly to subject a letter of resignation, which he did on Monday, with Mr. Bush accepting it yesterday,
In a statement, Mr. Bush praised Mr. Truly as a strong leader in during a troublesome time.
"It was under Dick Truly's able leadership and steady hand that NASA was able to rebuild the space shuttle program and return it to safe operation in 1988," he said. "The nation owes Admiral Truly a great debt of gratitude."
Mr. Truly, born in Fayette, Miss., on Nov. 12, 1937, is the eighth administrator of the space agency.
