HEADLINE: POST OWNER SAYS HE MAY MAKE OFFER TO BUY DAILY NEWS

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Peter S. Kalikow, owner of The New York Post, said yesterday that he intended to make an offer to acquire the bankrupt Daily News, a move that is said to have the financial backing of the Bankers Trust Company.
The announcement raises the curtain on the formal effort to find a buyer for The News, a process that could become a complex bidding war in which representatives of the paper's owners, unions and creditors weigh competing offers and try to agree on a deal that will probably require sacrifices by all the parties. 
 Howard J. Rubenstein, a spokesman for Mr. Kalikow, said yesterday that Mr. Kalikow would not close The Post if he acquired The News, but short of that all other options were open, such as making The Post an afternoon paper, as it once was.
Though Mr. Kalikow is himself in bankruptcy because of the decline in value of his real-estate holdings, a person privy to Mr. Kalikow's actions who spoke on condition of anonymity said that he has already won the fundamental consent of Bankers Trust, one of his major creditors.
From the perspective of Mr. Kalikow's creditors, The Post would probably have very little value if someone else buys The News, but a combined News-Post operation could eventually have significant value, though attaining that value would require an investment now.
Buying The News would give Mr. Kalikow a Sunday edition, which The Post does not have and which is considered a key to long-term profitability for large papers. In addition, The Post is only marginally profitable and, should The News fall into other hands, The Post's survival could be in great jeopardy.
Mr. Kalikow's decision to make a highly public declaration of his interest in The News also prompted speculation that he might actually be seeking to call attention to the advantages of owning both The News and The Post, in effect declaring to other prospective buyers of The News that they should also buy The Post.
It is highly unlikely that Mr. Kalikow would buy The News in order to close it down, since most of the value of the deal would be in the circulation and advertising relationships the paper has built up over the years.
The person familiar with Mr. Kalikow's plans said that Mr. Kalikow is anticipating making a cash offer of about $50 million for The News, which would be used primarily to secure reductions in the work force and other concessions from unions. Some of that money could also be used to reduce the paper's $53 million debt. He plans to seek an additional $50 million line of credit from Bankers Trust as working capital.
But bankers said yesterday that such a significant investment by a bank in a bankruptcy would be most unusual and some expressed skepticism that Bankers Trust would actually make such a loan, given the uncertainty and competitiveness of New York's newspaper marketplace.
 
'Buyers Begat Buyers'
 Representatives of the unions, creditors and management said yesterday that Mr. Kalikow's declaration of interest was welcome, but that he must follow the same procedure as other prospective buyers in establishing his ability to buy The News. Only then would he be given confidential information on The News prepared by Salomon Brothers.
"Buyers begat buyers," said Michael M. Connery, a lawyer from Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meather & Flom who is advising the unions.
Should other offers -- even lower ones -- be made for The News, an offer by Mr. Kalikow could face challenges on antitrust grounds because he would be buying a direct competitor. The Department of Justice, which would have to review a purchase by Mr. Kalikow, is obliged to favor a purchaser who would not reduce existing competition. But in this situation, with both buyer and seller in bankruptcy and two other newspapers in the same market, the antitrust implications are unclear and the situation would have to be examined as it unfolds.
If there are no other offers except Mr. Kalikow's, precedent strongly suggests that the Justice Department would approve.
Thomas A. Parisi, a senior vice president of Bankers Trust, said that the bank was advised that Mr. Kalikow was making the announcement, but had no comment on any details of the bank's role in a possible purchase.
In his statement, Mr. Kalikow said he has also advised the banks that make up the committee of his creditors of his intention. Mr. Rubenstein, a spokesman for Mr. Kalikow, said that the creditors were waiting to review Mr. Kalikow's plan, but had offered "no discouragement" to the concept.
Mr. Kalikow's declaration that he planned to make an offer for the chronically unprofitable News -- and Bankers Trust's apparent willingness to support him -- is the first concrete signal that The News will be able to attract serious buyers, which many in the newspaper industry have thought unlikely.
Also considered serious prospective bidders for The News are Mortimer B. Zuckerman, a New York real-estate entrepreneur and owner of U.S. News & World Report and The Atlantic Monthly, and Conrad M. Black, who controls Hollinger Inc., a public company based in Vancouver, British Columbia, that owns 96 daily papers worldwide, including The Daily Telegraph in London. In the United States, Hollinger owns 80 small dailies; among the largest of them is The Meridian (Miss.) Star, with daily circulation of 22,000.
 
'Anything Reasonable'
 Mr. Zuckerman declined to comment on his intentions regarding The News, but a person familiar with the effort to find a buyer for The News who spoke on condition of anonymity said that Mr. Zuckerman was one of the first people to receive a copy of a prospectus on the paper's financial condition and prospects, which began circulating late last week.
A spokesman for Mr. Black said only that "we look at anything reasonable that is for sale." A person familiar with Hollinger who also spoke on condition he not be identified said that a company representative had approached Mr. Kalikow about possibly acquiring both The News and The Post. Hollinger has been sent The News prospectus.
Mr. Kalikow declined to be interviewed yesterday, but in an interview earlier in the week he spoke hypothetically about what he might do if he owned both The News and The Post.
He said that he would probably invest in upgrading existing presses to print in color and would seriously consider moving The News's newsroom and some production operations to The Post building on South Street from The News's 42d Street headquarters.
Such a move would eliminate the cost of The News's current lease on the space, which is estimated to cost about $1 million a month and has been singled out by News management as a cost the paper would seek to greatly reduce, regardless of who the new owner might be.
The News filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy code on Dec. 5 in the wake of the death of Robert Maxwell, its owner. Mr. Kalikow filed for bankruptcy protection last August.
Mr. Kalikow said that, should he acquire The News, he would focus his attention on the newspaper business and significantly reduce his involvement in the real-estate business.
In his statement, Mr. Kalikow said that he would not acquire The News unless "certain efficiencies, economics and enhanced profitabliity" would occur. This generally means a significantly reduced work force, despite Mr. Kalikow's pledge to "save as many jobs as possible."
Members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union, which deliver The News, are probably especially vulnerable in a merger because The Post's trucks visit most of the same newsstands each day.
The News is scheduled to seek approval today in Federal Bankruptcy Court for a $10 million line of credit from Sterling National Bank & Trust Company. This has won the unanimous support of the paper's creditors committee, though the creditors are seeking some modifications.
Howard Seife, a lawyer at Winston & Strawn who represents the creditors committee, said that the creditors hoped to alter that part of the agreement allowing Sterling to call in the loan in the event that the creditors and paper's management do not agree on a reorganization plan. Mr. Seife said the creditors regard this as seeking to tie their hands, because and abrupt withdrawal of credit could force the paper to cease publication.
The News hopes that the line of credit will allow them to negotiate more favorable terms with suppliers, who are now generally requiring payment in advance.
 
'The Same Interest'
 Securing the line of credit has been the last obstacle before the focus shifts to finding a buyer, or -- failing that -- an investor for The News.
The mechanism for negotiating with prospective buyers is unusual in that representatives of all the parties at interest -- the unions, creditors, management and owners -- have agreed to review all offers together and, to the greatest extent possible, to negotiate together rather than trying to make separate deals with individual buyers that favor one party above another.
"Ultimately, we all have the same interest," said Nancy Peretsman, managing director of Salomon Brothers, the investment banking firm selected by News management to screen all the offers and prepare the prospectus.
But such an arrangement will be difficult to maintain when negotiating passes the initial stages, because the interests of the unions and the creditors may be quite different.
For instance, should Mr. Kalikow offer $50 million cash for The News negotiations would determine how much of that money would be spent to compensate union members who lose their jobs and how much would be spent to compensate creditors, who might otherwise have to settle debts for fewer cents on the dollar.

HEADLINE: U.N. Council Favors Peace Force for Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 13

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council moved ahead today with plans for its first peacekeeping operation on the European mainland, in which a 13,000-member international force will be sent to bolster the fragile cease-fire in Yugoslavia.
Secretary General Boutros Ghali won broad backing for his plan from the five permanent Council members. Mr. Ghali, acting on a proposal by his mediator in the area, Cyrus R. Vance, a former American Secretary of State, told Council members the force should be sent for at least a full year. 
 At a meeting with the representatives of the permanent members -- Britain, France, the United States, China and Russia -- Mr. Ghali said he was still unsure that all factions in the Yugoslav war really wanted to preserve the cease-fire and cooperate with the peace plan, diplomats and United Nations officials said.
Despite the risk that the peacekeepers might become embroiled in a shooting war between the breakaway Croatian state and its Serbian foes, the Secretary General argued that the United Nations must move ahead rapidly to strengthen the truce and allow Yugoslav factions to work out the political future at a peace conference to take place in Brussels.
The representatives of the permanent members appeared to support the plan, diplomats said, although the last word rests with their Governments.
"We are all for it," the representative from Russia, Yuli M. Vorontsov, said afterward. "We should not lose the opportunity because the window of opportunity is very, very small and we have to get there while the cease-fire is still holding."
By giving the peacekeeping force an initial yearlong mandate instead of the usual six months, the Secretary General argued, the Council would signal its determination for compliance and would send a message to local leaders that they cannot expect the troops to withdraw quickly before a political settlement is in place.
Authorizing deployment of the peacekeeping force for only six months, diplomats said, would arouse fears among the Serbian minority that Croatia might demand the withdrawal of the force before a political agreement is complete, leaving the Serbs unprotected.
Croatia's leader, Franjo Tudjman, has said in recent interviews that he wants the force to stay only six months.
In the letter he sent Wednesday endorsing the United Nations plan, he spoke of "technical questions" regarding the rights of the peacekeepers in Serbian enclaves of Croatia after the Serb-dominated Yugoslav Army withdraws.
Diplomats say he still appears unhappy with the United Nations plan to preserve the existing Serb-controlled local authorities in these areas until a new settlement is reached.
Milan Babic, the leader of Krajina, one of the largest of these Serbian areas in Croatia, continues to oppose the plan, although he has been overruled by his local assembly.
Once the permanent Council members endorsed the decision, the Secretariat immediately started to seek troops.
The senior official in charge of peacekeeping operations, Under Secretary General Marrack Goulding told representatives of some 30 countries that he now favors a total force of 13,000, the second-largest ever deployed. The largest force, 20,000 troops, was dispatched in 1960 to the newly independent Congo, now Zaire.
This would be the first peacekeeping force to be sent to the European mainland, but there has been a small force on Cyprus for years.
 
Financing Uncertain
 The force in Yugoslavia would consist of 12 infantry battalions of up to 900 troops, separate communication and logistic groups and several hundred police monitors.
The initial plan was for 10,000 soldiers and 500 police monitors, at a cost estimated at between $350 million and $400 million for a year.
The permanent Council members pay just over half the cost of peacekeeping operations, with the United States picking up 30 percent of the bill.
Where this money will come from remains unclear because member nations already owe the United Nations nearly $1 billion in unpaid dues for past peacekeeping operations and the regular budget. The United States accounts for nearly half the balance.
But President Bush has asked Congress to establish a $700 million contingency peacekeeping fund to pay the American share of unanticipated costs.
Countries invited to the meeting on forming the force included Ghana, Ireland, Pakistan, Poland, Australia, Canada, New Zealand, Denmark, Belgium, Egypt, Kenya, Argentina, Brazil, Malta, Venezuela and Nepal.
No countries have made a firm commitment to send forces. But officials hope to have the first units moving into Yugoslavia about two to three weeks after the Council authorizes the force, which could occur early next week.

Croats Remain Suspicious

Special to The New York Times
ZAGREB, Croatia, Feb. 13 -- Reports that the United Nations Secretary General would recommend deployment of peacekeeping forces in Yugoslavia was the news of the night in Croatia, topping evening news broadcasts and all Friday morning newspapers.
Many Croats, including many political leaders, are suspicious of the plan, fearing that it may lead to a long-term deployment that will allow rebel Serbs to maintain political control of the third of Croatia's territory they now hold.
Today's development is certain to meet with broad approval in Serbia -- especially among Serbian leaders who face multiplying economic problems and growing popular discontent as a result of the seven-month war.

HEADLINE: HOUSE DEMOCRATS WORK ON TAX PLAN WITH $400 CREDIT

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
House Democrats began working today on an alternative to President Bush's tax legislation, centered on temporary tax credits of up to $400 for 80 percent of all taxpayers, a permanent one-percentage-point reduction in the corporate tax rate and a modest cut in taxes on capital gains.
The costs of the Democrats' five-year $90.9 billion measure would be made up mainly by increasing the top individual income tax rate from 31 to 35 percent and imposing a 10 percent surtax on taxable income over $1 million. 
 The plan, featuring a credit to workers of up to a fifth of their tax for Social Security and Medicare, was discussed today by Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee. They will vote on various provisions of the plan on Friday and Saturday before putting it before the whole House at the end of this month.
 
A Plan to Aid Parents
 One major challenge to the proposal will be an effort by Representatives Marty Russo of Illinois and Thomas J. Downey of Long Island to replace the middle-income tax credits with credits only for families with children. "I think there's a real good chance" of making the change, Mr. Russo said, but he added that he was waiting for overnight computer runs to figure out how generous the credits could be without raising the overall cost of the bill.
And there may be challenges to the measure's complex plan for reducing taxes on capital gains in a manner much more limited than what Mr. Bush has proposed. This part of the proposal, offered by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the committee, borrows from a plan he supported in 1990 and is structured in a way to encourage investment in small business and to win votes from those Democrats who favor a capital gains cut.
Mr. Rostenkowski said after today's session, "I was impressed that my membership was so receptive." In recent years, when tax bills get passed, his ideas usually end up as a big part of them.
That may be true again, although increasingly bitter partisan exchanges in an election year make the outcome unpredictable. If Democrats get some version of this measure through the House, it will supply important elements for any eventual negotiations involving Mr. Rostenkowski, senators and the White House.
The chairman said that when this proposal gets to a vote in the House and is measured against Mr. Bush's plan, the American people can see "who has the best interests of the middle class" in mind.
At the White House, Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, denounced the Democrats for their party-line vote on Wednesday to send all of Mr. Bush's tax proposals to the floor in one package, instead of deferring to the smaller package he has said he wants passed first. Both of his plans feature a cut in capital gains taxes for all taxpayers who have them; the House will have a chance to vote on both of them and on the Democratic plan, too.
Mr. Fitzwater said the White House is "going to make America quite aware of just who is holding this plan up, who cares about jobs and who doesn't, who cares about economic stimulus and who doesn't, who cares about the economy and who doesn't."
"We do and they don't; we do and they don't," he continued.
Mr. Fitzwater said the White House was stalled for now by Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee, whom he compared to "weasels going into a hole." But he said, "On the Senate side, we will try to work with the Finance Committee and others to get good legislation."
But at the Finance Committee today, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, its chairman, complained of "the kind of vacillation that we've seen from the President." He accused Mr. Bush of changing his own plan this week, saying, "And for all we know there are going to be more changes to come in the days ahead."
 
President in a Hurry

 
 Mr. Bush has all along advocated quick passage of a smaller package that he says will stimulate economic growth, saying he could wait for his other proposals, like a bigger tax exemption for parents with children.
But he has altered the capital gains proposal in recent days. Originally, he would have reduced the rate from its current maximum of 28 percent to no more than 15.4 percent. But those gains would still have been subject to the alternative minimum tax rate of 24 percent that applies to certain taxpayers with a wide range of deductions and exemptions. More recently, he has agreed that it should not be subject to that 24 percent rate.
Mr. Bush's capital gains proposal was estimated in Congress as likely to cost $15.4 billion in revenues over five years, although the Administration believes it would stimulate so much growth that it would add to Federal revenues.
Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal was presented to Democrats today as costing only $4.2 billion over five years. In one part of his proposal, to stimulate the development of new enterprises, individuals would be taxed at only 16.8 percent on gains realized from small-business stock held more than five years.
Then there are two parts apparently intended to meet political desires for some capital gains cuts for many taxpayers without doing so at great expense.
In one, individuals whose other adjusted gross income does not exceed $150,000 would be taxed at 19.6 percent for gains on items acquired after the effective date of the new tax law.
And for items acquired before the effective date of the tax law, such individuals would be taxed at the 19.6 percent rate for up to $80,000 worth of gains during a lifetime.
Unlike the latest Bush plan, these capital gains preferences would be subject to the alternative minimum tax.
The proposal would also make one other change in capital gains rules, indexing for inflation the current once-in-a-lifetime $125,000 exclusion for a gain on the sale of a residence.
The heart of the Rostenkowski proposal is a credit of one-fifth of the 7.65 percent payroll tax that a worker pays for Social Security and Medicare, up to $400 for married couples and $200 for individuals. Some of it would be "refundable," so that the poor would get something even if they paid no taxes. The credits would be temporary, applying only to 1992 and 1993.
Mr. Russo and Mr. Downey have each proposed plans that would give refundable tax credits for children. Mr. Russo's plan has a $350 credit per child; Mr. Downey's plan has an $800 credit instead of the personal exemption.
But each of those plans would cost more than twice the $45.9 billion that part of Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal would cost, so the two lawmakers were seeking approaches that would reduce the credit, or apply it only to younger children, as a way to keep the total cost under control.
The biggest other cut in the Rostenkowski plan is the reduction of one percentage point in both the corporate income tax rate, to a 33 percent maximum, and in the corporate alternative minimum tax rate, to 19 percent. The cost estimate of that was $17.8 billion over five years. Another $7.8 billion would go for a permanent extension of the research and development tax credit. Several other expiring credits would also be made permanent, including those intended to promote low-income housing, jobs for welfare recipients and employer-provided educational assistance.
 
Seeking Revenue

 
 The major offsets to these cuts would be in individual income taxes. The current maximum rate of 31 percent would be raised to 35 percent for individual taxpayers with taxable income of $85,000, joint filers at $145,000 and heads of household at $125,000. (Under an anomaly in the current tax law, families with taxable income from about $80,000 to $200,000 already pay 33 percent on the portion of their income that falls in that range.)
In addition, the alternative minimum tax would be raised a point, to 25 percent.
Those changes would bring in $53.3 billion over five years, and another $10.5 billion would come from imposition of a 10 percent surtax on the taxes of those with taxable income of $1 million or more.
Another $11.6 billion would be raised by extending for two years the current limits on the itemized deductions and the personal exemption of certain high-income taxpayers.
The Rostenkowski plan also lifts intact a few of the more attractive, though relatively cheap, features of Mr. Bush's various plans.

HEADLINE: Loud Israeli 'No!' To a Halt in Housing

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's chief of staff said today that there was no chance Israel would accept a freeze on new settlement housing in the occupied territories as a condition for receiving United States loan guarantees to help absorb new immigrants.
Nonetheless, the official, Yossi Ben-Aharon, expressed optimism that a formula could be found that would enable Israel to get the assistance it wanted. The Bush Administration has demanded that Israel halt new construction in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. 
 Undoubtedly, his Government will have to live with Washington-imposed penalties that would reduce the value of the loan guarantees, Mr. Ben-Aharon said, but he predicted that aid of some sort would be approved. Israel would use the guarantees to obtain favorable interest rates in borrowing $10 billion over the next five years to help resettle hundreds of thousands of emigres from the former Soviet Union.
 
'Matter of Principle'
 "I think it is fair and correct to say that although the United States has a clearcut policy against settlements, it realizes that this issue pertains to a matter of principle for this Government," Mr. Ben-Aharon said in an interview. "You don't challenge a friendly Government on an issue that pertains to principle."
And Mr. Shamir, he said, would never betray his conviction that Jews have the right and the duty to build settlements in all territories they regard as part of the biblical land of Israel.
Other senior officials here are far gloomier about reaching an agreement, saying that the Shamir Government cannot live with the conditions that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has put forth in two recent meetings with the Israeli Ambassador to Washington, Zalman Shoval.
Their pessimism thickened after Reuters quoted an unidentified senior Administration official on Wednesday as suggesting that Washington was opposed to new housing not just in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, but also in East Jerusalem, which Israel annexed after the 1967 Middle East war.
Even before that report, Health Minister Ehud Olmert, who is close to Mr. Shamir, accused the United States of trying to push Israel back to its pre-1967 borders. "I am not very optimistic on the chance to agree on the loan guarantees," he said in an assessment shared by representatives of some American Jewish groups.
 
Assessing Israel's Need
 Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai, who has said he would rather give up the guarantees than agree to a freeze on settlements, told a news conference this week that it was "an absolute absurdity" to think that Israel's fate hinged on the American assistance. But others sounded less confident, including Jacob Frenkel, governor of the Bank of Israel, who warned of lower economic growth and higher unemployment if Israel forgoes the aid.
Even optimists acknowledge that the loan guarantees are dead if Washington in effect orders Mr. Shamir to choose: assistance or settlements.
But they are betting -- or at least hoping -- that the American reservations are tactical and that the Bush Administration, too, wants to help the immigrants, and therefore will try to find a way for both sides to save face.
Last week, Mr. Baker told Mr. Shoval that the United States would let Israel complete housing units already in progress but would accept no new starts and, moreover, would deduct one dollar in guarantees for every dollar that Israel spent to complete dwellings now under way.
Israel is prepared to slow new housing but not to stop it. And Israel wants the penalty to apply only to homes that may be built in the future.
In any event, Mr. Shamir has pledged that money borrowed with the American guarantees will not be used directly for settlements and that Russians and other recent emigres will not be guided there, even though some 350 newcomers were taken on a tour of the West Bank today by the Prime Minister's Likud Party.
Party officials said the purpose of the tour was to demonstrate the importance of the territories to Israel's security, not to sell the West Bank as a place to live.
Mr. Ben-Aharon, Mr. Shamir's chief of staff, said he was confident that Washington and Jerusalem could agree on a "clear arrangement" on the loan guarantees.
But what that formula might be was unclear even to him, he acknowledged. Beyond that, each side provides sharply varying numbers for the housing in progress whose completion the Americans would accept.
The Israelis say there are 13,500 such units. Mr. Baker initially used a figure of 9,000, and then reportedly lowered it last week to about 6,000, representing the upper limit of the additional houses he can abide by in occupied areas.
There is an odd twist to this numbers game: Critics of Israel's settlement policies are normally the ones who cite the higher figures, to prove that construction is rampant. The Israeli Government tends to use lower numbers, to show that, for all the uproar, its building activity is really quite modest.
Further complicating the dispute are factors that did not exist when it first erupted half a year ago.
 
And an Election, Too
 For starters, Israel is on the threshold of a campaign for parliamentary elections on June 23, a point underlined today by the formation of a new political party to champion the interests of the new immigrants. It is called Da, meaning yes in Russian, but how much it will attract voters is uncertain.
What is clear, however, is that whatever action Washington takes on loan guarantees between now and Election Day will be interpreted here as either favoring or hurting the Likud Party.
There are also the peace negotiations, scheduled to resume in Washington on Feb. 24, with some Palestinians warning that the process could fall apart if Israel gets the guarantees.
As an added complication, immigration from the Soviet Union has been dropping because of hard times in Israel, to 6,237 arrivals in January, the lowest monthly total in two years.
The dwindling figures have led Israelis to two contradictory conclusions: the loan guarantees are not needed quite as much as before, and they are needed more than ever to create a more favorable economic climate that would get immigration flowing heavily again.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
House Democrats began working on an alternative to Bush's tax legislation, centered on temporary tax credits of up to $400 for 80 percent of all taxpayers, a permanent one percentage point reduction in the corporate tax rate and a modest cut in taxes on capital gains. [Page A1.]
Retail sales rose 0.6 percent in January, the Commerce Dept. said, in one of the first important reports to signal a possible economic rebound. The increase was the largest in eight months in a crucial sector of the economy. [A1.]
Sales of U.S.-built cars and light trucks rose 23.8 percent in early February, auto makers reported, in what analysts called the strongest sign of improvement since summer. [D1.]
The cellular telephone industry is growing faster than ever, with an estimated 7.5 million users last year. [D2.]
The S.E.C. proposed that companies disclose executive compensation more clearly and ordered them to give stockholders the right to vote on executive pay. [D5.]
The first commercial test of gene therapy, a potentially revolutionary technique that could cure hereditary diseases and might also help in fighting diseases like AIDS and cancer, has been cleared by a Federal review panel. [D1.]
Most restrictions on farm chemicals shown to cause cancer in lab animals were lifted by the E.P.A. [A14.]
A judge struck down a San Francisco ordinance that was the only U.S. law aimed at regulating the purchase and use of video display terminals in private businesses. [A14.]
 
Companies
 Ford Motor lost $475.7 million in the quarter, it said, on revenues of $21.98 billion, capping a year with its largest deficit ever. [D1.]
Colgate-Palmolive agreed to acquire Mennen for $670 million in stock and cash, a "strategic acquisition" to increase its presence in personal-care products. [D1.]
The New York Post's owner wants to buy The Daily News. The expected bid is said to have the backing of Bankers Trust. [A1.]
Revco agreed to pay Jack Eckerd $7.5 million to drop its takeover bid. [D4.]
 
International
Daihatsu will stop importing vehicles to the U.S. because of mounting financial losses. [D4.]
 
Markets
There was a big selloff in the credit markets, helped by data carrying the scent of economic recovery. Also contributing to the decline in prices was the weight of unsold inventories of securities amassed by dealers during the Treasury refunding. [D1.]
Stocks fell sharply as hopes of a further Fed easing began evaporating. The Dow fell 30.18, to 3,246.65. [D6.]
Crude oil prices moved sharply higher as traders speculated that OPEC ministers would soon agree to cut production. [D13.]
The dollar climbed and gold prices fell after the Government reported unexpectedly strong economic figures. [D13.]
 
Today's Columns
The bad old 80's were a lot like the good old 60's, except for one vital dimension: poverty did not ease as the economy grew. While poverty shrank by a quarter in those golden Kennedy-Johnson years, it was actually higher at the end of the Reagan boom than in 1979. Economic Scene. [D2.]
Westmark International is the latest reflection of the theory that the sum of the parts is greater than the whole. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D6.]
Pepsi is planning a marketing blitz for Diet Pepsi, eager to translate the success of its Ray Charles campaign into sales. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D19.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Vehicle Sales Post Sharp Rise

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks rose a robust 23.8 percent in early February, auto makers reported today. Although analysts had expected a gain over the sluggish period a year earlier, they said sales for the first 10 days of the month were the strongest sign of improvement in the auto industry since last summer.
"We're off the bottom, and there seems to be genuine improvement in retail demand," said Maryann N. Keller, an automotive analyst with Furman Selz in New York. 
 Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, added, "There's no doubt about it; those tentative signs of strength that we saw in January were real."
 
Trucks Up More Than 40%
 Domestic cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.4 million units, compared with 6.1 million in the 1991 period. The nation's domestic auto makers posted sales of 143,307 cars for Feb. 1-10, up 14.8 percent from the 1991 period. There were eight selling days in both periods.
Light-truck sales rose by 42.8 percent, to 84,582 units. Sales of light trucks were particularly soft a year ago, reflecting concerns about the cost of fuel as gasoline prices rose during the Persian Gulf conflict, analysts speculated. Some interpreted the sharp rise in the most recent period as a sign that companies are stepping up truck purchases.
The overall gain was the strongest opening period for any month since July.
The guarded optimism of analysts and spokesmen for the car companies was supported by several dealers, who had reported swifter showroom traffic and sales in recent weeks.
"I never thought I would ever say I would take a year full of Januaries," said Dean Blair, president of Jim Foreman Pontiac-Nissan in Springfield, Ohio. January is traditionally a slow month for auto sales.
 
Momentum Continues
 Mr. Blair saidJanuary's momentum had carried into early February. He said he sold as many Pontiacs in the first 12 days of February as he did in all of February 1991. Customers seem more confident about the economy, he said, and many say now is the best time to deal for a new car.
At Brown & Wood Inc. in Greenville, N.C., which sells Pontiac, Cadillac, Isuzu and Jeep-Eagle products, owner Bill Brown said that last month was his second-best January in 56 years. And in early February, sales were up 15 percent over the period a year earlier. "It's a combination of things that is hard to put my finger on, but consumer confidence is up a little bit," he said. At the recent National Automobile Dealers Association gathering in Dallas, many dealers told him that they also had started 1992 with strong sales.
Emmett Horgan, owner of Rockingham Toyota Dodge Nissan in Salem, N.H., said showroom traffic and sales increased in recent weeks, and consumers seemed more confident. "There's a feeling that the economy has leveled off," he said.
Sales of the General Motors Corporation's North American-built cars rose 17.8 percent, to 73,436 units. The company's light-truck sales rose 38.2 percent, to 33,320.
The Ford Motor Company posted an increase in car sales of 13.9 percent, to 37,106 units. Sales of its trucks rose 32.3 percent, to 28,982.
The Chrysler Corporation sold 14,750 cars in early February, a 6.9 percent gain, according to estimates from Ward's, an industry publication. Chrysler does not report 10-day sales figures. Its truck sales, which include mini-vans and pickups, rose 76.1 percent, to 19,550, Ward's said.
The Honda Motor Company said sales of its American-made cars rose 24.4 percent, to 7,737; the Toyota Motor Corporation 58.9 percent, to 5,495, and the Nissan Motor Company 29 percent, to 1,758.

HEADLINE: Trenton Senate's G.O.P. Files Bill to Cut Sales Tax

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Exactly a month after the defeat of a Democratic drive to roll the sales tax back to 6 from 7 percent, Senate Republicans began their own tax-cut campaign today.
"Unlike Gov. Jim Florio's 'business as usual' $15.7 billion spending plan, our legislation takes a half-billion-dollar chunk out of state spending by removing its revenue source," said the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco of Scotch Plains, as he announced the introduction of the Republican rollback legislation. "That's half a billion dollars that will go back into taxpayers' pockets," Mr. DiFrancesco said. "That's half a billion dollars that will be pumped back into the economy." 
 The Republicans and a cadre of business, academic and community officials at the news conference said a reduction of one penny in the sales tax would spur the state's economy, restore public confidence in government and give New Jerseyans a psychological boost.
 
'Poppycock,' Says Democrat
 Almost immediately, the Democrats denounced the idea. Outnumbered 58 to 22 in the Assembly and 27 to 13 in the Senate, they could only watch and criticize as the Republicans put their tax-repeal effort into high gear with the announcement of the Senate bill.
"I think it's poppycock," said Assemblyman Wayne R. Bryant of Camden, the deputy Democratic leader.
"The public is fully aware of the Republican pledge to lower the sales tax from 7 percent to 6 percent," said the Senate minority leader, John A. Lynch of New Brunswick. "What has been consistently absent from any of the G.O.P. rhetoric is how they will cut the sales tax without adversely affecting property taxes, school funding or essential state services."
The Senate tax-reduction bill is similar to the one the Republicans introduced in the Assembly on Feb. 3, and the Assembly Policy and Rules Committee held the first public hearing on that measure today.
 
Florio's Least Popular Tax
 The sales-tax increase is the least popular section of a $2.8-billion tax package approved by the Democratic-controlled 204th Legislature in June 1990, with Republicans voting across the board against it.
After the Democrats suffered a crushing defeat in the Nov. 5 election, they tried unsuccessfully to add a sunset provision to the entire tax package. The Senate succeeded in passing it, but the effort fell short by two votes in the Assembly, where Republicans fought a frequently bitter campaign to block the rollback as irresponsible.
The Republicans won control of both houses on Nov. 5 by campaigning against the record tax package and promising to cut taxes. But since they came to power Jan. 14, the sales-tax rollback has become markedly more complex and politically charged.
First, Mr. Florio's budget proposal for fiscal 1993, which assumed a 7 percent sales tax, included a $341 million increase in aid for public schools. That meant the Republicans risked having to take away part or all of the promised schools increase to reduce the sales tax to 6 percent.
On Tuesday, the acting state treasurer, Samuel Crane, announced that tax revenues for December, including sales-tax revenues, were lower than anticipated.
And a poll by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, published last weekend, found that a majority of New Jerseyans would object to a sales-tax rollback if it resulted in a reduction of state services.
"The Republicans have created a pressure cooker, and they have put themselves into that pressure cooker," said Assemblyman William J. Pascrell Jr., the Democratic conference chairman and Mayor of Paterson.
The Republicans said they had not determined where cuts could be made, but they promised that they would not cut school aid to reduce the sales tax. "What we are looking to do is to cut the waste in government, not essential services," Mr. DiFrancesco said.
 
Concern Over Other Taxes
 The Republicans also tried to quell concern that property taxes would increase so the sales tax could be reduced. "We're not going to lower the taxes to raise other taxes," said Senator Randy Corman of Sayreville, a co-sponsor of the measure.
The Democrats responded by trying to stir public doubt about the Republicans' intentions. "What we see happening here is that the penny sales tax will be saved at the expense of New Jersey schoolchildren," the Assembly minority leader, Joseph V. Doria Jr. of Bayonne, said at a news conference.
Mr. Doria released copies of a letter to the Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian of Hackettstown, in which Mr. Doria criticized a bill, A-20, that would delay annual school elections for 1992 from April 7 to April 28. The Assembly Education Committee released the bill today, opening the way for a vote by the full Assembly.
"The object of A-20 is clear -- delay the timetable for school elections long enough to allow the Republican Assembly to use education funds to replace a revenue hole created by a penny reduction of the sales tax," Mr. Doria said in an interview.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Gains Tentative Pact On Sanitation

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration has reached a tentative agreement with New York City's 6,800 sanitation workers that grants a one-year raise of 3.5 percent but leaves a central productivity issue unresolved.
The city's recycling program has reduced the load for many sanitation workers, some of whom complete their eight-hour shifts in four hours. The union agreed to return to productivity levels spelled out in its 1980 contract. But what that means in terms of extended collection routes and what further efficiencies the city can gain have been set aside for further negotiation. Those issues will go to a mediation board if no agreement is reached within a year. 
 While Sanitation Commissioner Emily Lloyd hailed the agreement to return to 1980 productivity levels as a victory for the city's recycling effort, their inability to win further work-rule changes as part of the contract illustrates how difficult it is for the city to get unions to agree to productivity gains.
Work-rule changes have been an important goal for the city in a number of its labor negotiations, as it seeks both to hold down costs during the recession and to make long-term changes to streamline its operations.
 
Series of Negotiations
 "If the goal was to get a full day's work for a full day's pay, then the city failed miserably in these negotiations," said Raymond Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a public interest group. "If the city can't reach an agreement on something as simple as extending trash collection routes so that workers put in a full day, then it raises questions as to whether they can get productivity gains from other unions," Mr. Horton said.
The agreement with the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, which replaces a long-expired contract, is modeled after an arbitration panel's decision on the city police contract in November and is another step toward completing an almost interminable first round of settlements negotiated by the Dinkins administration.
Those negotiations began in the fall of 1990 with the United Federation of Teachers and went on to include District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters Local 237, and the city and transit police unions. The transit police contract, like the sanitation contract, followed the model of the city police accord, calling for a 4.5 percent raise over 15 months. Still to come are firefighters, correction officers and the housing police.
That first round of contracts has now basically expired, and the city must begin new rounds all over again with virtually all its unions. Those talks will be conducted under the Dinkins administration's recent promise to grant no raises during the next two years, except in exchange for productivity gains.
Under the sanitation contract, a labor-management committee will review the collection routes in the city's 59 districts to determine what productivity gains can be achieved. The committee, which will include the city's deputy commissioner for sanitation and a top union official, will set each district's workload to levels established in 1980 when the city started its two-worker truck program.
The agreement provides for workers to share in productivity gains that exceed the 1980 level. Ideally, the workers would receive a pay differential based on the increased workload, which would vary greatly among the districts.
 
Retroactive Raises
 The contract covers a 15-month period from July 1990 through September 1991, meaning that the union is still technically working without a contract and must begin new negotiations soon.
The contract provides for a 3.5 percent increase for the first year, then a 1 percent increase for the remaining three months of the contract's term. The wage increases will be paid retroactively.
Steven M. Polan, the city's former Sanitation Commissioner, who resigned last month to take a job in the private sector, praised the settlement, saying, "If the full potential of the agreement is realized, and I fully believe that it will, the contract represents a significant achievement for the city and a critical boost to its recycling program."
City officials said yesterday that the talks on further productivity increases would explore using specially designed trucks that would allow workers to collect both recycled materials and regular refuse. Currently, the recycling program requires a second round of collection.
A union spokesman, Jim Grossman, said the union was pleased with the contract because it allows the city and union to work together to settle the issue of recycling and its impact on regular trash collection. Mr. Grossman said that the union's shop stewards had agreed to approve the contract and that the contract would be presented to the union's membership for ratification by mail.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor David N. Dinkins announcing settlement with sanitation workers. With him at City Hall were Sanitation Commissioner Emily Lloyd, Labor Relations Commissioner James F. Hanley, left, and Deputy Mayor Milton Mollen, partly hidden. (Nick Malter for The New York Times) (pg. B1)
 
Chart: "MUNICIPAL UNIONS: Where the Contracts Stand"
 
Since taking office, the Dinkins administration has completed one round of negotiations with several of the city's major municipal unions, most recently yesterday's agreement with the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association.

Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association
A tentative settlement was reached yesterday for a contract that expired on Sept. 30, 1991. The ratification vote should be completed in two weeks. The agreement calls for a one-year raise of 3.5 percent and a 1 percent raise for the last three months.
 
Transit Patrolmen's Benevolent Association
A settlement was reached in January 1992; the contract, which expired Sept. 30, 1991, will be signed today or Monday.
 
Patrolmen's Benevolent Association
A 15-month contract, which expired Oct. 1, 1991, was reached on Nov. 15, 1991, after an arbitration panel rendered a decision.
 
United Federation of Teachers
An agreement was reached in Oct. 1990 for a contract that expired Sept. 30, 1991.
 
Teamsters Local 237 and District 37 of the American Federations of State, County and Municipal Employees
Both unions reached an agreement with the city in January 1991 for 15 month contracts. The Teamsters contract expired Sept. 30, 1991 and the District 37 contract expired Dec. 31, 1991.
 
Still Negotiating a First-Round Agreement
 
Uniformed Firefighters Association, Housing Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and Correction Officers Benevolent Association.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Clinton's Woes Are Kerrey's Frustration

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 13

 BODY:
After spending 20 weeks campaigning, and cycling through nine television commercials with three different slogans, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska seems to have finally alighted on a definitive theme: "electability."
For the last few days, Mr. Kerrey has been exploiting this theme with all the subtlety of a supermarket tabloid. The Senator's latest television advertisement, which will go off the air on Friday to make room for yet another generation of commercials, declares, "With America in crisis, the Democrats have to nominate someone who can win the Presidency in November." 
 But even as the campaign seems to have found a message, the theme seems to be an extension of the problems that have plagued Mr. Kerrey's candidacy from the beginning.
"Electability" was a quality that Mr. Kerrey, a Medal of Honor winner with a liberal voting record and engaging manner, was expected to demonstrate implicitly during the campaign. That did not happen, though. Instead of charm, Mr. Kerrey has tended to project the dry reserve of a technocrat. In a year when voters seem most interested in jobs, he has focused almost exclusively on health care, and when they seemed to be demanding detailed economic plans, he has insisted that lengthy position papers are not important.
 
Like Something Tacked On
 Now the message of "electability," analysts say, gives the impression of something tacked onto the campaign, like a happy ending on a sad movie.
"I think to make a candidate viable on the strength of electability is pretty weak," said David Moore, a poll taker at the University of New Hampshire. "Electability is kind of in the back of the minds of many voters, but it isn't something you can bring up front."
With his record of valor in Vietnam, Mr. Kerrey inherited the electability factor after disclosures that Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas had maneuvered to avoid the draft. The Kerrey campaign clearly hopes to use the same theme against former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who has advanced in polls as Mr. Clinton has slipped.
The issues raised by Mr. Clinton's draft record seem to have been tailor-made for Mr. Kerrey's benefit: the Governor and the Senator are both seeking to become the standard-bearer for new generation of Democratic politics and as one stumbles over the generation's most wrenching experience, the Vietnam War, the other should gain.
The fact that Mr. Kerrey has, so far at least, failed to benefit from the campaign's focus on service in the military is something that the Senator's advisers seem increasingly hard-pressed to explain.
 
An Ambivalent Public
 "I think we're doing what we can do," said Harrison Hickman, the Kerrey campaign's poll taker. "But it's awfully hard to communicate when the only story of the week is, 'What evidence do we have that Bill Clinton did what somebody said he did?' "
Mr. Kerrey himself seems to have a keen understanding of the public's ambivalence about Vietnam and the difficulty of turning the war to political advantage. Last week, when the first disclosures surfaced about Mr. Clinton and the draft, Mr. Kerrey was uncharacteristically critical of the Arkansas Governor, saying his explanation of his record sounded false. Since then, though, as new questions have arisen over a letter Mr. Clinton wrote to an R.O.T.C. officer, Mr. Kerrey has reverted to a more reflective tone.
"I was in the Philadelphia Naval Hospital when Bill Clinton was going through all this," Mr. Kerrey said today. "The polls at the time showed that Americans didn't support the war. The thought of going to war in 1969 in the face of that kind of opposition was a terrifying thought and people of conscience were saying no, and people were doing lots of things to make sure that they didn't go.
"The fundamental problem," he continued, "and the thing that causes all of us a great deal of anguish, is that we know if you graduated from high school and couldn't go on to college, you were on your way. That was the anguish of the time, of 1969."
 
New Challenges
 Mr. Kerrey's reluctance to issue new reproaches is in keeping with a campaign strategy of keeping the Senator above the fray while Mr. Clinton defends himself. Indeed, advisers to the Senator say they are less worried about Mr. Clinton now than they are about Mr. Tsongas, and about Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, whose standing in some polls has inched past Mr. Kerrey.
With the focus on electability, the Kerrey campaign is apparently hoping to undermine rivals without explicitly attacking them. Polls show Mr. Kerrey is viewed favorably by most New Hampshire Democrats, and his campaign is still hoping to turn this generalized good feeling into votes without resorting to negative campaigning.
"To have your positives be as high as his are and not move in the polls," said one Kerrey adviser, explaining the strategy "sort of defies gravity."

HEADLINE: Stocks Tumble, With Dow Falling by 30.18

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks fell sharply yesterday as investors' hopes of a further easing by the Federal Reserve began evaporating and bond prices collapsed on signals that the economy may be stabilizing. After a record close the day before, the Dow Jones industrial average staged a 30.18-point retreat, to 3,246.65.
Robert C. Walberg, analyst at MMS International, an economic analysis and research firm, said the economic data released yesterday, including strong retail sales and lower jobless claims, exerted pressure on stocks. Also a factor, he said, was the Treasury's 30-year bond auction, which did not live up to expectations and extended bond losses in the afternoon. 
 "This is going to accelerate investors' shifting their attention to an improving economy and corporate earnings," Mr. Walberg said. "Given the market is already trading at a lofty level, it leads people to pulling back and waiting for proof that earnings are indeed improving."
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 230.9 million, down from 237.6 million shares traded on Wednesday, with the composite index down 1.81 points, to 228.73. The number of issues declining yesterday nearly doubled the amount of those gaining, 1,113 to 609.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stock dropped 3.44 points, to 413.69, while the American Stock Exchange index fell 3.72 points, to 415.27.
Active Nasdaq trading took the composite down 5.82 points, to 639.10, while the Russell 2,000 closed at 211.54, down 1.07 points.
A steady barrage of program selling, some set off by futures trading as interest rates rose, added 51.42 points to the Dow, according to Birinyi Associates, a Wall Street research firm that tracks program activity.
John Brooks, a technical analyst with Davis Mendel & Regenstein, said the bond market took yesterday's economic data to mean that the economy was picking up. "I think that is the way you're going to have to play it."
Elsewhere in the stock market, Duty Free International slid 6 3/4, to 44 3/4, in Big Board trading yesterday after Canada announced on Wednesday that it would remove duties on certain imports, or about 25 consumer products representing about $1 billion of annual imports.
Supercuts, a nationwide franchiser of hair care stores, fell 2 1/2, to 22, as Graig Bibb, an analyst with Paine Webber, cut his rating to "attractive" from "buy."
Following an 87 percent increase in earnings for the first quarter, Mesa Airlines rose 1 3/4, to 22, as Helane Becker, an analyst with Lehman Brothers, initiated coverage of the airline with an "outperform" rating, traders said.
Barry Mannis downgraded his rating on Wheelabrator Technologies to "hold" from "buy" because the stock was nearing his price target of $37 a share. Yesterday the stock closed at 35, down 5/8.
Digital Equipment, rose 2 1/8, to 61 1/4, as Jay Stevens, analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds, repeated his "buy" rating, again telling his firm's salespeople about a Digital chip that is twice as fast as similar microprocessors on the market.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford Loses $475.7 Million In Quarter

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 13

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company, capping a year with its largest deficit ever, posted a fourth-quarter loss of $475.7 million today on revenues of $21.98 billion.
The latest results actually improved on last year's fourth quarter, when Ford lost $518.5 million on revenues of $24.19 billion. The narrower loss from a reduced sales volume "indicates that our efforts to reduce costs without compromising our product plans are working," said Harold A. Poling, the chairman and chief executive.
 
"Not Out of the Woods"
 
 Analysts cautioned that Ford might be facing more hard times. "Ford is not out of the woods," said Ronald A. Glantz, an automotive analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in San Francisco. Investors should realize "there is no chance of a dividend increase for several years," he said.
Investors took the results in stride today, as Ford's stock gained 62.5 cents, to $35.25. With 2.5 million shares traded, it was the fifth-most-active issue on the New York Stock Exchange.
For the year, Ford lost $2.25 billion on revenues of $88.28 billion, compared with a profit in 1990 of $860.1 million, or $1.86 a share, on revenues of $97.65 billion.
In 1980, Ford lost $1.54 billion, its second-biggest loss. When the General Motors Corporation posts financial results next week, the Big Three will have racked up an estimated $7 billion in losses last year, by far the industry's worst year ever.
"Many of the problems that affected us in 1991 are continuing into 1992 -- soft economies, intense competition and excess industry capacity," Mr. Poling said. Besides cost cuts, Ford forecasts a gradual economic recovery this year, he said, giving "us reason to believe our 1992 operating results will show substantial improvement," he added.
Ford declined, however, to disclose its internal prediction of whether it would be profitable in 1992.
 
Balancing Losses
 The car maker's worldwide automotive operations lost $712 million in the fourth quarter; $506 million of the loss came from the American automotive operations. The loss was balanced by a $236 million quarterly profit from Ford's financial services group, which includes the Ford Motor Credit Credit Company, the Associates Corporation of North America and the First Nationwide Financial Corporation.
Depressed sales volume because of the weak economy hurt Ford's United States results in 1991, but the No. 2 auto maker also lost market share during the period. Its share of the American car market dropped by one percentage point, to 20.1 percent, mostly reflecting weaker demand for Ford's two-door sporty models, the Probe, Mustang, Thunderbird and Cougar.
Ford's share of the American truck market was also down, by four-tenths of a percent, to 28.9 percent, reflecting a shift toward smaller trucks, away from the larger model segments in which Ford is strong.
 
Worldwide Sales Down
 Worldwide, Ford sold 5,359,000 cars, trucks and tractors to dealers in 1991, down from 5,872,000 a year earlier. For the quarter, factory sales totaled 1,296,000, down from 1,436,000 in the fourth quarter of 1990.
Overseas, losses in Britain overwhelmed Ford's profitable operations elsewhere. Although Ford remained the top-selling car maker in Britain, sales volume industrywide dropped by 21 percent, the biggest plunge in 40 years. Ford of Britain and Jaguar Ltd. together lost $1.1 billion last year; combined overseas losses, including the rest of Europe, Latin America and the Far East, totaled $970 million.
But Mr. Poling said, "We believe the worst is behind us in Britain, and we expect a modest economic recovery this year."
 
Financial Unit's Profit
 For 1991, Ford's financial-services business posted a record profit of $927 million, a 22 percent increase from a year earlier.
The aggressive sale of preferred and common stock and other tactics designed to strengthen Ford's balance sheet have left the company flush with cash to develop new products. Ford reported cash and marketable securities worth $9.8 billion at the end of the year, compared with $6.1 billion a year ago.
Mr. Glantz, the Dean Witter analyst, predicted Ford might be able to weather 1992 without additional financing.

HEADLINE: In Recession, Illegal Aliens Find a Cold Reception on L.I.

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CENTRAL ISLIP, L.I., Feb. 12

 BODY:
Shortly after her grueling overland journey here from El Salvador, Rosa R. lay terrified in an ambulance, about to give birth. She feared not the labor or delivery, but that her first encounter with American authorities would end in her deportation.
Now, at four months old, her son, William, has a fever, but Rosa is afraid to apply for aid: the last time she did, a social worker accused her of lying and threatened her with jail. This time, she fears deportation, and will likely send William to El Salvador. 
 Rosa's dread is shared by thousands of illegal aliens on Long Island, where a deepening recession and swelling public assistance rolls are cutting into the sympathy immigrants once found here, and where an estimated 100,000 Central Americans have settled in the last 10 years.
 
Caseloads Surge
 Advocates report growing hostility toward foreigners, even from social workers, whose caseloads have increased sharply as a result of the recession. There are no statistics that specifically track hostility toward foreigners here, but accounts from recent immigrants and the people who work with them, as well as steps to enact laws that would limit their rights, suggest they have become especially vulnerable as hard times set in.
In a stark example of the mood here, the Suffolk County Legislature is considering repealing a 1986 law promising illegal aliens that they will not be reported to the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service should they seek government assistance.
The 1986 law, the Illegal Aliens Access Act, was passed during a time of economic boom that translated into a more generous approach to social welfare, and signaled Suffolk County's interest in the well-being of refugees fleeing civil fighting in El Salvador. It is far from certain that the repeal will be adopted. But immigrants and social workers say the drive for repeal reflects a rising impatience with the presence of foreigners, legal and illegal, as unemployment and economic difficulties spread.
So far, the turn against immigrants has not occurred in other areas of the state. In New York City, where one in four residents is foreign born, city agencies generally interpret Federal laws as liberally as possible, granting Federal benefits to low-income immigrants.
"The city has long had a policy of not seeking to use the immigration law to deny people benefits, and of not becoming an enforcement agent for the Federal Government's immigration laws," said David Grunblatt, chairman of the New York County Lawyer's Association's immigration committee.
Still, Mr. Grunblatt is concerned that the Suffolk County bill, if passed, could ignite similar measures in other areas New York State hard hit by the recession. "It's one of those cases where the first one to jump in the hot water cools it for everyone else," he said.
The current Suffolk County proposal follows other recent attempts on Long Island to roll back any welcome once extended to immigrants and refugees.
Several months ago, an Elmont school principal reported two undocumented children to the immigration service when their parents tried to enroll them in school, and found broad public support at a subsequent public hearing before the local school board -- despite a United States Supreme Court ruling guaranteeing the children of illegal immigrants access to public education. The parents, fearful of deportation, quickly disappeared with their children.
The Glen Cove City Council, fed up with Central American labor pools on its street corners, passed an ordinance forbidding people to seek work or donations in public. The 1990 law, upheld by a district court, is being appealed by the New York Civil Liberties Union and the Central American Refugee Center.
And before that, the "English only" bill, defeated in the Suffolk County Legislature, would have made English the official language of the county, and forbidden using public funds to print posters and other documents in Spanish.
"The county is dying right now," said Rose Caracappa, a Republican, who is making her third attempt to repeal the Illegal Immigrants Access Act. "We can't provide health services for our residents. I'm going to set my priorities on them."
"With the recession going on and the increase in health and social services rolls, we don't have the caseworkers to handle the influx of cases coming in," she said. "I feel that as a legislator, it's my responsibility to address the needs of the legal residents, before we address the needs of the illegals."
Experts on immigration, as well as the bill's supporters and detractors, appear uncertain of the practical consequences for Suffolk County should the 1986 law be repealed. Because the illegal aliens are eligible for only life and death medical attention, childbirth and prenatal care, a legislative review of the proposal found savings would be "minimal."
 
Hazy Prospects for Bill
 It would only save the county significant funds, the review said, if it discouraged immigrants from seeking benefits for their American-born children.
While the prospects for the bill are unclear, its importance, advocates for the aliens say, lies in the tough new stance against outsiders it represents, and in the chills it is sending through the county's clandestine communities.
"Just discussion of the law is enough to intimidate immigrants," said Victor A. Jordan, president of the Caribbean, African-American Olive Branch, an advocacy group for American and Caribbean blacks, and a professor of economics at Empire State College. "It's used to get rid of them in general. To make them feel they'll never succeed in Suffolk County."
Under Federal law, caseworkers must "refer" an undocumented family seeking public assistance to the immigration agency, a sufficiently vague formula that allows them to tell illegal aliens they should go to the I.N.S. rather than report their names. The 1986 law specifically prohibited county workers from handing over names to the I.N.S., and was meant largely to reassure illegal aliens that they could come forward for help.
The move to repeal the law "goes against everything we are trying to do," said one public health nurse who does outreach work among immigrants, and who spoke on condition of anonymity. "Sometimes, people are afraid to talk, and we have to tell them we're trying to make sure the baby is healthy, not get them deported."
On a broader level, some here worry that turning against illegal immigrants who seek aid could open the way for discrimination against other groups, including legal immigrants and AIDS patients.
"People are reacting to new groups by trying to bring legal terms that are not practical, that go against the constitutional foundations of this country," said Ruben Quiroz, director of public policy at the New York-based Center for Immigrants Rights. "You cannot undercut people just because they are different from you."
Cathy Spiridon, a caseworker at La Union Hispanica, which runs a health clinic here in Central Islip, said employees at the Suffolk County Department of Social Services had in recent months become more hostile toward immigrant parents who seek benefits for their American-born children. She said immigrants had been badgered and called liars by social workers, denied permission to bring their own translators to interviews and had benefits cut to their children without adequate investigation.
"People look at us as if we're from another planet," said Maria D., a Mexican mother of four whose children were dropped from all public assistance on the first of the month. She spent the week with only rice to feed her children for dinner, unable to pay for a prescription to treat a severe infection that was swelling a gash on her 4-year-old son's lip.
Ruth Brandwein, the county's Social Services Commissioner, said caseloads on some public assistance programs had increased by as much as 20 percent over last year, increasing the pressure on employees. Some of them had spouses out of work, she added, and may be turning against the foreigners out of resentment. She said her office would investigate the allegations.
The Commissioner said the bill would hamper, rather than ease, the work of Suffolk County social workers in helping needy aliens. "Most of them are hidden, and don't seek help when they need it," she said. "We're dealing with a very large problem, and this bill is not allowing us to do what little we have in the past."
Many of the immigrants, like 24-year-old Rosa R. -- who did not want her last name used for fear of detection -- work under false Social Security numbers, paying full Social Security and Federal, state and local taxes while drawing few benefits. "Many of them are contributing their fair share," said Kenneth Drange, director of La Union Hispanica.
A social worker back in El Salvador, Rosa found an assembly-line job here wrapping sandwiches at a local catering concern at $4.50 an hour. She worked until the day William was born, and picked up again five days later. Her pay stubs show Social Security and all taxes deducted from her hourly wages. She lives in a house with 13 other aliens.
The better life she had once sought elusive, Rosa will be sending William home, not knowing when or how she will see him again. And she will continue to toil, in a far less welcoming world.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Promises to Modify His Economic Program

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 13

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia promised today that "urgent" corrections would be made in his six-week-old economic liberalization plan to force faster change upon collective farms and to better protect the poor from the steep new price rises.
"Life does not stand still and, therefore, these corrections are perfectly natural and even unavoidable," Mr. Yeltsin told the Parliament in announcing that he would deliver a television address to the nation next Wednesday spelling out the changes and reassuring the worried Russian public. 
 In the face of prices that have increased 350 percent since Jan. 2, the Russian President is expected to announce an increased state subsidy for pensioners and the poor.
 
Crisis on the Farms
 How he might push the badly stalled issue of land redistribution, however, remains unclear as the nation's collective farm managers attempt to deal with widening bankruptcy and confusion about their future.
The Russian Parliament has so far refused to accept full privatization with the individual right to buy and sell land, and Mr. Yeltsin has given no clear sign thus far that he might reach beyond the Parliament by exercising emergency executive power.
"Everything necessary must be done to insure the normal sowing of crops," said Mr. Yeltsin, whose aides lately have expressed concern about the steadiness of the nation's wheat supply.
Mr. Yeltsin's many roles in trying to stabilize Russia were on display today as he claimed success in his recent visits abroad to reassure leaders in Washington and other capitals, as he prepared for another fractious meeting Friday in Minsk with the other heads of the Commonwealth of Independent States, and as he moved to protect his political flank over economic reform.
In the latter, President Yeltsin drew appreciative laughter from the Parliament when he announced that he was putting his chief domestic critic of late, Vice President Aleksandr V. Rutskoi, in charge of reorganizing agriculture, in order "to occupy his time to the limit."
Farm problems were long the traditional tar baby for Communist politicians and, if the laughter in the Parliament today is any gauge, may still be still considered such in the new era of promised change. Mr. Rutskoi has had considerable time lately to spend in lambasting Mr. Yeltsin's program on the political stump and in bemoaning the sorry state of agriculture.
In returning to the commonwealth agenda to meet with the leaders of other republics of the former Soviet Union, Mr. Yeltsin will again try to resolve the future of the Soviet military establishment. This is an issue mainly snagged lately on Ukraine's insistence on building its own army and navy from Soviet units and equipment in order to protect its independence from domination by the far larger Russian republic.
 
An Army for Russia?
 In advance of the Minsk meeting, a military adviser to President Yeltsin has begun calling for the creation of a fully independent army for Russia of up to 1.5 million men. But Russia's Foreign Ministry spokesman, Vitaly I. Churkin, said today Mr. Yeltsin remained committed to a common army for commonwealth defense.
"Of course it can be done," Mr. Churkin commented on the call for a Russian Army by Gen. Dmitri A. Volkogonov. "But again this is not going to be our choice, because the best choice for the commonwealth would be to have a unified armed force."
Addressing the more immediate problem of the Russian Government's daily battle to stir economic change, Mr. Yeltsin's chief planner, Yegor T. Gaidar, said he saw signs that the ruble might eventually be stabilized. The ruble's currency market price has fallen back to 115 to the dollar, a drop of 25 rubles in the past few weeks, he said in a television interview.
But in other economic news, the latest Government statistics showedthat retail trade was only 63 percent of what it was a year ago, and industrial output was down 15 percent.
