HEADLINE: Worries Amid Growth For Cellular Telephones

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Like the tropical clouds over this always boisterous city, the national recession has overshadowed much of the telecommunications business, stunting its growth. An exception is the cellular telephone industry.
The cellular industry is growing faster than ever, with an estimated 7.5 million users last year, up about 40 percent from the previous year, according to the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association. 
 But even the owners of cellular telephone companies, as well as the manufacturers of telephones and switching equipment, gathered here for the cellular industry's annual convention, are plainly worried about the industry's future.
 
Both Growth and Decline
While the customer base continues to grow, monthly revenue per customer continues to fall. That is partly because of the recession but also because the industry's growth has been so pell-mell that it has brought in a lot of customers who do not use their phones very much.
The industry also faces the uncertainties of introducing digital cellular service in New York, Los Angeles, Chicago and Dallas later this year. That promises to be as revolutionary, expensive and disruptive as the introduction of compact disks into the music business.
While digital service will provide better sound and longer battery life, it will also require consumers to buy costly new cellular phones that receive both the digital and the current analog signals.
McCaw Cellular, BellSouth and Southwestern Bell are expected to be among the first to introduce digital service.
That executives are worried about the future was evident from the sweaty standing-room-only crowd at a seminar at the New Orleans Convention Center called "Revenue Trends: Is Decreasing Revenue Per Customer Inevitable or Preventable?" The slides of bar graphs from market analysts and cellular companies all seemed to slope downward to the right. And the pricing plans for consumers suggested by various speakers from companies like U S West and Bell Canada elicited a busy scratching of pens and pencils in the darkened room.
 
Gains Are Expected
 Year-end figures for industry revenue and average monthly bills have not been compiled yet by the cellular association, but everyone knows what they will say. Revenue for 1991 is certain to be far above the $5 billion record set in 1990, probably approaching $6 billion.
But the average monthly bill for the six months ended in December is certain to fall below the record low set in June of $74.56 a month. The industry peak came more than three years ago, $98.02 in December 1988. Average call length is also expected to show a decline from the 2.37 minutes recorded in June. The peak in average call length occurred more than two years ago, at 2.48 minutes.
Even their big area of growth, the number of customers, has come at a price for cellular operators. They pay independent commission sales representatives a head-hunting fee of up to $400 a subscriber, as well as a percentage of customers' monthly access fees or air time, the fees charged per minute of use. To make back those big expenses, companies need customers who talk.
Another area of concern to the industry is "churn," the percentage of customers who drop service or go to a competitor. It is a stubbornly high 2 to 3 percent a month, which in a full year means a typical company will see turnover involving a disturbinglty large one-quarter to one-third of its customers. And U S West found that 65 percent of its "dropout" customers did not go to a competitor, but eliminated service altogether.
Looming larger is digital telephone service, which may come as early as this fall to the nation's largest cities, where demand is so high that it is hard to make a cellular call.
Digital service uses streams of "ones" and "zeros," the language of computers, rather than the analog electromagnetic waves used since the days of Marconi. Digital sharply increases the number of callers that can be carried on a cellular system. The Federal Government has allotted a small band of frequencies to cellular telephones, which are radio transmitters that can be carried in a pocket, a briefcase or a car. They link up to the more familiar "land line" system of regular telephones.
Digital cellular carries the promise of better sound and few, if any, calls that are unaccountably interrupted, especially during use in an automobile. "Digital eliminates the snap, crackle and drop," said Alfred F. Boschulte, president of the cellular subsidiary of Nynex that serves New York State and New England.
For consumers, especially doctors, lawyers, Hollywood producers and other heavy users, digital will bring the onslaught of a new marketing campaign by their local cellular operator. Those users will have to be persuaded to buy "dual mode" telephones that could cost more than current models, which run about $1,000 for the tiniest pocket phones and somewhat less for car phones.
Cellular operators may also have to charge more for a digital minute of air time than for an analog minute. While digital service may provide better sound under a wider variety of circumstances, a properly functioning analog system is indistinguishable from the best digital, and that poses a significant marketing hurdle.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: New Hampshire;
Democrats Move to Capitalize on Clinton's Troubles

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 13

 BODY:
The Democratic candidates for President slashed, hustled and frantically repositioned themselves today, convinced that the tempest over Gov. Bill Clinton's draft record had created vast new openings in next Tuesday's primary here.
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa asserted that Mr. Clinton was no longer a serious contender in New Hampshire, and fired a withering new attack on the man who seems to be gaining the most from the Arkansas Governor's troubles, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts. 
 Mr. Clinton tried to change the subject, from his Vietnam draft history back to his economic program for the nation. "The character issue in this campaign is who is really willing to put it on the line for you to make your future better," he told an audience of retired people in Concord.
 
Kerrey Says He's 'Electable'
 Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, meanwhile, tried to sell himself as the most "electable" candidate in the field. "A decorated war veteran," one of his television commercials declares this week. "No one can question his patriotism."
And Mr. Tsongas, for 10 long months the lonely long shot in the race, was displaying the cockiness of a front-runner for his now-huge media contingent. He defended Mr. Clinton, attacked President Bush, and joked about his lack of charisma.
It was a day when New Hampshire was humming with politics, from the floor of the Statehouse to the environs of the Portsmouth Shipyard, from the overloaded airwaves of Manchester and Boston television to the the storefront campaign offices crowded with volunteers in downtown Concord. There was a keen pitch of excitement among the strategists and staffers who were struggling to get a handle on a race where so many voters seem so undecided so late.
New Hampshire voters are chronically, perhaps congentially, volatile, but Chris Spirou, the state Democratic chairman, said today, "I don't think we've ever faced this situation before."
 
Clinton Does Some Explaining
 Mr. Clinton sprinted back on the campaign trail today, one day after he found himself explaining and defending a letter he wrote in 1969 thanking an Army officer overseeing an Reserve Officers Training Corps program for "saving" him from the draft. His campaign advisers said he was intent on reaching over the heads of the news media and speaking directly to the voters; he did so tonight with a 30-minute live television show.
Mr. Clinton hired an independent research firm to assemble a dozen undecided voters who were allowed to quiz the Governor on any subject.
"For 13 years, this story was always the same in Arkansas. Until I got into the Presidential race, no one ever said anything different," he said. "And even nw, the facts are not in dispute. I put myslef into the draft and I got a high number."
He was also on the air with television commercials defending his draft record.
This afternoon, Mr. Clinton spoke, with palpable pleasure, of the themes that were the centerpiece of his campaign until it was rocked by accusations of infidelity from a supermarket tabloid, accusations that Mr. Clinton flatly denied. His voice grew stronger and his style ever more impassioned as he stood before the New Hampshire Legislature and talked of the economic challenges facing the nation. "We have to go beyond the established political solutions," he said. Alluding to Mr. Harkin, Mr. Clinton noted that he was sometimes accused of not being a "real Democrat."
The Arkansas Governor, who adroitly positioned himself last year as the voice of a redefined Democratic Party, added, "I do know I'm against brain-dead politics, in either party, or both." Throughout the day, the voters asked Mr. Clinton about Medicare, AIDS, the deficit and the future of the Haitian refugees; but the reporters who swarmed around him at every stop asked about the draft.
Still, he seemed energized by the crowds. "Every election is a fight, it's a contest," Mr. Clinton told cheering students at Winnisquam High School in Tilton, where, coincidentally, it was 60's Day and the students wore headbands, tie-dyed shirts and fringed vests.
 
Bringing Along Charisma
 Mr. Tsongas picked up an endorsement today from Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d of Massachusetts. After Mr. Kennedy delivered a rousing speech in Concord on his behalf, Mr. Tsongas quipped, "People say I don't have any charisma, so I brought some." When asked about Mr. Clinton's problems, Mr. Tsongas said he had no problem with the issues being raised, but objected to the frenzied manner in which they were being raised. He criticized Mr. Bush's health care plan as inadequate, and he defended himself from an attack from Mr. Harkin.
Emblematic of Mr. Tsongas's new stature in the race are the attacks now coming his way. Mr. Harkin, who is running neck and neck with Mr. Kerrey in the nightly tracking polls, used the Seabrook nuclear power plant as a backdrop to stress his emphasis on alternative energy sources and assailed Mr. Tsongas for favoring nuclear power.
"Mr. Tsongas has been a Seabrook cheerleader for that plant right there," Mr. Harkin declared. "There is no such thing as a pro-nuclear environmentalist." Mr. Harkin, who is running as the "real Democrat" in the race and the voice of traditional Democratic values, is also on the air with a new television commercial attacking Mr. Kerrey, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Tsongas, asserting they are promoting "trickle-down" economics. And in an interview, Mr. Harkin asserted that "the myriad of problems that seem to confront Mr. Clinton all the time" had eliminated him as a serious contender in New Hampshire.
 
Kerrey's Added Edge
 "It looks as though this race is coming down to a two-person race: Mr. Tsongas and myself," Mr. Harkin asserted. "We're closing in. The surge is out there. I feel the undercurrents pushing us up."
Mr. Kerrey's camp, obviously, sees the race quite differently. The Nebraska Senator is trying to present himself as the logical alternative to a damaged Mr. Clinton and to Mr. Tsongas, who is seen by many Democrats as something of a favorite son in New Hampshire who may not travel well. From the start of his campaign, Mr. Kerrey's allies have tried to present him as a Democrat who would be exceedingly well positioned against Mr. Bush in the fall, arguing that his record as a Medal of Honor winner, who lost his leg in Vietnam, makes him immune to the accusation of being soft on defense.
This argument, however, took on an added edge over the past few days, as the furor over Mr. Clinton's draft status grew. The commercial now on the air for Mr. Kerrey not only touts his military record, but notes that he is "not a regional candidate," apparently a swipe at Mr. Tsongas.
"We just have to drive our points home," said Steve Jarding, Mr. Kerrey's press secretary. "In some ways, it's easy. In some ways, it's frightening, because you don't have a second chance."
Mr. Kerrey himself told reporters today: "Every day this campaign rushes up to the wire. It's clear to me, this is a wide open race."
The organizers of an effort to write-in Governor Mario M. Cuomo here announced they were holding a rally on Sunday, featuring Arthur Schlesinger Jr. In a statement today, Mr. Schlesinger declared, "Mario Cuomo is the strongest candidate the Democrats can come up with" to beat Mr. Bush.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Waiving Fees and Doing the Right Thing for Love

BYLINE: By Andrew H. Malcolm

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
IT happened right about this time of year in the dental offices of Dr. Duane Schmidt. A bent old lady named Geneva wandered in. She had tried fixing her dentures with glue so she could chew her breakfast oatmeal. As Dr. Schmidt fit a new set, Geneva kept asking about the cost. "This isn't right," Dr. Schmidt thought. He said there would be no charge.
That was Valentine's Day, 1984, on First Avenue in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. 
 On this Valentine's Day, nearly 17,000 health professionals on the First Avenues, the Queen Streets and the Post Roads across this country, Canada and the New York metropolitan region will quietly present similar Valentines to their poor or uninsured patients. Together they'll waive more than $3 million in fees for more than 300,000 patients, offering inoculations, examinations, fillings, hearing aids, chiropractic work, eye tests, nutritional advice and even marital counseling.
"It just seems like the right thing to do," said Lester Licht, a chiropractor and the Connecticut coordinator for Doctors with a Heart, the nonprofit organization that sprang from Geneva's office visit. "Valentine's is a day associated with love and lets us fulfill the goal that attracted most of us to health care, helping people."
Yeah, yeah, sure. It's a revealing comment on our tough times and instinctive, seemingly savvy cynicism that a contagious continental sense of charity on a day more typically associated with getting candy can seem so strange and attract such little notice. It's so much easier to picture these folks in white coats signing over our checks to their BMW dealer. There must be a catch, right?
Well, here's the catch: Since the Government reserves tax deductibility for real socially beneficial causes like corporate takeover interest expenses, we can only let these health professionals feel good about a decent deed. (You can feel good too, if you want. It's free and nontaxable, for now. Then you can return to the depressing stuff on the next page.)
The day after Dr. Schmidt and his entire office worked free, he began getting calls from colleagues eager to enlist. Soon the outfit outgrew his filing cabinets and took up residence in a Florida computer, where Ann Knight enrolls new professionals at (813) 525-7212.
"This stuff is catching," said Dr. Jeff Cersonsky, a Southbury pediatrician who talked Stewart Nerzig, a nearby internist, into joining. They clear their calendars for the entire day for what they call "Tweeners." These are families who fall through society's cracks with several children and part-time jobs, none offering health coverage.
Of course, many doctors routinely donate free care. Dr. Ali Khodadoust, a noted ophthalmologist here, estimates 25 percent of his practice is free. Still, he and his consultant, Dr. Rocko Fasanella, canceled all surgery and office visits today. They'll open the Corneal Center here at 8 A.M. and close whenever the line ends. Last year about 20 received treatment. None paid the standard $160 fee.
Sometimes on Feb. 14, Dr. Mitchell Quintner and his associate, Tina Gage, have seen up to 80 free patients in his Milford dental office. The patients receive everything from cleanings and extractions to root canals and dental floss. Never has losing $4,000 in income felt so good. "I have a pretty good life," Dr. Quintner said. "It's one way of giving back a little."
Richard McMahon, whose family-run Zenith/Omni Hearing centers sell hearing tests and aids, anticipates giving away 10 $700 hearing aids again today. "A lot of people are hurting," he said, "especially in Connecticut. Government sure doesn't care. We need to care for each other."
This year Joni L. Mark, a certified social worker who runs the Women's Counseling and Psychotherapy Center here, joined her husband, Harry, an ophthalomologist, in offering free services. "If someone is worried about their next meal," she said, "learning where their head is at can seem a luxury. But depression pervades our entire view of life."'
Marita Holl, a Hamden nutritionist, has five appointments for free allergy, hypertension and cholesterol consultations.
Mr. Licht traces his involvement to growing up in the 1960's. "Now," he said, "I'm in position to try and keep those ideals alive." He expects 20 patients in his West Haven clinic.
Each professional said today's patients were by far the most appreciative of the year, often delivering letters or home-grown flowers. Some offer repayment later. Mr. McMahon refuses, saying, "Pass the gift on." Dr. Fasanella has been offered cookies and dancing lessons. "I'm the thankful one," he added.
Another patient, an unemployed woodworker and the father of two children treated by Dr. Khodadoust, offered to do any carpentry without charge. "Of course, I declined," said the surgeon, who is no handyman without his scalpel and laser. "But I did keep his card."

HEADLINE: TAJIKISTAN AGREES TO CURBS ON ARMS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUSHANBE, Tajikistan, Feb. 13

 BODY:
The mineral-producing former Soviet republic of Tajikistan agreed today to adopt an American-designed program for restricting the sale of weapons components and promised never to sell any of its uranium to countries that could use it to build atomic bombs.
President Rakhman N. Nabiyev made those and other promises to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who flew into the snow-blanketed capital of Tajikistan today from Turkmenistan.
Mr. Baker is touring seven former Soviet republics, including five with which Washington has not yet established diplomatic relations. 
 He has been trying to use the carrot of American economic assistance and diplomatic recognition to entice the leaders of those republics to commit themselves to a list of about a dozen principles including free markets, democratic elections, respect for existing borders, protection of minorities and promises not to develop or sell nuclear weapons technology.
 
Tajiks Say Yes
 Judging from his terse remarks to reporters after today's talks, Mr. Nabiyev was much more receptive to Mr. Baker's arms-control proposals than he was to his democracy and human-rights suggestions.
How much any of those promises are worth is an open question. They are being made by officials like Mr. Nabiyev, the head of the Communist Party in Tajikistan in the mid-1980's, who was recently brought out of retirement by former Communists to run against an Islamic fundamentalist slate. He won 58 percent of the vote but the Islamic Renaissance Party, which has ties with neighboring Iran and Afghanistan, won 38 percent.
An American official involved in setting up Mr. Baker's visit said the Tajiks could not have been more forthcoming. They said "yes" to every American logistical and scheduling request, the official said, but found it difficult to deliver on many of them -- an attitude that might apply to their commitment to American principles as well.
None of the republics want to say no to the United States. But their new Governments are so inexperienced in international affairs that they had to be advised by the American security teams on how to organize a proper motorcade.
 
Uranium Ore Deposits
 Whether Tajikistan has a free market economy is largely irrelevant to American interests. But its weapons-export policies are a real concern, and were a focus of Mr. Baker's discussion today with the President.
None of the Central Asian states Mr. Baker is visiting on this tour have nuclear weapons. Those that had short-range nuclear weapons deployed on their soil by the former Soviet Union have already had them withdrawn into Russia. Nevertheless, Tajikistan and neighboring Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan are rich in uranium ore. Both have also been visited before Mr. Baker got here by high-ranking Iranian and Libyan delegations.
The President of Turkmenistan pointed out to Mr. Baker during his stop there that the first Soviet atomic bomb was made with enriched uranium from his republic.
After meeting today with President Nabiyev, Mr. Baker said, "One of the principles which we did discuss, which the President agreed, was the principle that we would work together to implement a mechanism for controlling the export of technology relating to weapons of mass destruction."
 
Caution on Islam
 What Mr. Baker offered specifically was to send a team of American arms-control experts to Tajikistan to advise it on how to set up a system of laws and mechanisms to control and prevent the unauthorized export of technology related to nuclear weapons.
President Nabiyev said: "As far as the uranium is concerned, I must say the press is ahead of events. Tajikistan has never sold and will never sell uranium to other important countries."
Of all the Central Asian republics, Tajikistan has the largest percentage of Muslims, about 80 percent of its population of about five million, and it shares a long border with Afghanistan.
Therefore, President Nabiyev must be very careful in his dealings on the question of Islamic fundamentalist influence. When asked during his news conference with Mr. Baker about the rising involvement of Iran in Central Asia, he declined to answer.
 
Race Against Time
 Privately, he made it clear to the American delegation that neither he personally nor the predominantly Russian or Russian-speaking elite of his country find any appeal in the Islamic fundamentalist message, but out in the hinterlands that might not be the case.
Moreover, he said, given the proximity of Iran, his country needs and wants good relations with Teheran. Balancing all of those pressures is the tricky act for all of the Central Asian leaders.
Mr. Baker explained to Mr. Nabiyev, according to American officials, that the United States perfectly understood his desire and need to maintain good relations with Iran and Afghanistan but that emulating an Islamic fundamentalist system would be a mistake.
All of the Central Asian leaders, say American officials, appear to be in something of a race against time now. Unless the newly independent heads of state begin to deliver for their populations, radical messages, whether of an Islamic or secular variety, are going to begin to have a greater resonance.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House Memo;
Trick for Bush Is to Run Against the Bush of 1980

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
In a new commercial that his campaign began showing on television today, President Bush gazes into a camera in the White House. He reminds New Hampshire Republicans that they "will once again lead the nation" in choosing a President and asks them to "stand united to defeat the liberal Democrats in the fall."
Campaigning in New Hampshire last month, Vice President Dan Quayle repeatedly told voters: "The Republican revolution began here 12 years ago in the snows of New Hampshire. They've been trying to tell you made a mistake. You did not make a mistake." 
 There is only one catch: Mr. Bush's 1980 candidacy, built on moderate Republican themes, died in the snows of New Hampshire, where he lost badly to Ronald Reagan in the primary and later withdrew from the race.
But now it is an important part of Mr. Bush's strategy for the New Hampshire primary to harken back to the Reagan legacy and present himself as a true conservative in hopes of countering Patrick J. Buchanan's insurgency from the right -- even if it ignores Mr. Bush's 1980 defeat.
 
Trappings of Presidency
 Another part of the strategy is to drive home the theme of Presidential leadership, using the trappings of his office. Today's commercial is the second shot in the White House. An earlier one this week emphasized Mr. Bush's leadership in the war against Iraq last year.
Mr. Buchanan, the conservative columnist who is Mr. Bush's only Republican opponent, admits that the President has an enormous advantage from his incumbency, which enables him to command headlines and television time and draw big crowds.
But the first part of the strategy may prove more challenging, in part because conservative Republicans count Mr. Bush as a moderate apostate and in part because he has, in effect, begun a campaign against the George Bush of 1980.
After withdrawing from the Presidential stakes then, Mr. Bush swung his policies sharply to the right to become Mr. Reagan's running mate. In 1988, Mr. Bush won the New Hampshire primary by presenting himself as a more moderate, but still conservative, alternative to candidates like Jack F. Kemp Jr., Bob Dole and Pat Robertson, the television evangelist.
Now Mr. Bush is sounding more conservative than ever, campaigning against government that is too big and expensive and for welfare reform, deregulation and family values.
Burton Yale Pines, vice president of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research organization, said that in recent days, Mr. Bush had also been telling conservative Republicans that his Administration was going to start enforcing the Supreme Court's 1988 "Beck decision," which prohibits unions from collecting dues from nonmembers for anything other than collective bargaining.
"There's a whole range of conservative things that Bush could have done two or three years ago and is only doing just now," Mr. Pines said. "I'm glad he's deciding to cut regulations, but the taxes he is cutting are the taxes that he raised. The regulations he wants to reduce are the regulations he increased. The deficit he wants to cut is the deficit he raised."
Charles R. Black Jr., senior adviser to the Bush campaign, insisted that Mr. Bush ran on a conservative platform in 1988 and delivered on as much of it as he could."Pat Buchanan, who has undertaken an insurgent conservative candidacy, has only been able to identify two issues that he harps on: the tax increase and the civil rights bill," Mr. Black said.
He argued that Mr. Bush accepted a tax increase in 1989 only to get a compromise on spending cuts with Congressional Democrats and that Mr. Bush delayed signing a job discrimination bill until he believed it would not establish quotas.
 
Avoiding Ideological War
 Clearly, the Bush campaign does not want the Republican primary in New Hampshire to be an ideological battleground. "There aren't many people who are for Pat because they don't think Bush is conservative enough," Mr. Black said. "They are dissatisfied with the economy and want to cast a protest vote."
But Mr. Bush's appeal to the right is evident. And conservatives like Mr. Pines, who probably would not like Mr. Bush no matter what he said, are not buying it. "We're all full of love in our heart for the repentant sinner," he said, "but there is reason for us to be skeptical of this."

HEADLINE: Congress Studying Ways to Ease Pain of Huge Pentagon Cutbacks

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Fearing economic dislocation from $50 billion in cuts to the Pentagon budget, Congress is considering a variety of proposals to cushion the effect on communities, employees at arms plants and displaced military personnel.
Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, has proposed allowing military personnel a year's leave to attend college or undertake vocational training to prepare for civilian life, then providing increased retirement pay to those who go into teaching, law enforcement and other jobs designated by the Government as particularly useful to society. Congressional budget analysts have not yet determined the cost of the proposal. 
 Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, has called for keeping arms-production lines open to improve existing weapons, in part to keep highly skilled workers in military industries like fighter jet and tank manufacturing. Representative Beverly B. Byron of Maryland, who heads the Armed Services military personnel subcommittee, suggests sending displaced military forces to help the former Eastern bloc and Soviet countries rebuild.
Although no one is certain what the economic effect of the military budget cuts will be, members of Congress are reacting to concerns that the savings will seriously harm some areas of the country. Some members argue that some of the money should be reinvested in hard-hit communities or otherwise used to ease the pain.
The Defense Department has announced plans to cut $50 billion from military spending from 1992 through 1997, but some lawmakers have called for cuts two to three times that size. The aerospace industries in California and Texas and big shipyards in Connecticut and Rhode Island could be especially hurt.
The Administration has not offered any sweeping proposals about softening the effect of the budget reductions since the collapse of the Soviet Union. Christopher Jehn, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Force Management and Personnel, said in response to Mr. Nunn's plan: "The concept in general is an interesting one. When we get hard legislation, we will take a serious look at it."
 
$200 Million for Training
 The Pentagon's main effort so far has been to earmark $200 million since 1991 to help retrain and find jobs for employees from arms plants who have been laid off and help communities affected by base closings.
"This funding replenishes badly taxed resources already stretched to the max by cuts in defense spending," said Senator Christopher Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, where thousands of workers face layoffs at the Electric Boat shipyard in Groton following the Pentagon's decision to cancel the Seawolf submarine.
Until Congress approved the $200 million supplemental grant, the Office of Economic Adjustment, a tiny agency in the Defense Department, relied on a $5 million annual budget for grants to communities to help them redesign their economies after a base or arms factory closed.
Paul Dempsey, deputy director of the economic adjustment office, said that 93,000 civilian jobs were lost when the Pentagon closed 100 installations in the 1960's and 1970's, but that the new businesses that took over the sites now employ 158,000 people.
 
Both Winning and Losing
 More than two million military-related jobs will be lost by 1996, Senator Nunn said, and efforts to aid those hurt by the cuts will have to compete with causes like housing, health care and aid to the former Soviet Union for the savings.
"They are not losing their jobs because they failed -- they are losing their jobs because they were successful," Senator Nunn said in a speech last week that outlined a proposal that included early-retirement incentives, job retraining and community-service credit that would be applied toward military pensions. Proposals to encourage early retirement from the services are relatively new in the era of the all-volunteer military.
The Defense Department's proposed $281 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 is $10 billion lower than the current spending plan, largely from cutting expensive weaponry, including the Seawolf submarine.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney says these weapons are no longer needed, given the Soviet Union's demise, and that consolidation of the arms industry was a painful inevitability.
 
Not So Easy to Cut
 Mr. Cheney and his senior military advisers have fought to shield the active-duty military from deeper cuts than the Pentagon's plan to reduce the number of forces to 1.6 million by 1995, from the current level of 2 million. "That's a very complicated process to manage the force structure in that way," Mr. Cheney said. "It's a living, dynamic being. You've got people coming in, people serving, people retiring, so we've tried to do it in an intelligent fashion."
Pentagon rules now provide that most service members discharged against their will, for reasons ranging from obesity to homosexuality, are entitled only to a one-time payment of 5 percent of annual salary multiplied by years of service.
In the past month, the armed services have started offering voluntary buyouts to selected officers and enlisted personnel, with six to 20 years of active service, to winnow the force this year by about 55,000 people in specialties where there are surplus skills. Military personnel are eligible for retirement benefits after 20 years' active service.
 
To Encourage Shrinking
 Under the military's new plans to encourage these voluntary retirements, the Defense Department is offering an annuity or lump-sum payment to those who accept the offer. "It's better to get out now than to be forced out later, when there might not be a bonus," Sgt. David Hall, an 11-year Army veteran who served as a radar repairman in the Persian Gulf war, told The Army Times newspaper re
Personnel officials have been shrinking the military in a variety of other ways, including offering fewer promotions, setting smaller recruiting targets and accelerating retirement for some personnel who have served more than 20 years.
Lawrence J. Korb, a senior military personnel official in the Reagan Administration, said that declines in annual new enlistments -- from 320,000 five years ago to about 206,000 now -- will most hurt members of minorities, some of whom use the military as a ladder of social mobility.
Mr. Nunn's proposal, while not addressing this specific concern, maps out a strategy to allow the services to trim personnel in overstaffed specialities and train them for "critical community service jobs" that require leadership skills.
His plan would offer early retirement to senior officers and non-commissioned officers with 15 to 20 years' active service. This would be aimed at about 225,000 men and women, or 11 percent of the present total force. Mr. Nunn said their retirement would prevent the military from becoming top-heavy with senior officers.
 
Credit for Community Service
 To encourage the former service members to go into teaching, health care, law enforcement and other vital professions, they would receive one year of service credit for each year of community service, up to 20 total community-and-service years.
In addition, the proposal would allow active-duty military personnel, mainly combat troops, a year's leave to attend college or job training to prepare for civilian life. These forces would be eligible for education benefits.
The Defense Department would coordinate all programs to train, counsel and provide assistance to military personnel and Federal civilian employees affected by military cuts.
"If we act wisely, we can turn the enormous problem of excess talent in defense occupations into the enormous asset of new talent in non-defense occupations," Mr. Nunn said in his speech, warning that failing to do so could worsen the economy.

HEADLINE: Off and Running at Convention Site

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
The opening gavel of the Democratic National Convention at Madison Square Garden is five months away, but already 17,500 hotel rooms have been booked -- enough to house the entire population of Kings Park, L.I., or Gallup, N.M.
News organizations are already squabbling about just how cramped the press headquarters will be. 
 Top Democrats are concerned that the New York Knicks and the New York Rangers might end up in postseason playoffs. That could delay the convention construction workers hired to build the podium on which the candidates will stand and, after the Rangers' ice is melted away, the false floor on which the 4,922 delegates will cheer.
 
Into High Gear Already
 While voters' attention has been focused on the candidates in New Hampshire -- with an occasional, clearly unsolicited, glance toward Albany -- convention organizers in New York City have shifted into high gear. Contracts worth millions of dollars are being handed out, for everything from buses to carry the delegates to and from their hotels, to the big signposts that will say "Tennessee" or "American Samoa" marking off the delegates' seats. Space, how much (always a fighting issue in midtown Manhattan) and who gets it, is being argued over in the Democrats' offices a block from Madison Square Garden and in city offices across from the old Tweed Courthouse near City Hall.
Today the discussions will move into Madison Square Garden itself. Eight Democratic state chairmen will tour the arena to pass judgment on what the convention's staff has in mind for the layout and logistics of a gathering that will be part spectacle, part serious: a week of national agenda-setting, or so the Democrats hope.
New York City officials have their own agenda. They are banking on the dollars the delegates will spend to provide a $190 million booster shot for the local economy and municipal morale.
The prospect of big sales tax revenues from conventioneers' meals, hotel bills and shopping trips has city officials rolling up their sleeves. The city has budgeted $20.8 million for everything from guaranteeing the rent on Madison Square Garden to paying the police officers who will stand outside to buying insurance that will cover anyone who falls off the podium.
"We're trying to make this the emotional high that can help us through hopefully the last difficult period of this recession," said Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Development.
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero and other city officials are hoping that the convention will mean favorable publicity about New York, both among the delegates and in stories by the 15,000 journalists expected to attend. In hopes of showing them New York at its best, the city is lining up teams of perky volunteers to greet red-eyed delegates at airports. The city is also planning upbeat parties for the 56 delegations (one from each state, plus the District of Columbia and five territories) that will nominate the Democratic candidate.
In contrast to the five previous Democratic conventions in New York -- the first was in 1868, the last in 1980 -- the Dinkins administration is determined to make the 1992 gathering a citywide effort, not just a Manhattan event. The city and the Democrats have set up an organization-chart full of organizations staffed by what amounts to a political Who's Who.
As it does for every convention, to conform to Federal election laws, the Democratic National Committee created a subsidiary called the Democratic National Convention Committee and put the fate of its day-to-day operations in the hands of someone named Mario.
Not that Mario, but Mario Cooper, an 38-year-old lawyer who once worked at Macy's as a speechwriter for Edward S. Finkelstein, the chairman and chief executive officer. Before that, he was an advance man at the Carter White House. He answers to Alexis Herman, the deputy chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, who is also the chief executive of the convention group.
 
Negotiating Discount Rates
 The convention committee was responsible for negotiations for discount rates for delegates at 65 hotels, and for the somewhat more delicate negotiations about the name for the two hotels around which many convention activities will be centered, the Sheraton New York and the New York Hilton.
The Democrats needed two hotels because they decided there were not enough rooms in one for sleeping and offices. As for what to call them, the Democrats had a what's-in-a-name discussion. They considered "co-headquarters hotels" before christening the two hotels the "headquarters hotel complex."
To work with the Democrats, the city set up New York '92, which is responsible for convention infrastructure. Heading New York '92 is Henry Miller, a former aide to Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta. Mr. Miller oversaw Atlanta's winning bid for the 1988 Democratic convention.
Separately, the city set up another nonpartisan organization called the New York '92 Host Committee. It is helping to coordinate the very political parties planned during the convention. Leslie Marcus, the executive director of the New York '92 Host Committee, raised money for David N. Dinkins's mayoral campaign in 1989. She said last week that the Host Committee had raised $3.5 million toward its $6.5 million goal.
As for what people not attending the convention will see of Madison Square Garden, high-ranking Democrats have already had a first glimpse of how the weeklong will look on television.
The podium exists only as a secret model in an architect's studio in Carnegie Hall. The Democrats refuse to let it be photographed, but the 18-inch-wide miniature is already being televised. The architect, Richard Dattner, borrowed a tiny video camera hooked up to a television monitor to show convention planners what the finished podium would look like.
"It gives a sense of how to interpret colors and surfaces," Mr. Cooper said, "and gives us some sense of camera shots and angles that we need to be concerned about."
When the delegates arrive, they will be trailed by 15,000 reporters, editors, producers and technicians. They will be given work spaces on vacant floors in an office building across 33d Street from the Garden.
 
Space Squeeze 'No Surprise'
 That there is a space squeeze "is no surprise," said Steve Komarow, a correspondent for The Associated Press in Washington who is chairman of the Standing Committee of Correspondents, the group that arranges credentials for reporters wanting to attend both major parties' conventions.
He and other convention-bound journalists have memories of 1980, when "space was very tight." This time around, "the requests from news organizations will dwarf the available space," he said.
Will the convention planners get out their tape measures to make sure they are not being shortchanged? Will they rent more space for press headquarters at nearby hotels? Will cynical, hard-bitten reporters file the kinds of stories the city is dreaming of?
As they say on television, only time will tell.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Up 0.6% in Month In Hopeful Sign

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
In one of the first important reports to signal a possible economic rebound, the Commerce Department said today that retail sales rose by six-tenths of 1 percent in January.
The increase was the largest in eight months in a sector that represents about one-third of the nation's economic activity and is crucial to any economic rebound. 
 The report showed that sales of building materials rose by a strong 5.4 percent in January over December, while department store sales rose 2.1 percent, following a 1.6 percent decline in December. And auto sales, which represent about one-fifth of retail sales, rose by four-tenths of 1 percent in January.
 
Good Auto Report
 The nation's auto makers added to the encouraging economic news, reporting that sales of domestically built cars and light trucks rose a robust 23.8 percent in early February. [Page D1.]
Several economists said that the increase in retail sales reported today could mean the economy was beginning to lift itself off the floor, but others said that one month's performance was not evidence enough to conclude an end to the recession, especially with employment numbers remaining weak.
"It is possible that it is a start toward recovery," said Ian Borsook, an economist with Merrill Lynch. "But I think it's too early to say whether this trend will continue."
Still, after recent reports showing unemployment flat and durable goods orders down, today's report was welcome news in Washington, where the election-year White House is eager for any signs of recovery. Also welcome was a report from the Labor Department that for the second straight week the number of Americans applying for unemployment claims had declined.
But the strong economic news discouraged the bond market, as the reports on retail and auto sales and jobless claims all suggested the American economy had bottomed out and interest rates with it. Bond prices tumbled and yields jumped, which in turn disheartened the stock market, where the Dow Jones industrial average fell 30.18 points to close at 3,246.65.
On retail sales, the consensus prediction among economists had been for a a two-tenths of 1 percent increase, so the six-tenths gain, on a seasonablly adjusted basis, was good news.
 
Holiday Sales Were Up
 In another encouraging part of the report, the December retail figures were revised so that they were up by one-tenth of 1 percent, instead of down by four-tenths of 1 percent as the Commerce Department had originally reported.
"This report shows that the holiday season was not the unmitigated disaster we thought," said Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI/McGraw Hill, an economics consulting group in Lexington, Mass. "The report also says that January may have seen the beginning of the upturn in sales, but that doesn't mean in production because we know there is still lots of excess inventory."
Car sales for December were also revised upward, to a gain of two-tenths of one percent, from a decline of 1.1 percent.
Speaking about the overall retail sales gain, John E. Silvia, an economist with Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, said, "It's nice to have a positive number suggesting that the economy is recovering."
But he added: "I don't think the actual numbers are as strong as what was reported. The increase in retail sales doesn't jibe with the employment report, income growth report or consumer confidence numbers."
The Labor Department last Friday said that business payrolls shrank by 91,000 in January and that only with the help of a big surge in part-time workers was the unemployment rate able to remain stable at 7.1 percent.
 
Jobless Claims Down Again
 But today the department reported that first-time jobless claims declined for the second consecutive week. According to the report, 437,000 workers made their first visits to jobless offices for the week ended Feb. 1, down 13,000 from the previous week.
Secretary of Labor Lynn Martin said the report might be "an early signal that the economy and the labor market are poised for improvement."
According to the Commerce Department, retail sales were up eight-tenths of 1 percent last year over 1990, the smallest year-over-year nominal sales increase since 1961. Sales were $153.5 billion in January on a seasonally adjusted basis, and $1.82 trillion for all of 1991.
Statisticians make seasonal adjustments to account for differences that traditionally occur between months. For example, retail sales in December or retail employment in December are usually far higher than in January because of the Christmas season. In assessing month-to-month changes, economists seek to even out or smooth over these seasonal variations using calculations derived for each month from patterns over recent decades.
Thus, in comparing January retail sales with those of December, economists subtract from the December figure the amount by which seasonal factors make December higher than a typical month.
 
Keeping Up With Inflation
 Compared with the previous January, the report today showed that retail sales were up 3.9 percent, which economists said was not an impressive jump.
"A year ago there was a recession, so it's basically just keeping up with inflation," said Kurt Karl, an economist with the WEFA Group, an economics consulting group in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. "The problem is not that consumers aren't spending. The problem is they don't have much income growth. Employment has not been growing, and we're not going to see a lot of strength in retail sales until we see employment growth."
Analysts said the strong jump in building materials sales probably reflected the positive effects that low interest rates were having on homebuilding and home improvement.
Nonetheless, the report noted that sales of appliances, furniture and other home furnishings fell 2.9 percent in January, following a 1.5 percent increase in December.
 
Apparel Sales Slip
 And although department stores sales rose, apparel store sales dipped six-tenths of one percent, following a five-tenths of one percent fall in December.
"History has shown that coming out of recessions, a large surge in chain-store sales often is a signal of a changing economic environment," Michael P. Niemira, an economist, wrote in the Mitsubishi Bank's recent weekly economic report. Last Thursday, the nation's big chain stores reported better-than-expected sales in January.
Restaurant and bar receipts climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent after December's jump of 3.5 percent. Food store rose seven-tenths of 1 percent after an increase of five-tenths of one percent in December.
Sales at service stations rose 1.4 percent, after falling 1.2 percent in December.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Daihatsu Planning to Halt Imports to U.S.

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Daihatsu, the most recent Japanese entry in the American car market, will stop importing vehicles to the United States because of mounting financial losses.
Daihatsu America, based in Los Alamitos, Calif., began selling its Charade subcompact in 1987, and its Rocky compact sport-utility vehicle was introduced two years later. 
 Daihatsu, which sells vehicles in more than 130 countries, has been among the nameplates hardest hit by the recession; sales last year of 8,963 vehicles were off 41 percent from 1990. Its least expensive three-cylinder Charade sells for $6,797. Its base Rocky model costs $12,297.
 
200 U.S. Dealerships
 In total, Daihatsu has sold about 50,000 cars and trucks in the United States through about 200 dealers, and its decision will have little effect on the United States auto industry. Daihatsu is among the top six auto makers in Japan.
The company said it would stop making cars for the United States market through the end of the month and would end distribution to dealers within six months.
Daihatsu officials cited several reasons for their decision, including weak sales and future government safety regulations that would require significant investment.
C. R. (Dick) Brown, Daihatsu America's chief operating officer, said that to this day, consumers confused the car company with Hyundai, a Korean car maker, because of the common "dai" in their names.
When quality problems arose in early Hyundai products, Daihatsu was tarnished with the same reputation, he said.
Daihatsu also could not afford the marketing expense of increasing the brand's name, Mr. Brown said. "If you spent as much as it takes nowadays to get the awareness, you couldn't justify the cost on a per-unit basis," he said.
New luxury brands, like Lexus and Infiniti, typically spend more than $50 million a year on marketing.
But other foreign car makers are not shying away from the United States because of Daihatsu's experience. Kia Motors, South Korea's No. 2 auto maker, plans to introduce a compact car and a sport-utility vehicle next year.
 
Service to Continue
 Daihatsu said it would continue selling its Hijet off-road multipurpose utility truck in the United States, and Mr. Brown said he expected Daihatsu dealers, which also sell other brands, to service their customers after the imports end.
The company operates dealerships in most areas of the United States, except for the Northeast and Midwest. A dealer in Tucson, Ariz., who sold as many as 40 Daihatsus a month, said today that he was disappointed by the company's decision.
"It's a wonderful car with fantastic quality that was way out of proportion with its price," said Lee J. Beaudry, who operates nine dealerships.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rates on Treasury Securities Rise Sharply

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Data carrying the scent of economic recovery helped to generate a big selloff in the credit markets yesterday, pushing interest rates sharply higher.
Also contributing to the decline in prices was the weight of unsold inventories of securities amassed by dealers during the Treasury refunding auctions this week. 
 The tumble in prices coincided with the last of the Treasury's auctions, the sale of $10 billion worth of 30-year bonds. Demand for the bonds was only fair, traders said, and arose only after long-term interest rates had moved up sharply in the hours before the auction.
The securities were sold at an average yield of 7.91 percent, 10 basis points higher than the bond had been trading late Wednesday. To sell the securities, the Treasury chose to reopen the outstanding 8 percent bonds that mature Nov. 15, 2021, rather than issue a new maturity.
Economic reports released before the auction made an already sour mood in the market even worse, as they provided evidence of strength that would likely discourage the Fed from reducing interest rates further.
Reports of gains in January retail sales and auto sales for the first 10 days of February were stronger than had been expected, and initial unemployment claims fell for the second straight week.
"Those three reports were too much bad news for the market to absorb at one time," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America.
Traders said some buyers surfaced during the afternoon, when bond prices were at their lows of the day. But selling began anew after the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply registered strong gains in the week ended Feb. 3.
The recent strong growth in the monetary aggregates is seen by many analysts as another indication the economy may be stirring.
Indeed, the shift in market sentiment since the refunding auctions began on Tuesday has been startling. But traders and analysts said that little had changed, and that at current interest rate levels Treasury securities represented good value.
Thoughts that the Fed might need to lower short-term rates, a notion that was widely prevalent after the Government released a weak set of January employment statistics last Friday, has all but evaporated.
"The market has not only thrown out that idea, but they have priced in a tightening move" by the Fed, one government securities trader said.
 
'Fears Are Overblown'
 Victor Chang, president of VC Management Company, a money management firm, said: "The market is overstressed about the possibility that the Fed will tighten policy. I think those fears are overblown, and that the Fed, which does not want to jeopardize a recovery, will maintain a stable monetary policy through the first two or three quarters of an upturn in the economy."
That sort of thinking, however, was not manifested in yesterday's trading.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 101, down more than 1 1/8 points, to yield 7.91 percent, compared with 7.80 percent late Wednesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 3/8, down 25/32 , to yield 7.38 percent. The 6 1/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 98 1/2, down 25/32 , to yield 6.60 percent. And the new 5.50 percent three-year notes auctioned on Tuesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 5.73 percent, up from 5.54 percent late Wednesday.
 
Bill Rates Also Higher
 Short-term Treasury bill rates also moved higher.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.76 percent, up 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by 8 basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.89 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by 13 basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.08 percent.
The big rise in interest rates served as a powerful disincentive to most companies to issue new securities.
Nevertheless, underwriters led by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette did price two issues in the high-yield junk bond market.
The larger offering of the two was the sale of $200 million worth of senior notes for the Century Communications Corporation.
The noncallable 9 3/4 percent securities, which mature Feb. 15, 2002, were offered at various prices.
The securities are rated B-2 by Moody's Investors Service and B by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Municipal Bond Market
 The State of Wisconsin sold $219 million worth of tax-exempt securities at competitive bid in the municipal bond market.
A bid from a group led by the First Boston Corporation won the issue, which consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1993 to 2012.
The securities maturing in 1993 were not reoffered to the public. Yields on the securities that were repriced range from 4.20 percent on bonds maturing in 1994 to 6.60 percent in 2012.
The issue is rated AA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
The selloff in the Treasury securities market had an adverse impact on prices in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal securities.
Corporate traders said prices of most issues fell by anywhere from 1/2 point to 7/8 point, depending on maturity.
Meanwhile, prices of most widely quoted tax-exempt bonds fell by about 1/2 point, municipal bond traders said.

HEADLINE: Hardheaded Skills Equal Financial Headway

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
The good news is at least one New York City agency is operating more efficiently than it used to, despite steep budget cuts. The bad news is it is the agency that collects your taxes.
Over the last two years, since Carol O'Cleireacain took over as commissioner at the Department of Finance, changes have been coming fast and furious. And since the department is the one that administers the 23 taxes that pay for city services, manages the city's daily cash balances of $250 million and handles six million pieces of correspondence a year, any improvement in service could be considered a boon to many residents. 
 Taxpayers are now informed when they overpay and automatically credited with their refunds, instead of having to figure out their transgressions themselves and pester the city for refunds.
Property owners now get semiannual statements detailing for the first time how much they have paid in various charges, how much they are delinquent by, if at all, and the amount of interest they owe. If they have questions, they can call a new taxpayer assistance unit -- though the phone lines are often busy.
 
Demystifying the Process
 And on Jan. 15, Ms. O'Cleireacain (pronounced oh-CLARE-eh-can) unveiled what the city thinks the market values of individual buildings and condominiums are, and how they have changed over the last year.
"I am immensely impressed with what Carol O'Cleireacain has tried to do to demystify the process," said Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives, which represents 1,600 cooperative organizations and condominium associations. "The whole tax procedure was gobbledygook to many people."
Ms. O'Cleireacain has just embarked on her toughest challenge yet: orchestrating a campaign to change the structure of the city's property taxes so that owners of one- , two- and three-family homes are no longer subsidized to the same degree by owners of condos, co-ops and commercial properties, a proposal that is sure to set off a political firestorm among property-owning groups.
Strikingly, the new vigor of the finance department is coming when its budget is shrinking and when the number of employees reporting to Ms. O'Cleireacain has been reduced by about 500. By the end of this fiscal year on June 30, her work force will have been cut 19 percent and her budget 21 percent since she took office in February 1990.
That Ms. O'Cleireacain has been able and willing to negotiate those management hurdles has come as a surprise to some. As the former chief economist for the city's largest union, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, and as the chief economic adviser to the Rev. Jesse Jackson in his 1988 Presidential campaign, Ms. O'Cleireacain was expected by many in the business world to be soft on labor and hostile to business and real estate.
 
Some Union Disagreements
 But she has surprised friend and foe alike. She did not hesitate to replace about half of the top people in her department with her own selections and has cut her staff in percentage terms more than many commissioners. About 40 percent of those cuts came in the form of layoffs -- anathema in the labor movement.
"There have been some disagreements there," said Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37, some of whose members work at the finance department. "I've told her she's a member of management now."
At the same time, many of the steps she has taken to make the property-tax system more accessible have warmed the hearts of real-estate moguls in the city who had previously been fearful of her liberal background.
"I'm pleased with her running of the department," said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, who has been a frequent critic of the city's tax policies.
That is not to say that the tax roll is error free, or that the unevenness with which similar properties are often assessed has disappeared. Still, many of the changes now being put into effect are intended to provide taxpayers with more information, and to make it easier for errors to be identified and corrected.
Ms. O'Cleireacain is making headway with a mix of luck and hard-headed management skills.
She received help in coping with staff reductions when the City Council changed building inspections to once every two years instead of annually. She has benefited from large investments that her predecessors made in new computer systems. (She is the fifth commissioner of the department in five years.) So far, the new computers have enabled the department to improve its paper processing and to automate property assessments, allowing her to cut staff without reducing service.
"The most important thing I can do here is to move the Finance Department into the information age," Ms. O'Cleireacain said.
 
More Criminal Inquiries
 But the changes have to do with more than just new technology. Ms. O'Cleireacain has also shifted staff members from nonproductive areas to where they could generate more revenue.
The department no longer has enforcement officers regularly cruising the streets for commercial vehicles that lack inspection stickers or inspecting basement vaults. Many of those officers are now devoting their time to criminal investigations.
She has also shifted more of her auditors into the corporate tax area, and recast her legal department so that it concentrates on bigger cases, at the same time clearing up the backlog that went back 11 years, in some instances.
As a result, the department expects to generate $501 million in enforcement revenues this fiscal year -- about $62 million more than in the 1990 fiscal year, but with 166 fewer people.
One of the big questions facing Ms. O'Cleireacain in the future is whether she can keep it up. Her success in increasing revenues has been so helpful to the city that the latest financial plan assumes she can generate $500 million a year in enforcement revenues for the next four years.
Few who know Ms. O'Cleireacain would bet against her. An intense, ambitious commissioner, she consistently pushes herself and her employees to succeed. She decided to major in economics as an undergraduate at the University of Michigan, she said, because it was the hardest subject she could find. She went on to earn a Ph.D. in economics from the London School of Economics in 1977.
She will need that drive to change the city's tax laws. At a meeting of the city's business leaders, she indicated that she favored merging Class 1 housing, which comprises one-, two- and three-family houses, with Class 2 units, which are made up of co-op and condominium apartment buildings, a move that would level the playing field between the different property-owning groups, and almost certainly result in higher tax bills for small homeowners.
She said she would only support such a change, however, if it were phased in and some protection given to those with low incomes who could not absorb large tax increases.
Any change in the city's property taxes would have to go before the state Legislature and the City Council, both of which will undoubtedly be tough battles. If Ms. O'Cleireacain succeeds in getting her way on this thorny issue, she will truly have earned her reputation as a skillful manager.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Pepsi-Cola Plans Big Effort To Exploit 'Uh-huh' Theme

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
AS soon as Pepsi-Cola introduced Ray Charles as the spokes-singer for its Diet Pepsi brand, growling, "You got the right one baby, uh-huh!" it seemed the decision had indeed been the right one.
Consumers immediately took to the infectiously cheerful advertising created by BBDO Worldwide, ranking the campaign among the most likable and memorable of 1991. The phrase entered the vernacular, appearing on a line of licensed clothing and on cans and bottles of the soft drink. 
 There was just one uh-uh amid the uh-huhs: Diet Pepsi's market share ended the year as flat as day-old cola, according to Beverage Digest, an authoritative industry newsletter. It ranked fourth among America's leading soft drinks in 1991, with an 8 percent share, unchanged from 1990.
So, eager to translate Diet Pepsi's advertising success into sales, Pepsi executives are planning one of the industry's most extensive, and expensive, marketing blitzes ever on behalf of the 28-year-old brand. Beginning during CBS's telecast of the Grammy Awards on Feb. 25, Diet Pepsi will embark on an elaborate series of events intended to convince America that this April is "National Uh-huh Month."
"We've had tremendous image wins with the 'Uh-huh' campaign," David C. Novak, Pepsi's executive vice president of marketing and national sales, said in a telephone interview from his office in Somers, N.Y. "Our challenge for 1992 is to turn those wins into volume gains."
"We had good sales last year, especially given the economy," he added. "But we haven't leveraged Diet Pepsi's advertising and marketing. So, we're taking 'Uh-huh' to a whole new level."
While Mr. Novak would not discuss the cost of the campaign, soft-drink executives estimated it to be at least $25 million and perhaps as much as $50 million.
The problem facing Pepsi is a familiar one to advertising and marketing executives: How can a popular ad campaign be exploited to its fullest? Also confronting that question are companies like Ralston Purina, trying to capitalize on E. B., the pink bunny that parodies other ads in Energizer battery commercials, and Nestle, hoping to build on the interest in its serial commercials starring a couple searching for romance over a jar of Taster's Choice instant coffee.
The debate still rages over the effectiveness of such fondly remembered advertising as the animated Piel brothers, Bert and Harry, for Piels beer, and the skein of hilarious Alka-Seltzer spots like "I can't believe I ate the whole thing" and "Try it; you'll like it."
"If you can be very creative, and be very persuasive as well, then you've got the ideal," said Al Hampel, an advertising and marketing consultant in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., who popularized the phrase "It's not creative unless it sells" at Benton & Bowles during the 1970's.
"But too few people in the world can do that," he added.
The "Uh-huh" campaign did help Diet Pepsi last year, said Jesse Meyers, editor and publisher of Beverage Digest in Greenwich, Conn., in compensating for sales volume lost when fast-food chains like Burger King and Wendy's International switched to Coca-Cola Company brands from Pepsi-Cola Company brands.
"The advertising is fantastic," he added. "But in the soft-drink industry, distribution is the name of the game."
To that end, Pepsi will devote a significant portion of Uh-huh Month to what Mr. Novak called "partnerships with our retail customers, to make our advertising drive their sales." There will be in-store promotions and special events at supermarket chains like Kroger, convenience-store chains like 7-Eleven and fast-food chains like Subway.
Pepsi is even arranging for United Parcel Service to deliver one million 24-can cases of Diet Pepsi to consumers the company has identified as Diet Coke drinkers.
A spokesman for Coca-Cola in Atlanta described executives there as unperturbed about the potential effects of Uh-huh Month on Diet Coke. That brand's market share last year -- 11.7 percent, according to Beverage Digest -- ranked it third, behind only Coca-Cola Classic (20 percent) and Pepsi-Cola (18.4 percent).
And if, after celebrating Uh-huh Month, consumers have room on their calendars, they might find Coca-Cola asking them to commemorate the 10th anniversary of Diet Coke, which was introduced in July 1982.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Strong Economic Reports Lift Dollar While Gold Falls

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar climbed yesterday on world foreign exchange markets after the Government reported unexpectedly strong economic figures.
Gold prices fell, dropping $2.20 an ounce, to $355.90 on New York's Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted an after-hours bid of $355.35, down $2.15 from Wednesday's late bid. 
 A rise in United States retail sales and a decline in new claims for unemployment suggested that the Federal Reserve would not have to drive interest rates lower. The reports also contributed to a decline in bond prices, forcing yields on those securities higher and making them more attractive to foreign investors. That helps the dollar by increasing demand for the currency.
John McCarthy, chief currency dealer at ABN-AMRO Bank N.V. in New York, said traders bid the dollar higher in hectic dealings shortly after the release of the retail sales report, which showed that sales jumped six-tenths of 1 percent in January.
 
Some Still Cautious
 But he said the dollar failed to rise above its recent highs against key currencies, which suggested that traders were still wary about the recovery.
In New York, the dollar rose to 127.65 Japanese yen, from 127.40 yen on Wednesday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 127.33 yen, from 127.01 yen. In London, the late quote for the dollar was 127.70 yen.
The dollar also edged higher against the British pound. In New York, the pound was quoted at $1.7725, down from $1.7895 late Wednesday. In London, the pound fell to $1.7730, from $1.7880 Wednesday.
Other dollar rates as of 4 P.M. in New York, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.6240 German marks, up from 1.6065; 1.4600 Swiss francs, up from 1.4385; 5.5310 French francs, up from 5.4720; 1,220.50 Italian lire, up from 1,208, and 1.18625 Canadian dollars, up from 1.18085.
In the precious metals market abroad, gold fell to $356.30 an ounce, from $357.50 late Wednesday in London, and to $356.50 an ounce in Zurich, from $357 late Wednesday.
In Hong Kong, gold rose $1.29 an ounce to close at $357.96 bid.
Silver for current delivery fell 1 cent an ounce, to $4.203, on New York's Comex. Silver fell in London to a late bid of $4.21 an ounce, from $4.22 late Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Puzzling Poverty Of the 80's Boom

BYLINE: By Sylvia Nasar

 BODY:
DESPITE what you may be hearing from some of the candidates in New Hampshire, the bad old 80's were actually a lot like the good old 60's. The expansion lasted for almost as long as the 60's boom, eight years. The economy grew by nearly as much. And unemployment fell by an even bigger increment.
But in at least one vital dimension, the 80's were totally unlike the 60's. The official poverty rate, which counts the number of people whose income falls short of some minimum level, did not come down as the economy rose. While poverty shrank by a quarter in those golden Kennedy-Johnson years, it was actually higher at the end of the Reagan boom than in 1979. 
 That is pretty surprising no matter what side of the political divide one is on. Every prior economic expansion since World War II has lifted all boats, even the recovery in the sickly 70's. In fact, the skiffs of the working poor have generally been lifted faster than other Americans during economic rebounds, while joblessness ebbs after hitting low-income workers hardest in recessions.
So how come trickle-down economics did not work last time around, especially given that the unemployment rate fell by half, or more than five full percentage points, from 1983 to 1989? Some bright young labor economists -- two at Harvard, one at Princeton -- have taken a look at a variety of explanations and offered some intriguing ones of their own.
The most obvious suspect is the official poverty rate itself. Conservatives have been grousing for years that it overstates poverty because the data undercount income. Government handouts in the form of free or subsidized housing, medical care, and food, the "in kind" benefits that are excluded from most income measures, surged in the 70's, for example.
But, as David Cutler and Lawrence Katz point out in "Macroeconomic Performance and the Disadvantaged," which will appear in the spring volume of the Brookings Papers on Economic Activity, the fact that such benefits are excluded is irrelevant to the 80's because such benefits did not grow much in that decade.
Or perhaps poor people were living high and hiding more of their off-the-books income? Some analysts have argued that consumption, a much better yardstick of well-being than income in any case, at the low end of the distribution outstripped reported pay and other sources of cash in the 80's.
It is true, as Mr. Katz and Mr. Cutler discover, that there has been a lot less poverty in the United States, 10 percent based on consumption as compared with 13 percent based on reported income in 1988, if you use consumption as the basis for calculating a poverty rate. But, even on this measure, poverty did not decline in the 80's.
Perhaps greedy bosses ate workers' lunches? No cigar there either, say Mr. Cutler and Mr. Katz, both in the Harvard economics department. To their own evident surprise they find that labor's share of the economic pie, about two-thirds, did not shrink an iota in the union-busting 80's.
Instead, a slowdown in pay at the bottom end of the pay scale and a widening disparity between low-wage and high-wage workers is to blame. In other words, even though workers' slice of the economic pie did not shrink, highly educated, more experienced and more skilled workers took a bigger bite while the young, the uneducated and the unskilled got fewer crumbs.
Not only did jobs in manufacturing, where unskilled workers used to be able to earn premium pay, shrink as a share of total jobs, but within virtually every industry, demand for unskilled workers either slipped or grew more slowly than for workers with more to offer -- exactly the opposite of what happened in the 60's.
"Changes in relative labor demand against the less-skilled offset the effects of improved overall employment opportunities during the expansion of 1983 to 1989," write Mr. Cutler and Mr. Katz.
The problem may reflect the much-talked-about computerization of the American workplace, argues Alan B. Krueger, who is at Princeton University, in research that will also be published shortly by the Brookings Institution.
Mr. Krueger traces about one-third of the growing gap between the pay of high- and low-skilled workers to the mass invasion of the computer in the nation's shops, offices and factories during the 80's. Workers who use computers but are similar in every other respect to workers who do not earn a fat bonus of 10 to 15 percent for their knack with these machines.
What's important is that those who tended to use computers, he finds, are white, female and well educated. But those who do not are disproportionately black, male and high-school dropouts. Women and blacks, of course, have higher poverty rates than average and earn less per hour.
That sends a clear message to politicians who want to promote greater equality of earning power along sexual and racial lines. Instead of focusing only on getting teachers to call on girls in class, or just persuading black children to stay in school, maybe it makes sense to guarantee that these kids have equal access, and plenty of it, to computers in school.
