HEADLINE: A Euro-Fling on East 77th St.

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
THE bar in the Mark hotel is small, dimly lighted and as cozily intimate as a private club. So intimate that the Frenchman in aviator glasses, black jeans, and a jacket with Mickey Mouse stitched under a "Euro Disney" logo felt free to slide his chair to a corner table occupied by two women. "May I eat off your plate?" he murmured in a thick Parisian accent, smoke curling up from his Gauloise. He helped himself to a thick slice of goat cheese quesadilla and munched ingratiatingly.
Even the nicest Upper East Side hotels are not safe from creeping Eurotrash. My friend and I had checked into the Mark for a quiet, self-indulgent girls' weekend of room-service folly, a kind of Thelma-and-Eloise adventure. Fortunately for the Frenchman, we had not packed firearms. 
 And fortunately for us, most of the clients who stay at the Mark are not as extroverted. The Mark, which occupies a red brick and limestone building on 77th Street at Madison Avenue, is what is known in the tourism industry as a "boutique hotel," small, quiet, expensive and European, the last word usually meaning that the concierge has almost as much stature as the chef.
The Mark prides itself on a stylish staff (many of whom sport Italian suits, French or German accents and an unmistakable Continental hauteur) and speedy, impeccable service (room service Continental breakfast: 6 minutes 32 seconds). Lately, its serenity has been disrupted by daily picketing by members of Local 6 of the hotel and restaurant employees union. The hotel staff is union, but the waiters and busboys in the restaurant and Mark's Bar are not.
Since it was bought by the Rafael Group and renovated two and a half years ago, the Mark has developed a large following in the entertainment industry: among others, Harrison Ford and Mitsuko Uchida, the concert pianist, have stayed there. There are also representatives from the art and fashion world; well-heeled customers from the West Coast who enjoy being treated in at least one New York establishment as old, esteemed friends.
"We wouldn't stay anyplace else, and neither would our friends," said Jack Silberkleitt, a clothing manufacturer from Beverly Hills, who travels to New York on business eight times a year. He recently switched allegiances from the Regency to the Mark. "They take care of you," explained his wife, Cheryle, who, enveloped in a full-length black mink, seemed to know what she was talking about. (On cold days at the Mark, everyone wears fur, preferably mink. Even the doorman wears a jaunty astrakhan beret.)
She spoke lovingly of Giorgio, one of the Mark's more prominent concierges. "He can do anything," she crooned. "When Coco Pazzo is booked solid Giorgio can always get us in." She also said she loved the special touches awarded repeat customers: "They sent Jack a birthday cake last time we were here, and when we bring the kids, they put brownies and milk in their room." Mr. Silberkleitt spoke most fondly of the discount. "I get a good corporate rate," he said with simple pride.
The design of the lobby, which one assistant manager, Vasile, described rather excitedly as "contemporary Italian Neo-Renaissance style," is elegant and very much in keeping with the reigning Architectural Digest sensibility: black and cream marbled floors, Biedermeier chairs, 18th-century Piranese prints and yellow hallways punctuated with marble pillars and framed etchings of Greek and Roman urns. Even without the Neo-Classical chaises-longues, the Mark has a distinct "Mme. Recamier slept here" feel to it.
The service is speedy and the employees are pleasant, but at hundreds of dollars a night, first-time guests may hunger for a little more abject servility from the desk. When we checked in on a recent Saturday at noon, we were cheerfully informed that the room was still occupied and that we would have to wait for at least an hour. We waited for plaintive apologies and a restorative cocktail on the house, and were offered neither. We followed the minks, and went shopping.
The Mark does not have its own gymnasium or health club. Guests are referred to the East Side Fitness Center a few blocks away. For each use of the center, the hotel charges $25 a person, so it might be best to wait until the urge to exercise passes, preferably over tea in the restaurant.
 
A Two-Star Restaurant
 The French cuisine served in the Mark restaurant received enthusiastic praise and two stars from The New York Times in 1990. On average, dinner for two costs about $150. Tea is more affordable, and the ambiance is just as pleasant. Many hotels are famous for their elaborate English high tea. The Mark, which serves it in the small lower area of its two-tiered, oak-paneled dining room, fulfills even the most exacting Blenheim castle fantasies. Brewed tea is served in heavy silver pots and dainty porcelain cups, while the tea sandwiches are delicate, tiny and served without crusts. (Tea for two, albeit with a glass of wine, came to $46.86.) The richly carpeted room, like the bar, has an old, burnished, patrician feeling. On a buffet table at the entrance, there are huge glass bottles filled with pears soaking in amber-colored liqueurs: a chichi variant on pickle jars in an old-fashioned deli, but very pretty.
A warning: At a recent tea, the black mink coats were so numerous that one elegant patron, who was wearing a casual brown sheared mink jacket, seemed to feel underdressed. "Mine is the leopard, and my friend has the sable," she said sarcastically to the coat-checker.
Rooms range in price from $265 for a "superior" room to $295 for the "Mark Deluxe." (First-class hotels are given to the same grade inflation found at Ivy League colleges: just as some professors give no grade below a B, no self-respecting luxury hotel labels even its smallest rooms anything less then "superior.")
Whether "deluxe" or "superior," the rooms are large, airy and comfortable, but, given the opulence downstairs, their appointments are surprisingly bland. Even a $500-a-night "executive suite," which on weekends can be had for $350 (Continental breakfast included), came with few individual touches: the pale pink walls were decorated with only a few generic prints (19th-century soldiers; other rooms carry hunting scenes or botanical drawings). The carpeting was beige and wall to wall, and the furniture was standard issue: gray Lucite writing desk and nightstands. (No charming escritoire, dainty armoires or Biedermeier BarcaLoungers.) The couches, while comfortable, were upholstered with a Ramada Inn-style fabric in a pink, yellow and gray zigzag pattern that mainly looks like a pastel electrocardiogram chart.
Nearly half the rooms come with small kitchens, which in turn come with dishwashers but no dishes. (On the other hand, plates and forks from room service: 4 minutes 47 seconds.)
 
A Restrained Mini-Bar
 The best mini-bars are the kind that could keep a wealthy agoraphobe alive for days: well stocked with wine, liquor and soft drinks as well as cheeses, cookies and pate. The Mark mini-bar is more restrained, offering a full range of beverages, but only jellybeans and chocolate-covered popcorn to eat. The price list was hidden from view in a closed cabinet, perhaps on the universal mini-bar theory that if you have to ask the price, you can't afford it. (A Coke: $3.50.)
What the rooms may lack in idiosyncratic charm, they make up for in modern conveniences. The weekend suite came with television sets and VCR's in both the living room and the bedroom. The hotel film library stocks nearly 200 movies, from the usual blockbusters to cult films ("The Rocky Horror Picture Show," "The African Queen" and "My Beautiful Laundrette"). Even the pornographic offerings sounded almost high-minded, with such titles as "Dear Fanny" and "A Passage to Ecstasy."
Toiletries in the Art Deco black and white tile bathrooms were few, and disappointingly tasteful: tiny bottles of Neutrogena (the shampoo equivalent of PBS), orange sticks and cotton swabs in a tiny black box and toilet paper wrapped with a thin black ribbon. There was only one terry-cloth robe in a suite built for two, and no bubble bath. To some, this might pass for European raffinement, but to those accustomed to the standardized pampering provided by even lesser hotel chains, it smacks of stinginess.
The Mark offers solicitous service, comfort and sleek, East Side elegance. It is certainly more restful than the rash of such fashionable midtown establishments as the Paramount, the Royalton and Morgan's, Ian Schrager hotels whose prankish post-modern furniture can strike the faint-hearted as user-hostile.
But for all its charm, the Mark has a major weakness.
First-class hotels that offer neither flowers nor bedtime chocolates on the pillow in their $350 suites should beware: Thelma and Eloise have killed for less.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Checking into the Mark -- Small, quiet, expensive and European, it is the epitome of the "boutique hotel." (Ed Quinn for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Studio Proposes Weekly Bargain for Moviegoers

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Universal Pictures has proposed that movie theaters sell tickets at half price one day a week to stimulate weekday moviegoing, but theater owners gave the plan a mixed response today.
Some theater operators welcomed the proposal, but others said that discounting was already in place in many theaters and that the measure appeared to be a publicity ploy by Universal. But even critics of the idea said it underscored the restlessness and concern among studios and exhibitors about the uneasy financial state of the movie industry. 
 The proposal was made by Tom Pollock, chairman of the MCA Motion Picture Group, and Universal. Mr. Pollock said Wednesday that he was inviting theater owners to take part in an experimental bargain day that would offer half-price adult admissions for current Universal films every Tuesday.
"Midweek business for movies in America is a disaster," Mr. Pollock said in an interview today, blaming high ticket prices and lackluster films for lagging attendance. "The average screen in America has 38 people on a given weekday. Thirty-eight people all day! It's like flying from L.A. to New York with three people on board."
 
Cheaper Popcorn, Too
 Universal's proposal was intended to initiate debate about the impact of the high admission prices -- as much as $7 or $7.50 in some areas -- before the National Association of Theater Owners' convention next week in Las Vegas, Nev. Last year, movie admissions hit a 15-year low. Universal also urged theaters to reduce concession-stand prices, which have also drawn complaints from moviegoers.
Mr. Pollock said some chains will start adopting the half-price policy next week at theaters showing Universal films like "Fried Green Tomatoes," "Cape Fear" and "Kuffs."
But some theater owners said privately today that Universal was not proposing to lower its film rental costs while asking movie houses to limit their prices. At the same time, some owners said it would be unrealistic and difficult for movie houses to slash prices on Universal's films while maintaining separate prices for the movies of other studios.
 
Success in Canada Cited
 Support for the Universal proposal came from the Cineplex Odeon Corporation, which is partly owned by MCA. Allen Karp is president and chief executive of the Canadian-based company, which owns 1,157 screens and 267 theaters in the United States.
"Special pricing on Tuesdays has been interwoven into the Canadian theatrical exhibition fabric for several years with great success," Mr. Karp said. "It has had a positive impact both on the frequency of attendance for the regular moviegoer and in bringing out a large and entirely new audience who otherwise would not attend movies."
The plan was also endorsed by other chains, including Carmike Cinemas, a growing movie circuit based in Columbus, Ga., with more than 800 screens in the South and the Southwest, as well as the Pittsburgh-based Cinema World, and the Wometco Theaters, based in Florida. But several major movie chains reacted coolly, saying, essentially, that they already had discount programs for matinee audiences, students and the elderly. Such programs are called niche discounting.
Mr. Pollock said he had not spoken to other studio chiefs about the plan. "The movie business is sensitive to quality and price," he said. "You put better movies in the marketplace; more people will come. The question is, in a recession, is it too expensive for people to come out when there are so many other alternatives? You can rent a video much cheaper during the week than the weekend; in some places, it's only 49 cents. The video stores are aware they should reduce prices to increase volume. The movie business hasn't really done it."
He added: "If all 38 people who show up on the average get in at half price, and no one else shows up, then we lose a little money. But when times are tough -- and they are tough now -- we should try to be innovative and see what happens. I have a feeling more than 38 people will start showing once we cut the prices."

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Again: South Garden
This week, four months after the Battery Park City Authority formally put a stop to a much-criticized proposal for South Garden that would have blocked its spectacular Hudson River views, the authority announced new plans for the diamond-shaped, 3.5-acre plot at the tip of Battery Park City. 
 The authority's new team -- a seasoned one, experienced in the design of open spaces -- includes the Boston-based architectural firm Machado & Silvetti, the landscape architects Hanna/Olin from Philadelphia and the horticulturist Lynden B. Miller of Manhattan.
Absent from the mix is an artist, an omission that the previous design team finds puzzling. "It's a pity the authority abandoned its original idea and that there's not an artist in the new group," says Jennifer Bartlett, the artist who was part of the initial team, along with Alexander Cooper, the New York architect.
David Emil, the president and chief executive officer of the authority, says that the choice of architect and landscape architect was made after reviewing more than 60 proposals submitted to the authority, which had solicited architects, landscape architects and horticulturists in newspaper advertisements and by word of mouth.
"The choice of an artist as part of the original design group was something I inherited from a previous administration," Mr. Emil says. "In reviewing our needs, we now felt an architect and landscape architect was most appropriate. That's not to say we won't add an artist later, but initially we wanted a team that had thought a lot about designing open, urban spaces and would give us a powerful plan, one that would work within the context of the park system."
The authority's announcement ends years of relentless, and often bitter, criticism of Ms. Bartlett and Mr. Alexander's proposal. Their scheme called for a grid of 24 thematic plantings enclosed by tall hedges and a 10-foot-high concrete wall that would have virtually blocked all river views.
Everyone from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to community planning board members to residents of Battery Park City labeled the plan impractical, elitist and expensive. But Ms. Bartlett contends, "The scheme was eminently buildable, growable and could have been done within budget."
The current $12 million budget is $2 million less than the estimated cost of the Bartlett-Alexander plan. And Mr. Emil says that the authority is now committed to working with the community to see what local residents feel needs to be included in the garden plan.
While no artist is yet part of the South Garden proposal, artists' names are circulating in another Battery Park City Authority project. According to Mr. Emil, the authority is considering adding a sculptor to the design team that is working on the two-acre park around the World Financial Center. The sculptors Martin Puryear and Brower Hatcher are among the likely candidates. Whoever is selected will join the New York architectural firm Mitchell-Giurgola and the Cambridge, Mass., landscape architect Susan Child, who have already begun the initial design.
Still another Battery Park City project, and one that is further along, involves the sculptor Tom Otterness and North Park, just south of Stuyvesant High School's new campus. Mr. Otterness is at work on what he calls a "sculptural environment," which includes about 100 bronze figures covering a 160-foot-long path. It is to be completed in May. "It's whimsical, but in a dark way," Mr. Otterness says. Sketches for some of the imaginative, doughlike figures included in the design are on view beginning this Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art's exhibition "Allegories of Modernism: Contemporary Drawing."
 
Morley Is Moving
 When word spread that the figurative painter Malcolm Morley was about to leave the Pace Gallery for Mary Boone in SoHo, many in the art world wondered if the defection was a result of Arnold Glimcher's absentee management of Pace. It seems that Mr. Glimcher, who has been busy directing the film "The Mambo Kings," which opens on Feb. 28, was rarely at the gallery. Mr. Morley, art insiders say, felt neglected.
Mr. Morley's lawyer, Michael Lynne, said the artist had no comment; Mr. Glimcher did not return phone calls. But several art experts say they believe that Mr. Morley has a contractual obligation to Pace that might make his departure more complicated.
Ms. Boone would say only: "Malcolm is an artist that I've admired for a great many years. And I hope to do a show of his work next season."
Douglas Baxter, the director of the Pace Gallery, says he believes that Mr. Morley's planned departure has nothing to do with Mr. Glimcher's film career. "We worked very hard for Malcolm," he says. "He's a wonderful painter. Sometimes these things happen. He's the only artist to leave the gallery in seven or eight years."
In fact, Mr. Baxter insists that Pace is "not losing artists; we're gaining them." He points to Dan Flavin, whose first show -- "Colored Fluorescent Light 1964 and 1992" -- opens tomorrow at Pace's gallery at 142 Greene Street in SoHo. Mr. Flavin was represented by Leo Castelli, and most recently has been shown at the Rubin Spangle Gallery.
Mr. Baxter also cites Antoni Tapies, the 68-year-old Spanish artist, who is also joining Pace. "Tapies's achievement, relatively unknown here, is absolutely central to postwar art, both European and American," Mr. Baxter says. While Pace will show the artist's work in North America, Galerie Lelong will continue to represent him in Europe. "We're currently planning a Tapies show for February 1993," Mr. Baxter says. And the Museum of Modern Art is having an exhibition called "Antoni Tapies in Print," which will include more than 100 prints and illustrated books, opening May 7.
 
Koons May Leave
 Reports that the artist Jeff Koons is leaving the Sonnabend Gallery, where he has been showing his work for the last six years, have been circulating ever since his highly publicized -- and some have said pornographic -- show at the SoHo gallery closed just before Christmas. (The exhibition included many works depicting Mr. Koons and his wife, Ilona Staller, in various sexual positions and in various stages of undress.)
"The situation is like a ball of wax that has yet to be melted," says Mr. Koons's lawyer, John Koegel. "Ultimately, Jeff would like to be independent, but he has not left Sonnabend yet."
Money is apparently what is holding things up. "There's still a significant amount of money that the gallery advanced Jeff for the materials necessary to produce his work," Mr. Koegel says. Several calls to Mr. Koons's studios in New York and Munich, Germany, were not returned.
While neither his lawyer nor the gallery will discuss exact figures, art experts say they believe that Sonnabend advanced the artist between $3 million and $4 million over the years. The most recent advances helped him pay for his silk-screen-on-canvas paintings and the glass, plastic and wood sculptures of himself and his wife in the Sonnabend show.
"These works were expensive to produce," says Antonio Homem, the director of Sonnabend. "The gallery does give artists advances and they can add up to enormous sums." While Mr. Homem acknowledges that Mr. Koons and Sonnabend have had problems in the past, it is clear the gallery would like to continue to represent Mr. Koons. "Right now, we're trying to work things out," Mr. Homem says.
Both Mr. Homem and Mr. Koegel consider Mr. Koons's show an artistic success, but they say it is still too early to tell how much money was made. According to Mr. Homem, the three casts that were made of three sculptures have sold, and so have four paintings. Mr. Koons's work is pricey. His sculptures range from $65,000 to $150,000. An unusually large piece by Mr. Koons that shows him and his wife covered with butterflies costs $350,000.
Paintings were priced at $80,000. "Buyers were mainly private collectors from Europe and the United States," Mr. Homem says. "The American collectors were mostly from ouside of New York, some from the West Coast. But there was one New Yorker who bought a painting." And one museum, the Stedelijk in Amsterdam, purchased a glass piece called "Mound of Flowers" for $125,000.
"It takes courage to buy these explicit pieces," Mr. Homem says.
 
Ruth Siegel Closes
 The Ruth Siegel Gallery in Manhattan is another victim of the recession. At the end of February, the 57th Street space, which has specialized in young artists like Robert Jessup and Sam Messer for 10 years, will close. "It's been an agonizing few months," Ms. Siegel admits. "I waited to see if business would pick up, but it hasn't. And with the lease coming up for renewal at the end of the month, I had little choice."
Ms. Siegel says she will become a private dealer and art consultant.

LENGTH: 1073 words

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel

 BODY:

The Substance of 'Substance'
Everyone is suddenly paying so much attention to Broadway -- and why not, with 18 shows opening in the next three months? -- that no one is noticing the phenomenon of "The Substance of Fire." The play, by Jon Robin Baitz, about a family-owned publishing business, was a hit last season at Playwrights Horizons; the star, Ron Rifkin, won an Obie and a Drama Desk Award. It closed in June when Mr. Rifkin had to return to the television series "The Trials of Rosie O'Neill." That show was recently canceled, so he and his fellow cast members, Sarah Jessica Parker, Maria Tucci, Jon Tenney and Patrick Breen, are all back. Previews began at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater on Jan. 27, a few weeks after Andre Bishop, the former artistic director of Playwrights Horizons, moved to the same post at Lincoln Center Theater. 
 "Substance" does not officially reopen until Feb. 27. But after only three weeks of previews, Bernard Gersten, the theater's executive producer, says 18,000 of its 46,000 members have bought tickets, favorable word of mouth is spreading quickly to nonmembers, and the run at the 299-seat theater, which was scheduled through April, has been extended through July 26.
Well, good news is good news, but what is most interesting here is that the play's success is debunking at least two big theatrical myths. The first is the theory of momentum, which holds that if a show waits too long to reopen when changing theaters, it loses the momentum of people wanting to see it. The second myth is the January-February slump, when producers assume that all potential theatergoers are locked in their homes waiting for the spring thaw.
"This show had a tremendous reputation from its initial run that was not satisfied, since there were only seats for 9 or 10,000 people to see it," Mr. Gersten says.
Robyn Goodman, the co-artistic director of the Second Stage, had less luck transferring Lynda Barry's "Good Times Are Killing Me" last summer to the Minetta Lane Theater, where it ran briefly. She says subscribers could have saved the show. "Lincoln Center's membership is security up front to build word of mouth," she says. "When there's a mailing to your home with a discount ticket to a show your friends told you was great, you can't lose. There's no shlepping involved. If 'Good Times' had gone to Lincoln Center, it would still be running. But they didn't ask me."
 
Orpheum for 'Sight Unseen'
 Manhattan Theater Club is on a roll. Its Stage II production of Donald Margulies's "Sight Unseen," already extended through March, will transfer to the Orpheum Theater on March 26 for an open-ended run. The play, about a Jewish American artist who travels to London and visits his old girlfriend and her husband, received unanimously favorable reviews and will move with its original cast intact -- Deborah Hedwall, Dennis Boutsikaris, Laura Linney and Jon De Vries.
 
A Busy Choreographer
 Word on the street is that she's the next Michael Bennett. So no matter what the reviews say about "Crazy for You," the new Gershwin musical opening Wednesday at the Shubert Theater, its choreographer, Susan Stroman, is already a hit -- at least among producers and directors in the theater. Enough have seen the musical -- along with her work in "And the World Goes 'Round," the Kander and Ebb revue Off Broadway -- to have offered her jobs to last through the next year.
Ms. Stroman will choreograph Carnegie Hall's tribute to Stephen Sondheim in April, and Harold Prince's revival of "Showboat" in Toronto in the spring of 1993. In between, she has become Neil Simon's first choice to choreograph the musical-comedy version of his movie "The Goodbye Girl," to be directed by Gene Saks, with music by Marvin Hamlisch and lyrics by David Zippel. Rehearsals are scheduled to begin in November for a Broadway opening next winter.
 
Roles to Grow Out Of
 Know any boys who want to earn $900 a week? If they're between the ages of 7 and 10, send them to the Palace Theater tomorrow at 9 A.M. "The Will Rogers Follies" is holding auditions to replace the four children in the cast, who have grown too tall for their roles. The show needs boys between 4 foot 1 and 4 foot 7 who sing and move well. Dance training is preferred but not required. Members of all racial and ethnic minorities are urged to apply.
 
Random Notes
 If you find yourself in Boston this spring, you may want to check out the new Mrs. David Mamet. The Back Bay Theater Company's production of "Oleanna," the new play by Mr. Mamet, will be presented by the American Repertory Theater at the Hasty Pudding Theater in Cambridge. Rebecca Pidgeon, the wife in question, who also appeared in Mr. Mamet's recent film "Homicide," co-stars with W. H. Macy in the two-character play about a university professor and a student. Performances run from May 1 to 24. Also at the Hasty Pudding, from March 26 to April 26, is "Media Amok," a new play by Christopher Durang, directed by Les Waters. Anne Pitoniak and Lewis Black will join the American Repertory Theater company in this political satire set against the world of talk-show television. . . . At least two Broadway musicals are taking no chances on losing a single ticket-buyer who might have missed the shows' connections to their hit songs. "Man of La Mancha" seems to have taken on "The Impossible Dream" as a subtitle in many ads and on its marquee. And "Miss Saigon" has been running ads that say "The American Dream," referring to its big production number, which Jonathan Pryce made famous. The hope is that in a recession, tickets will sell as well as dreams. . . . The punch line to the recent flap on "Falsettos" is that the show is rehearsing at Lincoln Center Theater. Joining us late? After the two one-act musicals by William Finn and James Lapine about gay life in the early 1980's were directed by Graciela Daniele at the Hartford Stage and received raves, they were to transfer to Lincoln Center but didn't, because of costs and scheduling problems. Mr. Finn fell out with Andre Bishop, the theater's artistic director, and Mr. Lapine became the director. But after the incident went public, Mr. Bishop and Mr. Finn reconciled in record time. And when Fran and Barry Weissler, the show's new producers, discovered a shortage of rehearsal space caused by the crush of spring shows, they finally called Lincoln Center. A happy ending, after all.

HEADLINE: $25 and Under

BYLINE: By Eric Asimov

 BODY:
Finding a Burmese restaurant in New York is about as easy as remembering that Burma now calls itself Myanmar. So it's a surprise to find this engaging restaurant spicing up this drab stretch of gas stations and parking garages on Amsterdam Avenue on the Upper West Side.
Mingala West has avoided many of the fluorescent cliches of the Chinese restaurants that line Broadway one block to the west. The walls are cool and black, the banquettes and Breuer chairs inviting, and ceiling spotlights set off moody atmospheric charcoal drawings. 
 Myanmar is bordered by China, Thailand and the Indian subcontinent, and traces of each turn up in the food. The best dishes are generally the simplest, among them many of the appetizers, the bright salads and the tossed noodle dishes. Several of these, with a soup or an entree, make a fine shared meal for two.
Savory lentil fritters dipped in a vinegary-hot tamarind sauce are an addictive starter ($3.95). Steamed green beans, topped with sesame seeds and peanuts, are delicately fragrant with lemon ($4.50). The Southern Rangoon shrimp salad achieves a precarious balance, the searing heat of the seasoning relieved by cool mint leaves and lemon juice ($5.95).
Pungent Mandalay nungi noodles -- fat rice noodles tossed with chicken in a potato and bean sauce -- are accented with curry and garlic ($6.95). Northern Burma pan fry noodles are bright and vivid, incorporating pork, shrimp, ground peanuts, eggs and bean sprouts ($7.95).
Among the best of the poultry and meat dishes are mountain ruby chicken, an earthy blend of boneless chicken, peanuts, red pepper and zucchini ($8.75), and glass palace chicken, marinated chicken served with potatoes in a soothing blend of curry and coconut milk sauce ($8.75).
There is a modest wine list, but Singha beer from Thailand ($3) is the perfect accompaniment to these lively dishes.
Mingala West is now offering a lunch special for $4.50, including a salad or soup, vegetable fried rice, and a choice of two dozen entrees, and a similar early dinner special for $5.95.
"The recession, you know," a waiter said.
 
Mingala West
325 Amsterdam Avenue, at 75th Street, Manhattan, (212) 873-0787.
Best dishes: Sesame string beans and peanuts, Mandalay nungi noodles.
Average: Lunch: $4.50 (for three-course special) to $25. Dinner: $5.95 (for three-course early dinner special) to $25. (Prices exclude tax, tip and alcohol.)
Credit cards: American Express, Visa, Mastercard.
Hours: Noon to 11 P.M. Monday to Thursday, noon to 12 A.M. Friday to Sunday.
Wheelchair access: Restrooms are down steps, on a lower level.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: New Hampshire;
CLINTON STRESSING HIS ECONOMIC PLAN

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 14

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton took his extraordinary last-ditch effort to revive his flagging Presidential campaign to a live New Hampshire audience tonight for the second night in a row, appealing to voters to trust him to put the country back on the right track.
During the 30-minute live call-in show that was televised during prime time on a Manchester station, Mr. Clinton fielded only one question about his draft status during the Vietnam War, an issue that has raised new questions about the Arkansas Governor's credibility in recent days. 
 The rest of the time, New Hampshire residents who telephoned a toll-free number or made up a sedate studio audience asked about unemployment compensation, health care, the environment and energy policy. The program originated in Durham, across the state from Manchester.
In many ways, the questions resembled the sort that Mr. Clinton gets at campaign rallies, where he is seldom asked about rumors of extramarital affairs or the issues of patriotism that have eroded his New Hampshire support, according to recent polls.
His television appearance came at the end of a day in which he sought to refocus his attacks on President Bush and move beyond the problems that have threatened his campaign.
Only one questioner, a man from Hampton who identified himself as an undecided voter, asked Mr. Clinton if "in retrospect" Mr. Clinton should have said he simply did not want to go to Vietnam "rather than lying" and saying that he had genuinely made himself available for the draft in 1969.
"First of all, I didn't lie," Mr. Clinton said. "The facts have always been clear, and I'm the only person who's been telling the same sory in this for 13 years." Mr. Clinton's campaign has released an affidavit from a Republican member of the Hot Springs, Ark., draft board who stated that no undue influence was applied to allow Mr. Clinton to receive a deferment by promising to join the Reserve Officers Training Corps at the University of Arkansas.
Mr. Clinton has acknowledged that he wrote a letter in 1969 to an Army colonel supervising the R.O.T.C. program at the university and thanked him for "saving me from the draft." In the letter, Mr. Clinton, then 23 years old, conceded that he had been misleading when he said he intended to join R.O.T.C.
"I put myself back into the draft," Mr. Clinton said. "If I had gotten lottery Number 1, you wouldn't be calling me to ask this question."
When he did finally relinquish his deferment, Mr. Clinton was able to avoid the draft because he drew Number 311 in the first lottery, held on Dec. 1, 1969.
Mr. Clinton's audience, seemed more concerned about policy and their own lives than about the candidate's personal life. One woman asked him what he could do about getting a new train line built between Portsmouth and Boston.
Earlier in the day, Mr. Clinton vowed to return the campaign to talking about the issues.
"There's been a lot of falsehood out there," Mr. Clinton told a crowd of reporters at the supermarket stop. "I want the facts out there. The main thing I'm trying to do is give this election back to the people. You all are trying to stop me from doing it. I'm going to try to run this election on issues from here on in."
Mr. Clinton continued his general policy of ignoring his Democratic rivals, even as Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa held a news conference at a toxic cleanup site in Nashua to denounce Mr. Clinton for "sweeping environmental problems under the rug in Arkansas for more than a decade."
Two other Democratic candidates, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts and Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, also declined the opportunity to attack other Democrats by name. Instead, they reserved their criticism for policy issues like health-care reform and proposals for tax cuts for the proposals.
Mr. Kerrey, who has made national health insurance the centerpiece of his campaign, said today that he was "a bit of an underdog at the moment," but he insisted that he was not discouraged by public opinion polls showing him in a close constest for third place with Mr. Harkin.
Even as he aimed an occasional barb at a rival, Senator Kerrey continued to insist today that his first concern was not his own future, but the country's. "This is not just about electing a new President," he said. "It's about trying to take America in a new direction."
But Mr. Clinton's recent troubles continued to hurt his best efforts to conduct business as usual. At the supermarket, the tabloid newspapers at the checkout stands featured him on the cover, and after he passed shoppers at the mall, some of them murmured about him in his wake.
 
Looking Back in Empathy
 David Barker, a 44-year-old sales manager from Merrimack, and Richard Seyfried, 45, a locksmith from Salem, said they both drew high draft lottery numbers during the Vietnam War and thought no less of Mr. Clinton because of reports of his efforts to avoid the draft in 1969.
But neither man said they think that Mr. Clinton can now be elected.
"I think Bill Clinton's got a credibility problem," Mr. Seyfried said after shaking the Arkansas Governor's hand in a Sears, Roebuck store. "It's just the whole air of how the press has played up the problem makes it an issue, whether there is any realism behind it or not," said Mr. Barker. .
Nevertheless, Clinton campaign aides said that the Governor's slippage in polls had bottomed out, and that their private polling showed him regaining some ground on Mr. Tsongas.
 
Good News for Tsongas
 Three independent polling organizations, conducting continuous surveys that keep track of changing voter sentiments, showed Mr. Tsongas leading Mr. Clinton by at least eight percentage points through Thursday. The American Research Group, Gallup and KRC Communications Research are each interviewing 150 to 200 likely Democratic primary voters nightly, and are issuing each day the combined results of the previous two or three nights.
Late today, Mr. Clinton's campaign workers issued figures showing that they had raised $1 million in the last two weeks at the height of Mr. Clinton's problems.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans;
Bush, Slipping in New Hampshire, Hopes for Rally and 'Home Run'

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEDFORD, N.H., Feb. 14

 BODY:
President Bush arrives in New Hampshire Saturday for a final two-day spurt of campaigning, facing a deteriorating political situation and the need to stage a late rally like the one that brought him victory in 1988.
Although the White House continues to maintain that all is going according to plan, Bush strategists here are seeking a decisive victory and are increasingly worried about the challenge of Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator. One said today, "We're slipping again, and the President needs a home run this weekend to turn it around." 
 Mr. Bush's visit to the state on Wednesday generated lukewarm support at best. He won no more applause from the State Legislature than Mr. Buchanan did earlier in the week, even though Mr. Bush has five or six times as many backers among the legislators. At a visit to a shopping mall here, the crowd was big and polite enough but notably standoffish.
Worst of all from Mr. Bush's point of view, he failed to dominate television or newspaper reports in the state, with the troubles of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas in the Democratic race stealing much of the attention.
Significant numbers of voters interviewed by canvassers and by reporters are starting to repeat the themes of Buchanan advertisements, without mentioning the source of their ideas. "We can't afford Bush for another four years," said a woman in Claremont, in western New Hampshire, and a man in Portsmouth commented, "He doesn't have a real economic plan."
 
A Shift Toward Buchanan
 After seemingly stabilizing his support at the beginning of the month, Mr. Bush stayed away for two weeks, giving Mr. Buchanan another chance to persuade the economically battered electorate here that Mr. Bush had forsaken them. In the polls that continuously keep track of fluctuating public opinion, three survey organizations found that large numbers of voters began leaving the President and describing themselves as uncommitted.
Now, says Dick Bennett of the American Research Group, an independent poll-taking firm, new data show that two-thirds of undecided voters are beginning to move toward Mr. Buchanan. Another potential problem is Jim Lennane, a wealthy businessman who has spent $500,000 on anti-Administration television advertisements.
"I think the President is really in trouble," said Gerry Chervinsky," the poll taker for The Boston Globe. "He might well not get 55 percent of the vote."
The Bush brain trust does not see that happening. Ron Kaufman, the White House political director, said in Concord this week, "I think we're doing remarkably well."
Presidential strategists hope to score at least a 2-to-1 victory on Tuesday, with Mr. Bush approaching two-thirds of the vote. That would make it harder for Mr. Buchanan to raise money to compete effectively in Georgia, which votes on March 3, and the other state he is emphasizing, Texas, which votes on March 10.
But even among the President's backers, there is evident concern as the final weekend approaches, four years after he overtook Senator Bob Dole of Kansas to win New Hampshire and put his drive to the White House in gear. Several of them said they were concerned about his inability so far, in a race that remains highly volatile, to generate intensity or commitment.
Senator Warren B. Rudman, the state's most popular politician, who has made a radio commercial for the President, said the other day that Mr. Bush had not come here "early enough or often enough" to get the job done.
 
Need for Reassurance
 "People are a little like characters out of Brigadoon up here," said Tom Rath, one the President's principal advisers in this state. "They know they go off into the mist again after Tuesday, not to be seen or heard from for four years. So they need reassurance they won't be forgotten.
"That's our job for this weekend. The President has to convince them that he'll still remember them on Wednesday, after the votes are counted."
Conversely, Mr. Buchanan will continue to try to persuade the voters that Mr. Bush is a fair-weather friend. For weeks, the challenger has been banging away at the President's decision to increase taxes after having promised not to do so. Today he escalated his attacks at a news conference, accusing Mr. Bush of "a cynical betrayal of the American middle class."
"In his State of the Union address Mr. Bush said his $500 extra deduction for each child was at the heart of his new economic plan," Mr. Buchanan said in his assault on the President's credibility. "Now we learn it isn't even in his plan. In retrospect, it appears to have been a giant political scam to hoodwink New Hampshire voters into believing George Bush favors tax cuts for working people."
Former Representative Chuck Douglas, Mr. Buchanan's highest-ranking backer in the state, expressed delight at Mr. Bush's change of signals on the tax break for dependent children, saying, "We never in our wildest dreams thought that in the final three or four days we'd be handed an issue like this."
This has been a mighty battle of television advertisements, with each campaign buying 25 to 30 commercial spots a day on WMUR, the state's leading station, as well as substantial numbers on Boston outlets. By primary day, Mr. Buchanan will have spent $1.7 million on television, an aide said. Mr. Bush probably will have spent only slightly less, although he joined the electronic fray later.
Most of Mr. Buchanan's money -- he has raised about $2.5 million -- has come from direct-mail solicitations, with the average gift about $50.
 
Painting Foe as Protectionist
 So far, Mr. Bush has refrained from attacking Mr. Buchanan by name, but he has labored heavily to paint the former White House speech writer as a protectionist and an isolationist. On Wednesday, for example, he warned voters here "not to listen to the siren's call that says we can't compete and we've got to turn inward." No state would suffer more from protectionism than this one, he said, estimating that 35,000 jobs here were directly linked to foreign trade.
But this week, Bush campaign aides said, a debate has been raging about whether to use negative advertisements, attacking Mr. Buchanan, that have already been prepared. Mr. Rath said he thought that attacks would be a mistake, partly because Mr. Buchanan and his ideas were not the issue. But others argue that discrediting the conservative challenger, even as a protest candidate, was becoming imperative.
Mr. Buchanan clearly believes the isolationist label does him no harm. At today's news conference, he was asked by a foreign reporter for assurances of a continuing American role "in the outside world." He replied with gusto: "My friend, this campaign is not about the outside world. It's about the U.S.A."

HEADLINE: Lawyer Says Saudi Detention of Sheik Is Political

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A Western human-rights campaign on behalf of a jailed Saudi sheik heated up yesterday when the lawyer F. Lee Bailey said the sheik was being held for political reasons and demanded to know his whereabouts.
Mr. Bailey asserted yesterday in an advertisement in The New York Times that the Saudi Government had been holding Sheik Mohammed al-Fassi without charge since October "in inhumane conditions" in Riyadh, the Saudi capital. 
 "To my knowledge, he's been charged with nothing so far; he's just imprisoned," Mr. Bailey said in a telephone interview from his office in Florida. He has been Sheik Fassi's lawyer for 10 years.
 Saudi officials refuse to discuss Sheik Fassi's whereabouts. In Saudi Arabia, prisoners do not have to be publicly charged within a specific period of time after they are detained. Nor are they guaranteed access to a lawyer before they are charged.
 
Reportedly Seized in Amman
 Sheik Fassi's family and supporters say he was seized in Amman, Jordan, and illegally sent back to Saudi Arabia, which had demanded his extradition. The Jordanians are believed to have handed him over to improve relations with Saudi Arabia, which cut off badly needed economic aid when Jordan supported President Saddam Hussein of Iraq after the invasion of Kuwait.
Although Sheik Fassi has represented himself as a champion of democracy and has frequently called for political reforms, some prominent Saudis say he has no constituency in the kingdom, and he is probably best known in the West for his flamboyance.
He repeatedly embarrassed Saudi royalty while living in Florida, where he walked out without paying hotel bills and wrote bad checks to charities. He also drew the wrath of the local humane society when he adopted and then neglected more than 100 homeless cats in Miami Beach.
In California, he outraged neighbors by painting the genitals on classical statues at his Beverly Hills mansion in bright colors.
 
Spoke on Broadcasts From Iraq
 Reports of such actions deeply offended many people in Saudi Arabia, a conservative, religious country. But Sheik Fassi's broadcasts from Baghdad in October 1990 were considered far more serious. The station was used to beam anti-Saudi propaganda from Iraq during the Persian Gulf crisis.
Mr. Bailey said that in those broadcasts, Sheik Fassi "had the courage to suggest that a democracy might be a better practice in the region."
Saudi Arabia is ruled by King Fahd, an absolute monarch. He has pledged to establish a consultative assembly in the kingdom, although it will have little real political power.
Sheik Fassi's sister, Princess Hind, is married to Prince Turki, a brother of King Fahd. Mr. Bailey said yesterday that he had written to the King this week asking to see Sheik Fassi, who has not been heard from for more than a month.
King Fahd insisted in an interview with the Arabic weekly magazine Al-Hawadeth that there is "not a single political prisoner" in the kingdom.
The campaign for Sheik Fassi's release is backed by human rights groups. In November, an advertisement signed by 120 supporters appeared in major Western newspapers. It said in part, "Stop the detention of political prisoner Mohammed al-Fassi -- his only crime was speaking out for democracy in Saudi Arabia."
Last month, a mysterious counter-ad appeared in American and European dailies, quoting 20 people who signed the earlier ads as saying that they were withdrawing their support for Sheik Fassi because he had been charged with forgery. Mr. Bailey said in his advertisement yesterday that some signers were not aware their names had been used in the second ad.
William Adler, a spokesman for The New York Times Company, said, "Both advertisements, the Jan. 31 and the Feb. 14 advertisement, met the conditions of advertising acceptability for The New York Times. The Times does not take a position on the relative claims of the two advertisements."
One of the American signers of the Jan. 31 advertisement signed an affidavit certifying that consent was obtained from anyone named in the advertisement, in accordance with advertising acceptability standards, Mr. Adler said.
 In New York, the Saudi mission to the United Nations had no comment on the matter.

HEADLINE: A New Health-Insurance Crisis Underfoot

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
Imagine an undiscovered health crisis in America: 110 million of the nation's residents living with no health insurance and suffering in silence. Well, sort of silence.
The Presidential candidates have yet to mention the problem, but some insurers say this may be the year when America finally is ready to invest in a big way in health insurance for pets. With a $99 policy, one company says, an owner no longer has to wince at the cost of a $1,000 CAT scan for a cat, a pacemaker for a geriatric retriever or ultrasound for a pregnant Pekingese. 
 The company is starting a national promotion campaign that veterinarians say could vastly improve the quality of animal health care.
"With all the conversation surrounding human health care, many people may now consider that insurance may work for animals as well," said Fred Tierney, a New York veterinarian and an adviser to Medipet, an insurance plan promoted by the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company. "Many people who are not wealthy will want to provide for their pets like family members."
But consumer advocates and some economists call the new campaign by a mainstream company ridiculous.
The notion of insuring pets is an attempt to cash in on the nation's enormous health-care profits, the critics charge, to bring millions to veterinarians and insurers and upward spiraling costs to everyone with a furry dependent.
They say it is another example of economically unnecessary or unsound insurance for which Americans already pay millions of dollars a year, protecting themselves against such things as lost frequent-flier miles or rainy days at the beach.
"Once consumers believe that insurance is paying the bills, they agree to treatments and costs they never would have permitted if they were paying directly from their pockets," said J. Robert Hunter, the executive director of the National Insurance Consumer Organization in Washington, a nonprofit group. "Just as in human medicine the result would be more technology and higher prices for everybody."
For years veterinarians have complained that they have been denied the financial support available to physicians, and that for lack of money their patients are usually denied the full fruits of modern medical science. Magnetic resonance imaging, computerized axial tomography, radiation treatments and chemotherapy for cancer, sophisticated laboratory tests, among other expensive services, could bring longer and happier lives to many animals, they say, if their masters were not quite so concerned about the costs. Extensive cancer treatments, for example, can cost hundreds or thousands of dollars.
Owners facing hefty bills often chose to put their animals to sleep. Since World War II, small numbers of pet insurance policies -- designed to spread the cost among consumers -- have been sold by small insurance companies. Until recently they fared poorly.
This year, however, a major insurer, Fireman's Fund, together with the Animal Health Insurance Agency of Danbury, Conn., is starting a significant nationwide sales push to make the product something more than an oddity. This month they are beginning a cable television campaign of half-hour "infomercials," aimed at reaching 20 million viewers.
 
Direct-Mail Campaign
 It follows the first of a planned series of direct-mail campaigns begun last fall through Sears, Roebuck that was designed to reach more than 600,000 households, said J. Scott Henderson, Medipet's president.
At a time when human health insurance is in the headlines, the company's pet-coverage slogan is: "Because they're family, too!"
In addition, another company that has been offering pet insurance for years, Veterinary Pet Insurance of Anaheim, Calif., reports a surge in sales in the last year of more than 20 percent, to 90,000 policies last year. Although the company has had some problems with the state insurance department, which has required it to increase its capital reserves, the company says consumer response continues to rise rapidly and it plans to begin its own national advertising campaign in the next year.
 
Pet Insurance Terms
 With more than 52 million dogs and and 55 million cats living in the United States, according to a 1987 study by the American Veterinary Medical Association, the potential market is vast.
Under the basic Medipet plan, masters pay $99 a year for pets up to age 9, to cover up to $1,000 in bills for any injury or illness. The deductible is $50. Or they can pay $42 for up to $2,500 in coverage with a $250 deductible.
Medipet refuses to pay for psychiatry, root canal or dental capping. Veterinary Pet Insurance does cover acupuncture, but its policies, too, have limits. Its fine print says pets will not be covered during wartime for injuries sustained "in resisting attack," nor will it pay for injuries suffered during insurrection, rebellion or revolution.
Supporters of the idea say it is unlikely that pet insurance will lead to the type of price spiral that has afflicted human medicine. Michael Walters, a spokesman for the American Veterinary Medical Association, which supports pet insurance, says dogs and cats are better risks in many ways than more typical consumers.
"They don't smoke as a group," said Mr. Walters, quite seriously. "They rarely travel by automobile. They are less likely to be victims of street crimes. So a lot of things that put people in the hospital don't put animals there."
Hilary Robinson, a 39-year-old unemployed book editor with two boxers and a pug in a tiny New York apartment, praises her three Medipet policies. A fourth policy helped her pay for the kidney specialists, the chemotherapy and holistic veterinarian who treated a third boxer who died of cancer recently.
"It saved us thousands of dollars," she said.
But Orin Kramer, an economist and consultant in Princeton, N.J., who specializes in insurance issues, says that widespread insurance for pets may have results that mirror human health care strikingly.
 
Healthier Animals, More Vets
 "Animals would live longer and animals would be better positioned to overcome serious diseases," Mr. Kramer said. "Animal health care costs would rise significantly and more people would be attracted to the veterinary profession."
Given time and sufficient price rises, consumers would become increasingly concerned about high premiums, Mr. Kramer said. Insurance companies might begin to compete for the lower-risk customers, offering, say, special premiums for poodles, in contrast to German shepherd and other dogs with a higher incidence of joint problems. And then, possibly, a debate might erupt about cost controls.
"To what extent do you move to managed care?," Mr. Kramer asked.
Mr. Hunter of the National Insurance Consumer Organization said that consumers should buy insurance primarily to protect themselves against catastrophic events. It makes more sense to put money aside into savings, he said, to pay for smaller unexpected costs. Mr. Hunter, a longtime industry critic, lumped pet insurance together with what he described as other types of marginal policies.
But Mr. Hunter did express an interest in life insurance for cats.
"Imagine a type of life insurance," Mr. Hunter said, "where you don't have to pay the first eight times the policyholder dies."

HEADLINE: Despite the Forecasts of His Fall, Mobutu Has Zaire in His Grip

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Six months ago Zaire seemed on the brink of political chaos as mutinous soldiers rioted and the 26-year autocratic rule of President Mobutu Sese Seko began to crumble. But despite dire predictions from most Zairian political analysts and foreign diplomats, General Mobutu now seems more firmly in control than ever.
His political resurrection is in large part because of growing infighting among the anti-Government movement and also his deft handling of dissension within the country's army and police units. The result, analysts here say, is that the prospects are fast fading for this impoverished central African country to join the democratic trend sweeping much of the continent. 
 For more than a year the President has spent most of his time aboard a yacht on the Congo River, about 18 miles from the center of the capital, and has issued directives from there. Nearly everyone says that if he were to enter Kinshasa, he would be a target. But he has managed to frustrate the opposition by controlling the Government apparatus while virtually never entering the city.
Over the last decade, in fact, General Mobutu has spent increasingly less of his time in the capital. Frequently he has appeared on television from the yacht, holding news conferences or meeting with diplomats and political leaders.
Last September, in the face of mounting criticism of his rule, General Mobutu took some steps to share power with a group of religious, civic and opposition political leaders. But in recent weeks he has abruptly reversed himself, startling the United States and other foreign governments as well as many of Zaire's 40 million residents.
At the same time, anti-Government leaders say soldiers loyal to the President have become increasingly assertive, arresting and occasionally physically assaulting those perceived as a threat to the Government.
The pivotal event occurred in late January when Prime Minister Nguza Karl-i-Bond, who was appointed by General Mobutu last November, called off indefinitely a national conference that had been working on a formula for holding the country's first multiparty elections since it gained independence from Belgium in 1960. The conference began last July, but it had been repeatedly stalled by disputes over who among the various political and civic groups would be allowed to attend.
Mr. Nguza said the conference had become too costly and was degenerating into political chaos, assertions that opposition leaders mocked as a sham. "Nguza is talking nonsense," said Joseph Ileo, who served as Zaire's Prime Minister in the 1960's and is now a leading opposition politician. "He has become a dictator like Mobutu."
Etienne Tshisekedi, who served briefly as Prime Minister last October and now heads Zaire's biggest opposition party, the Union for Democratic and Social Progress, said General Mobutu and Mr. Nguza were "criminals, who are determined to stay in power for as long as possible."
 
4th Prime Minister in a Year
 Mr. Nguza is the fourth Prime Minister named by President Mobutu in less than a year. Since he joined the Mobutu Government, he has been denounced and disowned by much of the opposition, although he continues to maintain that he is sympathetic to their cause.
This weekend, the President indicated on national television that he was willing to resume talks with opposition leaders about sharing power, but it was not immediately clear whether this meant a resumption of the national conference.
Increasingly, the confusing and contradictory turn of events seemed to confirm suspicions of many Zairians that President Mobutu never really intended, as he promised last September, to relinquish power.
Just what has motivated President Mobutu and his Prime Minister's recent actions is not clear, but two theories are gaining adherents. One is that Zaire's opposition has demonstrated its weakness by attracting only token public support for a series of general strikes called to protest the President's growing intransigence against conceding more power. General Mobutu thus believes he can abort the national conference without sparking widespread protest that could threaten his grip on power.
Another theory circulating among political analysts here is that he never intended the conference to succeed, and hopes instead to avoid any threat to his political hegemony by calling elections before the opposition can organize a campaign against him.
According to this view, the President believes he could win an election against an unprepared opposition despite the growing turmoil in Zaire. The United States and other Western Governments have said that some form of transitional government is needed as a bridge between General Mobutu's autocratic rule and free and fair elections.
 
Violence and Looting
 The September accord between the President and the opposition followed a week of looting and violence triggered by mutinous soldiers angered because they had not been paid. Discontent had been rising for months, however, as the country reeled from a severe economic crisis and as opposition leaders pressed General Mobutu to adopt democratic changes in Zaire, long regarded as one of Africa's most closed political systems.
The United States, France and Belgium, the former colonial power of The Congo, have also condemned the decision to cancel the national conference. In perhaps the strongest condemnation to date of the Mobutu Government, the State Department said in a statement that the suspension of the conference offers few "prospects for national reconciliation and democracy."
Echoing the blunt criticism from Washington, Melissa Wells, the United States Ambassador in Zaire, said in an interview that the national conference had "engaged the hopes of the Zairian people, and to that extent it cannot just be thrown aside." She indicated, however, that the United States was holding out hope that President Mobutu would reverse himself.
American and Western diplomats said they felt particularly betrayed by Mr. Nguza's action because during a tour of Washington and European capitals in December, he made assurances that the procedural disputes that had plagued the conference from the outset would be resolved. At a Congressional hearing this week, Herman J. Cohen, Assistant of Secretary of State for African Affairs, said the Prime Minister's cancellation of the conference "was very disappointing and made us very upset with him personally."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Challenger;
As a Candidate, Buchanan Shows Compassionate Side

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 14

 BODY:
To listen to Patrick J. Buchanan on the stump is to witness a startling transformation. While it has not vanished completely, the fire-breathing, hard-edged, economic and social Darwinism that made Mr. Buchanan famous in his columns and on television shows like "Crossfire" has been tempered. In its place is a candidate striving to be seen as a sensitive, caring populist.
As a writer, Mr. Buchanan called AIDS "nature's retribution" against homosexuals and said the disease was spread by "promiscuous sodomy -- unnatural, unsanitary sexual relations between men." On the campaign trail he talks of showing compassion for people with AIDS, which he now compares to the cancer that killed his brother. 
 As late as December, Mr. Buchanan said homeless people who refuse to go to shelters should be locked up. In a recent interview, however, he said society must distinguish between harmless individuals who are down on their luck and "those who are deranged and dangerous and felons out on the street who like this as a way of life." The latter group, the candidate says, is a "tiny minority" of the homeless.
 
'Well, I Care'
 In recent days Mr. Buchanan has praised Alfred E. Smith, the 1928 Democratic Presidential candidate who was a populist governor of New York. He scorned as "vulture capitalism" a suggestion by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady that now was a good time for speculators to invest in real estate because property values in the state were so low. In place of his high-decibel rantings as a regular participant on the "McLaughlin Group" news-analysis program, Mr. Buchanan's campaign commercials have him speaking in muted tones, telling voters that, until he entered the race, "those in Washington behaved as though they did not care. Well, I care."
The candidate has not completely changed and still has plenty of harsh things to say. For example, Mr. Buchanan recently said it was absurd for the United States to maintain an economic blockade of Haiti to try to restore the ousted President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, whom the candidate called a "dingbat priest."
But in an interview, Mr. Buchanan said his experiences campaigning in economically depressed New Hampshire had caused him to question some long-held beliefs.
Before the campaign Mr. Buchanan opposed extended benefits to the unemployed. He now supports them.
"You don't alter your views, but you certainly modify what might be strong intellectual positions when they come into conflict with the reality out here," he said. "This has made me much more radical in terms of the need to deregulate the economy to cut taxes. But at the same time you can't go into those unemployment offices, see those guys about to lose their homes without saying, 'Well, we ought to go ahead with 12 more weeks of unemployment benefits.' "
 
Image 'Wasn't Selling'
 To some, the new Buchanan is little more than an campaign conversion, a dressing up of the candidate in new rhetorical garb when the old fashions could not be sold to enough voters.
"In Buchanan's case, the sharp edge that he was projecting wasn't selling very well," said Charles O. Jones, a political scientist at the University of Wisconsin. "It's one thing to go up to New Hampshire and tell voters what they already know -- that it's an economically depressed area and to point out who's President. But negative campaigning in you own party gets tiresome. People want to know what you've got to say about their problems."
The candidate's change also underscores something else. Despite running as an outsider who will stand up for the little guy, Mr. Buchanan has in fact been a Washington insider; a mover about in a cloistered world of pundits and policy makers; the owner of a Mercedes and a Cadillac who admitted he has never ridden the Washington subway. When Mr. Buchanan visited a Manchester homeless shelter on Christmas Eve, it was the first time he had ever been inside a soup kitchen.
 
Listening in a Different Way
 "It's one thing to talk about grand ideas, but when you talk about them to people who are worried about their taxes being raised or their Social Security being cut, you listen in a different way and take on some of their concerns," said Thomas E. Cronin, a political science professor at Colorado College who ran for Congress in 1982.
"You do take on a greater consideration for the average person," Mr. Cronin added, "particularly when you're in the upper 1 or 2 percent income bracket and you don't normally mingle with them."
Indeed, Mr. Buchanan now speaks disdainfully of conservatives who inhabit the "antiseptic" world of think tanks or commentators whose jobs are not threatened by tough economic times -- a description that could easily be applied to himself.
John McLaughlin, the host of the "McLaughlin Group," said in an telephone interview that he had told Mr. Buchanan he was at his best -- and most sensitive -- when he left Washington and reported from the field.
"But this is a rarity for you. What you do is go to your home in McLean, go in your office, sit down at your typewriter and you drive yourself angry with your ideas."
 
Shift on Free Trade
 The biggest shift in Mr. Buchanan's political philosophy is in the area of trade. As an aide to former President Richard M. Nixon, Mr. Buchanan lobbied for a Presidential veto of a bill passed by Congress to protect the country's shoe industry. As late as 1988, Mr. Buchanan said the rise of Asian capitalism was a success for American foreign policy. "To squander that in an absurd 'trade war' because we cannot compete with Korean cars or Japanese computer chips would be an act of almost terminal stupidity," he said.
But Mr. Buchanan announced his candidacy in New Hampshire with the slogan "America First." And this week in an address to the New Hampshire Legislature, the candidate said that "we Americans have got to stop being trade wimps," and advocated that the United States take retaliatory action against countries that engage in unfair trade practices.
Mr. Buchanan acknowledges his change in thinking, though he says he has been moving away from a pure free-trade stance for about a year. "I believe America should be No. 1," he said. "I want to see her No. 1 in industry, manufacturing, standard of living. But I also believe in free trade. If it comes to the point where the free trade theory conflicts with that, then it's the free trade theory that's going to give way."

HEADLINE: Cuomo Halts Planned Cut In Medicaid

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Hours before the action was to take effect at midnight, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last night temporarily suspended a 10 percent cut in the state's $550 million program of reimbursing pharmacies for the prescription drugs they dispense to 2.5 million poor people covered by Medicaid.
"We're temporarily suspending the implementation of these cuts to allow for further discussion with the pharmacists," Terry Lynam, a spokesman for the Governor, said in Albany after discussions involving Mr. Cuomo, legislative leaders and lobbyists for trade groups representing some 3,700 pharmacies. 
 The trade groups, including the Pharmaceutical Society of the State of New York and the Empire State Pharmaceutical Society, have argued that the cuts would pose an economic hardship for small pharmacists and that some might be forced to stop serving Medicaid patients or handling the most expensive prescriptions, many of which are used to fight H.I.V. or cancer.
Officials of the State Department of Social Services, which administers the reimbursement program, say the cuts are required under Federal regulation and insist that they would not seriously harm the industry. They say a hotline would be set up to direct any Medicaid recipient to a pharmacy that would help.
 
Concern Over Pricing
 Since 1978, the state has paid pharmacies for Medicaid prescriptions based on the average wholesale price of each drug, plus $2.60 as a dispensing fee for each prescription. The pharmacies often buy the drugs wholesale at a discount, and Federal and state surveys suggested that many were making excessive profits on some drugs, an assertion denied by the pharmacists.
In 1987, however, the Federal Government wrote new rules to control health costs. These directed that states, to continue receiving Federal aid paying half of Medicaid costs, cut 10 percent from the reimbursement rate based on wholesale drug prices.
Lawsuits by pharmacies and their trade groups kept the state from imposing the cuts immediately. The state offered to settle by increasing the dispensing fee to $3.90, but the plaintiffs refused. But recent court rulings cleared the way again for the state to implement the cuts, which were set for 12:01 A.M. today.
Governor Cuomo's spokesman, Mr. Lynam, said that last night's temporary suspension -- expected to be in effect at least a few days -- had been ordered "to give a little extra time to resolve this to everybody's satisfaction -- so Medicaid patients can get their drugs, the state can get its savings and the pharmacists can be satisfied that we are going about this in the right way."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Industrial production fell sharply in January and factory utilization slid as businesses struggled to bring inventories back in line with sales; producer prices also slipped, thanks to sharply lower energy and food prices. But economists are paying more attention to Thursday's rosier reports. [Page 37.] 
 House Democrats agreed on a tax-cut bill they said would show they cared about the middle class, while Republicans catered to the rich. If the proposal becomes law, Democratic committee aides said, taxes will increase for only the top 1 percent of taxpayers, while declining for everyone else. [37.]
Cars fueled with a mixture of alcohol and gasoline emit more smog-causing chemicals and are more costly to operate than those running on reformulated gasoline, according to a study issued by the auto and oil industries. [37.]
Wholesale prices fell for the second straight month in January, the Government said, another sign that the sluggish economy is holding inflation in check. [49.]
Tumbling sales pushed business inventories up 0.4 percent in December for a fourth straight monthly rise, the Commerce Department said. [49.]
An undiscovered health crisis to some, a ridiculous notion to others: health insurance for pets, it seems, may be headed for the big time. [1.]
 
Companies
LTV filed a reorganization plan that for the first time since it entered bankruptcy in 1986 carries the tentative support of its five main creditor groups and the Federal pension guaranty fund. But court approval could be delayed for months. [37.]
Warren E. Buffett and his lieutenants portrayed Salomon as a firm that had lost a tremendous amount of business and, after a top-to-bottom renovation, was now primed to claw much of it back. [37.]
Saturn and Toyota raised their prices, a day after a report that showed signs of an upturn in auto sales. [39.]
McCrory said it would miss a debt payment and hinted that it might file for bankruptcy protection. [39.]
 
International
OPEC oil ministers are close to an agreement that would cut the group's total oil production by a little more than a million barrels a day from its current 24.2 million. [38.]
A fund to stabilize the Russian ruble may be set up by the U.S. and other Group of Seven nations. [4.]
 
Markets
Stocks ended a volatile week on a steady note, with blue chips practically unchanged and the broader market showing weakness. The Dow ended at 3,245.97, off 0.68 for the day but up 20.57 for the week. [40.]
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed, as short- to intermediate-term issues continued to fall while bonds staged a bit of a recovery. [40.]
The dollar closed higher after first falling in response to two economic reports. [46.]
Wheat futures prices ended on a strong note, bolstering ideas that the week's steep loss was just a blip in a bull market. [46.]
 
Today's Columns
Should investors rush to buy tax-deferred annuities in case the law changes? Financial experts are divided. Jan M. Rosen: Your Money. [38.]
Fax machines, despite their speed and convenience, are not a particularly private means of sending or receiving documents. One advertising executive thinks he has a simple solution. Edmund L. Andrews: Patents. [38.]
