HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
The Persian Gulf war left Saddam Hussein in power but freed Kuwait from his control, broke his military power and, in the opinion of some experts, paved the way to Middle East peace talks. Yet the war and its aftermath have also taken as many as 200,000 lives.
The debate over this ambiguous outcome has been eclipsed, in the year since the war ended, by matters as diverse as the Palm Beach rape trial and the Presidential campaign. 
 But some people do continue to brood over the war, whether it was just and whether the teachings about just and unjust wars inherited from Cicero, St. Augustine and Grotius proved adequate for judging it. Those broodings may be important for the future moral health of the country.
Although President Bush defended the Persian Gulf conflict in just-war terms after it began, no one imagines that he and his closest advisers planned their diplomatic and military moves while reviewing a list of the requirements that a military action should meet to be considered just:
"Just cause, Jim?" Check. "Honorable intentions, Dick?" Check. "Legitimate authorization, Colin?" Check. "Exhaustion of less violent alternatives, Brent?" Check.
"Reasonable chance of success? Likelihood of doing more good than harm? No deliberate attacks on civilians? Scrupulous efforts to minimize the losses of both troops and civilians?" Check, check, check, check.
Indeed, the just-war tradition "is not a mechanical template or a moral computer into which data are plugged and answers pop out," George Weigel said in a recent conference at Vanderbilt University on just-war thinking. Mr. Weigel is the president of the Ethics and Public Policy Center in Washington.
Just-war thinking is far from supplanting other ways Americans approach warfare: pacifist rejection, realpolitik calculation, crusading fervor or simply visceral response to graphic images of enemy atrocities or battlefield carnage.
But Mr. Weigel and other proponents of just-war thinking believe that its categories have increasingly seeped into American public discourse, explaining for example why Gen. Michael Dugan of the Air Force was promptly dismissed, in September 1990, when he floated the idea of carpet-bombing Baghdad.
The theory not only tested the war, however; the war also tested the theory. Several recent books and discussions like those at Vanderbilt show that the war exposed enough ambiguities in just-war thinking to trouble its adherents as well as its critics.
To begin with the most elementary of questions, What is "a just cause?" In the eyes of most just-war adherents, reversing a flagrant act of aggression -- Iraq's invasion and annexation of Kuwait -- was about as clear-cut an instance of a just cause as could be expected. But what about maintaining the balance of power in the Middle East? The toppling of Mr. Hussein himself? The prevention of nuclear proliferation? The protection of a vital energy source?
The Rev. J. Bryan Hehir, a frequent adviser to Roman Catholic bishops on international issues, warns against extending the notion of just cause beyond resistance to aggression to concerns over nuclear proliferation or access to resources.
Michael Walzer, in a foreword to a new edition of his "Just and Unjust Wars" (Basic Books, 1992), limits just cause to "restoration plus" -- the liberation of Kuwait and the crippling of the military power that had made the invasion possible. He refuses to include the transformation of Iraq's government to one that respects human rights.
Mr. Weigel regards just cause much more broadly, emphasizing the nature of Mr. Hussein's rule and the threat it posed to peace in the region and to the world's oil supply. Unlike Mr. Walzer and Father Hehir, Mr. Weigel located the "moral tragedy" of the war in the failure to remove the Iraqi leader, or at least to prevent his remaining forces from crushing the Kurdish and Shiite rebellions.
Similar questions surround the just-war criterion that military force can be used only as a last resort. When, if ever, is the point of "last resort" reached? Opponents of the war's morality continue to argue that negotiations and economic sanctions were never given a chance to work.
Mr. Walzer and Mr. Weigel believe that many opponents of the war bent the last-resort criterion from something involving a reasonable judgment to a debater's exercise in abstract logic. The theoretical possibility of further economic presssures could always be evoked by those unwilling, in reality, to condone military action under any circumstances.
Finally, does the obligation to avoid direct attacks on civilian targets rule out massive destruction of a nation's infrastructure -- its electric power grids, water pumping and purification plants, sewage systems, transportation and communication links?
In the gulf war both pilots and weapons demonstrated remarkable success in sparing civilian targets. But American strategy deliberately struck at the infrastructure, considering it a legitimate military target.
Mr. Weigel agrees with that assessment, despite its "aftereffects on civilians," which others have described as widespread malnutrition, epidemics and deaths owing to the breakdown of food and water supplies, sanitary services and medical care.
Mr. Walzer believes this constituted "an attack on civilian society" in which "it is the military effects, if any, that are 'collateral.' "
For many people, these arguments are little more than Monday-morning moral quarterbacking. But the adherents of just-war thinking insist it is not simply a way of assessing current actions; it is also a way of shaping future attitudes.
Questions like the scope of a just cause, the meaning of last resort or the legitimacy of targeting electric power grids and water supplies should be systematically pursued in forums ranging from the military academies and university seminars to interfaith gatherings and Congressional committees.

HEADLINE: Panel's Democrats in Tax Accord

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
House Democrats agreed today on a tax-cut bill they said would show that they cared about the middle class and that Republicans catered to the rich.
Announcing agreement on a package that will go to the full House later this month, Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, whose Democratic members approved the bill tonight, said: "I think we need fairness in the tax code. That's the difference between Democrats and Republicans. We're going to see to it that middle-income Americans have a better tax break." 
 If the proposal becomes law, Democratic committee aides said, taxes will increase for only the top 1 percent of taxpayers, while declining for everyone else.
The six-year measure would offer $90 billion in tax reductions and a matching $90 billion in increases. The biggest cuts are tax credits of up to $400 for working couples, and a one percentage point reduction in corporate tax rates, to 33 percent. The bill also provides a cut in taxes on capital gains, weighted toward new ventures. This cut would be much less sweeping than what President Bush wants.
The main sources of new revenue are an increase to 35 percent from 31 percent in the highest income tax rates, which would apply to taxable income over $85,000 for individuals, $145,000 for couples, and $125,000 for heads of household, and a surtax of 10 percent on taxes owed by people with taxable income over $1 million.
The measure agreed on today differed little from the proposal Mr. Rostenkowski laid before committee Democrats on Thursday. The biggest difference is in the capital gains proposal, which is simpler than Thursday's plan.
An attempt by Representatives Thomas J. Downey of Long Island and Marty Russo of Illinois to replace the middle-income tax credits with a refundable tax credit of $180 for each child was defeated this morning on a 13-to-7 vote.
One section on capital gains in the legislation would set an effective rate of no more than 14 percent for investments in small companies held at least five years. Thursday's proposal had been 16.8 percent.
Then, instead of allowing a rate of 19.6 percent on other gains, this proposal would keep the current maximum rate of 28 percent, but the gains on all items purchased after the bill's effective date would be indexed for inflation, so there would be no tax on any profits made simply because all prices went up.
Today's action was another step in the steady intensification of partisan debate over taxes that began when President Bush used his State of the Union speech to challenge Congress to pass his proposals by March 20. They are focused heavily on a capital gains tax cut, accelerated depreciation for new industrial investment, and steps to encourage home buying.
 
Challenge to Bush
 Today the Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee formally laid down their challenge to his proposals, which have been altered since January to provide an even bigger cut on capital gains taxes. Their plan aims its tax breaks, even its capital gains cut, much more toward lower- and middle-income taxpayers than does the President's.
If they can get the bill passed by the House, which is less than certain because some House Democrats usually oppose any tax increases at all, they would then deal with an undoubtedly different measure the Senate will be considering in March, and be seeking compromise with the Senate and the White House in conference.
But for today, there was no talk of seeking agreements.
"I don't want a compromise," President Bush said today while campaigning in Belcamp, Md. He explained that he wanted his narrower plan acted on first and his other proposals later: "I want them to pass this, and then we'll get into negotiating on this big baby here."
Mr. Bush toured three houses under construction in Arborview at Riverside, a 100-home subdivision of mostly frame condominiums, town houses and single-family homes about three miles from the Aberdeen, Md., Army post. About 90 percent of the occupants are first-time home buyers.
Asked by a reporter what was wrong with raising taxes on the wealthy, he replied: "We don't need any tax increases. What we need to do is stimulate the economy, and every time you aim at the wealthy you hit these guys," referring to the home builders. He said: "Why divide, kind of keep trying to divide America, class against class. Why not get on with stimulating the economy so everybody's going to have a piece of a bigger pie?"
Mr. Bush also asserted that the tax reductions in the Democratic bill would not be paid for by the increases, and would therefore require Medicare cuts to make up for them.
"We must really be doing our job because we're irritating them downtown," Mr. Rostenkowski responded. "The bill is complete. The bill is paid for."
The middle-class tax cut in the bill, which the chairman will present to all House Democrats at a caucus next week, is basically one he proposed last fall. It would refund 20 percent of Social Security and Medicare taxes, up to $200 for individuals and $400 for couples. Those limits would be reached generally by individuals with earnings of $13,000 and couples with earnings of $26,000.
The credits would be temporary, expiring in two years.
The reductions in corporate tax rates would be permanent. Not only would the basic rate be reduced a point to 33 percent, but the corporate alternative minimum tax, for companies with large deductions and exemptions, would also be cut one point, from 20 to 19 percent.
Neither of those changes has any counterpart in Mr. Bush's proposals. But some other provisions that may help taxpayers outside the top brackets are borrowed or adapted from Mr. Bush's proposals.
 
Plan for I.R.A.'s
 They agreed to his proposal that first-time home buyers be permitted to make early withdrawals from Individual Retirement Accounts without the normal 10 percent penalty. But they rejected a $5,000 tax credit he had proposed for such purchases, too.
They proposed a tax credit, limited in most cases to $300, for interest charges on student loans. When interest exceeds 10 percent of someone's income, the credit could go to $500. Mr. Bush had proposed making such interest deductible. Democrats often prefer credits to deductions, since deductions are worth more to people paying a higher rate of taxes than to those in lower brackets, while credits are equally valuable to all taxpayers.
In a largely symbolic move, expected to raise only $1.9 billion over six years, they proposed that corporations be barred from deducting that part of an executive's compensation that exceeds $1 million a year.
Far more would be raised by the new maximum rates on individuals. The Democrats expect to raise $53.3 billion over six years by adding the 35 percent bracket and increasing, from 24 percent, to 25 percent, the alternative minimum tax for individuals with large amounts of tax-exempt income.
Committee aides said it was important to consider the impact of the 35 percent rate not just on people's taxable income. Individuals who would become subject to it at $85,000 of taxable income usually have adjusted gross income of about $105,000 and $20,000 in deductions, an aide said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Two lobbyists, at foreground left, conferred as other lobbyists and journalists mingled in the first-floor hallway of the Longworth House Office Building yesterday, outside the Ways and Means Committee room where House Democrats were working on their version of a proposed tax bill. HEADLINE: 7 Industrialized Countries Prepare Fund to Aid Ruble

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
The United States and other Group of Seven nations have begun laying the groundwork for a multibillion-dollar fund to stabilize the enfeebled Russian ruble, and some officials say such a fund might be set up in three to four months.
When President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia visited Washington two weeks ago, he and his economic aides strenuously urged the United States to help set up a fund that would, in effect, back the ruble with foreign money and so reduce economic and political instability during Russia's long and difficult winter. 
 And as some Groups of Seven nations push for a fund, which has been estimated to range from $5 billion to $12 billion, the United States has hinted that it might take part.
But American officials see many obstacles, among them Russia's high inflation rate, its large budget deficit and the primitive state of its banking system. Some American and European officials say it would be unwise to set a fund up when Russia's economy was in such a state of flux and when the people of Russia and the other former Soviet republics that use the ruble have such little confidence in their currency.
 
Economic Reform Plan
 Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said this week that Washington would support such a plan only if Russia agreed to comply with an International Monetary Fund program of economic discipline.
"It may well be that there might be some participation by nations, either as a group or bilaterally, in support of an I.M.F. program," Mr. Baker said Monday. "I frankly don't see that happening before there is a credible, overall economic reform program that has been devised with the international financial institutions."
Many Western officials say there is a good chance that a stabilization fund will be created shortly after Russia and other republics join the International Monetary Fund. Fund officials say Russia might join in late April at the time of the fund's spring meeting.
Last Monday, Russia began negotiating in Moscow with a fund delegation on a program in which Russia would agree on goals for budgeting, pricing policy, credit policy and privatization. In return, Russian officials expect aid from the global lender, perhaps in a stabilization fund, perhaps in a fund to help finance imports.
A stabilization fund is money that foreign nations contribute to supplement a country's gold and other reserves. The fund is used to back that country's efforts to maintain its currency's value in international transactions, and in doing so increases domestic confidence in the currency. If the currency comes under attack, money from the stabilization fund can be used in foreign exchange markets to defend the currency.
There is some dissent within the Group of Seven -- the United States, Japan, German, France, Britain, Italy and Canada -- about how soon to set up a stabilization fund. British officials have called for urgent action, saying a commitment to such a fund would provide much needed confidence to the Russians. The British have suggested that Russia be allowed to join the fund even before the April broad meeting.
"We thought it would be advisable if the Commonwealth of Independent States could know that the G-7 were holding out this idea of a stabilization fund," a British Treasury official said.
French, American and German officials say a stabilization fund should come after the April fund meeting. Group of Seven officials say Japan is wary of committing new aid to Russia until there is further progress in settling the dispute over ownership of the Kurile Islands.
Some analysts said the Administration was toning down its support for the plan because the fund could involve a foreign aid commitment of more than $1 billion in a campaign year when the President has been accused of spending too much attention to foreign affairs.
"Politically, I can't see this happening until after November," said a Senate staff member, adding that the Administration and Congress would hesitate to make large new foreign outlays.
Indicating Congress's reluctance to make additional foreign-aid commitments, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, chairman of a Senate Appropriations subcommittee on foreign aid, said last week that Congress would not approve the Administration's proposal for a $12 billion appropriation for the world lender.
"There's just not the support on the Hill for it," the Vermont Democrat said.
 
'Pivotal Political Moment'
 If the Group of Seven nations fail to contribute to a stabilization fund, some economists say it is possible the money would come from the lending agency.
Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard economics professor who is an adviser to the Russian Government, said a stabilization fund should be set up within weeks rather than months because Russia's situation is so precarious as the nation swallows tough economic reforms.
"This is a pivotal political moment in Russia's history," Mr. Sachs said. "If the ruble starts strengthening, if goods come into shops, if the Government is bolstered to carry out further reforms, then they can succeed. If, on the other hand, sentiment turns negative, the ruble weakens and shops remain empty, then things can spin out of control."
He said Russia's recent reforms have slashed the budget deficit from 20 percent of gross domestic product to about 5 percent and are slowing the printing of money.
 
Billions Could Be Lost
 In January 1990 the Western industrial nations formed a $1 billion fund to help stabilize the Polish zloty as the post-Communist Government in Warsaw began a sweeping series of free-market reforms. Not a dollar of that fund was tapped because Poland's economic program quickly restored confidence in the zloty.
But American officials voice fears that billions of dollars could be lost from the proposed ruble-stabilization fund if it is established before the time is right. The concern is that the ruble will come under attack, and that large amounts of money from the fund will be spent to keep the ruble from plunging against foreign currencies.
"When you look at developments in the former Soviet Union, you see there is a lot of fog," said a German Finance ministry official who insisted on not being identified. "It has to clear up before there can be action like the zloty fund."
Advocates of a fund say little money can be lost because Russia would be prohibited from tapping the fund if it fails to comply with the lender's program. They say the only way the ruble would come under serious attack would be if Russia did not follow the program.
Some economists say a stabilization fund might not be needed.

HEADLINE: The Dow Is Virtually Flat, at 3,245.97

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks ended a volatile week on a steady note yesterday, with blue chips practically unchanged and the broader market showing a bit of weakness. The Dow Jones industrial average adjourned for the long weekend at 3,245.97, off just 0.68 point for the day but up 20.57 for the week -- a week that saw another record high.
Trading was choppy, with the market under pressure from the outset, as some investors sold to reduce exposure ahead of the three-day weekend, while others simply rotated out of growth issues into cyclical stocks. 
 Blue-chip issues recouped much of the day's losses on the strength of transportation stocks, particularly autos and airlines, and a firming of bond prices following weaker-than-expected industrial production data for January.
 
Big Activity in Auto Stocks
 Automobile stocks were active, with the Big Three carrying the market for the day, along with airline stocks. Chrysler rose 1 1/4, to 16 3/8; Ford Motor was up 1 7/8, to 37 1/8, and General Motors was up 1 1/2, to 38 1/8. The companies hogged three of the top five spots on the New York Stock Exchange active list.
Talk among analysts is that auto sales are expected to improve this spring as a result of the Federal Reserve's efforts to lower interest rates, and that the average car is now more than eight years old, so there is a replacement demand. Besides that, they note that the Japanese are raising their prices.
John H. Shaughnessy, senior vice president and director of research for Advest Inc., said he was surprised "that the market did not react more negatively to the poor 30-year auction on Thursday and the fact that interest rates are backing up." He added: "This has been an interest-rate-driven market, and if rates go up and the economy does not turn around, then equities would be in big trouble."
 
Losers Outnumber Gainers
 On the New York Stock Exchange the volume was 221 million, down from 230.9 million on Thursday. The Big Board composite slipped 0.57, to 228.16, with losing issues ahead of gainers by 902 to 786.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was down 1.21, to 412.48, and the American Stock Exchange index was down a point, to 414.27. Trading on the Nasdaq was active as the composite dropped 2.67, to 636.43, while the Russell 2,000 ticked up 0.2, to 211.56.
Analysts said soft bond prices kept stocks under pressure as yields rose, making bonds more attractive to investors looking for the best return.
 
B.P. Off 1 1/8, to 58 1/4
 In trading yesterday, British Petroleum fell 1 1/8, to 58 1/4, as analysts said the company was not ruling out a future dividend cut, following disappointing 1991 earnings results released Thursday. Traders said John Hervey, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., did not think that a dividend cut was likely but that it might not be as safe as he had thought.
Citing what he said was an accelerating earnings growth, Mark Gulley, an analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, raised his rating on Morton International, an industrial and consumer products company, to buy from hold. Mr. Gulley said investors were looking ahead at 1993 earnings as the company prepared to step up production of air bags for the 1994 car model year.
The stock was up 2 1/8 yesterday, to 62 1/2.

HEADLINE: Ex-Soviet Atom Scientists Ask Baker for West's Help

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHELYABINSK-70, Russia, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Some of the top nuclear bomb designers of the former Soviet Union, aware of Western concern that they not sell their expertise to hostile powers, presented Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today with a list of commercial scientific projects they were ready to work on if the West would just invest in them.
In a remarkable encounter, Mr. Baker became the first Western official known to have visited Chelyabinsk-70, a top-secret military nuclear complex near the old industrial city of Chelyabinsk in the Urals. Chelyabinsk-70 and other secret military towns were not listed on published Soviet maps. A Russian official said the numerical suffix on the name was for postal reasons. 
 The Russian nuclear bomb designers who greeted Mr. Baker appeared to be almost desperate in their desire to obtain civilian contracts from the West to keep themselves employed now that their own Government has announced major cuts in military projects. Mr. Baker seemed in tune with their desires as he told them of American and German plans to help create a "clearing house" for nuclear and other scientists in Russia.
 
Like a Salesman's Pitch

Speaking quickly, like a salesman who has only a few minutes to make his pitch, the chief scientist of the Chelyabinsk-70 weapons design center, Yevgeny N. Avrorin, presented Mr. Baker with a long list of commercial products that his scientists could produce if they had Western investors.
These included industrial diamonds, fiber-optical equipment, nuclear medical equipment and computer software that they hoped might particularly appeal to Japanese electronics companies.
 
'Remarkable,' Baker Says
 When Mr. Baker's motorcade arrived at the nine-story building in Chelyabinsk-70 where his meeting was held, every window in the structure was packed with scientists, technicians and secretaries, creating a remarkable multi-story tableau of smiling faces and waving hands. The vigor of the reception in sub-zero weather suggested that the Russian scientists saw the United States and the West as an answer to their economic woes.
"This is every bit as remarkable for us as is it for you," Mr. Baker said as he sat in front of a blackboard in a classroom filled with the most senior nuclear bomb designers of the former Soviet Union.
The scientists said the pay rate at their institute ranged from 857 rubles a month for technicians to 1,500 rubles a month for the top nuclear bomb designers. At one time these were impressive salaries, well above the average of about 300 rubles a month. But with the runaway inflation of the ruble, these salaries are no longer so privileged. Even with occasional bonuses and subsidized food and housing, the scientists said they were struggling to keep themselves afloat.
In his prepared remarks at Chelyabinsk-70, situated just east of the Ural Mountains in western Siberia, Mr. Baker told the scientists: "We know that right now your options at home are limited and outlaw regimes and terrorists may try to exploit your situation and influence you to build new weapons of war. We want to help you find new projects that will allow you to remain in your country and earn a decent living, applying your skills to the cause of science and peace, rather than forging weapons of war."
To do that, Mr. Baker said, the United States and Germany, in coordination with Russia, will discuss how to establish "an international scientific center" in Russia that might also have branches in other former republics.
 
Clearing-House Role Seen
 "The center would play a clearing-house or facilitating role," Mr. Baker said. "It would receive, review, generate and fund proposals for projects. It would help match projects with qualified scientists and individuals and monitor projects to insure proper use of funds. Actual projects themselves could be carried out by top scientists throughout the new independent states. It would be open to scientists from all the new independent states."
Chelyabinsk-70 is one of two nuclear bomb designing complexes in the former Soviet Union, the other being Arzamas-16, situated near the Volga River. A sister city about 20 miles away, Chelyabinsk-65, actually manufactures the nuclear bombs designed here and was visited by a Senate delegation in January.
The Chelyabinsk district was the site of one of the worst nuclear accidents in history in 1957 -- worse even than Chernobyl, although it was not reported at the time. Some stored nuclear waste exploded, irradiating a wide trough of territory and forcing the evacuation of some 30 villages.
Mr. Baker flew from Dushanbe, Tajikistan, this morning, where he was on a tour of Central Asian republics, to Yekaterinburg, one of the chief cities in the Urals. From Yekaterinburg, formerly known as Sverdlovsk, he drove for two hours south through a forest of pine and fir trees to Chelyabinsk-70, which consists of about 100 acres of buildings and apartment houses surrounded by double barbed-wire fence.
 
Nods of Approval
 The 30-odd senior scientists gathered for Mr. Baker in Chelyabinsk-70 in the building known officially as the All-Union Scientific Research Institute for Technical Physics nodded their heads in approval at all of his remarks. But before Mr. Baker even began, Viktor Mikhailov, Russia's Deputy Minister for Atomic Energy, and Mr. Avrorin, the chief scientist at Chelyabinsk-70, presented the Secretary of State with what they described as a hasty translation of their own proposals for employment.
Mr. Avrorin explained that Chelyabinsk-70 is one of 10 closed military industrial cities spread around Russia and employs 16,000 people, about 9,000 of whom are technicians and 7,000 production engineers and scientists.
"Our institute is well equipped with scientific research equipment," Mr. Avrorin said. "This has come at great expense to our taxpayers, and we understand that now is the time to give this back. We have a huge scientific research potential, and therefore conversion to different types is not so painful. We have no shortage of ideas. But we have no sufficient financing for them."
He went on to tell Mr. Baker that the institute is interested in developing cooperation with foreign countries, particularly the United States.
Mr. Avrorin stressed that he and his colleagues were not looking for handouts and were not begging.
"It is important not just to have money for living, but also interesting work," he told Mr. Baker.
He said the center had been working to develop synthetic microscopic diamonds that could put an edge on knives that would never have to be sharpened. The center, he said, has also done sophisticated work on fiber optics and various applications of nuclear medicine and nuclear magnetic resonance. He also suggested joint mathematical research between Chelyabinsk and Los Alamos, the American nuclear weapons laboratory in Mew Mexico.
Beyond seeking investors for such commercial applications, Mr. Avrorin asked Mr. Baker to help provide government guarantees for potential investors, as well as customs and tax breaks to make such deals more attractive. To coordinate the proposals, he suggested "a bilateral commission" of American and Russian scientists quite similar to what Mr. Baker was suggesting.
 
No Commitment by Baker
 Mr. Baker did not commit himself in any way, although he promised to study the Russian proposal carefully. He said that an American arms control team would meet him in Moscow on Monday for talks on this subject with the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, and that at that time they would try to begin formalizing some arrangements for cooperation.
Vladislav I. Nikitin, deputy director of the institute, told reporters that as far as he knew no former Soviet nuclear bomb designers had been approached yet by foreign powers. He said that for now, leaving Russia for more money abroad did not appeal to the premier scientists working at Chelyabinsk.
Mr. Nikitin said, "All the noise about the brain drain is having an influence on the state of mind of our scientists and is now driving this process."
He maintained that since 1988, Chelyabinsk-70 has been converting its research to civilian applications and that now roughly 50 percent of its research was military and 50 percent non-military. The problem, he explained, was that conversion to civilian projects was expensive, and without commercial customers there was no way for the institute to cover its costs.
 
Tour of Laboratories
 After Mr. Baker spoke with the scientists, he toured one of their laboratories, and was shown various experiments involving plutonium, uranium- 235 and tritium. While the buildings in the complex looked neater and more well-built and well-kept than the normal Soviet office block, they still had a 1950's feel about them, and there were few computers to be seen.
Before leaving, Mr. Baker asked his hosts if they would allow him to be filmed by an American network television crew as he visited a memorial to one of the founders of the Soviet nuclear program that is situated on the grounds of Chelyabinsk. The director said that he was very sorry but that absolutely no filming was allowed inside the gate. It had never been done, he said.
But as the director spoke, the other nuclear bomb designers sitting around him in the classroom began whispering, "Let him do it, let him do it." Finally, the director relented, and all the Russian scientists applauded.
"See, it is a new day," Mr. Baker said.

HEADLINE: Treasury Issues Mixed, With Bonds Rising

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, as short- to intermediate-term issues continued to fall while bonds staged a bit of a recovery.
While some market participants were cheered by the upturn in bond prices, economic reports released yesterday should have benefited the entire fixed-income market. 
 Traders said a rise in the midmonth survey of consumer attitudes by the University of Michigan, even though it was tiny and confidence remains at a very low level, was not welcome news. It suggested to traders that consumers may begin spending more in the future, which could ignite inflation, the foremost concern of credit market participants.
Two other reports yesterday, however, suggested that inflation would remain under control for the foreseeable future. Producer prices fell three-tenths of a percent in January, and industrial production dropped nine-tenths of a percent, steeper than most forecasts had projected.
The implications of the numbers, however, were lost on traders.
"This market is getting great news and it keeps going down," said Jay Goldinger, a principal at Capital Insight, a bond brokerage firm in Beverly Hills, Calif. "I don't think I want to be around when it gets some bad news."
The only piece of information that did seem to please traders were rumors that the Fed had bought for a customer as much as $1 billion worth of Treasury securities with maturities from 2 to 30 years. A spokesman for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which handles such trades, would not comment on the rumors.
But the talk had a salutary effect on bond yields, which earlier in the day breached 8 percent for the first time since late November.
"The rise above 8 percent triggered some bottom fishing, and that helped stabilize the market," said William V. Sullivan, Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds.
The bulk of yesterday's activity was telescoped into the morning hours. On the recommendation of the Public Securities Association, an industry trade group, trading in Government securities stopped at 2 P.M., Eastern time, to observe the long Washington's Birthday weekend. The market will be closed Monday.
At the close of trading yesterday, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 1002/32 , up 6/32 , to yield 7.90 percent, compared with 7.91 percent late Thursday. But the rise in yields over the course of the last week has been steep: on Feb. 7, bond yields were at 7.75 percent.
In the secondary Treasury note market, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 10025/32 late yesterday, up 1/32 , to yield 7.38 percent. But prices of the 6 1/4 percent five-year notes fell by 1/8 point, to 9813/32 , to yield 6.63 percent. And the 4 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 9910/32 , down 2/32 , to yield 5.24 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged to up slightly.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 3.79 percent, up 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged at a late offered rate of 3.89 percent.

HEADLINE: Dusseldorf Journal;
A Would-Be Conqueror Is Now Russia's Booster

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUSSELDORF, Germany

 BODY:
Friedrich Wilhelm Christians was a young panzer commander when Hitler invaded the Soviet Union in 1941 and his force was ordered through the Ukraine to Baku, Azerbaijan, places he says younger Germans barely know.
At the end of the war he was stationed near Konigsberg, today Kaliningrad, then surrounded by advancing Soviet forces, until he and a comrade jumped on a tramp steamer that took them across the Baltic to Sweden to escape the Soviet onslaught. 
 Twenty-four years later, in 1969, Mr. Christians was the first German banker to go back to the Soviet Union, to negotiate with the Soviet Government the first of many immense deals involving German deliveries of industrial goods, like steel pipes, in exchange for raw materials like natural gas. Over the years, Mr. Christians, who is now chairman of Deutsche Bank, Germany's largest, made dozens of trips to Moscow.
 
A Competitive Edge
 Mr. Christians, who is 69 years old, is one of a number of German business leaders who have personal histories and experiences that seem to give them an advantage over their business competitors in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. Further, the background of men like Mr. Christians seems to enable them to meet some of the concerns raised by Germany's history in Eastern Europe at a time when rising German investment is generating some anxiety in the region.
Mr. Christians's background, for example, left him a major advocate of German trade with Eastern Europe. In the early 1980's, this embroiled him in a political controversy that split the Reagan Administration and the Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt over construction of a new gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.
Washington said the multibillion-dollar deal, financed by German banks led by Deutsche, gave the Soviets Western technology and a cash boost at a time of major Soviet rearmament under Leonid I. Brezhnev and would heighten West Germany's economic dependence on the Soviets. The Germans denied that the impact of the deal was that great or that it jeopardized Germany's reliability.
With the opening under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Mr. Christians took a particular interest in Kaliningrad and the Baltic shore he had come to know as a young officer. On a trip to Moscow in 1988, he proposed to Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze that the city be transformed into a kind of free trade and settlement area, a major port linking the old Soviet republics with Scandinavia, Poland and Western Europe. Together with German friends, he founded a Konigsberg Initiative.
"My proposal was: no re-Germanization, but a Europeanization," Mr. Christians said, sipping tea in his Dusseldorf office. "Konigsberg should be restored as a great port, an exchange for people, ideas, capital and goods."
In this, Mr. Christians was little different from many German businessmen, who acquired some ties to the east while serving in armies in the Soviet Union or languishing in prisoner of war camps, some even learning scraps of pidgin Russian.
Since the Soviet coup last August, Germans have been returning to Konigsberg in increasing numbers, only to be depressed on finding a region swept of its German cultural heritage, he said.
 
Cut Off From Birthplace
 "The younger they are, especially those 30 and 40 who were born in Kaliningrad, the more open they are. Recently I had a visit from a young artist and his student friend. They were proud of the city's historical past.
"But with the older generation it's different. Shevardnadze once said to me that for them, Kaliningrad remains a trophy of the war."
For some people engaged in business, Eastern Europe was the place of their birth, though the loss of German lands after the war meant they could not return for many years. Count Ferdinand von Ballestrem, for instance, was born in Breslau, today Wroclaw in Poland, in 1943, just before Hitler declared it a fortress in a last, futile attempt to halt the invading Russians.
His family settled in Silesia around Gleiwitz, today Gliwice, in the mid-18th century and built up the coal mining and steel making industries.
But after World War II, the family was driven out and its properties, including coals mines and steel mills that at their peak employed some 40,000 people, were nationalized by Poland's Communist Government. Silesia's wartime industries, sapped of German labor, used forced labor during the war, and anger ran high toward industrialists after the war. Count Ballestrem concedes that had family members remained, "they would not have survived."
Until 1975, he and his family were refused entry to Poland, though he now travels there freely. Today he is a senior executive at Ferrostaal, one of Germany's largest steel trading companies, which is deeply engaged in Poland's economy by arranging so-called triangular deals to offset chronic cash shortages. Typically, Ferrostaal buys Romanian crude steel, delivers it to Canada, and uses the proceeds to purchase Polish railway wheels that it then delivers to the Romanians, for a fee.
Now he is helping to establish a management school at Poland's Catholic University in Lublin, and together with other German businessmen has organized courses in Poland and in Germany to teach Polish executives Western business practices.
But he discounts a large investment stake by Ferrostaal in Poland. "Even if they gave us their factories for one mark," he said, "we do not have the billions needed to get them running again.
"Things have been so totally turned around that we must now try to cooperate so that some day it would be possible for a German to live and work in Wroclaw or Katowice just as he would in Paris or New York, or Liege."
He recalled that Liege, in Belgium, had once been part of the German Reich, too, but added, "Certainly, this is far more difficult."
"Naturally, a Pole who thinks in the categories of 1945 sees a criminal in every German," he said. "It's our job to bring them to the year 1992."

Darchinger for The New York Times), a German who was born in Poland, have gone back to those countries to conduct business.

HEADLINE: Study Says Recession Wiped Out 80's Boom in Cities

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 14

 BODY:
While the entire region has suffered from employment losses during the recession, the sharpest drops have struck the cities, with some declines so steep that they wiped out in a year or two all of the gains of the boom years in the mid-1980's, according to a university report released this week.
A study focusing on New Jersey by a team of Rutgers University researchers shows that Newark, Jersey City, Paterson, Elizabeth, Trenton and Camden, the state's largest cities, were rescued from "an economic free fall" by the strong growth that began in 1982. But after peaking in 1989, each of the cities fell back to a lower level of employment than they showed in 1982.
 
Boom's Heroes Are Villains
 Suburban private employment similarly peaked in 1989, and then dropped by 2.3 percent in the following 12 months. But for the cities, the job loss amounted to nearly five percent of their total. 
 The report, "New Jersey Cities in the 1980's, an Economic Report Card," was written by James W. Hughes, a professor of urban planning, and Joseph J. Seneca, a professor of economics. It is part of the Rutgers Regional Report, a periodic study of regional economic and planning issues. The release of the report coincides with the third anniversary of the onset of the recession, which economists measure from February 1989, the peak employment month for the region.
Mr. Hughes said in an interview that the villains in his bleak urban employment review were easy to spot: they were the heroes of the boom years.
"Defense, financial services, real estate, broad service growth -- they were the economic locomotives that powered the 80's, and they are all derailed," he said. "Now we are all desperately looking for new sources of motive power to put us back on the tracks."
Figures provided by state and Federal labor statisticians show that the Rutgers report's analysis of New Jersey's urban employment holds broadly true for the rest of the region, notably New York City, although over a longer period. The city's private employment grew to 3 million in 1989 from 2.8 million in 1982, only to fall back to below the 1982 level last year, according to preliminary figures for 1991 from the State Department of Labor.
But because of the relative employment strength of upstate cities, Buffalo, Syracuse, Rochester and the Utica-Rome area, New York State's overall urban private employment managed to hold on to most of the gains of the 1980's. The three biggest upstate cities, Buffalo, Rochester and Syracuse, all profiting from liberalized trade policies with Canada, saw their total private, non-agricultural employment rise from 964,000 in 1982 to 1.13 million in 1989, the level at which they remained with only a slight decline through 1991.
 
Few Cities Improved
 Yet of the 17 biggest centers of non-government employment in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, only four -- Buffalo, Syracuse, Utica-Rome and Newark -- improved their employment from 1989 to 1990, and then by only small margins.
Employment outside of government in Connecticut shows a steady loss of jobs in the cities. Hartford, Bridgeport, New Haven, Stamford and Waterbury grew from 837,800 total employment in 1982 to a peak of just over 1 million in 1989, and then fell back 995,300 in the following year.
Because of different methods used to collect them, the employment figures are not directly comparable from state to state. But they accurately reflect employment trends within the states. Economists tend to focus on private employment as the best indicator of economic performance, because government employment does not respond to general economic conditions as quickly.
According to the Rutgers report, the strong growth of the 1980's came just in time for New Jersey's cities. The steady losses in manufacturing employment and the drain of retailing into suburban malls contributed to the loss of 49,000 jobs, 13.9 percent of the total, from the six cities between 1975 and 1982, a period when most of the country was recovering from recession.
"Thus, during the second half of the decade of the 1970's and the early yeas of the 1980's, New Jersey's cities were arguably close to economic free fall, led by employment declines in Camden and Newark approaching 25 percent," it said.
The boom years carried over into the state's cities, with employment increases led by services, transportation and construction, the report said.
"Thus, a rising economic tide did raise all ships, including the state's urban centers, albeit at a much lower rate of increase compared to the gain experienced everywhere else in New Jersey," the report noted.
The authors doubt the state will see a spurt in employment like the one of the last decade anytime soon.
"That period is history," said Mr. Hughes. "We may have bottomed out but we still haven't recovered yet, and meanwhile we're still grasping for the idea that will pull us out, the idea of the 90's. But I haven't seen it yet."

HEADLINE: Oil and Auto Industries See No Gain From Alcohol Fuel

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
The domestic automobile and oil industries have issued a study that purports to show that cars fueled with a mixture of alcohol and gasoline emit more smog-causing chemicals and are more costly to run than those using on reformulated gasoline.
But the conclusion was immediately criticized by the chairman of the California Air Resources Board and representatives of the alcohol industry. They said the data were meaningless because they were based on older cars with obsolete pollution control systems. 
 The immediate criticism may keep the study from doing what oil company representatives said was its primary objective: to influence legislators and regulators in setting air emissions standards. With a huge investment in gasoline production, they oppose subsidies or mandates that promote the use of alcohols, like methanol, in motor fuels.
"On the Federal level, these results should make clear to our lawmakers that legislation for large methanol subsidies or mandates to compel the use of methanol-fueled vehicles are not in this nation's best interest," James W. Kinnear, the president of Texaco Inc., said in a statement.
He also said states, especially those in the Northeast, should be wary of adopting California emissions standards that promote the use of alternative fuels.
But Jananne Sharpless, the head of the California board, said the agency "has already established that emissions from a methanol-powered vehicle are 50 percent less smog-forming than the same volume of emissions from a gasoline-powered car."
The study is part of a joint research effort undertaken by the auto and oil industries in October 1989. One part examines emissions, while two others examine the economics of converting cars to operate on methanol fuel and the costs of operation. More reports are expected in the future.
"The basic conclusion is that there will be no environmental benefit to buying a flexible-fuel vehicle, but it will cost more," said John J. Wise, the vice president for research for the Mobil Oil Company.
 
Results Are Surprise
 "It shows that ozone would increase 26 percent in Los Angeles" with methanol as a fuel, said Robert Trunek, senior vice president for technology at ARCO. Ozone is one of the key components of atmospheric smog. "That came as a surprise," he added. "Most people anticipated a decline."
The study also show that reformulated gasoline would cut ozone-forming emissions in the same region by 26 percent. "That's a 52 percent swing in ozone between reformulated gasoline and methanol," Mr. Trunek said. "That is a very surprising and significant finding."
But Raymond A. Lewis, the president of the American Methanol Institute, said the study gave a misleading picture of emissions. He said it included cars from the early 1980's, whose fuel handling and emissions control systems were not well adapted to any fuel other than gasoline.
Helen Petrauskas, Ford's vice president for environment and safety engineering, said the real message of the research was that "both methanol and gasoline are showing more promise than anyone thought a few years ago."

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Fell In January

BYLINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14, Reuters

 BODY:
Wholesale prices fell for the second straight month in January, the Government said today, another sign that the sluggish economy is holding inflation in check.
 The Labor Department said the Producer Price Index fell three-tenths of 1 percent after a revised decline of one-tenth of 1 percent the prior month. The department had previously said that wholesale prices fell two-tenths of 1 percent in December.
 The drop continues a trend established last year when wholesale prices posted their first annual decline in five years.
 
Some Worrisome Data
 Nonetheless, the report was not all good inflation news. If volatile food and energy prices were excluded, the wholesale price index rose three-tenths of 1 percent in January, the department said.
 In comments on the economy today, President Bush chose to emphasize Thursday's reports that showed a jump in retail sales in January and a decline in weekly claims for jobless benefits.
He said things were looking up, and he called on Democrats to approve his anti-recession tax cut plan.
 "The economy is getting ready to move," Mr. Bush said, speaking in Belcamp, Md. "Interest rates are down. Inflation is down. Everything is not all gloomy. What it needs is a stimulative push right now."
 Officials of the Bush Administration, hoping to put some life into the economy by the November election, have been urging the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates further. The latest reports offer few obstacles to further cuts, but it is far from clear that the central bank -- where officials have expressed concern about the anemic economy -- will ease credit again.
 Three years of slow growth or recession are having an impact on prices from trucks to computers and gasoline. The last time wholesale prices rose was in October.
 
Energy Prices Drop
 The January drop in producer prices came as energy prices fell 2.8 percent after declining 1.4 percent in December. Energy prices have fallen 10 percent since January 1991, when the Persian Gulf crisis sent the cost of oil soaring.
 Gasoline prices fell 7 percent last month, far more than December's 1.6 percent drop, and prices for natural gas, electricity and home heating oil also fell.
 Food prices fell for the eighth time in nine months, sliding three-tenths of 1 percent as producers got less for eggs, pork, chicken and citrus. Fresh vegetable prices rose.
 Car prices were up 1.5 percent in January after remaining unchanged in December. Car prices have risen 3.5 percent in the last 12 months, the department said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Shrugs Off New Data and Ends Day With a Gain

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed higher yesterday after first falling in response to two economic reports and then recovering as the market gave more weight to upbeat retail sales figures issued Thursday.
Gold prices fell in New York and overseas. Gold dropped $2.20 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $353.70. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $353.25, off $2.10. 
 Analysts said the dollar fell after the Government reported industrial production slipped nine-tenths of 1 percent in January, a sharper drop than the five-tenths that the financial markets had generally expected.
The Labor Department's report that producer prices fell three-tenths of 1 percent last month, another larger-than-expected decline, also took the dollar lower.
Weak production levels and a cooling of inflation give the Federal Reserve more leeway to lower interest rates, and lower rates would tend to depress the dollar's value.
But the market's surprise soon wore off. Traders shrugged off the latest figures and instead focused on Thursday's report of a healthy gain in retail sales last month.
Revitalized spending by consumers raised hopes that the economy would turn around and that interest rates would halt their decline.
Walter Simon, a vice president with Bank Julius Baer & Company in New York, said the dollar was also helped by rumors that the Fed had entered the market to push the currency up.
At the same time, he said, there was concern that central banks might intervene to stop the dollar from climbing too high. The dollar has surged recently amid signs the economy might be recovering.
The dollar rose to 1.6265 marks in New York, from 1.6240 late Thursday. In earlier European trading, the dollar rose to 1.6285 marks from 1.6230.
The dollar also advanced against the Japanese yen, rising to 127.80 yen in New York from 127.65 yen. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose 0.62 yen, to 127.95. Later, in London, it fell to 127.80 yen.
The British pound fell against the dollar, slipping to $1.7715 in New York from $1.7725. In London, the pound fell to $1.7685 from $1.7730.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.4650 Swiss francs, up from 1.4600; 5.5370 French francs, up from 5.5310; 1,221.25 Italian lire, up from 1,220.50; 1.18665 Canadian dollars, up from 1.18625.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A Days Inns Executive Is Promoted to President

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Hospitality Franchise Systems Inc. yesterday promoted Doug Collins to be president of its Days Inns of America unit. Mr. Collins had been senior vice president and chief financial officer of Days Inns since 1990.
Hospitality Franchise acquired Days Inns last month for $259 million from the Tollman-Hundley Lodging Corporation. Hospitality, a wholly owned subsidiary of a unit of the Blackstone Group investment firm, also owns the Ramada and Howard Johnson hotel chains. All three hotel chains operate as franchisers. 
 With the acquisition of Days Inns, where the average room rate is $40 a night, Hospitality has 2,300 franchised properties, with Days Inns accounting for 1,250 hotels.
Days Inns, which is based in Atlanta, has been hard hit by the weak economy, along with the rest of the lodging industry. The average hotel was only 60 percent full last year, and Mr. Collins said Days Inns' occupancy rate was in line with the industry average.
Mr. Collins added that "1990 and 1991 have been very difficult years for the hotel industry." Still, he said, there were some signs that business and vacation travel were picking up in recent months. "We like to think we have hit bottom," he continued. "We are guardedly optimistic about the future."
Most of the chain's hotels are in the United States, but the company is starting to expand in India. Mr. Collins said that 25 percent of Days Inns' franchisees were Asian-Americans and that an Indian franchisee in the United States was trying to popularize the hotel chain in India. There is one Days Inns in India, and five more are planned.
Before joining Days Inns two years ago, Mr. Collins was president of Imperial Hotels, a 50-hotel chain.
Mr. Collins is a certified public accountant with an M.B.A. from George Washington University. He and his wife, Peggy, have four children and live in Atlanta.

HEADLINE: Paying Off a Loan Early Can Hurt

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
As people race to refinance loans to get better interest rates, some may end up paying hundreds or even thousands of dollars in hidden interest charges because of an accounting method used by some lenders.
The method, known as the "rule of 78's," inflates the amount of interest that the borrower must pay if the loan is paid off or refinanced early in its life. The procedure is generally not used for first mortgages, but some lenders use it for second mortgages, home equity loans and loans for cars, boats and mobile homes. 
 The term "rule of 78's" refers to a formula used to compute the interest. Though it is forbidding to any but those with plenty of sharp pencils and a penchant for precise figuring, here is a primer:
Using a 12-month loan as an example, the numbers 1 through 12, each representing a month, are added together -- 1 plus 2 plus 3, and so on -- yielding a sum of 78. If the borrower pays off or refinances a loan after one payment, he is assumed to have paid 12 seventy-eighths (about 15 percent) of the total interest owed; after two payments, 12 seventy-eighths plus 11 seventy-eighths, and so on.
 
The Unpaid Principal
 In effect, the formula credits the borrower with paying more of the total interest bill -- and thus less of the principal -- in the early payments. So if he pays off the loan in the early months, he will find that he owes more principal than if the loan carried simple interest.
The inflation in the interest is typically highest about a third of the way through the loan. With a large, long-term loan, it can amount to thousands of dollars.
Take, for example, a 15-year $30,000 loan for a mobile home at 16 percent interest. If the procedure in the rule of 78's is used, a consumer who repaid or refinanced the loan after five years would pay an extra $4,595 in interest. With other accounting methods, like simple interest, there is no hidden charge.
"The bottom line is that the rule of 78's is a consumer rip-off," said Margot Saunders, an lawyer at the National Consumer Law Center in Washington.
Even some lenders who use the rule are offering alternatives. The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, for one, is increasingly making car loans with simple interest, said Linda Kosinski, a spokeswoman. But the company does use the rule of 78's in several states, including Pennsylvania, and in the District of Columbia, she said.
Ms. Kosinski suggested that a car buyer ask the dealer if a simple-interest loan is available. "We think simple interest is more consumer friendly," she said.
At least 16 states, including New York, prohibit lenders from using the rule of 78's procedure. But it is permitted in many states, including Connecticut, and loans made in recent years in states that are phasing it out may still be affected by it, said the Consumer Federation of America, an advocacy group in Washington.
Consumer groups are concerned, too, because some courts have ruled recently that lenders in states that allow the method may use it on loans to people who live in states that prohibit it.
"The state laws aimed at outlawing these practices may not be protecting consumers," said Peggy Miller, director of banking issues for the Consumer Federation. She said the rulings may affect people who are thinking about refinancing loans, because any saving from lower interest rates may be offset by prepayment costs.
 
A Holdover From Hard Times
 The rule of 78's was adopted by lenders in the 1930's as a quick way to figure how much interest remained on loans when they were prepaid by borrowers. Personal and car loans were small then, and the rule of 78's was not considered unfair because it has little effect on refinanced loans that are small or short term. It also has no consequences for loans that are repaid over their full term.
But over the years, as loans lengthened in term and grew in size, the method's quirks became more apparent and more troublesome. The reasons are complex, but the method effectively allocates a larger proportion of a borrower's payments toward interest in the first years of a loan and less in later years.
So the formula's mathematical quirks also may make it less attractive to refinance a loan late in its life, because the effective annual percentage rate decreases over time.
For example, a 12-year 14.5 percent loan using the rule of 78's procedure is actually carrying an annual interest rate of 9.19 percent after nine years. So anyone who rushes out to refinance such a seemingly high-interest loan at 9 percent may be making a mistake, Ms. Miller said.
"You'll just extend the life of an existing loan without any benefit," she said.
 
 
A TIP: LOOK BEFORE LEAPING
 The Consumer Federation of America has this advice for those who want to refinance loans:
First, read your contract to see if the terms "rule of 78's" or "sum of the digits" appear. Even if they do not, ask the lender if your loan is bound by the rule of 78's. Lenders are not required to mark the loan documents.
Before you refinance or prepay, ask the lender to estimate in writing the amount of any penalty that would be invoked because of the rule of 78's. Use that as a guide to decide if it is worthwhile to switch to a lower-interest loan.
Make sure that your new loan uses a simple interest method, rather than the rule of 78's.

HEADLINE: MARATHON;
In Vietnam, Race Sets New Course

BYLINE: By BARBARA BASLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Le Buu was once a dedicated Vietcong guerrilla, fighting first the French, then the Americans, whom he called "the invaders."
But today, dressed in a dapper white suit and a pinstriped shirt, he greeted his former enemies as friendly competitors and welcomed them to the first Ho Chi Minh City International Marathon. The race will take place Sunday, with runners making their way through the heart of this elegant city, which residents still call Saigon. 
 When an American financial consultant who does business here first suggested the idea of a marathon, the Vietnamese were intrigued but skeptical. "They said, 'Will people come all this way to run in this heat?' " recalled the consultant, Bruce Aitken, who lives in Hong Kong. "I brought them running magazines and showed them there were marathons all over the world -- from Boston to Bangkok, London, Paris. And they got excited."
 
Sports as Marketing
 Because of its stumbling economy, Vietnam today is eager to rejoin the international community -- to attract foreign investors and foreign loans. It has made a number of conciliatory gestures, and this marathon, with its surrounding silk banners, dragon dances and schoolgirls in native costumes, is one more way to show its new attitude.
The marathon hoopla represents a real change for a country that only reopened its doors to tourists in 1987.
With more than 250 runners from 26 countries, this is the first major international sports event to be held in Vietnam since the fall of Saigon in 1975, said Buu, the director of the Ho Chi Minh City Sports Authority and the deputy chairman of the marathon.
It is a race rich with meaning, as veterans from both sides of the Vietnam War run side by side past old monuments and memories.
"I was a conscientious objector during the war, and I'm here racing with American veterans and Vietnamese veterans," said Bill Rodgers, the 44-year-old American who has won the New York City and Boston marathons. "I think we all feel this marathon is a symbol -- something to bring all of us together."
 
Embassy Is Course Landmark
 The course will take runners under the gracious shade trees of Le Duan Boulevard, past the former United States Embassy, whose rooftop landing pad was used to evacuate Americans and some Vietnamese when Saigon fell to the Communists from what was then North Vietnam.
The course runs along the Saigon River into the rice paddies of the countryside, then ends at the former Presidential Palace, now Reunification Hall.
While much of Vietnam remains impoverished, Ho Chi Minh City, with a population of almost 4 million, is the commercial heart of the country. It has bustling markets with stalls overflowing with fruits, vegetables, meats, pottery and even United States Army boots, backpacks and canteens left over from the war. The streets are filled with bicycles and motorbikes, and there are scores of discos, bars and nightclubs, one of the most popular being Apocalypse Now, named after the American movie about the Vietnam War.
Organizers say they expect crowds in the hundreds of thousands to line the marathon route. The Vietnamese Government has publicized the marathon in nightly television announcements.
 
Serious and 'Fun' Runners
 Buu said that while soccer is the most popular sport in Vietnam and running is a relatively new activity here, runners began to train as soon as news of the marathon was sent to all the people's committees in the provinces. Now, 92 Vietnamese will join the international runners in the marathon on Sunday, and 600 other Vietnamese are expected to compete in "fun" races to be held on Saturday. Buu said of his 92 countrymen, only 8 have run in a marathon before.
The race has had its problems. By international standards, the field is small, largely because of its distant location and the lack of corporate sponsorship.
"The big problem, of course, was that American companies, which are very generous about sponsoring sports events, were not allowed to sponsor this marathon because it was in Vietnam," Aitken said.
Aitken believes the event will probably lose money. "But I think for the runners, this will be fun and very, very successful," he said. "Despite our losses, we expect to hold another one next year."
For Buu, the race will show "we let bygones be bygones. We want people to understand our country. We want to create understanding and harmony."

HEADLINE: Production Down 0.9% Last Month

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Industrial production fell sharply in January, and factory utilization slid as businesses struggled to bring inventories -- particularly of cars and trucks -- back in line with sales.
The Government said yesterday that output fell by nine-tenths of a percent, its third decline in a row and the largest in 11 months. 
 Producer prices also slipped last month, thanks to sharply lower energy and food prices as well as the difficulty that many companies are having in raising prices. [Page 49.]
 
Looking Farther Ahead
 "Today's reports paint a bleak picture of the first quarter," James Annable, chief economist at the First Chicago Bank, said yesterday.
But economists are paying more attention to Thursday's reports that showed a pickup in car sales, consumer spending and money growth, all of which, they said, point to economic growth in the spring. The nation's auto makers said car and truck sales in early February were up 23.8 percent, while the Government said January retail sales grew six-tenths of 1 percent. As a recovery begins to unfold, spending typically picks up before production shows gains.
"The data hint at a possible turn in the economy, but a full-blown recovery is probably still a few months away," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch.
 
Harbingers of Spring
 Mr. Annable said: "The weak production numbers indicate where we are right now. The spending numbers are signs of spring, like twigs in swallows' beaks."
The Federal Reserve, Mr. Annable said, would probably focus on the more forward-looking indicators and not act again soon to reduce interest rates. The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, and his colleagues are acutely aware that the central bank's most common mistake has been to cut rates when the economy was too far into a recovery. Before the 1980's, the Fed often ignited inflationary booms by easing too much at the beginning of upturns.
"They believe they have gone far enough" in cutting rates for now, Mr. Annable said.
One reason is that the money supply has been growing briskly since early January, a trend that also points to more spending. For the first time in months, M-2, which includes cash and checking and savings accounts, is growing at the midpoint of its target range instead of at its lower end, the Federal Reserve reported on Thursday.
 
Goods Are Piling Up
 Last month's sharp production cutback was probably prompted by a pile-up of inventories before Christmas, Mr. Steinberg said. That pile-up, much bigger than assumed in the fourth-quarter report on gross domestic product released a couple of weeks ago, was reported by the Commerce Department yesterday. It could well result in an upward revision in the final report on fourth-quarter G.D.P., initially reported to have risen three-tenths of 1 percent after inflation.
Business inventories grew four-tenths of 1 percent in December, the fourth straight increase, while sales of manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers slid 1.7 percent. "Weak sales show that the inventory buildup was involuntary," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence.
The slump in industrial production reported by the Federal Reserve yesterday left the output of the nation's mines, factories and utilities only a tiny bit higher than it was when it hit bottom last spring. Auto production plunged 8 percent, to 5 million units at an annual rate, well below the recent sales pace.
The Fed also revised December's overall production rate to show a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent, double the drop of two-tenths originally reported. November showed a revised decline of three-tenths of 1 percent, rather than the two-tenths first reported. And October production was flat, after first being estimated as down one-tenth of 1 percent.
Breaking down the January output numbers, production of consumer goods fell seven-tenths of 1 percent, mining activity dropped two-tenths and utilities were off four-tenths of 1 percent.
Output of capital equipment other than computers -- mainly heavy machinery and transportation equipment -- also declined for the third month in a row. That suggests that investment spending by businesses is weakening this quarter. Even construction materials registered a drop, surprising because building activity has been strengthening recently.
The production cuts left factory utilization even lower than it was last spring when the overall economy hit bottom.The rate slumped to its lowest in more than eight years, with plants operating at just 78 percent of capacity, off from 78.8 percent in December. It was the lowest since the beginning of the recovery from the recession of the early 1980's.
Those figures suggest, Mr. Yardeni said, that any broad revival in manufacturing profits is still some time away. When there is plenty of capacity to spare, businesses have a hard time raising prices and that makes it difficult to increase earnings.
 
Stagnant Period Is Seen
 If sales to consumers and businesses keep firming and the housing market continues its recovery, Mr. Steinberg of Merrill Lynch said, industrial production could start moving up again in the spring. "In the meantime, output is likely to be flat or slightly down, " he said, as retailers and wholesalers struggle with an unwanted overhang of goods on their shelves.
The recovery in consumer buying, which perked up in January, is likely to proceed at a modest pace, he cautioned. The University of Michigan's latest poll of consumers, taken during the first part of this month, showed only a slight rise in confidence, indicating that consumers are still worried about their economic prospects.
The Michigan index of consumer sentiment ticked up a statistically insignificant six-tenths of a percentage point, to 68.1 from December's 67.5. That is well below last summer's levels, which were in the mid-70's, though not as dismal as the readings after Iraq invaded Kuwait in the summer of 1990.

HEADLINE: Bashing Lawyers. Also Justice.

 BODY:
Playing off public distaste for lawyers, the Bush Administration embraces "reform" of civil justice. "Let's stop America's love affair with lawsuits," the President says. And Vice President Quayle condemns the costs and delays of litigating civil cases. Bashing lawyers may be fun, but this campaign risks harm.
Lawyers have indeed encouraged an increasingly litigious society. But Mr. Quayle addresses himself mainly to richer Americans, like manufacturers, municipalities and doctors. He offers nothing for the poor and middle class who need lawyers but can't afford their fees. 
 Lawyers do extract costs from the economy. But they also police the marketplace, drafting and enforcing the contracts that make a $6 trillion economy function. Yes, many bright people are drawn to law at the expense of vocations that create wealth. But many lawyers, including Mr. Quayle, apply their skills outside the practice of law.
Mr. Quayle makes some harmful, some useful and some harmless proposals. The harmful include requiring a losing plaintiff to pay the defendant's legal fees, sharply curtailing contingency fees for lawyers and recklessly attacking punitive damages.
Supporters of the "loser pays" rule believe it discourages frivolous lawsuits. It also discourages legitimate but risky ones. Similar arguments apply to contingency fee arrangements by which lawyers get a percentage of the winnings, but only if they win. Such fees often provide the only access to justice for people without means.
Punitive damages -- awards over and above straight compensation for civil wrongs -- have sometimes spun out of control. Mr. Quayle wants states to limit punitive awards to the actual financial harm the plaintiff suffered. But what of a wrong that caused small financial harm but such distress that the jury wants to teach a lesson?
Mr. Quayle would encourage more programs for out-of-court resolution but doesn't propose funds to pay for them. He also refuses to seek long-deferred increases for Federal poverty law programs, which he unfairly derides.
The President, likewise, fails to distinguish between meritorious and meretricious suits. "Health costs would be an awful lot lower if we didn't have a lot of frivolous lawsuits going after those doctors for malpractice," he says. That assigns no blame to doctors who malpractice, only to suits charging malpractice. An overloaded civil justice system needs reform, not simplistic slander.
