HEADLINE: Keeping the Pipeline Filled at Merck

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

DATELINE: RAHWAY, N.J.

 BODY:
Every company has its legends. At Merck and Company the latest is about Proscar, the new drug that shrinks enlarged prostates and is awaiting Government approval. It involves a remote Caribbean mountain village with a population of male pseudohermaphrodites and an obscure medical paper about them. P. Roy Vagelos, Merck's chairman, seems never to tire of telling the story, and anyone inquiring about Proscar's prospects as the company's next billion-dollar megadrug is sure to hear it from other Merck executives as well. And no wonder, since the Proscar legend says a lot about survival in the bare-knuckles competitiveness of the drug industry these days, illustrating how basic research and unrelenting patience must be combined to bring a drug to market.
The story goes like this: In 1974, Dr. Julianne Imperato-McGinley of Cornell Medical College in New York told a conference on birth defects about a group of hermaphroditic children in the Caribbean. Appearing sexually ambiguous at birth, they were raised as girls. But at puberty they grew external genitalia and developed deep voices and male musculature. Her research group had found that a genetic trait caused a deficiency of an enzyme called 5-alpha reductase. This suppressed levels of the male hormone dihydrotestosterone, causing alteration of the male children's sexual development. 
 In the fall of 1975, copies of a monograph about the conference landed on the desks of Dr. Vagelos, then Merck's basic-research chief, and Glen Arth, a senior Merck biochemist. Like mosquitoes homing in on a picnic, they seized on a phrase in Dr. Imperato-McGinley's description of the children's physical characteristics when grown: "The prostate, however, remains small . . ."
Here, then, was a possible clue to a drug that would shrink an enlarged prostate, something that Merck -- and nearly every other drug company -- wanted to develop. If levels of dihydrotestosterone could be lowered with a drug that inhibited the enzyme's action, that drug would find an eager market among the 15 million American men plagued by enlarged prostate, an embarrassing and often painful condition which can block urine flow, interrupt sleep and cause serious infections.
 
Almost on the Market
 The rest, as they say, is history. Earlier this month, a scientific advisory committee at the Food and Drug Administration voted to recommend Merck's new prostate drug, Proscar, as safe and effective. The committee action makes it highly likely that the drug will win final F.D.A. approval, probably this summer.
On Wall Street, Merck in recent years has come to be regarded as almost god-like. Proscar seems likely to only burnish that image. Some analysts are predicting the drug will be generating $1 billion in annual revenues by 1996. If so, it will be following on the heels of other Merck blockbusters: Vasotec, a blood-pressure drug with $1.75 billion in sales last year, and cholesterol-lowering Mevacor, with $1.09 billion.
In fact, Merck is so wildly successful that increasing numbers of analysts, investors and competitors have begun to ask: How long can it keep winning?
"The big question for Merck is, 'What are you going to do for an encore?' " said Marc O. Mayer, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein, who, like most pharmaceutical-industry analysts, likes Merck's near-term prospects. On the other hand, said David Lippman at Dean Witter Reynolds, "I like Merck but I like Bristol-Myers Squibb better."
Pressures for lower drug prices are growing as fierce as the competition among the big multinational companies -- Merck, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Glaxo, SmithKline Beecham and Sandoz -- all of which are pouring billions of dollars into finding and marketing new drugs.
The pharmaceutical industry is also under increased scrutiny because of recent questions about the safety of products -- for example, Dow Corning's silicone breast implants and Upjohn's Halcion, a sleeping pill. But even industry critics generally give Merck good marks for its integrity and credibility. Merck "tends to be a lot less doctrinaire and more willing to consider the notion that safety sells products," said Linda Lipsen, Washington legislative counsel with Consumer's Union.
More bothersome is what Merck's next big drug after Proscar will be. "Merck does not appear to have other potential billion-dollar drugs that might be approved in the next two to three years," said Ronald Nordmann of Paine Webber Securities. Dr. Vagelos said he has the same concern, but he can take comfort from the fact that none of Merck's big drugs will lose their price-protecting patents until 1997, making it possible to keep its $1 billion-a-year research machine rolling, and to gear up for after-patent marketing. "It's a game we play," he said. "When patents end, we race to maintain the product flow."
And so far, Dr. Vagelos, a 62-year-old physician and biochemist who came to Merck in 1975 after stints at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., and Washington University in St. Louis, has a reputation for keeping Merck ahead of the pack. Profits rose 19 percent last year, to $2.12 billion on sales of $8.6 billion. The stock, having been split twice in just over five years, closed on Friday at $148.25.
 
The Price Pressures
 Drug prices have been increasing for years at double the general inflation rate. Seeking to blunt Congressional threats to crack down on the trend, Merck was the first to announce, in April 1990, its own price restraints and discounts for government programs for the poor.
Dr. Vagelos vowed that Merck's prices would rise no faster than overall consumer prices. Securities analysts note that Merck, which has 19 drugs each adding at least $100 million to annual sales, can well afford to take such a statesmanlike stance.
As for Proscar, which many patients are expected to take daily for the rest of their lives, Merck executives plan to use the occasion of F.D.A. approval to "make a statement." As Dr. Vagelos put it, "We plan to have a price that is affordable to the great majority of people throughout the developed world."
On top of the pricing pressure, Merck is also having to cope with what amounts to a sea change in how drugs are purchased. The nation's half-a-million active physicians are losing authority over prescriptions as hard-bargaining hospitals, employer-insurer groups and health-maintenance organizations dictate decisions and force price discounts.
Dr. Vagelos said the company is "working on promotion and marketing approaches that will reduce our costs and ultimately reduce prices." As it becomes less important for Merck to visit individual doctors, Merck will obviously need fewer sales people. But change "won't happen overnight," Dr. Vagelos said. "It may take years to get there."
In the meantime, Merck is planning a marketing blitz for Proscar, which must be taken for several months before showing results.
The goal, of course, is to wean urologists away from the alternatives, like Hytrin. Hytrin, an Abbott Laboratories blood-pressure drug, seems to bring immediate relief of prostate symptoms, but it has not been shown to shrink the prostate itself as Proscar promises to do. Pfizer has a similar blood-pressure drug called Minipress.
Meanwhile, SmithKline Beecham is conducting large-scale tests of its own prostate drug. Merck is rushing to develop a second-generation product to protect the Proscar franchise.
Inevitably, said Joyce Albers, an analyst at First Boston, "competition will gobble up some of the market" for Merck's big products. She noted that four similar drugs -- Bristol-Myers's Monopril, Warner-Lambert's Accupril, Hoechst's Altace and Ciba-Geigy's Lotensin -- are chasing Merck's best-selling blood-pressure treatment, Vasotec.
Vasotec, prescribed for people who have had serious heart attacks, is still far ahead of the others, Ms. Albers noted, and could pull further ahead if the F.D.A. approves its application for treating the less seriously ill.
As for Merck's cholesterol-lowering Mevacor, its other big earner, Bristol-Myers Squibb has dispatched squadrons of sales people to issue a challenge with Pravachol. The Bristol-Myers entry was approved by the F.D.A. Oct. 31 and sales may reach $400 million in 1992, analysts said.
Seeking profit-generating buffers, Merck has been entering into joint ventures that could produce revenue by mid-decade. DuPont Merck Pharmaceutical is developing new drugs from DuPont's well-stocked research pipeline, like the heart drug losartan. Merck and Johnson & Johnson are developing over-the-counter versions of Merck drugs like the ulcer treatment Pepcid to create new business as patents expire.
Merck is already benefiting handsomely from the American rights it obtained to sell the products of AB Astra, an innovative Swedish drug maker. Astra's Prilosec, another ulcer treatment, is already generating more than $200 million a year for Merck and the two companies plan to extend their partnership.
Dr. Vagelos said Merck is looking for other alliances and partnerships. "It does not make sense for the No. 1 company to have only 5 percent in worldwide market share and 9.5 percent in the U.S.," he said.
 
The Medical Process
 The F.D.A. committee's favorable decision on Proscar, delivered on Feb. 4, followed a dozen years of laboratory and animal experiments and then three years of testing the drug on more than 1,600 men through clinical trials around the world.
The prostate, a walnut-sized gland in the pelvis, produces fluid that helps to nourish and transport sperm. The gland surrounds the urethra, the tube that carries urine from the bladder through the penis.
More than 70 percent of men have enlarged prostates by the age of 65, a condition known as benign prostatic hyperplasia, or BPH. Men who live into their mid-80's have a 90 percent chance of developing the condition.
Urologists say about 25 percent of BPH cases can be life-threatening and up to 40 percent need surgery. A prostatectomy to treat BPH is the most common surgical procedure in American men over age 50; about 400,000 are performed each year at a cost of $3 billion.
Dr. Logan Holtgrewe, president-elect of the American Urological Association, said that while Proscar's expected approval appeared encouraging, the enlarged prostate is a long-term disease. "We don't know how these drugs are going to play in the long run," he said.
Seeking to answer such questions -- and obtain scientific ammunition for its marketing efforts -- Merck is starting a four-year study involving more than 3,000 patients at 100 medical centers. It will, not incidentally, introduce dozens of influential physicians to the new drug.
In the data presented to the F.D.A. advisory committee, Merck said that Proscar reduced prostate gland size by at least 20 percent in more than half of patients after six months.
The company said 57 percent of patients who took the drug once a day for six months had improved urine flow and 71 percent experienced lessened urinary distress symptoms. Of these, about one-third had improvement considered to be excellent.
As to side effects, Merck said there could be danger to a male fetus in a woman who had been impregnated by a man taking the drug. And sexual dysfunction, mainly impotence, among patients taking Proscar was twice the rate found in those in the same age group who were taking a placebo drug. The dysfunction was "reversible" if a patient stopped taking the drug.
So far, Proscar has not been shown to either prevent or treat cancer of the prostate, which strikes 122,000 men a year and kills 32,000. But Gary H. Rasmusson, the Merck biochemist who synthesized Proscar, said the company hopes to develop a cancer drug using approaches somewhat similar to that of Proscar.
 
The 'Dream Team'
 Dr. Vagelos, who must retire at age 65 in November 1994, is nurturing a group of younger executives he calls his "dream team." They include Richard J. Markham, 41, marketing director; Edward M. Scolnick, 51, research director; John L. Zabriskie, 52, manufacturing chief, and Jerry T. Jackson, 50, who supervises animal and farm drugs, vaccines and deals with other drug makers.
Dr. Vagelos grew up in the shadow of Merck's Rahway headquarters, serving coffee and pie in the family luncheonette after classes at Rahway High School. He waited on tables to help pay his way at the University of Pennsylvania and the College 0f Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University.
After joining Merck, he immediately applied his faith in the notion that important therapies could be based on drugs that would manipulate human enzymes. The work that produced Proscar was just one example. "The same strategy gave us Mevacor," he said.
When he retires, Dr. Vagelos will be out of the loop at Merck for the first time in 19 years. But he expects Proscar to remain part of his life. "Like a lot of males, I'll be taking the drug," he said.
 
 
THE JAPANESE CONNECTION
 Unlike many American companies, Merck sees Japan as an opportunity, not a threat. Its Banyu unit is No. 11 among drug makers in Japan, the world's second-largest pharmaceutical market after the United States.
Banyu's 1991 sales were $800 million, representing 10 percent of Merck's worldwide revenues. Merck acquired majority ownership of Banyu in 1984, becoming the first and only American company to take control of a "first-tier company on the Japanese stock exchange," as P. Roy Vagelos, Merck's chairman, put it. It may also be the last. Dr. Vagelos recalls that after the deal the chief executive of a major Japanese company, whom he declined to name, said crisply: "It will never happen again."
Banyu hopes to be one of Japan's five largest drug makers by the year 2000. It will benefit this year from the recent approval in Japan of Zocor, one of Merck's two cholesterol-lowering drugs. In a uniquely Japanese setback, approval of Proscar "probably lost two years," Dr. Vagelos said, because of "laboratory aberrations," now corrected, he said.
In Japan, drug makers hand over new products for testing by an independent, Government-paid professor. Japan does not accept F.D.A.-approved testing, and the F.D.A. seldom accepts Japanese testing.
Japanese doctors make much of their money by filling their own prescriptions. The Government pays for all drugs, and sets prices, starting high for new drugs, but cutting prices for older products every two years. Merck's antibiotic Primaxin, for instance, took a 16.9 percent cut in 1990.
Merck is opening a new cancer and heart research laboratory at Tsukuba in April. It licenses one of its big products, the ulcer treatment Pepcid, from Yamanouchi of Japan. Analysts said Pepcid generated $595 million in 1991 sales for the American company.

HEADLINE: At Work;
When Japan Inc. Comes to America

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
Jiro Ishizaka has an American-style work schedule. Does this mean that Mr. Ishizaka works a little Tuesday through Thursday, but saves most of his energy for planning, executing and recovering from a weekend carouse -- the portrait of the typical American worker drawn recently by a Japanese politician?
Not exactly. Mr. Ishizaka, the Los Angeles-based chairman of the Union Bank, which is 75 percent owned by the Bank of Tokyo, is a self-described "salaryman." Like other Japanese salarymen, he puts in a long day at the office. His schedule, Mr. Ishizaka believes, makes him much like many Americans. "Look at lawyers in the U.S.," he said. "They work so hard. They don't mind working through the night." 
 It is not at all clear that Mr. Ishizaka approves of anyone working through the night, and his sympathy seems to fly against the received wisdom that the cultures of work in Japan and the United States are antipodal. So does a survey of Japanese executives in the United States done recently by the Japan America Society of Southern California and Manning, Selvage & Lee, a public relations firm. It found that 94 percent of the 100 respondents had modified their management style as a result of living and working in the United States. And, the survey said, the executives had come to value the very American qualities -- assertiveness and individualism, for example -- that are often said to exasperate Japanese managers.
Japanese executives and Americans familiar with how Japanese companies do business abroad expressed little surprise at the survey's results. "As long as you do business here, you have to adapt to American practices," said Leo Shinozaki of the information arm of the Japan Federation of Economic Organizations. And no one thinks the dark, Satanic offices of Japan Inc. are going to empty out as salarymen start following their bliss or that the intricately braided ties between Tokyo and its corporate outposts are likely to come unbound anytime soon.
But to Americans accustomed to being on the rump end of Japanese public opinion, the idea that the Japanese find something to admire in their work culture comes as a surprise. "We didn't go in with any preconceptions," said Chris Doyle, who worked on the survey and said he was startled by the results, particularly by some of the respondents' suggestions: "Have equal opportunities for everyone." "Be more outspoken." "Stop thinking about seniority and how long you work for a company." "Be more openminded, have a more open system." "Have a more enjoyable personal life." "Emphasize play as well as work."
Will the national reptile of Japan soon change from Godzilla to the lounge lizard? Executives say that adapting to the style of the host country is simply commonsensical. "Americans working in Tokyo likewise have to adapt," Mr. Shinozaki said. Mr. Ishizaki, in his precise English, truncates a familiar phrase but the sentiment comes through: "You do as Romans do."
Nevertheless, the survey appears to be a very small indicator of an evolution in Japanese social attitudes taking place far from the feverish domain of Japanese-American economic relations. Change comes even to cultures with as abiding a respect for tradition, and bureaucracy, as Japan, and many say Japanese living abroad, especially in America, are the vanguard of that change.
"They return from their first or second assignment and give lessons to people who are still there," said Masaki Murakami, a general manager of Mitsui and Company in New York. For young Japanese, the fissures caused by cultural and political enmity are closing: "Younger people have so much exposure to America. They have learned from the American way." Mr. Murakami said he is more willing to delegate authority than he used to be and -- heretically -- no longer assumes a company should retain executives for life if they are unproductive.
All of this confirms the feeling of Union Bank's Mr. Ishizaka that Japanese and American styles are converging not diverging -- and that the generation entering the work force now will accelerate the convergence. Joseph Brunetto, president of JapanAmerica Communications, a publisher in Hartsdale, N.Y., compares the current restless generation of Japanese to Americans who came of age during the 1960's. "They grew up affluent. They are more expressive and they think of themselves more," said Mr. Brunetto, who lived in Japan for several years. They rebel by not going into companies, by traveling and by living in the United States. "These things would not have happened 20 years ago in Japan," he said.
 
 
 
THE DAMAGE DONE BY POLITICIANS
 The contretemps over Japanese criticism of American work habits has discomfited many Japanese executives in the United States. "It's a touchy subject," said Masaki Murakami, of Mitsui and Company. "Japanese companies are in an awkward position, and I think Americans working in the companies feel a little strange."
Some executives worry that with a few ill-chosen buzz words politicians at home have managed to undo years of business diplomacy. "Japan is the friend, not the enemy of America," said Jiro Ishizaka, chairman of the Union Bank, sounding like a man trying to make peace between a cobra and a mongoose. Mr. Ishizaka, who arrived in the United States on the day Richard M. Nixon was elected to his second term, has learned one of the most valuable American management techniques. He declared the recent cycle of criticism and wounded feelings between Japan and the United States overblown and blamed the news media: "The media always takes the most negative side," he said.

HEADLINE: Stop Beating Up on Employees

 BODY:
To the Editor:
When will corporate America wake up? Workers cannot give their most productive and creative performances within a system that holds them in utter contempt. ("Take This Job and Love It," Jan. 26) The International Business Machines Corporation has an annual review process that will assign failing grades to 10 percent of its workers. That I.B.M. is not unique is an American disgrace. Corporate America has a long tradition of beating up its workers, and this tradition is responsible for much of the economic malaise infecting this country. 
 Rather than inspiring employees to find new solutions to company problems, punitive grading systems insure that American workers will continue to be preoccupied with personal survival and spend most of their creative energies cultivating their bosses. But no matter how skillful, at I.B.M. 10 percent of the work force is set up to fail. Whether a worker survives or is turned out, most will vow never again to pour their hearts and souls into any kind of a corporate endeavor. I wonder if the real motivation of I.B.M.'s management is to turn workers into scapegoats for the company's well-publicized downturn.
Corporate America will become competitive only after it drums fear from the workplace and invests in systems allowing workers to win, not lose. When that happens, there will be no stopping us.
 
JANE MORRISS
Groton, Mass., Jan. 26
 
The author is former editor of employee communications at the Otis Elevator Company.

HEADLINE: Coins

BYLINE: By Jed Stevenson

 BODY:

Ration Coupons as Money
The breakup of the Soviet Union has created hope among collectors that each of the emerging republics will create several new coins and bills. So far this hasn't happened, and Ukraine's new use of rationing coupons as money doesn't go a very long way toward diversifying the currencies. 
 Ukraine has done the expedient thing and simply monetized what was in fact the main currency circulating there, although not officially recognized. Its old food-rationing tickets are now the unofficial money and are called coupons.
Rubles of the former Soviet Union are still in use throughout Ukraine, but Ukraine says that Russia didn't supply it with enough rubles in January to meet the higher demand for notes caused by rising prices. The shortage forced the Ukrainian Government to use the rationing tickets it had on hand as currency. Ukraine plans to issue a real national currency, to be called the hryvnia (pronounced HRIV-nee-uh), later this year.
The ration coupons were originally used to deter residents of the other republics, mostly Russians, from entering the Ukraine, snapping up Ukrainian goods cheaply and then returning to Russia. But lately, all salaries in the Ukraine are being paid in equal proportions of rubles and ration coupons.
The coupons, a little less than half the size of a United States dollar bill, show St. Sophia Cathedral in Kiev on the reverse. The front shows one of Kiev's founders, the denomination, and the word for coupon prominently displayed.
While these coupons fall under the numismatic category of emergency money, they still make up an officially recognized currency that trades at 16 to the dollar on the black market. But collectors, international banks and probably Ukrainians themselves are likely to be more comfortable with the hryvnia when it finally appears.
 
Trial $1 Coins Struck
 While Russia and the Ukraine struggle to straighten out their currencies, the United States Congress is again wrestling with the problem of the $1 coin. A proposal to stop printing dollar bills has been on the Congressional agenda for several years.
Those arguing for the dollar coin cite its usefulness for toll and vending machines. They also cite the high cost of printing paper money, which lasts only about 18 months while a coin typically circulates for about 20 years.
Those who oppose the introduction offer the example of the Susan B. Anthony dollar, which was minted only from 1979 to 1981, and was discontinued because of its unpopularity. Some thought it too small; previous silver dollars had been 50 percent larger. Others thought making the Anthony dollar compatible with vending and toll machines made it so similar in size to the quarter that they could not be distinguished easily. At any rate, 400 million of them sit idle in Government vaults, waiting for either a better day or a melting pot.
To promote public interest in a gold-colored $1 coin, the Olin Brass Corporation of East Alton, Ill., has struck a pattern piece of one possible design of a new clad coin and offered samples of it to the House Coinage Subcommittee for testing. Olin Brass now supplies the United States Mint with the copper-nickel alloy used in quarters, dimes and half-dollars.
Two examples of the trial coins were struck, one made of an alloy of copper, nickel and zinc, the other of aluminum and bronze. Both have a golden color and feel different from a quarter when touched blindly in a purse or pocket.
Olin's design features a Minuteman on the obverse and an eagle on the reverse. There is no denomination, so these trial coins cannot be confused with legal coins. Of almost 1,000 trial pieces minted, only about 200 have been handed out. Most of those were distributed for testing in vending machines and as souvenirs to members of the Coin Coalition, a group that advocates the adoption of a $1 coin.
Olin Brass says it isn't sure what to do with the rest, and may simply melt them down. So far the company hasn't given or sold any examples to coin collectors, not even collectors who are also company stockholders.

HEADLINE: Lives and Loves of Tall, Charismatic Presidents

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Social scientists," Leslie Hawke states (letter, Feb. 2), "should not ask whether or not Gov. Bill Clinton has had an affair, but whether or not there is a correlation between poor political leadership and infidelity. My guess is that they would find no correlation -- but what if they uncovered the opposite?" 
 We have been studying Presidential leadership from George Washington through Ronald Reagan. Our findings on this question are that there is no direct correlation between Presidents who have mistresses and objective measures of effectiveness in handling international, social-domestic or economic issues.
However, there is an indirect relationship. Presidents who are tall and have a reputation for being highly charismatic tend to have mistresses. Presidents who are tall and charismatic also tend to be better performers and to be rated as great or near great in surveys of political scientists. All of these findings are statistically significant, indicating that they could not have occurred by chance. Therefore, Presidents who are tall and charismatic are more likely to have mistresses and to be effective. As Ms. Hawke points out (and our data support her conclusion), "People who run for President are risk takers, and they love a conquest."
Perhaps having a mistress goes with the territory covered by effective Presidents.
 
ROBERT J. HOUSE
WILLIAM D. SPANGLER
Philadelphia, Feb. 7, 1992
 
The writers are professors at, respectively, the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School and the State University of New York, Binghamton.

HEADLINE: We Need a Real National Rebuilding Program

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It looks as if we will not see prosperity for a long time. The programs proposed are bits and pieces, which may be of help, but are more likely to give us what was called stagflation in the 1950's -- the continuation of an economy operating far below capacity. Something needs to be added to provide more jobs and invigorate the flow of goods and services.
An enormous area where unfilled needs might be used as the catalytic agent is the infrastructure. We have not properly maintained our assets nor kept pace with the requirements of change. 
 We are far behind in building and maintaining roads. Our bridges are a danger and a disgrace. Our schools have depreciated from lack of repair and are out of balance with population changes. Waste disposal is a critical problem. Many areas are sadly in need of decent low-cost housing. Our cities and towns have reached a frightening point of reduced staff and delayed maintenance.
In all these areas, the needs are clear, and there undoubtedly are plans for action in the files that could be quickly put to work.
The Federal Government is the only source for leadership in these national problems. However, it is difficult for it to act effectively so long as we are determined not to use the Government's borrowing capacity for these purposes. So far as economic recovery is concerned, we seem to be in a kind of gridlock.
It is a failure in recognizing our real priorities when the use of the nation's credit is allowed to prevent action needed to deal with economic recovery and the sorry state of our infrastructure. We need an effective government program aimed at providing a massive increase in jobs and purchasing power.
The program problem is not an either-or matter. The proposed bits-and-pieces analysis would still be carried forward. My suggestion is for a major addition to provide rapid action that would strengthen our infrastructure and put thousands to work. The direct and indirect effects of such pump priming would be widespread and visible.
 
WILLARD L. THORP
Pelham, Mass., Feb. 3, 1992
 
The writer, a retired professor of economics at Amherst College, was a member of Franklin D. Roosevelt's brain trust, 1933-35.

HEADLINE: For Some Seeking Presidency, Winning Isn't the Only Thing;
Another Campaign? Feelings Are Mixed

BYLINE: States News Service

DATELINE: Washington

 BODY:
THOUGH Senator Bill Bradley and Thomas H. Kean, then the Governor, are better known among those who filed as possible Presidential candidates in 1988, there were several other New Jerseyans who actually ran for President that year. They look back on the campaign with mixed feelings.
James R. Messenger of Piscataway, an Emmy Award-winning television producer, will not even discuss his 1988 race, which he said cost him $15,000 of his savings and taught him a few things about major party support of lesser-known candidates. 
 But Mr. Messenger, whose film work has twice earned Academy Award nominations, did send a reporter his well-designed press packet outlining a complete Presidential platform, as well as a statement explaining why he was no longer involved in politics.
"I ran as a Democrat for President in order to try and introduce into the Presidential campaign the true issues facing this nation," he said. "Unfortunately, no one was interested."
Although Mr. Messenger had sought major party support, he said official response was confined to a state party official announcing that he "didn't have a chance" to win a single vote.
"That was the extent of 'help' from the Democratic Party," Mr. Messenger said. "With all due respect, I have nothing else to say."
But there were some positive results. William Marra of West Milford, a philosophy professor at Fordham University, was the Right to Life Party candidate and the nation's ninth-highest vote-getter in the last Presidential race, earning 22,560 votes.
An articulate speaker who ran on a "Family First" platform, Professor Marra said minor party candidacies were needed to broaden the national debate, which he said remained fixed on economic issues.
He said he would probably not run again "unless someone comes up to me with $16 million in campaign funds," adding that he doubted that this would happen. "I never had any illusion that I would win, but I was glad to do what I could to call attention to other issues. But once is enough."
James Mac Warren, then a Jersey City resident, received 11,435 votes in 1988 as the Socialist Workers Party candidate. Though the national campaign was grueling, he said, it was "a very interesting experience."
"What you've got to understand is that most of the people we appeal to are those who have lost all interest in the political process," he said. "They see the other candidates as Tweedledee and Tweedledum."
Now living in Chicago, Mr. Warren said he would consider running again, if asked.
Running a minor party candidacy could also be considered fleeting fame. It was in 1984 that Dennis L. Serrette, also of Jersey City, received 50,000 votes as the first Presidential candidate run by what is now the New Alliance Party. In 1988, he became the only minor party candidate on the ballot in all 50 states, receiving 201,430 votes in the process.
But after months of searching in response to a reporter's inquiry, party officials have been unable to locate Mr. Serrette, who they say has not been seen nor heard from in years.
But there will always be Henry Krajewski, the pig farmer from Secaucus who ran for President several times beginning in the 1950's. "His legacy," said David A. Bositis, at thea senior research associate at the Joint Center for Political Studies in Wasahington, "is that his campaign buttons and souvenirs have become one of the rarest items among political memorabilia nationwide."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1314 words

HEADLINE: WINTER GAMES;
Democrats Dread a Season Without Heavy Hitters

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: HANOVER, N.H.

 BODY:
The not-so-secret secret of this year's Democratic Presidential campaign has been the reluctance of the party's A Team to take the field.
Is that judgment too harsh? Well, here's what Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska thinks of his main rivals, according to a radio commercial broadcast in New Hampshire this weekend: Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas? "His campaign is in trouble." Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts? "Another Massachusetts candidate who's strong in the Northeast but has little support in the rest of the country." Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa? "The kind of old-style Democrat who's failed before." All this from a candidate who himself has struggled to attract the support of one Democrat in 10 here -- yet still touts his electability. 
 "The campaign in this state began with the perception that this was a second-rate field," said Richard Winters, a political scientist at Dartmouth College. "During the last three or four months, the candidates haven't matured much. They haven't demonstrated a lot of depth. Some of them, like Clinton, haven't shown much judgment. So the initial impression has not been weakened, except for Tsongas, who has come into his own precisely because he has seemed calm and articulate and steady when the others have not."
The exigent voters of New Hampshire may have decided that none of the active combatants quite fills the bill. That's what many of them tell reporters who ask, and the polls strongly suggest that they are prepared to deliver an inconclusive verdict on Tuesday, with no runaway winner and no one knocked completely out of the race. Muddle, in other words. A much longer campaign than originally anticipated. And lots of pressure on the non-runners to think about late entries, as perilous a course as that obviously is.
 
Missing Personages
 Once upon a time, you could make a list of the Democrats' big guns, and it would be more or less the same as the list of Presidential contenders. In 1960, almost all the heavy hitters ran -- Johnson, Symington, Humphrey, along with a much less senior figure named John F. Kennedy. This year, the active field includes a former senator who left office in 1984, two relatively junior senators, a small-state governor and Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, a former governor who left office in 1982.
Absent from that list are Mario M. Cuomo of New York, the ranking Democratic governor; leading senatorial figures such as George J. Mitchell of Maine, Al Gore of Tennessee, Lloyd Bensten of Texas and Sam Nunn of Georgia; and the dominant figures in the House, including the speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, and the majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri.
One reason for the weak Democratic field, of course, is the vagaries of political timing. When Mr. Gore, Mr. Gephardt, Senator Jay Rockefeller of West Virginia and others were making their go/no go decisions, President Bush seemed all but unbeatable; only a few weeks later, he seemed highly vulnerable as the recession took an ever firmer hold on the country. But a larger factor, surely, has been the collapse of the party apparatus since 1972. Party elders once played a key role at several points of the nominating process, discussing among themselves the available talent, encouraging or discouraging candidates according to their views of what would appeal to the electorate, looking for skeletons in candidates' closets.
The process wasn't perfect by any means, but it provided a rudimentary screening process. Now there is something approaching self-selection for Presidential hopefuls, limited only by the ability to raise enough money to compete in Iowa or New Hampshire and some sort of minimal credibility.
With the proliferation of primaries, the role of the convention and the smoke-filled room has been minimized. The choice has usually been made long before the delegates assemble. In theory, the importance of primaries might have put a premium on having a national reputation before the campaign begins, but in fact television advertising, that maker of instant if insubstantial reputations, has made that unnecessary. It has also made money-raising one of the principal if least visible campaign activities.
Candidacies have become poll-driven and consultant-crafted, and those relatively new technologies have made long apprenticeships less vital. So a man like Bill Clinton, known only in his small home state and in professional political circles a matter of months ago, could not only run this year but find himself widely proclaimed, months before any votes were counted, as the front-runner, probable early victor and answer to his party's prayers for a new approach. Clearly, he has outstanding qualities, including an incisive, well-organized mind and a gift for leadership; the Rhodes scholarship selection committee recognized that when he was a lad. But under the old system, he would have found it hard to project them onto the national screen from Little Rock.
Under the old system the party elders would have looked into the reports, which everyone in politics had heard, about Mr. Clinton's marital problems and draft record, and at least tried to evaluate whether they were serious impediments to a candidacy. Under the old system, in which the candidates tended to be people already known to the public, the revelations that have undercut Mr. Clinton's standing might have been less damaging.
Only superficially known or understood, the out-of-nowhere candidate is vulnerable to being blown off course by the first puff of bad news.
None of this completely explains why many people think Mario Cuomo, say, is a man of substance and Bob Kerrey, say, is not. Most Americans, including those who want him to run, would be hard pressed to name Mr. Cuomo's main accomplishments as governor, and many Americans know that Mr. Kerrey is an authentic war hero. Yet the New Yorker is widely seen as the heavyweight.
Some people are natural leaders, whether in football or Wall Street or national politics, and people sense it. They are born dancers, not awkward yokels who get through Arthur Murray's and forget the steps the minute they step onto a real dance floor. And some people seem to embody or at least to make credible connections to party and national tradition, while others seem manufactured, all too ready to mouth tomorrow today's poll reports.
It may be that Mr. Tsongas, now widely considered the pace-setter, will move steadily through the primaries and win the nomination, or that one of his active rivals will. But that seems unlikely to many, which is one reason why the "unauthorized" write-in campaign on behalf of Mr. Cuomo, who delights in its every move, attracted so much attention last week. If he or any of the others is to jump in, it would have to be soon; many filing deadlines have already passed, and others lie just ahead.
"If Bill Clinton doesn't weather the storm, you'll see a groundswell for others, and the best positioned is Gephardt," said Representative Dan Glickman, a Kansas Democrat. Mr. Bentsen says he's as reluctant as ever, but when he was asked in Texas the other day whether he was happy with his decision not to run, he said, "Some days I am and some days I'm not."
For the moment, it's mostly talk. There are reports of discreet inquiries by "friends" of possible candidates, meaning members of their staffs, as to the possibilities in South Carolina, Maine and California. The Draft Cuomo Committee is working on Massachusetts and Illinois and Missouri.
These things usually come to nothing. But in the years since Vietnam fractured Democratic comity, stranger things have happened. This is the party, after all, that nominated George McGovern and Jimmy Carter, neither of whom, a year before the event, seemed to those ubiquitous party leaders to have any business in the race.

HEADLINE: WINTER GAMES;
Rating the Field, In the Imitable Style of George H.W. Bush

 BODY:
One way to understand a political campaign is to put yourself in the place of a candidate. Maureen Dowd, a Washington correspondent of The Times, last week asked several Bush advisers to say, as frankly as they could, what they are telling the President about the Democratic Presidential field in Tuesday's New Hampshire primary -- and what Mr. Bush himself thinks of his would-be opponents. Ms. Dowd was inspired to submit the results in the style that has come to be known as Bushspeak.
 
Memo from George Bush Re: The Competition
Mother told me not to gloat. Don't use the Big I. Still, got to gloat a little. In secret. Sure, I know things are looking b-a-a-a-d for the home team right now. Approval ratings cratering. Voters in New Hampshire very angry at me about the economy in the ditch and raising taxes and running around with my pals, Mikhail and Boris and Kiichi and Francois. Pat Buchanan, tattling on me for being a moderate, says I'm like a 5-year-old and can't handle Congress. Oh yeah? Serves him right if John Sununu takes his place on "Crossfire." 
 Didn't think that protectionistic thing and that phony swagger would go over. Buchanan is saying I'm not Reagan II, I'm Skull and Bones I, and at the campaign they joke that it's a rumble between the Dead End Kids and Greenwich Dancing Class. But it won't be too funny if Buchanan gets 37 percent in New Hampshire and 25 in Super Tuesday, as my friends on the right are predicting. Watching that guy's "Read My Lips" makes me go ballistic.
But then I look at the Democrats, acting so weird and crazy, and I know we're going to be able to keep our snorkel above the waterline and get another four years. My campaign guys say we should feel lucky. Democrats didn't send in their first team, and the second string is having a power outage.
Clinton -- history. Paul Tsongas? Bring him on. Bye-bye wimp issue. I wish he'd stop reminding people that I didn't know what a supermarket scanner was. But anybody who likes the capital gains tax cut can't be all bad. There are a couple of worry warts in our polling office who say that Tsongas fits the profile of the kind of candidate voters want: No lies. No excess promises. The fact that he isn't smooth means he doesn't come across as a real politician, and that's good. They're worried that Tsongas might have some kind of reverse chic, and then we'd have to go with reverse reverse chic, but they don't know what that means yet.
Not worried, though. Not worried. Not worried. Message: Not Worried. The voters had their choice between hyperthyroid and no thyroid in '88 and they chose me. No one here believes that the Democrats will ever let Tsongas be the nominee anyhow. Once he goes South, he's dead meat. The South'll never go for another short, preachy Massachusetts liberal with a funny name who believes in gay rights. O.K., he wasn't a governor, but are we sure he didn't furlough anybody?
Harkin. What's that Jim Croce song? Meaner than a junkyard dog. He'd be the easiest to beat, but he'll burn himself up before I get to him. Dinosaur. Windbag. Don't like him, and hate it when he calls me George Herbert Walker Bush and the Vice President J. Danforth Quayle. It's bad manners. People should leave those kind of personal insults to staff.
Jerry Brown has a good message on the outsider thing but he's out there with the floating rings of Jupiter. I mean, what's with the turtlenecks?
My guys were worried about Bob Kerrey in the beginning. Thought he had the best story and could get the baby boomer vote.
Got mad at Kerrey for going nasty on the flag-burning thing in 1989. Accused me of exploiting the issue for my own benefit. I admire the young man's heroism in Vietnam, but what's with that guy? Think it comes down to desire. I'm willing to do what I have to do to get re-elected. He doesn't seem to have it in his gut. I agree with Eddie Mahe, who said, "You can have a kid playing class A or class AA ball and then they hit the big leagues and it falls apart."
Pamela Harriman will probably be reconvening everybody out at her farm this week. As Ed Rollins says, "If Clinton goes down, this field ain't it."
Wouldn't mind if Lloyd Bentsen got in. He beat me for the Senate once, but I could take him this time. He's no George Bush.
Gephardt? Tried to kiss and make up, and he's been helping me out with some legislation on Capitol Hill. Doro dates his aide, Bobby Koch. Don't know if he'll be my son-in-law, but there's a connection there. But Dick would get so personal and cutting. I just wouldn't like it.
Of course, the one who would really drive me nuts is Cuomo. My guys are divided about him, with some saying he's formidable and others saying he's overrated.
Cuomo is indecisive and geographically undesirable and he can't do retail politics. Can you see Mario Cuomo sitting on a hay stump in the middle of a wheat field or eating a tamale at a Texas barbecue? You think my pork rinds and country music was a stretch? Wait until the South gets a load of Teilhard de Chardin.
They say I'm thin-skinned and obsessed about the media. Bet he'd spend most of his time on the trail racing for the papers and magazines to see what was being written about him.
Using the hot line to Albany to encourage the Republicans up there to keep the pressure on, to make Cuomo's life as unpleasant as possible. Don't want him turning my horseshoe pit outside the Oval Office into a basketball court.
He's still flirting with getting in, and if he did, it would be class warfare. We'd get so far under each other's skin that some people would call it a transplant.
Cuomo told one columnist that I make him feel like the guy who comes to clean the swimming pool. Well, he tries to turn me into a cross between Rudy Vallee and Marie Antoinette. Calls me "the guy in the white shoes." Says I'm "throwing bon bons to a starving nation." Those kind of snide, cheap attacks send me up the wall.
But if he could get to me, I could get to him, too. In his Harvard speech the other night he sounded like just another Doom-and-gloom-o-crat, defending welfare and tax hikes. If he tried all his semantic voodoo mumbo-jumbo with me in a debate, all that stuff about "Pelagianism" and "palliatives" and "econometric models" and "the cyclical gods of the economy," I'd just turn to him and say, "Lighten up, Mario. Come over to the White House and we'll throw some 'shoes. And by the way, if you're so smart, why is New York such a mess?"

LENGTH: 1266 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
When the Bad Guy Is Seen as the One in the Green Hat

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When he bought 56 acres in Commerce City, Colo., in the 1970's to make room for his expanding business, Kenneth S. Valis believed he was investing in the future of the Colorado Paint Company. But in the 1980's, when a landfill that bordered on his property was found to be an abandoned toxic waste dump, Mr. Valis's purchase suddenly turned into a nightmare caused not by pollutants, but by the Government's environmental protectors.
Under provisions of the 1980 Superfund law giving the Environmental Protection Agency broad powers to clean up toxic dumps, the agency put a lien on Mr. Valis's property, erected a fence around it, dotted the landscape with monitoring wells, pumps and piping and then barred any other use of the ground while the dump was being cleaned up, a process that could last 30 years. 
 Last November, Mr. Valis filed suit in the United States Claims Court in Washington, charging that the Government's cleanup work was tantamount to seizing his property, and demanding just compensation.
Across the country, cases like this are fueling a broad movement to roll back the Government's authority to enforce environmental laws. The steadily growing strength of the environmental movement, culminating in enactment of the Clean Air Act in November 1990, is now encountering a backlash in Congress, the courts and in the streets. For example, loggers in the Northwest who have been protesting Government restrictions on cutting the region's last virgin forests to protect endangered spotted owls have succeeded in turning the issue into a moral question over a family's right to earn an honest living. A committee of Bush Administration Cabinet secretaries is set to resolve the dispute later this year.
"What we're talking about is advancing the notion of balanced environmental protections," said Jackie Lang, spokeswoman for the Oregon Lands Coalition, a group in Salem that represents forest industry workers, property owners, logging companies and other users of natural resources. "We're finding that most of these environmental laws are pushed by professional environmentalists. They are power-hungry people who put plants and animals above middle America."
George T. Frampton, president of the Wilderness Society, said the backlash is being driven by conservative groups that believe environmentalism has replaced Communism as the No. 1 enemy. "They have fixed on environmentalism as the green phase of international socialism," he said. "It's flying in the face of what's happening in the world and it's flying in the face of what business is doing in this country. The business community is looking toward the 21st century. This movement is looking to drag us back to the 19th century."
 
City Slickers
 The strength of the property rights movement, as it is often called, comes from the joining of the old wings of the 1970's Sagebrush Rebellion in the West -- miners, loggers, ranchers and energy companies -- with private landowners in the East and South. Many of those living in rural regions east of the Mississippi River were once city slickers who moved to the country only to discover that their land had been declared a restricted wetland, lay near an unknown toxic waste site or was home to an endangered species.
Among the leaders of the movement is Peggy Reigle, who left her job as vice president of finance at The Daily News in New York and bought an abandoned 138-acre farm for $400,000 on the eastern shore of Maryland in 1988. She wanted to sell 14 lots and discovered that the wetland laws barred her from developing at least part of the land and scared buyers away. She is now chairman of the Fairness to Landowners Committee, a group of 8,800 property owners in 30 states whose aim is to limit protection to only the most valuable wetlands, allowing development on the rest. "It's a national crisis," she said. "Landowners, and I mean moms and pops, not oil companies and miners, are being abused by restrictions that no longer make sense. Their lives have been devastated and their land is being held hostage by these laws."
Up and down Pennsylvania Avenue, the councils of government are taking note of the backlash. After complaints by landowners that rules for developing low-lying forests and other wetlands were too strict, President Bush last summer proposed changes that would make half of the nation's wetlands eligible for development.
In the United States Claims Court, conservative judges appointed by President Bush and his predecessor, Ronald Reagan, are beginning to rule in favor of property owners. Late last year, in the largest award to date, the Department of the Interior was directed to pay a Wyoming coal company $150 million because it barred the company from mining coal in a protected area.
Lawyers representing environmental groups say that if the trend continues, the cost of enforcing ecological protections could cripple the Government's regulatory programs. But other legal experts say the decisions are a logical result of the judicial concern that in aggressively enforcing its environmental laws the government is overstepping its authority and violating basic rights.
 
'Reasonable' Limits
 "These decisions reflect the view that our constitutional legal system can accommodate property rights and environmental protections," said Roger Marzulla, a former Assistant Attorney General who helped shape the Reagan Administration's policy on environmental regulation and property rights. "Where there are environmental gains that overwhelm constitutional liberties, it is perfectly reasonable to set some limits."
In Congress, a telling indication of the property movement's influence is the reluctance of environmental leaders in the House and Senate to open the 1972 Clean Water Act and the 1973 Endangered Species Act to amendment. Although the statutes are due to be renewed this year, lawmakers of both parties say the property rights movement has attracted considerable support for new amendments that could weaken both laws.
"The mood in Congress is not currently friendly to environmental initiatives," said William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. "The mood was already negative before we began to encounter economic problems, and it's gotten worse in the last few months."
The attack of the property rights movement comes at a vulnerable time for environmental groups. After a decade of rapid expansion that led to ever larger staffs and the construction of plush national headquarters in Washington, New York and San Francisco, groups like the National Audubon Society, the Environmental Defense Fund, the Sierra Club and the National Wildlife Federation find themselves in the uncomfortable position of being identified with the establishment -- the regulators enforcing the stronger new laws.
"The property rights backlash is the most important challenge to the modern environmental movement that has appeared in years," said Erik J. Meyers, general counsel of the Environmental Law Institute in Washington. "What's been surprising though is that the environmental groups have done almost nothing to counter it."
Environmental leaders around the country agree the movement is losing its edge. "We have become complacent, and the organized interests that are winning on some of these issues should have been expected," said William R. Neil, assistant director of conservation for the New Jersey Audubon Society. "Anybody who doubts that should see how much ground we lost on the wetlands issue, which we thought was in the bag."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Stressing Foreign Policy Could Cut Both Ways

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
President Bush has always been supremely conscious of his place in history, insisting on conducting what he considered his statesman's duties long after his political advisers told him he'd better pay more attention to domestic matters.
Mr. Bush does want to be re-elected, and he recognizes that economics, not diplomacy, is driving the 1992 campaign. But his aides say he is convinced of two things: There is not much he can really do about the economy, even though he knows he must appear to be trying, and his greatest strength as a candidate is his record as Commander in Chief and diplomat. 
 Indeed, former President Richard M. Nixon had some advice that Mr. Bush might well find palatable: Push foreign policy as hard as possible. "People are feeling safe enough in the world that they just might feel they can afford the luxury of a Democratic President," Mr. Nixon told a group of reporters recently.
But for Mr. Bush, following such a course is a formidable challenge this year, for his strength in foreign policy could yet turn into his greatest weakness.
To maintain his obvious heavy advantage over the Democratic field, Mr. Bush not only has to address economic issues. He must also find ways to make expertise in foreign affairs relevant, or at least remind Americans of his accomplishments on the world stage.
And he has to do that without raising questions about which of Mr. Bush's driving forces is dominant: his vision of himself as the world's leader or the imperative of being re-elected. As Mr. Bush starts talking more about foreign affairs, as he certainly will after the Democrats choose a candidate with few or no credentials in foreign affairs, it may become difficult to tell foreign policy and politics apart.
Clearly, undertaking some adventure overseas would invite accusations of playing politics with national security, especially if it involved, say, new fighting in Iraq. On the other hand, Mr. Bush could argue that he cannot abandon his duties and that scheduled events -- a drug conference this month, a Russian-American summit, a meeting of the industrialized democracies in July -- are in the national interest and obligatory. But even that has perils. "I hope the economy is better by the time Bush gets back into foreign policy heavily, because if it isn't, he may find himself severely criticized for not staying at home and dealing with our problems," said John P. Sears, a former campaign manager for Ronald Reagan.
In addition, each foreign policy issue facing Mr. Bush has the potential of putting him in a double bind.
It is in Mr. Bush's interests on one level to talk about the Persian Gulf war, which he does at every opportunity. But he may simply be reminding voters that Saddam Hussein remains in power. "It's a clear negative if he doesn't get rid of him," said Senator John C. McCain, Republican of Arizona. But another Republican, Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, said it would be tough to take on Mr. Hussein. "If Saddam makes a bad move or it's discovered that he's much farther along in nuclear development than we thought, I don't think Bush would hesitate to whack him. But I don't think he wants to for the very reason that he would be criticized for doing it for political purposes."
 
Acting Presidential
 Mr. Bush's advisers believe his leadership in the West's response to the breakup of the Soviet Union can reinforce his image of acting Presidential, and he is to meet with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia by mid-summer. "Letting people know he is doing everything he can to demolish those weapons of mass destruction that are laying all over the former Soviet Union could be a big plus," Senator McCain said. But the Russians just do not seem so threatening, and Mr. Bush will be hard-pressed to give Mr. Yeltsin much financial help.
In July, the leaders of the industrialized democracies will gather in Munich to discuss trade issues. Mr. Bush can demonstrate his diplomatic skills and drive home a favorite point: that foreign policy and domestic policy are inextricably tangled. The problem is, he stumbled badly on his last trade outing, in Japan; the last thing he and his campaign want is for him to come back again with nothing concrete to offer.
The Middle East could offer Mr. Bush some political relief -- if Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's efforts to get real peace talks moving succeed. But that is no sure thing, and Mr. Bush seems content to stay out of this diplomatic snarl, apart from saying his "new world order" made the talks possible.
Meanwhile, Mr. Bush can try to find the proper balance between showing he cares about the economy and being Presidential abroad. He can also do what he has been doing, which is to try to stir patriotic sentiments over the gulf war and take credit for ending the cold war. But Mr. Bush is left sounding at times almost as if he is pleading when he makes his case for Americans to stay attuned to foreign affairs.
"The America we know is a country ready to take on the world and rise to new levels," he said last week. "Never in this nation's long history has America turned its back on a challenge and we are not going to start now. A proud America will never be protectionist. It will never be protectionist."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 6; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 916 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Customers Feeling Less Than Friendly To Friendly Bankers

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Several weeks ago, with a record number of homeowners seeking new mortgages to take advantage of low interest rates, Bank of America imposed a hefty new fee on refinancing applications in California. To the San Francisco-based bank, which was struggling to keep up with the immense demand for refinancing, the fee was a reasonable way to discourage all but serious customers from applying, especially since the fee would be applied to the transaction's closing costs or refunded if the loan was rejected.
But to many consumers, the fee -- 1.5 percent of the loan amount, up to a maximum of $3,000 -- was yet another example of arrogance and high-handedness at financial institutions. "It's outrageous," said Ken McEldowney, executive director of Consumer Action, a consumer advocacy group in San Francisco. "In the eyes of the consumer, the bank is saying, 'We're so big that you don't have a choice, and if you want to do business with us, you'll have to toe the line.' " 
 Indeed, despite some overall success by banks in improving their service, the relationship between customers and financial institutions often seems more tenuous, and sometimes more hostile, than ever before.
Consumers have plenty to gripe about. Their local savings and loan may well have failed, and they are paying with tax dollars for the $300 billion bailout of the industry. Their bank may well have merged with another, often forcing them to do business with a company they did not choose, or cope with a local branch closing.
People pay $20 or more in some cases for bouncing a check. Many are still paying a 20 percent interest rate on their credit-card balances, even though general interest rates, and the rates paid on savings accounts, are the lowest in decades. And if they have tried to refinance a mortgage recently, as hundreds of thousands of homeowners have, they probably found the process slow and expensive. "There is no question that there is anger on the part of consumers towards financial services companies," Mr. McEldowney said.
The growing resentment comes at a time when banks need customers more than ever. "Service quality is very much on the minds of most of the bankers I talk to," said Joe Belew, president of the Consumer Bankers Association, a trade group in Washington. "Banks are trying to serve their customers better because there is more competition out there. Detroit makes auto loans and the phone company offers a credit card. Consumers have more choices than ever before."
Banks have also been motivated to treat customers better because retail banking -- selling savings and checking accounts, credit cards and loans to consumers -- is a far more attractive business right now than most other aspects of banking. That has remained true even though many banks, including Citibank, have recently been troubled by recession-inspired problems with consumer loans. Loans to real-estate developers have proven to be a disaster in recent years. Big corporations have increasingly eschewed bank loans, opting instead to raise money on Wall Street or by issuing their own paper. And banks in this country learned that loans to foreign countries were too risky.
 
Customers vs. Cutbacks
 The drive for customer service, however, has often run head on into the push by banks to reduce their costs by closing branches, laying off workers and encouraging sometimes reluctant consumers to use teller machines instead of tellers. A number of years ago Citibank barred all customers in New York with balances of under $5,000 from using human tellers, relegating them to the cold if perhaps more efficient and cost-saving world of automation. The move infuriated customers, and Citibank was forced to reopen its teller lines to everyone.
A survey done last year for The American Banker newspaper by the Gallup Organization found that 66 percent of those surveyed were "very satisfied" with their financial institutions. The results suggested that customer satisfaction was increasing after having declined several years earlier.
Richard Beebe, a spokesman for Bank of America, said the bank now gives bonuses to branch employees based in part on service quality. Training procedures now stress the importance of calling customers by name, knowing the banks' services and being courteous.
So why did Bank of America slap new fees on refinanced mortgages? To improve service, Mr. Beebe said. The bank has been overwhelmed with applications, he said, and much of the work going into processing them is for naught when customers choose to go somewhere else for a loan, or to wait a little longer to see if rates drop further.
"People expect when they go into any kind of home-loan transaction that it will take some time. But when the system gets as full as it is now, it takes longer and longer, and people get frustrated," Mr. Beebe said. "We want to direct our resources to customers who are most serious about refinancing with us so we can provide them the highest level of service."
Consumer advocates say that many other banks have set much more moderate fees for the same purpose. They also wonder about how the bank will treat its customers during and after its pending $4 billion merger with the Security Pacific Corporation of Los Angeles, the largest banking merger to date. Bank of America has not provided any details yet, but the merger is expected to involve large-scale branch closings and the layoff of thousands of employees from the combined companies.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
A New Attempt to Get Ireland Going Again

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY

DATELINE: DUBLIN

 BODY:
In his time, Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey was castigated for being an over-spending populist, and praised for streamlining Irish finances and nourishing the modest boom of the late 1980's. Few leaders before him in this country's 70 years of independence had dominated Irish political and economic life as Mr. Haughey, who was forced out last month from the post he had held for 8 of the last 12 years amid economic recession and allegations of corruption among his friends.
Stories of Mr. Haughey's conviviality and wit are being retold now with fondness, and some sense of metaphor. There is the time, some 20 years ago, he told his drinking chums, that he was stopped by a policeman while driving the wrong way on a one-way street. 
 "Did you not see the arrows?" the stern officer said.
"Arrows?" the dashing politician replied, "To tell the truth, guard, I didn't even see the bloody Indians."
Mr. Haughey's successor is hoping for better luck. Albert Reynolds, a former finance minister who has in his time dressed up as a cowboy and sung country and western, knows the arrows of Irish political life. He has probably two years to get the country moving again before the next general election.
The country of 3.5 million people he is trying to revive has a mixed view of itself and its social and economic problems. On one hand, Ireland is among the 30 wealthiest nations in the world. But it is one of the poor members of the European Community, down at the bottom of the 12 with Portugal and Greece. The Irish countryside is still a series of dream-inducing green hills, lakes, bays and fields, unspoiled by pollution, as the Industrial Revolution missed this country and left it largely unspiked with smokestacks, its rivers and streams full of clean fish.
But there are also growing suburban slums and an unemployment rate of 20 percent. Perennial social issues like divorce and the availability of condoms are expected to face renewed heated debate in Parliament, where politicians who want change also do not want to be seen as opposing views of the Roman Catholic Church in a country that is 95 percent Roman Catholic.
The social and economic roots of Ireland's condition are tangled, but traceable. As a Catholic country, where the church opposes contraception, Ireland has the highest birth rate in Europe. And it has heavy emigration. In the late 1980's, young Irish men and women were finding work in America, Britain and Australia, leaving here at a rate of about 30,000 a year. They sent home millions to their families and, by staying abroad, kept unemployment relatively low. But the world recession hurt, especially in America, drying up construction and hotel jobs. Ireland's net emigration dropped to zero in 1990.
 
New Job Sources
 Each year the good Irish school system puts about 25,000 new people in the job market, but the country only produces about 2,500 new jobs. Officials like Desmond O'Malley, the Minister for Industry and Commerce, feel that the youth of Ireland will help supply labor well into the next century to European countries like Germany, whose populations are getting older. Mr. O'Malley, leader of the Progressive Democrats party, whose support enables Mr. Reynolds to head the Government, also runs the International Development Agency, which has drawn hundreds of American and other foreign companies to Ireland, creating several thousand jobs in recent years.
But most officials, and foreign experts, feel that Ireland's economy will remain a function of the world economy, and that for now the country must hope that the European Community continues its heavy subsidies -- and that Irish agriculture adjusts to competition in the new Europe, learning, for example, to produce chocolate candy instead of raw milk, free-range lamb instead of scrawny mutton. The country, says Michael Cuddy, an economist at the University of Galway, must lose its "begging bowl" mentality.
With the economy such a preoccupation, most Irish push to the back of their minds the problem of violence in Northern Ireland. Mr. Reynolds, and other officials, however, have begun to indicate that the European Community might eventually assume a role in settling the civil war there.
The principal social issues here remain divorce and the distribution of condoms. In 1985, the nation rejected a proposal to allow civil divorce. Now, many officials say, the mood has changed and a referendum would approve divorce legislation if it provided for reconciliation attempts before a divorce was granted.
The condoms issue has had its ludicrous aspects. Liberals cite the rise in AIDS as a reason for making condoms more widely available. Conservative forces put out a pamphlet titled "67 Reasons Why Condoms Spread AIDS," which produced the threat of a counter-leaflet, "67 Reasons Why Motorcycle Helmets Spread Head Injuries."
In the upcoming debate, the most popular official, President Mary Robinson, may have difficulty getting her opinions across. Before her election she was an avowed liberal on social issues and favored a law to permit divorce. But as President, she is restrained by the Constitution from taking part in politics.
That job belongs to Mr. Reynolds, a 56-year-old former businessman who as a pet-food manufacturer was so assiduous as to taste the product himself. Now to get them to accept budget-cutting, revenue-raising reforms, Mr. Reynolds will have to cajole and sweet-talk his countrymen. He once even serenaded them, going on television in 1972 to sing a country ditty, "Put Your Sweet Lips a Little Closer to the Phone."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Mary Robinson of Ireland and the newly elected Prime Minister, Albert Reynolds, in Dublin last week. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
The Winds of Peace Buffet Connecticut

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
A rich mix of history and fate combined to create the specialized culture of military manufacturing that has thrived in Connecticut. Since the Revolutionary War, when George Washington bought his cannon here, through the days of Samuel Colt's Civil War arms empire, the Winchester trench mortar of World War I and later the Seawolf nuclear submarine, hundreds of Connecticut companies and hundreds of thousands of residents have found a niche in supplying the tools of war.
But the onslaught of the recession and the end of the cold war are forcing a stressful re-evaluation of the old military connections with Washington. Layoff announcements from both Pratt & Whitney, the jet engine maker in East Hartford, and the General Dynamics Electric Boat division in Groton have crystallized the concerns, as the state braces for 16,400 layoffs from those two companies alone over the next six years 
 In the Federal fiscal year that ended last September, Connecticut fell from its accustomed rank of No. 1 in Department of Defense spending per capita to No. 2, with only $1,289 per person in the state, down from nearly $1,800 in recent years. Massachusetts is now in first place. The 1990 number compares with $462 per capita in New Jersey and $378 in New York.
The vulnerability goes deeper still. The Department of Commerce estimated several years ago that about 70 percent of all manufacturing in Connecticut was defense oriented, either through direct Federal contracts, subcontracts with other companies or basic metals manufacturing used for weaponry.
The ungainly term that has become the rallying cry, from politicians in Hartford to the shop floors and boardrooms of the military companies, is "diversification." But industry experts, workers and elected officials say the word is misleading because it makes the harsh choices facing Connecticut seem easily managed.
The stickier reality, they say, is that Connecticut must decide all over again what it will be, especially when confronting a long-term decline in military spending. For companies, it means more than new products; it means changing the culture and learning how to sell products in the open marketplace. For the state government, battered by its own prolonged fiscal crisis, it means triage, using limited funds to help some companies and not others.
For many individual workers, like Michael Martin, diversification means deciding whether to abandon the home state or stick it out. Mr. Martin, who is 45 years old, lost his job last September as a quality-control manager after 24 years at the United Nuclear Corporation's naval products division in Montville. The company lost its Navy contract making nuclear engines for submarines in 1990, and by next January all but about 35 of its 1,150 employees will be dispersed.
 
An Exodus
 So far, Mr. Martin has drawn a job-search line in a 50-mile circle around his home in Waterford. This spring he'll widen it, and if nothing turns up by summer, he'll move. About 50 percent of all white-collar employees at the company have already left the state, according to United Nuclear officials who have tracked the exodus. Hourly blue-collar workers, by contrast, have mostly stayed, partly because new employers will help with moving expenses for executives, but usually not for shop-floor workers.
Most of Mr. Martin's former colleagues who have found jobs have taken pay cuts. United Nuclear's personnel manager, Holly Ellis, who will lose her own job at the end of this year, said for most blue-collar workers, who have retrained in fields ranging from cooking to fixing cars, earning 70 percent of the plant's average $15 an hour wage is about the best that can be hoped for.
The state's efforts at helping have been hampered by questions of whom to help and by how much. Of a $10 million diversification fund set up last year, only $200,000 has been awarded, to help a company preparing a study on how to diversify. Other proposed grants, including a $3 million award to Textron Lycoming, a tank-engine maker in Stratford, have come under sharp attack.
"Why should we invest when they didn't?" asked State Representative William R. Dyson, co-chairman of the General Assembly's appropriations committee. "A billion-dollar operation and we pay them millions to think about another way."
 
First, Layoffs
 Although there are some conversion success stories, they are few. A Wallingford company that made strongboxes to protect communications hardware in war conditions is trying to use that technology to protect utility equipment in severe storms. An engine-parts maker in Waterbury bought commercial Scandinavian technology and has landed a contract with Caterpillar.
For many of the large companies, however, the first option has been to shed workers, then try to build on what is left.
Without financial assistance, "many companies will define conversion as going from 15,000 to 5,000 employees," said the Rev. Kevin D. Bean, an Episcopal priest who has studied the state's military dependence for the last decade, and has served on various state panels studying the issue.
Another factor is time. A recent national survey of military contractors conducted by the Winbridge Group, a consulting concern in Cambridge, Mass., said that of those companies that have already tried to diversify, 65 percent needed at least a year after completing initial studies to bring a product to market.
Michael J. Cahill decided he couldn't wait. Mr. Cahill, a 45-year-old engineer, worked in military jobs for 16 years and was laid off twice, most recently by United Nuclear. Last year he moved to Florida to take a job at a strictly civilian engineering firm. But he said he had an additional reason to leave. His wife, Leonor, worked for a bank, another badly battered Connecticut industry. Last year alone 20 banks failed in the state.
"She didn't lose her job, although she probably would have," Mr. Cahill said.
