HEADLINE: THE NATION;
How Can You Tell a Recovery When You See One?

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Everybody's doing it, peering through the thick fog of dismal economic data, company layoffs and gloom-and-doom punditry for glimmers of an economic rebound. For those who would like to join the search for early signs of economic revival here are some suggestions about where to look.
Start with a glance at the calendar. Post-World War II recessions have tended to be relatively short, a year on average, while expansions have been relatively long. On that score, a recovery is overdue. The last wave of economic expansion crested in July 1990. Technically, the recent recession ended last spring, when the economy stopped shrinking, but actual recovery remains painfully stalled, especially for the approximately 9 million people out of work. 
 Or take a look at stock prices. When the market goes on a tear, millions of investors are betting on economic recovery and higher profits. True, Wall Street has occasionally panicked, predicting slumps when only slowdowns appeared. But it has never risen more than a few percentage points during a post-World War II recession without presaging an economic recovery. The Dow is up more than 12 percent over its early December level.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady likes to scan the papers for earnings turnarounds. They're straws in the wind, he says, showing that some of the forces that originally knocked the economy down -- bloated costs, too much inventory, shopped-out consumers -- are starting to dissipate. His favorite example: in the fall Goodyear Tire had a 10-fold profit gain from the prior year.
Keep a close eye on Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan. Easier money and lower rates, which the Fed can deliver, help end downturns by making life easier for debtors and making it cheaper for companies and households to borrow. The money supply -- cash, checking and saving accounts as well as money market mutual funds -- is growing briskly after months of going nowhere. But short-term interest rates -- the cost of borrowing money for a few months -- are lower now than in a decade and a half. Three-month Treasury bills are paying less than 4 percent. The cost of long-term loans hasn't come down nearly as much but has still returned to the levels of the early 1970's, with 30-year Treasury bills paying less than 8 percent. Smaller interest payments are already making corporations a bit flusher and refinancing by homeowners has added up to billions of dollars in new buying power.
Keep a close tab on how consumers are feeling. They account for two-thirds of the economy and their mood swings have been unusually important in the current slump. When they brightened after the gulf war victory last spring, so did the economy. When they turned morose in the wake of corporate layoffs last summer and fall, spending and the economy stalled.
Alas, as of the moment, the bad mood shows no signs of lifting. The latest reading from poll takers at the University of Michigan shows that consumers remained in the dumps in the first half of February.
 
Signs of Life
 But the gloom hasn't stopped home buyers -- especially first-time buyers who are seeing the lowest mortgage rates since they got out of college -- from making down payments. Housing, incidentally, has led the economy out of every recession in post-war history. Home buying lifts demand for everything from appliances and carpets to venetian blinds. It also encourages builders to dig new foundations and hire back unemployed construction workers. And the buyers who come back to the market put a floor under sagging house prices.
So what's happening now? The moribund housing market is showing signs of life, although they're still pretty hard to detect in markets like California and New York City, which were hot in the 1980's. Housing starts are up from their lows last year in every major region of the country except the West. Single family housing starts are up 41 percent since they bottomed out last year.
Look at the neighbor's driveway. If there's a new pickup parked there, breathe a little easier. Once the economy is on the way to recovery, car sales typically pick up. That's what they've been doing in the last few weeks, though it's far too early to tell if they will have more staying power than they did last summer.
Take a stroll at the mall. Retail sales are not, strictly speaking, a leading indicator. But with consumers calling the shots these days (in the last recession, they kept stubbornly spending), buying is probably a more sensitive indicator of where the economy is heading. The Government reported last week that consumers were out buying in January. And the same report said that consumers hadn't been quite as penny-pinching between Thanksgiving and Christmas as was initially reported.
A series of declines in new applications for unemployment insurance are among the most reliable indicators that the economy is getting healthier, says Erich Heinemann, chief economist of Ladenburg Thalman, a brokerage house. Such claims have been creeping down for the last couple of weeks.
Some important numbers tell more about where the economy has been than where it is going. Joblessness typically keeps rising after recoveries begin -- partly because businesses keep staffs lean until they're sure that the orders will keep coming and partly because workers who dropped out of the labor force during the recession start looking for work again.
 
No Sure Things
 No sign, taken by itself, is a sure thing. A good way to hedge your bets is to look for a substantial and sustained rise in the so-called index of leading indicators compiled by the Commerce Department. But don't expect the sight to cheer you. After rising handsomely last year, the index has lately been slipping.
What are the pros predicting? No growth yet and maybe even another dip in the current quarter. But just wait until Memorial Day. The Blue Chip consensus of 51 economic forecasters expects a modest rebound, at a 3 percent or so annual rate, in the year's second half.
Most of the signs aren't there yet. If more bright spots fail to appear, the economists are betting that the Federal Reserve will keep pushing down rates until they do. Not a bad bet in an election year.

HEADLINE: Fiscal and Political Forces Move Pakistan to Seek Afghan Peace

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 15

 BODY:
After nearly 13 years of war in Afghanistan, the Pakistani Government has moved decisively to end the conflict, which has left more than a million people dead, devastated the country's economy and driven three million refugees, nearly a fifth of the country's population, across the border into Pakistan.
A vital supporter of the fundamentalist Islamic guerrillas in Afghanistan since Soviet tanks roared into the country in December 1979, Pakistan late last month abruptly ceased supplying arms to the rebels and endorsed United Nations efforts to end the fighting and bring democracy to the country.
 
Economic Motivations
 In doing so, Islamabad is no longer insisting on the installation of an Islamic government in Afghanistan. Instead, Pakistan now favors a United Nations plan to bring together all the factions, including representatives of the former Communist Government in Kabul, to form an interim government that would rule until elections could be held. 
 Pakistan's shift has been brought on in large part by its urgent desire for a stable Afghan government that can serve as a bridge to economic and political ties with the new Central Asian republics formed from the old Soviet Union. Many leaders in those republics are wary of Islamic fundamentalismin neighboring countries and within their own borders.
Other factors motivating Islamabad are the growing burdens placed by the three million Afghan refugees within Pakistan, the continuing ineffectiveness of the guerrillas and the staying power of the Afghan Government of President Najibullah three years after the withdrawal of Soviet forces.
"This is most significant because it marks a shift in Pakistan's attitude because for the first time it represents a political solution," said Sardar Aseff Ahmed Ali, Minister of State for Economic Affairs and in large measure the intellectual force behind the change.
Pakistan's shift, in the view of senior western diplomats here, clears away the last major obstacle to ending the fighting. Nonetheless, senior Pakistani officials and diplomats caution that the ethnic, regional and political fragmentation of rebel groups may make it difficult, if not impossible, for a peace plan to succeed.
Only three of the seven main rebel groups in Pakistan have endorsed the peace process, and fundamentalist guerrilla leaders led by Gulbuddin Hekmatyar have publicly rejected it.
In September, Washington and Moscow agreed to halt all weapons shipments to both the United States-backed guerrillas and the Soviet-backed Kabul Government on Jan. 1. Pakistan, however, declined to embrace the accord signed by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the former Soviet Foreign Minister, Boris D. Pankin.
 
A Political Tack
 Since then, Pakistan's approach has been shaken by the collapse of the Soviet Union and the glaring failures of the guerrillas on the battlefield. It has awakened to the probability that a military solution can never be achieved.
"We are looking for a steady political settlement of the problem," said Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif in an interview. "We have announced the support of the United Nations resolutions. We now favor very strongly a meeting of the jirga," a traditional gathering of tribal groups that has become a centerpiece of the United Nations plan.
He said he hoped that "all concerned, including the U.N., will use their best efforts to organize this. Only that will lead to a political settlement."
The shift dovetails with Washington's interest in checking the spread of Islamic fundamentalism. To some degree it is an expression of Pakistan's desire not to further alienate the United States, which is pressuring Islamabad to abandon its effort to develop nuclear arms. Pakistan, stung by American legislation cutting off military and economic aid, has gone out of its way to accommodate American concerns on other issues.
 
A Matter of Little Choice
 Riaz Mohammed Khan, soon to be Islamabad's first ambassador to Kazakhstan and a long-time policy-maker said, "The most important element was the change in the Soviet Government's attitude on an interim government. Once they accepted it, the U.N. could put forward a plan."
Pakistan's support for the guerrillas stemmed as much from its abhorrence of the Communist Government in Kabul as its own determination to conduct an Islamic war of justice, a jihad, that would bring Islamic rule to Afghanistan, an objective pressed relentlessly by Pakistan's fundamentalist parties. Even now, the parties are taking the Government to task for abandoning the guerrillas. But most officials and observers felt there was no choice.
"The Mujahedeen showed they couldn't do anything," said Maleeha Lodhi, the editor of The News, the country's newest and suddenly most successful newspaper. "Basically all the old options were exhausted."
Last year, when it became clear that the United States and the Soviet Union were going to end their involvement in Afghanistan, the guerrillas launched two major offensives, one against the provincial capital of Jalalabad and the other against the town of Gardez. In both cases, the rebels were decisively beaten back by the Afghan army.
"The lesson of Gardez is that the jihad is over," said a Western diplomat in Peshawar. "I don't think we'll see anymore large-scale fighting. The Mujahadeen just can't get anybody to fight anymore. The jihad is over. They lost."
But Mr. Ali, the Minister of State for Economic Affairs, said that Pakistan's decision to abandon a military solution had less to do with the Mujahedeen than the changes in Central Asia. It is becoming clear, he said, that Pakistan's economic fortunes will be tied to opportunities in countries like Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan and Tajikistan.
"Basically, this was triggered off by my Central Asian visit," he said of a trip he led late last year. "They said there could be no meaningful relations with Pakistan until the Afghan problem is settled."
Already India, Pakistan's principal commercial competitor in South Asia, is moving aggressively through Central Asia. Pakistan, which places great stock in its Islamic credentials, is hoping to appeal to the Central Asian republics in part as a natural ally, and in part as an economic partner and an entrepot to the world.
Mr. Ali said that if the war ends, the road linking the republics through Afghanistan to Pakistan can be opened. He said he hopes to persuade the World Bank to finance a rail line from the republics to the port of Karachi. "This opens all of Central Asia," he said.
But he said Central Asian leaders told him repeatedly that they had no desire to see a fundamentalist government imposed in Kabul.
"Central Asia," he said, "sent us a signal: . . . 'if you try to force a solution, we will continue to supply weapons.' This was totally misread by the Mujahedeen."
The guerrillas' misreading of the republics' resolve to back Mr. Najibullah, even though Moscow had withdrawn support, was one frustration that proved decisive for Pakistan.
Another came during a visit to Islamabad by the Russian Vice President, Aleksandr V. Rutskoi, last month. Pakistan had promised that five Russian prisoners of war would be turned over to him, but rebel leaders refused to give them up.
"That triggered off a whole new thinking in Pakistan," Mr. Ali said. "People began asking, are these people worth it? These people have become the biggest obstacles in the peace process and in finding a solution to the Afghan problem."
 
Grand Assembly Proposed
 Then on Jan. 25, Siddique Kanjo, the Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, announced that Pakistan was throwing its support behind the United Nations peace plan, a move Ms. Lodhi called the "first major foreign policy decision" by the year-old Government. Under the proposal, a gathering of 150 Afghans from all factions, a Loya Jirga, or Grand Assembly, would meet in April and form a smaller body that would function as an interim government until elections could be held. In the meantime a cease-fire would be imposed.
The ground rules exclude "controversial personalities" like President Najibullah, although his Government would be represented. Although he is one of the few national figures in Afghanistan, the rebels' hatred of Mr. Najibullah makes any role for him in a future Afghan Government extremely doubtful.
After weeks of frantic shuttling among Kabul, Islamabad, Teheran and the refugee camps in Peshawar, Benon Sevan, the representative of Secretary General Boutros Ghali who is trying to encourage the delicate political choreography necessary to bring all parties together, gave voice to the first glimmers of hope.
"The chances for a political settlement to this 13-year conflict are looking brighter than ever," said Mr. Sevan, who has spent five years trying to replace bullets with dialogue.
The Islamic fundamentalist Government of Iran, which supports two Iranian-based Afghan guerrilla groups in addition to those in Pakistan, has its own Afghan refugee problem and has expressed support for the peace plan.
However, Pakistan's decision to support Mr. Sevan's efforts was met by hostile comments from the religious right and the hard-line fundamentalist Afghan resistance groups, including the three largest and best-armed factions. The leader of rigorously fundamentalist Hezbe Islami, Mr. Hekmatyar, said, "I'm surprised to hear Sevan expressing 'optimism,' because out of 25 Mujahedeen groups based in Iran and Pakistan, 22 have flatly told him that they will never attend such an assembly."
But Pakistanis and diplomats here say that only Mr. Hekmatyar's faction and two others pose a challenge. And even if the factions refuse to go along, the Pakistanis say they have no intention of letting the fundamentalists scuttle the peace plan.
"If Benon Sevan fails in convincing these three gentlemen, then these three people will be bypassed," said Mr. Ali, "and they will become tribal brigands. This is something governments in Afghanistan have always lived with. They will be a little pocket somewhere. Everything will move ahead. They will not be allowed to be an obstacle."

HEADLINE: NEW YORK REPORT FINDS DRUG ABUSE RIFE IN SHELTERS

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
Eighty percent of the homeless men housed in New York City's vast armory shelters and 30 percent of the adults in shelters for families use drugs or alcohol, most commonly cocaine, , an extensive survey by a mayoral commission has found.
This is the first survey of the homeless in city shelters to include widespread urine testing as well as face-to-face interviews in which the residents were questioned about drug and alcohol abuse. What emerged was a portrait of a far more troubled population than had previously been documented. Only a minority of the homeless needed just housing to get back on their feet, the survey found.
 
New Agency Is Sought
 In addition to extensive drug and alcohol use, the survey found, the city's homeless are hobbled by interwoven afflictions: extreme poverty, mental illness, AIDS, domestic violence and lack of education and job skills. The survey, which tested and interviewed about 1,000 of the city's 15,500 adult shelter residents, was conducted over three weeks for a mayoral commission studying the problems of the city's shelter system. 
 Citing the new evidence, the commission, headed by Andrew Cuomo, is calling for a complete overhaul of the city's efforts, including a new agency or authority to run the system, more small shelters with specialized services and new rules that would give permanent housing only to those who successfully complete treatment or training, depending on the need.
The commission's 118-page report was delivered to Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday. A copy was obtained by The New York Times.
A mayoral spokesman, Leland T. Jones, said Mr. Dinkins was pleased that the commission had "reaffirmed" the Mayor's advocacy of smaller, service-enriched shelters. He said Mr. Dinkins wanted to study the creation of a new agency to run the system "to test the theory against the reality and see if it's the best way to go."
Mr. Dinkins will meet with the commission chairman, Mr. Cuomo, on Tuesday, and will probably release the report on Wednesday, Mr. Jones said.
Mr. Cuomo, who runs a nonprofit group that operates shelters for families and who is the son of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, declined to comment on the report until the Mayor had a chance to review it.
The commission's survey found differing drug use among various segments of the homeless population. The urine testing was anonymous and voluntary. Such testing generally detects drug use in the previous three days. No one was paid to participate, the report said.
 
Previous Surveys
 Over all, urinalysis of 525 men in an array of shelters, including smaller ones for people with special needs, found that 65 percent of them tested positive for alcohol or drugs, mainly cocaine. In the large barracks-style shelters, the incidence was even more common: Fully 80 percent of the men there had drugs or alcohol in their systems, again mostly cocaine.
Another 495 adults, mainly women in family shelters, were tested. In the family shelters that offered more services and privacy, drug or alcohol use was 26 percent, compared with 34 percent in the large congregate shelters. As in the shelters for homeless single people, cocaine was overwhelmingly the substance detected through urine testing.
Previous research that relied on interviews had suggested that drugs were not so pervasive. A recent survey conducted for the city found that only 18 percent of the adults in singles shelters said they were using drugs, though officials said at the time that they believed that figure underestimated the problem.
In analyzing the new data, the commission cautioned that there was tremendous diversity within the population of drug users. Some are addicted and will require long-term residential rehabilitation, while others need outpatient care, acupuncture or methadone, the panel said. For yet others, the report said, drug use is a symptom, not a cause, of homelessness, which can be traced to a knot of problems including poverty and lack of skills, as well as the general evaporation of decent-paying manufacturing jobs in the New York region.
The report noted that some of the homeless appeared to have had a drug problem before they entered the system. But others appeared to have become ensnared once they were in the shelters, which have become notorious as dangerous places where drugs are often sold openly.
George McDonald, an advocate for the homeless and one of the three commissioners who drafted the report, said yesterday that the bleakness and violence of the armories, like Fort Washington in upper Manhattan, had contributed to the high levels of crack abuse among homeless men who often spend years in such shelters.
"They do it out of despair and desperation and the utter hopelessness of the situation," he said. "They feel worthless."
Already, the highlights of the commission's recommendations, which were disclosed by some commissioners two weeks ago, have drawn praise from elected officials including City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and the Borough Presidents of Queens, Brooklyn, Staten Island and the Bronx.
But the highlights were criticized by members of the Dinkins administration -- including Deputy Mayor Cesar A. Perales, who said he was not convinced that the commission's ideas would work. Since then, Mr. Dinkins has said the recommendations intrigue him.
 
Mayor's View
 Mr. McDonald said yesterday that the Mayor had told him that he "would be surprised by the consensus" for the commission's recommendations within his administration.
In its report, the 22-member commission harshly criticized the city's current shelter system as an exorbitantly expensive failure that fosters dependency rather than helping the homeless overcome their often crippling problems.
In particular, the commission assailed "the absurd waste and inhumanity" of the armories, where the city's Human Resources Administration spends $18,000 a year for a single man to sleep on a cot in a room with 900 other men.
The commission's report calls the $53,000 a year that city spends to keep a family in a barracks-style shelter where they have little or no privacy and few services "simply another expensive handout."
"The system was not, and is not, designed to empower a family to escape persistent poverty and dependence on government programs," the report stated.
The survey found that the typical family in the shelter system was headed by a young black or Hispanic woman with a very young child. Typically, the mothers themselves had grown up in families on welfare. One in five had been physically or sexually abused. One in 10 had spent time in foster care.
Almost one-third of the families had never had an apartment of their own and more than a third had no high school diploma and had not worked in the last year. Four of 10 families had either a mental health or drug abuse problem.
The commission called homeless single men and women "a forgotten population." While the city has already spent hundreds of millions of dollars upgrading its system for families, homeless single people -- possibly an even needier population -- have been relegated to dangerous shelters with almost no services.
"It is not enough to provide only 'shelter' to these vulnerable and troubled individuals," the report said. "Many of them need significant social services and medical attention."
Of homeless single people, 94 percent were minorities, half had served time in jail and one-fifth had been homeless for five years or more.
For these men, the commission advocated expanding the use of programs modeled on the Federal Job Corps, which provides education, training and counseling.
The commission counseled the Mayor to modify the new plan for homeless men and women that he proposed last October. The Mayor's plan, which called for the city to build and nonprofit groups to run 24 small, specialized shelters in mainly middle-income residential neighorhoods, ran into strong opposition from elected officials and city residents afraid to live near the homeless.
Instead, the commission advocated that nonprofit groups build and operate the new programs. Drug-treatment centers would probably not be placed in residential neighborhoods but in commercial or mixed-use areas or outside the city entirely, the report said.
The commission contended that private agencies could do the job better and more efficiently, while specialized programs would help the city qualify for more Federal funds to pay for drug treatment and job training.
The cost savings and increased revenues would mean that the city could provide more services to the homeless and build 5,400 units of emergency and permanent housing -- 50 percent more than the Mayor had proposed -- at the same $280 million cost as the Mayor's beleaguered five-year plan.
The commission said its approach would allow the city to pay for 1,100 more drug- and alcohol-treatment slots and 763 more permanent units.
The commission also contended that the city should ask more of the homeless themselves, even as it provides them with enriched services.
To address concerns that families living doubled up have declared themselves homeless as a way to obtain subsidized permanent housing, the commission would require the homeless to document their poverty and lack of housing alternatives before being granted shelter. Now such requirements are not generally enforced.
The commission also would require the homeless to complete treatment or training programs before placing them in permanent housing or providing them with a voucher to obtain housing in the open market.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Part of the Atlantic Avenue Armory shelter in Brooklyn. According to a survey of about 1,000 shelter residents by the mayoral commission on the homeless, 80 percent of the homeless men housed in New York City's armory shelters abuse drugs or alcohol. Chart: A Portrait of the Homeless
 
Demographic, Social and Economic Background
 
Shelter residents are only slightly less educated than the general population. In family shelters, 55 percent said they completed high school and 13 percent attended college. In the single shelters, 20 percent of men and 30 percent of women attended college.
 
More than 40 percent of adults who headed households in family shelters reported having three or more children. Nationally, 27 percent of women report having three or more children.

Fifty-three percent of family shelter residents came from households that received public assistance, 19 percent were physically abused, 10 percent spent time in foster care and 18 percent lived with someone who abused drugs or alcohol.
 
At shelters for single residents, males were more likely to have been in jail -- 55 percent -- than either female residents of single shelters -- 29 percent -- or adults in family shelters -- 15 percent.

Homeless History

Almost 90 percent of the families became homeless within the last two years; half of the single ones did. Twenty-two percent of homeless single residents became homeless more than 5 years ago, compared with 4 percent of families.
 
Fourteen percent of the families said they had stayed in a street, subway or park sometime during the year before entering the shleter system, with 43 percent saying they had stayed there for a month or more during that year.
 
A large proportion of families -- 31 percent -- and singles -- 27 percent -- had never had a house or apartment of their own.

Health and Mental Health

Poor health is a serious problem for a large proportion of residents of both single and family shelters. Twenty-one percent reported a serious or chronic health problem, and about 25 percent reported having been hospitalized in the last two years.
 
A sizable proportion of reswidents of family and single shelters reported receiving treatment for mental health propblems. Ten percent of family shelter residents and 12 percent of single shelter residents said they had been hospitalized for a mental or an emotional problem.

Employment

About a third of the family-shelter resident reported working in the last year, and 72 percent said they were employeed in the last three years.
 
Single residents are more likely to have worked recently than residents of family shleters. Fifty-five percent report of the singles said they worked during the last year, compared with 32 percent of family-shelter residents. (pg. 44)

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

HEADLINE: The 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Surging in New Hampshire, Tsongas Is the First to Marvel

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 15

 BODY:
Before the last candidate debate, Paul E. Tsongas was in a practice session with his aides when he suddenly asked a question that sent the room into a hush.
"What do I say if they ask me, 'Did you ever?' " the sad-faced candidate said. 
 His aides leaned forward, shocked and intrigued that the blandest of the candidates was concerned about the spicy topic of marital infidelity.
"Well, did you ever?" one of his aides asked.
"Well, no," the candidate replied, "but I'm afraid if I say that, I'll sound too self-righteous."
While the other candidates in the Democratic field worry about being too slick, too cosmic, too mean and too flaky, Mr. Tsongas worries about being too pious.
And the terrified Democratic hierarchy worries about Mr. Tsongas. In a scene reminiscent of the movie "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid," the candidate keeps plodding relentlessly along the trail, gaining ground, as the party leaders look over their shoulders with fear and grudging respect, wondering, "Who is that guy?"
 
Sign of Party's New Age
 That guy is the unlikeliest of front-runners -- a bland former one-term Senator from Massachusetts who suggests that his campaign theme should be the soundtrack of "Les Miserables" and who decided he ought to be a President at a time when not even his fellow Greek-Americans would return his phone calls begging for money.
And the fact that he is where he is shows what the Democratic Party has come to: It is the age of self-anointment and hand-made campaigns.
Mr. Tsongas's ambition -- or "purpose," as he calls it -- was not born in a smoke-filled room. It began in a germ-free room at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, where Mr. Tsongas spent six weeks in isolation recovering from radical lymphoma therapy and deciding that he wanted to do something special with whatever time he had left. He still counts the number of days since he first felt a lump in his groin on Sept. 29, 1983: 3,058.
He did not think of running for President himself at first. He suggested to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York that he run and talked to Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska. But in the end, with the sound of one hand clapping, Mr. Tsongas decided to take his beloved 86-page pamphlet, "A Call to Economic Arms," covering everything from a recycling ethic to spirituality, and run himself.
Mr. Tsongas says he believes that despite the fact that the nation andparty took years to recover from the Jimmy Carter malaise message, the voters are ready for someone unvarnished who will tell them to take their economic medicine without the sugar-coating of middle class tax cuts.
"The country knows that there's been a lot of glitz and morning-in- America years and the net result of not facing up to reality is what they're looking at now," he said. "And there comes a point in everyone's life when they get scared and say: 'Enough. Hey, we're grownups. Tell us the truth. We can handle it.' "
Last night, at a crowded 51st birthday party for Mr. Tsongas at a Holiday Inn here, his doctor, Tak Takvorian, was citing an invitation for the candidate to be the host of "Saturday Night Live" as an indication that he's ready for prime time.
But when Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas stumbled a second time and the spotlight swung to Mr. Tsongas this week in New Hampshire, he was nowhere to be found. To the utter astonishment of the pundits, his public schedule was nearly empty on Tuesday and empty on Wednesday.
Riding in his campaign van on Thursday, Mr. Tsongas was asked how he spent his day off. Without looking up from his favorite task, signing copies of his economic booklet, he replied: "I took my daughter to school. I went swimming. I spent three hours on the phone. In the evening, I spent some quiet time with the kids. I heard all the horror stories about overscheduling on the Dukakis campaign and I don't want to run around like a chicken without a head, exhausting myself and making no progress and looking haggard on television."
Mr. Tsongas, whose doctor says he has been free of cancer for five years, knows questions are raised about his health when he keeps light schedules. But he has his own way of dealing with the health issue, and it is, as usual, straightforward.
He has entered the national Masters and Y.M.C.A. swimming competitions with the strenuous butterfly stroke, not a stroke he usually swims, as "a political statement."
 
Reporters at the Y
 On Thursday at the Concord Y.M.C.A., Mr. Tsongas allowed the cameras and reporters to come with him while he went swimming.
An embarrassed Mr. Tsongas took off his sweat suit, stripped down to his bikini Speedo, and did a few laps while boom microphones hung over his head and reporters tried to ask questions without falling in the pool.
What if Roger Ailes, the conservative political consultant, and the Republicans spread rumors about his health? he was asked.
"I've issued a challenge to Roger Ailes: 50 yards of the butterfly, kiddo," Mr. Tsongas said, as he stood at the end of the pool.
When one reporter suggested that such a challenge might finish off the Falstaffian Mr. Ailes, Mr. Tsongas shrugged, saying, "If it happens, it happens."
Mr. Tsongas gets tired of being asked about his recurrent cough, and tells reporters that it is simply from a dry throat, and that Mr. Clinton has the same thing. But Dr. Takvorian says the explanation is that because of the candidate's "history of radiation," his throat tends to get drier.
While Mr. Tsongas says he knows he has to change if he wants to run the sort of campaign that could survive in the South and West and challenge President Bush, he still seems too caught up in the wonder of his sudden surge to do more than enjoy it.
"I intend to make lack of charisma the chic phenomenon of 1992," he said.
 
Marketing Plainness
 His earnest discussion of issues and his dry, self-deprecating humor delivered with Bob Newhart timing have worked well for him in small group meetings with well-informed, flinty New Hampshire voters.
But now Mr. Tsongas is struggling with the notion of how to market plainness as a national identity.
He seems to believe on some instinctive level that even though the Democrats are dubious about whether nebbish power will carry him to the convention, he must stay a minimalist.
"If I begin to be a man of many notes, then I get lost in that," he said.
His only bows to political sophistication so far: He has acquired a dozen red striped ties, a totem he respects so much that when he sees others wearing red striped ties he accuses them of wanting to be his vice president. For debates, he has learned how to sit up alertly at the table with hands folded and look directly at the moderator.
He has also learned to smile more, even though he feels like "a smiling baboon" sometimes. "Even Mario Cuomo told me to smile more," he said.
 
Sense of Amazement
 No one is more amazed at his new status than Mr. Tsongas himself, who, like the proverbial tortoise passing the hare, looks around him with a slow, blinking bemusement at the vagaries of fate.
He laughs at a newspaper column declaring of his candidacy, "I've seen the future and it isn't pretty," and he says: "You know what my reaction to this is? Wonder. If I had not lived through this, I would not have believed these things are possible."
Although the crowds and cameras have arrived, the short, pale, balding candidate is so low key that he often sidles into the midst of voters and handlers before they even know he has arrived. The stealth campaigner stands quietly, waiting for the attention to come to him, a stark contrast to politicians like Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Clinton, who force themselves upon a room.
The late-night comedians are already having a field day. Johnny Carson joked that Mr. Tsongas's slogan should be "Paul Tsongas: The Only Candidate Who Can't Get Babes."
But unlike Michael S. Dukakis, who left Democrats and Greek-Americans traumatized with his robotic delivery and failure to fight back against George Bush, Mr. Tsongas has an engaging wit. He knows that humor may leaven his preachiness and his dour economic message.
At his birthday party, his campaign played a song by the Capital Steps comedy group, "The Sounds of Tsongas," sung to the tune of "The Sounds of Silence," that suggested the candidate was boring, the voters were snoring and "the words you can profit from are written by a dweebish nerd."
 
An Egotistical Streak
 Of course, with his rising status come tougher questions, and Mr. Tsongas sometimes gets tetchy when asked about his former lobbying activities and his support of nuclear power, an unpopular position among Democrats in this state.
Those who have followed his career have noticed an egotistical streak, a moral certainty, buried within the self-deprecation, and that could turn out to be a political weakness.
At a fund-raising event one night, he told his listeners that before his surge in the polls, he sometimes wondered why he was running and felt this way toward the American public, "If they want to go to hell, let 'em go."
And at Dartmouth College last week, he snapped at a young man who talked about the dangers of radiation, referring to a nuclear plant run by a utility company that includes Mr. Tsongas as a board member.
"Don't ever lecture me about cancer," he told the student in an atypical meltdown. "When you've had it and dealt with it, then we can have a discussion."
It was the sort of thin-skinned reaction to criticism that has been rare in a campaign where Mr. Tsongas has been largely ignored. But those who have watched him over years say this sanctimonious streak is likely to surface more as he comes under more intense scrutiny.
Recalling the Dartmouth incident in an interview the other day, Mr. Tsongas said softly: "The cancer thing is very close to the surface. The one thing this campaign has done is bring a lot of old memories and emotions very close to the surface that, in normal life, are pretty far down in my psyche."
About his Democratic rivals who have promised tax cuts and easier economic nostrums, he said: "To hell with them. They all took the easy cop-out. So to hell with them."
Mr. Tsongas's no-Santa-Claus prescription for the country reflects his own fate. It is a realism shaped as much by illness as by political experience.
So as he leaves these taciturn parts for states that like a little show business with their politics, he observes, "Whatever happens, happens," and he adds, "This is when the brutal part starts."

He took a break from a practice swim at the Y.M.C.A. pool in Concord, N.H. (Edward Keating/The New York Times) (pg. 26)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: New Hamsphire;
DEMOCRATS OFFER EMOTIONAL DRAMA IN NEW HAMPSHIRE

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 15

 BODY:
The New Hampshire Democratic primary contest has produced a final weekend of emotional campaigning, with much of the drama coming from the personal appeals of two men: Gov. Bill Clinton, battling to prove the endurance of a candidacy that began with great hopes, and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas, almost tearfully thanking his supporters for carrying him farther than he was ever expected to go.
Mr. Clinton campaigned with passion and seeming abandon, hoping that his campaign had now bottomed out after the furor over his draft history and was on the upswing. 
 "I want these people to see me out there working hard, reaching out to them and fighting until the last dog dies," the Arkansas Governor said today as he and his wife, Hillary, stalked the voters of Manchester, cornering every passer-by, greeting every child.
"I'm going to go out there and keep trying to cut through to the people, to tell them that I have the best message, the best record, and the best chance to change their lives," he said.
 
A Chant for '92
 Mr. Tsongas came close to tears today as he thanked campaign workers for sticking with him. "I'm so grateful," the former Massachusetts Senator said. "Without you, there would be no campaign, no credibility. I hope you feel what I feel about you."
Sounding almost awed by the status he has achieved by moving past Mr. Clinton in the New Hampshire polls, Mr. Tsongas chanted, "Three more days, three more days."
The emotional pitch of the Democratic race had its counterpart on the Republican side today as President Bush, in his most direct assault yet on his challenger, Patrick J. Buchanan, accused the conservative commentator of distorting Mr. Bush's record.
The polls this weekend show Mr. Tsongas at the head of the Democratic pack, followed by Mr. Clinton, with Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa and Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska neck and neck for third place.
The Kerrey campaign has all but conceded the top spot in the New Hampshire race and is hoping to emerge from the state with enough support to go to the primaries in the West. Speaking today in Concord, Mr. Kerrey seemed relaxed and insisted he was confident of moving on.
"I look forward to debating Paul Tsongas in South Dakota," Mr. Kerrey said, referring to the Feb. 25 primary there. "It will be a much different debate."
 
Sticking to the Issues
 As with many New Hampshire primaries, political fortunes have shifted time and again in these final days. And no one is making hard predictions about the outcome after a nationally televised debate on Sunday night, an event that is expected to be a rough collision of candidates going for broke. Among the many variables is the strength of the write-in vote for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York.
This is, in short, a classic New Hampshire primary, in which about 125,000 Democrats in this quirky, atypical state -- 98 percent white, ranked 40th in population -- test and torment a handful of candidates and define their party's Presidential future.
Whatever else comes out of this primary, the voters have set the framework for the national debate, forcing the candidates to produce an array of economic plans and to stick to the bread-and-butter issues that seemed lost in the 1988 Presidential campaign. Many of the voters here seem dazed by how quickly their boom of the 1980's turned to bust.
Marie Mullikin, a Derry resident who became a symbol of economic distress when she presented Mr. Harkin with a fat sheaf of home-foreclosure notices in her community, said in an interview this weekend: "This is going on all over the country, and the President says there is nothing wrong. Mr. President, there is."
All the candidates were closing with economic appeals. Mr. Kerrey's television commercials said he was running for President because "the dream of prosperity for the middle class has been shattered." And Mr. Harkin, who has escalated his attacks on his rivals in recent days, was denouncing his opponents for backing special "fast track" authority for President Bush to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico.
Mr. Harkin, who is campaigning as the voice of traditional Democratic values and is hustling to make the cut here as a major contender, used as his backdrop today a rubber and tire plant where workers were notified this week that the factory would close within a year and more than 200 jobs would be transferred to Mexico.
Mr. Tsongas said at his rally in Manchester that his campaign was also about "jobs, jobs, jobs," although his economic proposals are far different from Mr. Harkin's -- including a cut in the tax on capital gains to encourage investment. And Mr. Clinton was touting his record in Arkansas "for better jobs and better education."
 
Sparks at the Finish
 Veterans of Presidential campaigns have long predicted that once the 1992 race got started, it would be a rocket sled ride, and on this, at least, they were right. No one has had a wilder ride than Mr. Clinton, who has turned these final days into a quest for political redemption. He had shot to the top of the polls here as the man with a plan for economic renewal and a keen sensitivity to the grievances of the middle class. Then came the allegation from a supermarket tabloid that he conducted a 12-year affair with a singer, and the tempest over whether he sought to avoid the draft in 1969.
For all his denials, Mr. Clinton was transformed from the man with a plan to the man with a past. All the character testing and background checking that played out over months for the candidates of 1988 has been compressed, for Mr. Clinton, to a few harrowing weeks. "Had it been any other candidate, he would have been out of the race," George Bruno, one of the Governor's New Hampshire advisers and a former state Demoratic chairman, said this weekend. "But he keeps coming back; he's very up."
Mr. Clinton is racing around the state, trying to undo the damage; the man who worried about the effect of his draft record on his "political viability" at the age of 23 is not about to let go now.
"Now I feel like we're back to where we started in this campaign," he said this weekend, straight into the camera, in a 30-minute call-in program that is part of his strategy to reach over the news media and talk directly to the voters. "Me, the people of New Hampshire, and the issues."
One of Mr. Clinton's new television commercials asserts, "He's been tested in ways the other candidates haven't," and urges, "Take another look."
Mr. Clinton asserted today that despite the draft issue his support in the South would hold firm; a round of primaries will be held there on March 3 and 10. "I feel very comfortable about where we will be when the dust clears," he said.
He shied from predictions about Sunday's debate. "Based on what's happening this week," he said with a resigned smile, "I've learned not to anticipate anything."
Equally intense are the men and women around Mr. Clinton, young Democrats who came to believe much of their early, glowing press and can smell the White House after 12 years in the political wilderness. To the Governor's allies, his careful politics -- the straddling between left and right, the attempt to reach out to the middle class and make a new Democratic case for a more active Federal Government -- represents a last, best hope for a return to power.
By this weekend, many analysts were saying that Mr. Clinton had staunched his political bleeding, although Mr. Tsongas retained his lead in the local polls. "Clinton has asked for a second chance," said Gerry Chervinsky, a poll taker who conducts nightly surveys for the Boston Globe and WBZ-TV in Boston. "And as I sit here today, I can't say it's over yet."
 
Ranking in the Polls
 In a poll published today in The Globe, conducted Thursday and Friday, Mr. Tsongas was at 32 percent, Mr. Clinton at 25 percent; Mr. Harkin and Mr. Kerrey at 11 percent each and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California at 5 percent. The poll was based on a sample of 400 people considered likely to vote in the Democratic primary on Tuesday and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points.
Polls released tonight suggested, however, that Mr. Clinton's support had begun to fall again. Still, polling in New Hampshire is mercurial, and Sunday night's debate is expected to have an enormous impact on the race.
Frank Greer, Mr. Clinton's media consultant, argues that the Governor is in the race for the long haul. "If we finish second or third, this is a campaign that has the message, the strategy, the resources, and the organization on the ground that means we will still win the nomination. We are the only campaign that can say that."
While the sleek, well-financed front-runner stumbled, the spotlight turned to the quintessential dark horse. Mr. Tsongas entered this race back in April as a regional favorite, and many expected him to fade as the contest developed. Instead, he has become a safe harbor for many voters, a reflection, in part, of the other candidates' difficulties in making a case.
Mr. Tsongas has carved out a niche as the economic truthteller of the party; he is not running to be Santa Claus, he says, to hand out tax cuts to the middle class, which most of his rivals propose. Economic recovery will be hard, he says, and in this state, dotted with foreclosure signs and closed shops, where nearly everyone has been touched by recession, there is a rough credibility to that message.
Still, some analysts say Mr. Tsongas is not fully capitalizing on his moment to present himself as a potential President, whose campaign can transcend his region -- a question that is widely asked in the party outside New Hampshire. He has stuck to a remarkably light schedule in recent days, which Mr. Chervinsky described as "a big mistake" and a missed opportunity to "close the sale."
Today, Mr. Tsongas talked with high emotion to his supporters, who have worked this state for months. He talked of the purpose that drove his campaign, the commitment to the economic measures essential for the next generation. Rather than think of "November, November, November," he said, his campaign was following "a vision to govern."
Mr. Kerrey has remained philosophical despite polls that show him lagging. "I'd like you to know that I'm not at all, and in fact it's my nature not to get, discouraged," he said at a dinner Friday night. "I understand that the good people of New Hampshire wait quite a long time to make up their minds. They decide at the last minute. Sometimes they decide and change, decide and change, a little bit like Governor Cuomo of New York."
And Mr. Harkin kept battling to the end -- and defended his strategy of hard-hitting attacks on his opponents. "I'm campaigning hard on my record," he said, "on my vision and program to get America back to work again. If that's tough, well, I'm sorry. It's a tough world out there."
All of this is playing out in a small state that has become a theme park for elections, where every snow-covered hill and town hall becomes a potential backdrop for the television cameras. Call it Primaryville -- a place that exists until Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Rockefeller Family Tries to Keep A Vast Fortune From Dissipating

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
The Rockefeller name is synonymous with the summits of wealth and philanthropic largesse. The family has founded museums, universities, philanthropic foundations, and some of the country's biggest national parks.
But, like so many Americans, the Rockefellers -- albeit on a grander scale -- are worried that their future generations may not be able to enjoy the life or influence the family now has. And so they have begun a vigorous effort to bolster their fortune, which they currently estimate at $5 billion to $10 billion. 
 For decades, the family quietly collected the interest on billions of dollars, and gave away hundreds of millions. What changed? Some family members pressed for access to the core of the fortune to increase their income. The climate for investment soured and produced lower yields. And most important, as the family grew, so did the number of people with claim to a piece of the fortune.
"Historically our goal has been the preservation of wealth rather than the amassing of wealth, but now that the client base is moving to 100 there is a new emphasis on growth," said David Rockefeller Jr., one of the many great-grandchildren of John D. Rockefeller, the family patriarch and America's first billionaire.
In trying to rebuild their legendary wealth, the Rockefellers for the last few years have made numerous and substantial private investments in Asia, Latin America and Europe. They have created a formal corporate structure under which most of their diverse business enterprises operate. And they are slowly increasing the level of risk they are willing to take in the quest for higher returns on their investments.
The family fortune has accustomed the Rockefellers to living very well indeed. But for most of this century, they have also a unique level of power and prestige that has gone hand in hand with their wealth and their tradition of philanthropy. As each generation splinters the family fortune, it is becoming harder for the family to maintain its status.
Currently, family members personally donate about $50 million a year to various causes, while foundations endowed by the family give away about $17o million each year. "The work here is to rebuild the per-capita wealth," David Rockefeller Jr. said. "But will we find another Standard Oil? Probably not."
John D. Rockefeller, an accounting clerk, became one of the richest and best-known men in the world by turning a $4,000 investment in an oil refinery business into a large stake in the Standard Oil Company, which grew into a formidable monopoly. It was broken up into smaller companies that were the predecessors of Exxon, Mobil, Chevron and others. By 1914, Mr. Rockefeller was worth more than $1 billion (adjusted for inflation, that would be about $13.8 billion today). In 1917, he gave his only son, John Jr., $460 million (about $5 billion in today's dollars).
In 1934, John D. Rockfeller Jr. established trusts for his daughter and five sons that consisted of oil company stocks and real estate holdings. These trusts still hold the bulk of the fortune. Another set of trusts were set up in 1952 for his grandchildren, the fourth generation of the family. When family members die, their trusts divide into new trusts for their children.
In the last three years, the family has hired a new team of professional money managers. They oversee Rockefeller Financial Services, as the new family holding company is called, and are also developing a money management business for institutions and wealthy families who want to invest along with the Rockefellers.
The 200 or so professionals who manage the family fortune are known within the family as either "the family office" or "Room 5600," the number of the suite where they work on the 56th floor of 30 Rockefeller Plaza. These advisers also handle the family members' income taxes, philanthropic pursuits and legal work, insure their huge art collection and help write speeches for family members.
 
The Fourth Generation Takes the Family Torch
 The changes in the family's investment strategy also reflect the nearly complete passing of the family torch from the famous Rockefeller brothers to their children, the fourth generation. The changes are also an attempt by David Rockefeller Sr. to provide some direction to the fourth and fifth generations of Rockefellers, who are not likely to be the nexus of wealth and influence that their parents and grandparents were.
Most of the Rockefeller money is tied up in various trusts that keep the principal out of the hands of the beneficiaries, who live off the substantial interest. Some of the 1934 trusts, which hold the bulk of the fortune, will end with the death of the fourth generation, and some fifth-generation family members will immediately get possession of huge fortunes.
With that in mind, the family, prodded by David Rockfeller Sr., determined that it was time to create a structure that could provide direction, sophisticated advice and options for family members as they prepared for the 21st century.
David Rockefeller Jr., who is 50 years old, recently succeeded his father as chairman of the Rockefeller Financial Services. Virtually all the family's investments, with the important exception of Rockefeller Center, are overseen by Rockfeller Financial Services.
The mortgaging and sale of interests in the 12 original buildings in Rockefeller Center in 1985 and 1989, respectively, was one instance in which the family withdrew some of its core wealth that was tied up in real estate that paid no dividends. That complex deal, which gave the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Japan a majority position in Rockefeller Group Inc., the company that owns the buildings, allowed the family to take $2 billion out of their New York real estate portfolio at the peak of the 1980's property market.
The money was put into the trusts that hold most of the family wealth and greatly increased the interest income that some family members collect annually.
 
'If You Don't Have It You Can't Give It Away
 "Until the very recent past people didn't care too much whether the company was making money as long as their account was doing well," said John Harris, the chief executive of Rockefeller Financial Services. "It had to become more of an institution and David and Laurance kicked off a study of the family office three years ago that reached the conclusion that a certain critical mass and growth was needed.
"If you don't have it, you can't give it away," said Mr. Harris of the family's prospects for continued philanthropy. "It's a little like the royal family. Charles and Diana, for example, spend most of their time raising money for philanthropy."
The Rockefeller offices are in many ways quite modest, even pinched. It consists of a warren of small individual offices, the furnishings largely nondescript. But on the walls are European paintings and works of African art that would do many a museum proud. David Rockefeller Sr.'s modest suite, for example, is dominated by a large Chagall painting.
Rockefeller Financial Services has five main arms. Rockefeller & Company is the money management arm, with over $3 billion in its care, more than two-thirds belonging to members of the family. Each participating family member has a separate account that is managed according to his income and growth needs as well as tolerance for risk in investments.
David Rockefeller Jr. said the family hoped for a 10 percent annual return on its investments and was looking abroad for opportunities.
There are also several pooled funds that combine various pieces of the family fortune. Several hundred million dollars in Rockefeller & Company comes from large institutions like universities that invest some of their endowments with the Rockefeller family office.
Rockefeller & Company has been managing institutional money for about 10 years but only recently has begun to make money management a source of profits for the family. For its institutional clients, the company has about 15 percent of the money in fixed-income securities and cash, 51 percent in large stocks, mostly European, 31 percent in small stocks and 3 percent in private joint-venture deals.
For the family, the company has roughly 8 percent of its money in 14 joint venture deals in Asia, Latin America and Europe. Most of the money is in equities, with roughly 35 percent in large capitalization stocks, another 30 percent in fixed-income securities and the balance in an array of small capitalization stocks, private deals and cash. The Rockefellers believe that the best returns in the next few decades will be in the developing nations of Asia and Latin America.
Among the 14 ventures are Elex Computer Inc., in South Korea, which distributes Apple Computer Inc.'s equipment in Asia and also provides consulting services to businesses, and Gwalia Consolidated Inc., an Australian mining company with a large gold mine and valuable properties.
A second family arm is Venrock, the family's enormous venture capital arm. It has invested in more than 70 small technology companies in Silicon Valley and New England. Eleven of those start-up investments were brought to the public markets last year, allowing the family to take some profits and make 1991 one of Venrock's most profitable years since Apple Computer went public.
So far this year one Rockefeller-backed company, Gilead Sciences of Foster City, Calif., has gone public. Two others, Opta Food Ingredients Inc. and Agridyne Technologies Inc., have registered to make initial public offerings.
A third arm is the Rockefeller Trust Company, the only private trust incorporated in New York State. It manages nearly 300 family trusts, a few of which are philanthropic.
Another arm is the Rockfeller Insurance Company, which provides family members with liability coverage for their work as directors and officers of many corporations and charities.
The fifth arm is Acadia Risk Management, an insurance broker that places policies for the family's enormous art collections, real estate and private planes. David Rockefeller Sr.'s art collection, alone, was valued at $500 million several years ago.
Only David, 76, and Laurance, 82, survive from the family's third generation, which included Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller, former Vice President and Governor of New York, Winthrop Rockefeller, former governor of Arkansas, and John D. Rockefeller 3d. Until the early 1980's there was no organized Rockefeller family business to speak of, only a handful of extremely wealthy individuals who lived off the income generated by trusts and who informally shared the costs of running the family office.
Laurance Rockefeller has pushed for greater access to the family fortune. He was also central in pushing the trustees to complete the Rockefeller Center deal. Described as a deeply introspective man, he is currently the biggest philanthropist in the family, parting annually with tens of millions of dollars for environmental causes, hospitals and universities.
 
Donations Often Exceed His Income
 In June 1990, for example, he pledged $21 million to create a Center for Human Values at Princeton, his alma mater. He has also given about $40 million to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City. Laurance is believed to have given away more than $200 million of his own money, and according to Mr. Harris, his donations often exceed his income. He has even managed to persuade the trustees of the 1934 trusts to allow him to invade his trust and give away part of the principal.
The Rockefellers are not alone in contending with low rates of return on many investment vehicles of the 1980's. Many people with big money are on the prowl for places to put some of it.
"In the 1980's with investments in the stock market, the bond market, initial public offerings and real estate you almost couldn't go wrong," said David Horn, a senior vice president of the Northern Trust Company, which provides administrative and consulting services to wealthy families. "In the 1990's you're seeing the collapse of some of these investments and so you're seeing families at this level trying to fight the ravages of taxes and inflation by reaching into riskier direct investments."
He added: "Unless you do some pretty innovative things and look at nontraditional way to grow assets, having a few billion dollars now won't be enough if you have the kind of philanthropic world vision that the Rockefellers do."
Granted, none of the younger Rockefellers are impoverished. But some want more income from the family's wealth. Only two of the fifth-generation Rockefellers are direct beneficiaries of the 1934 trusts, which generate most of the annual income. The 1952 trusts support mainly the fourth generation. In the fifth and sixth generations, most members are supported by small trusts their parents and grandparents set up at their birth.
Some of the younger Rockfellers have demonstrated an interest in business. Peter Rockefeller, for instance, a 34-year-old grandson of Nelson A. Rockefeller, is studying for a master's in business administration at Dartmouth's Amos Tuck School, and 31-year-old Steven Rockefeller Jr. recently completed an M.B.A. at Yale's School of Management. The latter, whose father apparently gave him shares in the company that owns most of Rockefeller Center, is one of the few members of the fifth generation whose income increased substantially with the mortgaging of the property and the sale of the company to Mitsubishi.

HEADLINE: U.N. Finds Haitians Who Fled Anew

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 15

 BODY:
United Nations officials said today that interviews at a United States-run refugee camp at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, were turning up numerous cases of Haitians who fled their country and were intercepted and returned, only to flee a second time from what they said was repression by the army or police.
The statements from these people, gathered by officials from the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, contrast starkly with the Bush Administration's position, repeated in arguments before the Supreme Court on Friday, that there is no evidence of mistreatment of Haitians who are forcibly returned to their country.
 
'Specially Targeted'?
 The United Nations refugee specialists said that in recent days 35 Haitians who fled their country a second time aboard small boats have already been identified, and one official predicted that "many more will be emerging." 
 These Haitians are not on a list of 41 people at Guantanamo who officials say will soon be allowed into the United States to pursue political-asylum claims.
The 41 all say that they have fled twice. But they left Haiti together on Jan. 9, raising questions among some officials whether they concocted their stories as a group. United Nations refugee experts said that those more recently identified as having fled a second time came from different areas of Haiti and left individually.
"The one outstanding feature of all their stories," said a United Nations official who is familiar with the interviews, "is that they say they have been specially targeted as being repatriates who have denounced the Haitian authorities to the U.S. I can't assure you that they are all telling the truth, but having listened to them carefully, I have no reason to doubt them."
Since the refugee crisis began in October, the month after a coup deposed Haiti's elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Washington has insisted that most of more than 15,000 people who have fled Haiti are economic refugees, not political refugees.
On Friday, Justice Department lawyers submitted to the Supreme Court the results of Government investigation into the claims of 4 of the 41 refugees seeking asylum. The Court is hearing an appeal from immigration-rights groups hoping to prevent or postpone the Haitians' return.
State Department officials and diplomats said that these four refugees were chosen because their accounts of repression in Haiti offered the most detail of arrests, manhunts and killings. But they said that field investigations in Haiti turned up nothing that would corroborate their accounts and much to rebut them.
 
Coffee, and No Sympathy
 "In one case, one of our officers had coffee with two of the people who had supposedly disappeared," a State Department official said. "In another case, one of the refugees who said he had been a political activist alleged that he had taught at a particular school. We went to the school and they had never heard of him. We talked to local activists and they had never heard of him."
Immigration-rights advocates strongly criticize the Government for focusing on only 4 of the 41 cases and said all the claims of political persecution in Haiti should be investigated before more people are sent back.
A leader on the Haitians' behalf, Arthur C. Helton, director of the refugee project of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, said: "The United States authorities are hopeful that any concern at the Supreme Court can be assuaged by preliminary investigations into four individuals and a general assurance that thorough investigations will now occur.
"But it is increasingly clear that the political decision to pursue forced repatriation with a vengeance has overwhelmed even these disturbing reports of abuses, and there is no reason to believe serious attention will ever be paid to the claims of these individuals."

HEADLINE: Baker's Trip to Nations Unready for Independence

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TASHKENT, Uzbekistan, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's journey through six former Soviet republics began a week ago in Moldova with a small scene that set the tone for the whole trip. When Mr. Baker's sleek white-and-blue Air Force 707 rolled up to the V.I.P. terminal at Moldova's main airport, there was no one at the bottom of the stairs to greet him.
Karen Groomes, Mr. Baker's protocol aide, descended the stairs first, looked around, and saw five men standing stiffly about 30 feet away, staring at Mr. Baker's plane with that deer-caught-in-the-headlights look in their eyes. It seems that the Moldovans had entertained few state visitors recently, and they had forgotten the drill. Ms. Groomes gently motioned them to come to the bottom of the stairs to receive Mr. Baker in the manner to which he is accustomed. 
 Similar scenes were repeated throughout the Caucasus and Central Asia, as though these outlying republics, which for 70 years were run from Moscow, were taking their first tentative steps in international diplomacy by playing host to the American Secretary of State. These encounters in Moldova, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Turkmenistan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan seemed to underscore just how unprepared for independence so many of these republics are.
 
Robbed of a Transition
 "The coup plotters won; in the end they got their revenge," said a senior American diplomat based in Moscow, referring to the Soviet officials who plotted the failed coup against President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in August. His argument was that the coup, by triggering the rapid breakup of the Soviet Union, robbed it of the transition period it need to go from a union run and dominated by Moscow to a collection of self-governing, self-sustaining independent countries.
"They needed two, maybe three years to make the transition," the diplomat said. "But thanks to the coup boys, it all just happened overnight, before anybody was really ready."
In the European republics of the former Soviet Union the statues of Lenin have all been toppled from their pedestals, but in the Central Asian republics, such as Turkmenistan and Tajikistan, the statues are all still standing. As much as these republics resented Moscow's domination of their affairs, they were also dependent upon it for guidance and sustenance, and many of them have not yet quite figured out how to fill the power void.
Passing by the Lenin statue still standing in the heart of Tashkent, an Uzbek Foreign Ministry official accompanying reporters traveling with Mr. Baker remarked: "We are not independent in our minds or in our habits. In many ways, we remain the same."
 
Every Republic for Itself
 But without Moscow to provide food and distribution, it is turning into an every-republic-for-itself competition. In Dushanbe, Tajikistan, food rationing had to be instituted two weeks ago because Ukraine stopped shipping its sugar and Kazakhstan began charging exorbitant prices for its meat.
When the President of Tajikistan, Rakhman Nabiyev, summoned his Cabinet for an emergency meeting two weeks ago to deal with the food crisis, he confessed to his public, "We have little experience in such affairs, but we should look for and find ways and methods of lowering the prices, especially of basic foodstuff."
Mr. Baker's conclusion from his trip, aides say, was very simple: Some of these new countries are going to make it, and others are going to join the swelling ranks of third world basket cases, just limping along. Those that are most likely to make it, he concluded, are those like Turkmenistan that have economies based on agriculture, oil, gas and minerals, on the assumption that it is easier to privatize an economy based on agriculture and energy than an industrialized economy, which will have to modernize if it is to compete on the world market.
The problem of transition is compounded by the fact that every leader in the outlying republics with whom Mr. Baker dealt seemed to have the same biography: Former senior Communist Party boss who managed to switch hats quickly enough in the last year or two and to pass himself off as a reformer. These former apparatchiks are now overseeing the transition to a market economy in most of Central Asia.
 
The Ethnic Problem
 Another factor that will determine which of these republics flourishes and which does not will be how they handle their ethnic problems. Here again, Moscow's iron fist keeping the lid on nationalist tensions and Moscow's role as a neutral referee are missed in some ways.
Mr. Baker began this trip in Moldova seeking assurances from its Government that it would not discriminate against its Gagauz minority, a Turkic -Christian people living in the republic, as well as its Russian minority. Both groups have tried to split from Moldova now that it has split with Moscow and is talking about unification with Romania.
From Moldova, Mr. Baker flew to Yerevan, Armenia, where the focus of his talks was Nagorno-Karabakh, an enclave of Azerbaijan with a majority population of Armenians who want to reunify with Armenia but are being stopped by Azerbaijan because 30 percent of the people of the enclave are Azerbaijani. Azerbaijan has cut off all food and energy supplies to Armenia.
Mr. Baker, apparently suffering from a splitting headache after two days of wrestling with such issues, was asked at a news conference in Yerevan if he had any plans to visit Nagorno-Karabakh to try to mediate. His categoric answer seemed to stun his hosts.
"I do not plan to go to the region, or to the autonomous republic myself, either on this trip, nor do I have any plans to go there in the future," he said.
 
No Complications Needed
 Mr. Baker's only advice was to say to Armenians and Azerbaijanis that "the job of creating a new, independent nation and bringing it into the community of nations and establishing a free-market economy is a big enough job in and of itself. It does not need to be burdened with, or complicated by, a continuing dispute regarding Nagorno-Karabakh."
Because these outlying republics are still headed in many cases by Communist Party bosses, and because some of them have difficult ethnic problems. dealing with them from Washington's perspective will be very complicated.
The United States wants to have relationships with the Central Asian states, if for no other reason than because they are rich in strategic resources like uranium and oil, and to forestall Islamic fundamentalist expansion into this area.
Mr. Baker tried to win commitments from each of these leaders to various democratic and market principles as a condition for American diplomatic contacts. Yet as he did so, he seemed to discover that relations with them are, for the near future, going to be based less on their desire to embrace American values, and more on America's decision to turn a blind eye to some of their behavior -- from reports of torture of political prisoners in Azerbaijan to the intimidation of opposition leaders, as happened while Mr. Baker was in Turkmenistan.
Reporters traveling with Mr. Baker were told toward the end of his trip: "It is probably true with respect to all of these new nations that as they emerge from totalitarianism and seek to become democratic, their performance is not going to be spotless. But there are a number of goals and objectives that we have to keep in mind, and we need to reconcile these in the best way that we can and approach the emergence of these new nations in a manner that best serves the interest of the United States, and in a manner that does not in any way sacrifice our principles."
