HEADLINE: Poland Again Saddles Up the Steed of Reform

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Feb. 15

 BODY:
After riding to power on growing public opposition to Poland's economic reform program, the new Government is reluctantly embracing the main tenets of its predecessors.
An economic program to be announced Monday promises a loosening of the money supply and a bit of help for the ailing state sector. But Premier Jan Olszewski's Government is insisting that the total deficit will be held to 5 to 6 percent of the gross national product, slightly more than 1991. 
 The big question, however, is whether the package will meet the budget austerity requirements of the International Monetary Fund. Forgiveness of half of Poland's $45 billion foreign debt, tentatively agreed upon last year, depends on receiving the Fund's imprimatur. A senior Polish official warned that the plan to be announced Monday may not satisfy the fund.
The I.M.F. suspended a three-year agreement with Poland last year after targets for money supply growth and budget deficits vastly exceeded projections. Fund representatives told Polish economic planners this week that Poland must live within its means. Such restraint was lacking in the past year, when real wages rose 3 percent -- about $200 monthly -- even as productivity fell sharply.
"I wonder if the I.M.F. realizes how difficult is the social and political situation of this country," said the senior official. "We need to have a sensible budget, but we need to preserve democratic processes, and one need has to be balanced against the other."
During the campaign, Mr. Olszewski called for renegotiation of Poland's deal with the I.M.F. Now he is boxed in by a budget deficit, faces growing opposition within his own Parliament, and has found little room to maneuver.
Once the poster-child of post-Communist economics for its bold program of "shock therapy," Poland has lately been the focus of anxious concern in the West. The private sector has boomed since the program began on Jan. 1, 1990, while state businesses, particularly companies dependent on trade with the Soviet Union, have collapsed.
A majority of the winning candidates in last year's parliamentary elections ran against the reform plan. Public opinion polls document a steady drop in the public's support for faster privatization, and Government forecasters predict that unemployment, now at 11 percent, will reach between 17 and 19 percent by the end of the year.
Recently, President Lech Walesa delivered a ringing speech at the Council of Europe in which he blamed Western Europe for flooding the Polish market with goods while failing to invest.
Immediately after the speech, he called in Western reporters to assure them that the comments were not aimed at the United States and that the country had no intention of seriously deviating from its economic reforms.
Zdzislaw Najder, chief adviser to Mr. Olszewski, insisted the new Government is proposing important changes in emphasis, particularly in the area of protecting potentially profitable state-run industries. But he also acknowledged that the rhetoric of last year's Parliamentary campaign has long since collided with the realities on Poland's national balance sheet.
When the Olszewski Government took office, Mr. Olszewski immediately called the budget deficit of more than $1.6 billion "catastrophic" and said that it would take two months for his Government to come up with a plan.
Those results are to be unveiled next week. Drafts of the proposal call for faster privatization, lower interest rates and the printing of additional money to revive failing state-run enterprises. The state companies would be protected both by more direct intervention from the central Government and such anti-import measures as required labeling in the Polish language.
The key vote will come on a proposed budget within a month. "This Government can propose a budget that is very austere," said Piotr Nowina-Konopka, senior member of the Democratic Union party, which holds 14 percent of the seats in the Parliament and is drawn from the center left wing of the Solidarity movement. "And if it's a non-austere budget, we won't vote for it, and Olszewski will be brought down."

HEADLINE: Political Formula for a Tax Proposal

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
The tax bill put forward by House Democrats as an alternative to President Bush's proposals has three underlying purposes, and the first is plainly the most important: to make a political argument for the Democrats about tax fairness.
The second goal is to do that without harming the economy by generating excessive stimulus or creating tax loopholes. And the third goal, where it can be done at little fiscal or political cost, is to clean up the the tax code a bit. 
 Democrats are stating their political argument loudly. Republicans do not believe in a fair tax code, proclaimed the bill's author, Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. "The Democrats are thinking about the middle class," he said.
To a politician, rather than an economist or demographer, the nice thing about his middle class is that it is so big that hardly any voters are left out. Democrats say their preliminary figures show that only the top 1 percent of taxpayers would pay more taxes in 1992 and 1993; the other 99 percent would pay less.
 
Bush Pushes His Plan
 Mr. Bush disagrees. In Nashua, N.H., today he argued that when taxes on the rich were raised "that hits the little guy over and over again." Later in New Boston, N.H., he said Congress should "set aside politics" and pass his proposal instead of theirs.
Politicians, of course, reach for their wallets when they hear another politician telling them to put aside politics.
Indeed, the Democrats' bill would probably not exist at all if this was not an election year. Most of the advice Mr. Rostenkowski's committee got last December in hearings was to do nothing and wait for the recession to end. He has made no secret of his personal agreement with that view, while adding "the politics of it isn't going to allow us to do that."
And the slogan of middle-class tax relief has been chanted so loud, so often by so many Democrats that a Congress they control is not going to produce a bill that cannot claim that philosophy.
That guaranteed a committee rejection of Mr. Bush's call for reducing taxes on capital gains from a maximum of 28 percent to 15.4 percent. Most of the money that proposal would give taxpayers would go to individuals with incomes over $100,000, many of whom do not even slide into Mr. Rostenkowski's large middle class.
Instead, the Democrats' bill tries to take what the appears to be the two strongest arguments for capital gains cuts and use them, inexpensively, for more modest changes.
 
Accounting for Inflation
 Mr. Bush said today in Nashua he wanted a capital gains cut "so that business can invest and hire more people." Democrats are generally skeptical that a cut in capital gains taxes would lead to much productive investment, but their bill would reward investors if that happens. It would cut the tax, to 14 percent, but only for new investments in small businesses, held for at least five years.
The other part of the Democratic bill would index new investments against inflation for capital gains purposes. Under current law, if someone bought $10,000 worth of stock and sold it for $15,000, after holding it for four years while the cost of living went up 20 percent, equivalent to $2,000 of the stock's value, the capital gains tax would apply to the entire $5,000 profit. Under the Democratic proposal, the capital gains tax would apply only to the $3,000 not attributable to inflation.
But including some kind of capital gains rate cut is also a political strategy. A substantial minority of Democrats find more appeal in changing the law than in using it as an issue against Republicans, and Mr. Rostenkowski wants to keep as many of them as possible with the party when his proposal goes against the President's on the floor at the end of the month.
There are at least two other ways that both Mr. Bush's original big package and the short list he now talks most about helped set the Congressional agenda. Two relatively small items absorbed intact in the bill are the provision to allow first-time home buyers to tap Individual Retirement Accounts without the ordinary 10 percent penalty, and measures to encourage mortgage investment in real estate.
 
Debate on Tax Credit
 While campaigning Mr. Bush talks most about his proposal for a $5,000 tax credit for first time house buyers. In New Boston today he said "it would mean 1,000 new housing starts, 2,000 construction jobs." The Ways and Means Committee Democrats disagreed. They said the credit was too small to lead to new construction or sales, while being big enough to cost the Treasury more than $6 billion over six years. They did go for the I.R.A. measure, figuring some individuals could draw enough out of their funds to buy houses, and calculating that it would cost only $1.3 billion.
Mr. Bush also speaks enthusiastically of a proposed accelerated depreciation plan for new investment. "That's money to buy equipment to upgrade the plants, to create new jobs now," he said in Nashua.
The Democrats responded with a one percentage point cut in corporate tax rates. "We're rewarding winners," said Representative Thomas J. Downey of Long Island, pointing out that companies that did not make money did not pay taxes and therefore would not benefit from this rate cut.
But the details are a means to a political end, and a worthy political disagreement. Mr. Bush today accused the Democrats of wanting to use the tax code to "redistribute the wealth."
Mr. Rostenkowski might not have chosen that term, but can hardly dispute the charge. He said Friday that his Chicago constituents were enthusiastic "about the tax cuts that they were going to enjoy, at the expense of the wealthy."

Revenue: $11.6 billion.

HEADLINE: The 1992 Campaign: Republicans;
SCHWARZENEGGER ASSAILS BUCHANAN

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GOFFSTOWN, N. H., Feb. 15

 BODY:
The Bush campaign finally got out the "B" word today, but it took a bigger man than the President to do it.
Appearing at President Bush's side in this suburb of Manchester, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Mr. Bush's loyal heavy lifter, did what Mr. Bush has been avoiding for weeks: He mentioned Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator who is challenging the President in the primary on Tuesday, by name. 
 Mr. Buchanan's attacks have clearly stung Mr. Bush, and the President today indirectly accused him of spreading "flat, outright lies." But Mr. Bush, who ran a heavily negative campaign here and across the country in 1988, has made a tactical decision not to do that this year in New Hampshire, and Mr. Buchanan's name can never be read on the President's lips.
"We want to make sure that when it comes Tuesday, February 18th, that you all go out there and help the President and pump up his vote," Mr. Schwarzenegger told a crowd in a school gymnasium that got to its feet, cheered, whistled, squealed and generally gave the movie star a much bigger ovation than it granted the President.
 
'Send a Message to Pat'
 "I want you to vote, and at the same time send a message to Congress," said Mr. Schwarzenegger, who is chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports. He grinned as he borrowed a line from "Terminator 2," his latest hit. "At the same time, send a message to Pat Buchanan: 'Hasta la vista, baby.' "
After the event Bush aides simply smiled with satisfaction when asked if the campaign had put Mr. Schwarzenegger up to it. But the Bush campaign was counting on Mr. Schwarzenegger's appearances this weekend to build up an enthusiasm that has been notably lacking from the President's campaign events here.
Mr. Schwarzenegger accompanied Mr. Bush to New Hampshire for a final weekend of campaigning in which he scrambled today to recover from accusations that he had abandoned a popular proposal to increase the tax deduction for children.
Mr. Buchanan pursued the attack today, running a new television advertisement that accused the President of not taking the extra $500 deduction seriously because he dropped it from a seven-point list of urgent economic measures that he gave Congress this week. "Don't be fooled again," the ad says. "It's George Bush that's taxing and spending your future away."
 
Some Indirect Criticism
 But having made the purely tactical decision not to use a negative commercial that had been prepared on Mr. Buchanan, Mr. Bush confined himself today to indirectly criticizing Mr. Buchanan for criticizing him. Although Mr. Bush lumped his Republican challenger with the Democrats, it was clear that the President's comments were aimed chiefly at the man who had spoiled his hopes of coasting through the primary season unscathed.
"I really honestly believe that the people of New Hampshire are a little bit tired of all these negative advertisements and all the attack-dog tactics coming from the left and coming from the right," said Mr. Bush, who made a last-minute rally here four years ago with commercials that attacked Senator Bob Dole and then ran a heavily negative general election campaign against Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee.
Just as Mr. Dole complained that Mr. Bush's ads in 1988 distorted his record, Mr. Bush complained today that Mr. Buchanan's ads were misleading.
The President did not miss a chance to take an indirect slap at Mr. Buchanan. At the Goffstown school, he criticized "some of my opponents" who are calling for a freeze on Federal spending. That, he said, would take money from the Social Security checks of the elderly. The only candidate calling for such a freeze is Mr. Buchanan.
 
Bush on the Defensive
 The charge that Mr. Bush was not seriously pushing the extra $500 deduction has become the focus of Mr. Buchanan's last-minute assault on the President, who has been battling accusations that he is not doing enough to help ordinary Americans. And much of Mr. Bush's day was devoted to defending himself against the charge instead of taking the offensive on his own proposals, as he had hoped.
At each stop today, Mr. Bush waved above his head a copy of the thick bill that he submitted to Congress. "Yesterday, I'm told New Hampshire voters were subjected to flat, outright lies about this plan," the President said. "This plan includes many things, including deductions for student loans and tax relief for families for children."
"It's in there," he said over and over again. "It's in this bill."
Responding to Mr. Buchanan's accusations, Bush aides acknowledged that the President had said in his State of the Union Message that the $500 deduction was needed "right away." They said he did not include it in his smaller package, which he wants Congress to pass by March 20, because the deductions would not be recorded until next year and therefore do not immediately stimulate the economy.

HEADLINE: In Corner of Asia, Hope for New Trading Center

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HUNCHUN, China

 BODY:
Frozen cornfields and mud-brick villages now dominate the landscape around this remote town, where a shallow river called the Tumen marks the intersection of the borders of Russia, North Korea and China.
As local peasants huddle for warmth on the kang -- the beds built over fireplaces in each room of their cottages -- officials in a half-dozen Asian capitals are considering an extraordinary plan for jointly developing this bleak spot into an international trading center that would rival Rotterdam as the world's busiest port. 
 The United Nations is helping organize discussions of the project, called the Tumen River Area Development Program. Whether or not the trading center is ever built, the discussions are already bringing together nations that were once cold war enemies.
The Tumen River -- now a sheet of ice on which peasant children skate -- delineates the border between China and North Korea and between Russia and North Korea. The project would straddle the area where the three nations converge, creating a duty-free shipping and processing zone covering up to 4,000 square miles, a bit smaller than Connecticut. Enthusiasts say this multination zone would become the trading locus of northeast Asia.
 
'A Pretty Good Chance'
 "It's got a pretty good chance of becoming reality," Ding Shicheng, an architect of the project, insisted in an interview in the provincial capital, Changchun. Mr. Ding, a scientist and Government official whose large office is full of maps and statistical abstracts from countries in the region, has been backing the project since 1984. Only in the last 18 months have international discussions begun with the United Nations and foreign countries.
"China wants to see this happen," Mr. Ding added. "So does North Korea. The Soviet Union is having some problems, but the project would be good for Russia, and I think they'll support it. Mongolia and other nations will also back it, along with the U.N., so with all these countries supporting it, it's more than just an idle hope."
While the zone would consist of land from just the three countries bordering on the Tumen River, any other nation would be invited to invest in the program or use the port. In particular, the plans call for Mongolia, a landlocked nation of mountains and desert, to build a rail line to trade through the port. Japan and South Korea would be involved in planning and financing the project, and together those six nations are the central players in the discussions, although China also welcomes investment from the United States, Taiwan and Europe.
So far it is unclear whether project supporters like Mr. Ding are visionaries or dreamers. No comparable international project exists anywhere, and construction would probably cost $35 billion or more, most of which would have to be raised abroad. There is little indication that any companies or countries are willing to invest such huge amounts in a remote part of China, in bankrupt North Korea and in a hinterland of unstable Russia.
 
Worth the Cost?
 "It's a dream," a Japanese official said. "From the Japanese businessmen I've talked to, I don't think they're prepared to invest in it."
The problem is that while the presence of an efficient new port would benefit each of the countries in the region, it is not clear that it is worth the astronomic cost or that it would benefit investors. Foreign companies and banks are already leery of investing in factories in Russia or North Korea.
Roy D. Morey, the director in Beijing of the United Nations Development Program, which is financing an $825,000 preliminary study of the proposal, said that while much remains uncertain, he believes that the project is feasible. He said the countries in the region are highly complementary: Japan and South Korea have capital but lack natural resources, while Mongolia, North Korea and the adjacent parts of China and Russia abound in resources like lumber and minerals but lack the money to develop them or transport them to world markets.
Access to foreign markets, capital and expertise has already transformed China's southeast from farming villages into a manufacturing belt with one of the fastest-growing economies in the world. The decline of old animosities -- between Japan and Russia, China and Russia, North and South Korea, China and Mongolia, North Korea and Japan -- now inspires hope that in the aftermath of the cold war, southeast China's success can be replicated in the northeast.
"If there hadn't been the changes that have taken place in the last year and a half, people would regard this as a pipe dream," Mr. Morey said. "Now it may still not happen, but it certainly is worth $825,000 of risk money to be put up by the U.N.D.P. to further investigate the key issues."
The Tumen River project management committee will meet for the first time in late February, in Seoul, South Korea. Every country involved in the project, including North Korea, is expected to attend, just as each country attended preparatory meetings in Mongolia and North Korea.
The proposals now under review call for a 20-year development period, including construction of about 10 terminals scattered among ports in the three countries. One terminal would handle all the grain in the region, another the timber, a third the oil, and so on.
There would even be a passenger terminal for cruise ships, plus a new international airport. Plans also call for several five-star hotels, 100-car trains, an upgraded highway network, three major new electricity plants, fiber-optic telecommunications systems, "smart" office towers run by computers and new plants to provide potable water and to dispose of waste.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Russian trucks waiting to cross the border from Hunchun, China. The North Korean border is nearby, and the area is under consideration for development into an international trading center that would rival Rotterdam, the Netherlands, as the world's busiest port. (Nicholas D. Kristof/The New York Times)
 
Map of Border area between North Korea, China and Russia, indicating Tumen River.

HEADLINE: Argentina's President Turns Economics Into Poll Approval

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 11

 BODY:
A year ago, plagued by inflation, scandal and criticism for pardoning military officers accused of human rights violations, President Carlos Saul Menem seemed in political trouble. His approval rating had plunged just below 20 percent, the lowest since his election in 1989.
Now, after leading the economy to its lowest rate of inflation in more than 20 years and managing to stay pretty much untainted by allegation of corruption against aides, Mr. Menem is riding a wave of support seldom seen in this country. 
 He won a major victory in midterm elections last fall and made a successful visit to the United States in November. By December, his approval ratings had shot up to 70 percent, despite scandals that are widely regarded as his greatest political vulnerability.
Mr. Menem's economic plan, which stops excessive printing of money, cuts Government payrolls and sells state-owned companies, received a 74 percent approval rating.
 
Mooting Checks and Balances
 But economists and political scientists warn there could be a downside to the President's growing popularity: the weakening of institutions that are able to check the misuse of power.
"We have an enormous concentration of power now in Argentina," said Miguel Angel Broda, an economist. "It is not in the Cabinet, or in the Economy Ministry or in Congress. It is directly in Carlos Menem. He has the kind of power that Charles de Gaulle had in France."
The opposition Radical Party is divided and casting about for a platform. The unions have been weakened by privatization and new labor laws. The military's budget has been slashed. And while Mr. Menem's party has effective control of both houses of Congress, his style of ruling by decree often removes legislators from policy decisions.
Mr. Menem's economic efforts, though, have produced results. Argentina is to receive a $3.2 billion three-year loan from the International Monetary Fund next month, and bankers say that by the end of the year, a critical settlement with creditor banks could be negotiated to reduce Argentina's foreign debt by as much as 40 percent.
The stock market has soared, and a rising tide of foreign investment is coming into the country.
 
Uncomfortable Issues
 But many political analysts here predict that once the overall economy is stable, popular concern will turn to other issues -- like corruption, chronic poverty and the plight of retirees, many of whom have had their monthly benefits cut to $100 by Government austerity measures.
The President's most vulnerable point seems to be corruption. Almost weekly, new allegations are made against senior officials.
Last month, Mr. Menem finally asked for the resignation of Miguel Angel Vicco, his close friend and presidential secretary, who has been accused of owning part of a company that sold 47 tons of tainted powdered milk to Government aid programs. Mr. Vicco denied owning any part of the business.
So far, the President has used what seems to be a formula for handling corruption charges against top aides. At first he vigorously defends the aides, complaining that the press is controlled by Communists. As the charges become more credible, he begins to back off. If aides are indicted, he asks for their resignations.
 
Court Action Lags
 Still, little has come of these corruption cases. The Argentine courts proceed slowly, and prosecutors and lawyers often assert that judges are either paid off or come under political pressure, rendering the judicial system all but powerless.
"The public sees him as being surrounded by corruption," said Felipe Nougera, a partner in the polling firm of Mora y Araujo, Noguera & Associates.
In addition, many people wonder whether the President himself is linked to any of the scandals.
"He has been dodging bullets for a long time," Mr. Noguera said. "Someday, one is going to hit him."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina who is riding a wave of support after his approval rate fell below 20 percent a year ago. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: 250 March in Rain to Protest Teaneck Verdict

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEANECK, N.J., Feb. 15

 BODY:
About 250 blacks staged a milelong march and a 50-minute rally in a chilling rain here today to protest the acquittal of Gary Spath, a white Teaneck police officer, in the fatal shooting of a 16-year-old black youth, Phillip Pannell, here nearly two years ago.
"We were set up -- perpetrated," the dead youth's father, Phillip, told the crowd huddled under umbrellas in front of the Teaneck Municipal Building. "We said we'd go through the system, and once again the system failed us." 
 Mr. Pannell noted that Officer Spath has two children and said he hoped he could "feel my pain."
"I got somebody missing," he shouted through a bullhorn. "My daughter Natasha has somebody missing. My wife Thelma has somebody missing."
 
Sharpton's Marchers Bused In
 The protest occurred without incident. About half the marchers were from Teaneck and nearby towns, and about half arrived with the Rev. Al Sharpton in two buses from New York City. Almost all the marchers and onlookers were black.
The two main speakers at the rally -- Mr. Sharpton and the Rev. Herbert Daughtry of Teaneck, both advisers to the Pannell family -- admonished the crowd to avoid violence and refrain from marching to Officer Spath's home in the nearby community of River Edge. Mr. Sharpton had suggested during a rally last week that he might organize a future march to Officer Spath's home.
Black residents active in protesting the shooting have urged Mr. Sharpton in recent days to abandon that idea. In a speech today, Mr. Sharpton ruled out going to Officer Spath's home.
"We refrained from doing that out of our own dignity," he told the crowd. "Don't lose your dignity and imitate your oppressor."
An all-white jury of 10 men and 2 women acquitted Officer Spath of one count of manslaughter on Tuesday after about eight and a half hours of deliberation. Mr. Sharpton called the verdict a "sham."
"We cannot accept a kangaroo court that would make Alabama and Mississippi blush with shame," he said.
 
'The System Don't Listen'
 Clusters of blacks watched from sidewalks and windows as the protesters walked south on Teaneck Road, a main commercial thoroughfare, from Bryant School, near the site of the shooting on April 10, 1990. Some cheered, some shook their heads, and most did not join in the march.
"The system don't listen to people walking down the street," said Malik Jacques, a 17-year-old student at Teaneck High School. Another onlooker, Kendal Brown, said, "I don't know what this is going to accomplish."
The marchers were restricted to the front steps and lawn of the Municipal Building. The rest of the municipal complex, including the police headquarters and library and parking lot behind them, were cordoned off. Police officers with riot helmets and nightsticks stood in front of headquarters to prevent a melee like the one that began in the parking lot the night after the shooting and ended in a milelong rampage up Teaneck Road by hundreds of black youths.
Dorothy Hackett, 31, came to the Municipal Building today from neighboring Hackensack, site of the trial, with her 10-year-old son Antonio. She said she hoped the speeches would be a lesson for her son.
"I'm hoping he realizes that people speak out for what they want and say it nonviolently," she said.
One of the few whites in the crowd at the Municipal Building, Robert Stefan of Teaneck, said he had been involved in community dialogues after the shooting. "The vast majority of Teaneck residents do not support the racial radicals, including Mr. Sharpton, who come here to further their own political or economic goals," he said.

HEADLINE: Daunting New Task: Helping Minority Companies

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
When Mayor David N. Dinkins announced last week that he wanted to insure that businesses owned by minorities or women receive a larger portion of city contracts, his motive was clear: to broaden opportunities for those who have been disadvantaged.
But the experience of many other cities, as well as several states and the Federal Government, suggests that it is much easier to articulate goals in government contracting than to achieve them, many experts say. 
 "This is an extraordinarily complex challenge that the city is facing," said Kathryn Wylde, president of the New York City Housing Partnership, a nonprofit group that develops housing for working-class New Yorkers.
Mr. Dinkins said he had ordered agencies to develop programs to increase minority representation in the awarding of more than $5 billion a year in city contracts. The Mayor said he wanted the city ultimately to award more than 20 percent of its contracts to businesses owned by minorities or women, without resorting to quotas.
 
New York One of the Last
 New York is one of the last of the country's large cities to create such goals. The Federal Government began encouraging the use of businesses owned by minorities and women in 1968, and New York State has had comparable programs for years.
Some local agencies, including the Transit Authority and the Transportation Department, have long been required to observe Federal and state guidelines when they use Federal or state money for construction.
Many experts said the Dinkins administration should learn from the experience of other cities and other levels of government as it creates its own program. There have been many problems, ranging from the use of fronts that masquerade as minority-owned companies but are really owned and controlled by whites, to reluctant bureaucrats who fail to enforce contracting goals, to slow payment by government agencies, which can force a fledgling business into bankruptcy.
"None of the programs work smoothly, but some do work," said Timothy Bates, chairman of the graduate program in urban policy analysis at the New School and an economist who studies minority-owned businesses.
"I'd say Atlanta is the obvious success," Dr. Bates said. "Los Angeles works well. Chicago, after many painful years, is starting to work well."
The use of fronts has been a problem everywhere, most often in construction, Dr. Bates said. A general contractor, who is often responsible for insuring that 10 percent or 20 percent or even 30 percent of his subcontractors are owned by minorities or women, will declare an employee a 51 percent owner of the new company, Dr. Bates said.
"It's just a game," he said, with the paper owner having no real financial and managerial control. Cities with good compliance on minority contracting "often turn out to be those using fronts," Dr. Bates said.
There are ways of screening out fraudulent companies. Harriet R. Michel, the president of the National Minority Supplier Development Council, which links major corporations with minority-owned suppliers, said her agency carefully examines a company's stock certificates and financial records to determine its authenticity.
It can be more difficult to ascertain the real ownership of businesses owned by women, Ms. Michel said, particularly in states like New York and California that have community property laws. A woman may be fronting for her husband, she said, and such practices can be hard to ferret out.
Authenticity has been the most persistent problem, but not the only one. Bureaucrats are often resistant to change, either because they are reluctant to work on behalf of companies owned by women or minorities or because they are set in their ways.
A half-dozen audits by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan demonstrate that many New York State agencies have not been vigilant about achieving affirmative-action goals.
For example, Mr. Regan's auditors found that the prime contractor in a project by the Metro-North Commuter Railroad to repair the roof of Grand Central Terminal listed four minority-owned subcontractors. None of the subcontractors were certified by Metro-North's parent agency, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, as authentic minority-owned companies, and none appeared to be certifiable, the Comptroller's report said.
Many financial requirements make it hard for new, small companies to compete for government contracts. Experts said the city would have to create strategies to help fledgling companies owned by minorities and women overcome obstacles.
Ms. Wylde's organization has created a program for minority subcontractors who want to become builder-developers. It includes help from banks and the state's mortgage agency and advice from "mentors," established developers who help the minority contractor but have no financial stake.
Ms. Wylde said the city should devise similar public-private partnerships to help companies owned by minorities and women to obtain credit, capital and other essentials.

HEADLINE: The 1992 Campaign;
Difference Among the Democratic Candidates

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

 BODY:
The five main Democratic Presidential candidates agree with each other more than they disagree. All, for example, favor much more Federal involvement in areas like education and health. To one degree or another, they support grants or tax breaks to help develop specific industries. They emphasize more Government spending on what they call "infrastructure" -- highways, sewer systems, airports and the like. The Democrats also believe abortions should be basically unrestricted. But on the following issues, they take somewhat different approach.
 
MAIN THEME
Brown: The country's policies across the board are misguided because the system is corrupt and politicians are greedy.
 Clinton: The middle class has suffered most from the mistaken policies of the last 12 years, and that must be reversed.
 Harkin: Old fashioned liberalism is the wave of the future.
 Kerrey: The first step toward economic and social revival should be comprehensive national health insurance.
 Tsongas: The Government should work with business and not at cross purposes.
 
TAXES
 Brown: Replace the existing income tax system with a flat, 13 percent tax on all income and a value-added tax, similar to a national sales tax, on business transactions. Deductions allowed only for mortgage interest, rent and charitable contributions. Temporary amnesty for tax evaders. Give business a tax cut for hiring workers from poor neighborhoods.
 Clinton: Cut income taxes of middle class by several hundred dollars a year and offset the cost with tax increases of unspecified size on those with incomes above $200,000. Cut capital gains tax for investment held at least five years in new businesses. Give investment tax credit to small and medium sized businesses. Expand earned income tax credit. Prohibit businesses from writing off the cost of excessive salaries and bonuses for executives.
 Harkin: Give no tax cut to middle class or reduction in capital gains tax. Provide investment tax credit for specified industries.
 Kerrey: Give two-year refundable tax credit worth 20 percent of Social Security and Medicare taxes, which would save a family earning $30,000 about $400 a year. Increase taxes by an unspecified amount on incomes above about $200,000. Allow tax credit for investments in plants and machinery. Cut capital gains tax by not taxing the part of the profit attributable to inflation. Impose a 4 percent payroll tax on employers and 1 percent on workers to pay for national medical insurance.
 Tsongas: Do not cut income taxes. Tax capital gains on profits from stocks at progressively lower rates depending on how long the stock is held and impose an even lower rate on gains from investments in small businesses. Raise income taxes on the wealthy. Increase the gasoline tax by 3 cents to 5 cents a gallon. Give temporary investment tax credit. Provide more favorable tax treatment of individual retirement accounts.
 
MILITARY AFFAIRS
 Brown: Cut the military budget in half over the next five years.
 Clinton: Cut military spending by one-third over the next five years. Stop production of the B-2 bomber and the Star Wars missile defense system.
 Harkin: Reduce military spending and the size of the armed forces by half over the next 10 years. Cancel B-2 bomber but continue to develop weapons that might stimulate a useful commercial industry like the V-22 tilt-rotor aircraft. Rely more on the National Guard and Reserves.
 Kerrey: Reduce military spending more than President Bush wants but avoid a meat-ax approach and be careful that the military is large enough and well enough equipped to meet any possible threat.
 Tsongas: Reduce military spending by an unspecified amount. Cut overseas bases rather than those at home. Require economic rivals like Japan and Germany to bear a larger share of the cost of their own defense. Stop selling weapons to third-world countries and persuade allies to do the same.
 
HEALTH
 Brown: Install a national health insurance system that bypasses private insurance companies. Emphasize preventative care, "acupuncture, chiropractic and wellness programs."
 Clinton: Require employers to provide insurance coverage for workers or pay an additional tax into a public fund to cover the uninsured. Establish a Government board to regulate medical-care prices.
 Harkin: Bring labor, business and Government experts to a negotiating table to work out the best form of comprehensive national health insurance.
 Kerrey: Abolish Medicare, Medicaid and the existing employer-based insurance system. Pass revenue from new taxes to the states. Allow people to choose insurance from their state's plan or from private policies that meet minimum Federal standards. Pay the private companies a fixed amount based on the number of people they enroll. Have doctor and hospital fees set by the state governments.
 Tsongas. Enroll everyone in a group like the company where they work and provide a public plan for those who are not part of another group. Have private insurance companies and health maintenance organizations bid for contracts from the groups. Let sophisticated purchasing agents employed by the groups decide which plan is best for their members in terms of fees and services.
 
TRADE
 Brown: Has not stressed this issue the way the other candidates have.
 Clinton: Says he is basically a free-trader. Blames the Japanese for about one-quarter of the United States's trade difficulty, and says this country should retaliate if Japan does not change its ways. Otherwise, says businesses, workers and the Government must work together to compete better in international commerce.
 Harkin: Supports tougher enforcement of existing trade laws and new forms of retaliation if necessary to force trading partners to open their markets to American goods. Voted against giving President Bush authority to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico.
 Kerrey: Favors whatever steps are needed to force other countries to open their markets. Voted to give the President authority to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico.
 Tsongas. Says trade restrictions are counterproductive. Believes the only way the United States can compete in international commerce is to improve the quality of its own products. Foreign companies should not be allowed to take over certain strategic industries in the United States.
